oai_dc:dc.dc:title: African American Life in Memphis, Tennessee: A Compilation of Collections
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The African American Life in Memphis, Tennessee collection touches on the vast contributions of African Americans in the Bluff City. The papers address the early struggles of African American and reflect the rich and productive lives they have led in Memphis. The extensive collection is divided into portions on the arts, business, medicine, politics and religion, and covers events from the beginning to the end of the 20th century. The papers serve as a valuable resource for researchers who wish to understand the significant contributions African Americans have made to the city. -- African Americans have had an immeasurable impact on the arts in Memphis, and the collection contains a section of material on musicians, actors, visual artists and dancers who have lived in Memphis and traveled through the city. This section also provides significant historical information on Memphis’ role in the development of jazz and the creation of the blues as a distinct musical form. -- The section related to business includes articles on individuals such as J.E. Walker, founder of Universal Life Insurance Company, which provide insight into the entrepreneurial spirit of African Americans in Memphis. The portion of the collection devoted to medicine includes information dating back to the Memphis Cooperative Drug Company which was founded at the beginning of the century, as well as articles that relate to the creation of Champion Pharmacy in the 1980s. -- The papers include programs from various events sponsored by the local chapter of the NAACP. Also included are several minute books from the historic Beale Street Baptist Church that date back to 1901. The portion of the collection focusing on religion also contains numerous church histories, as well as an assortment of church anniversary booklets that also provide some information on individual families.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; art; business; churches; civic clubs; dance; economy; education; family; fraternities; medicine; music; NAACP; newspapers; parks; politics; public service; religion; social life; sororities; theater;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Catholic Human Relations Council Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Catholic Human Relations Council was founded in Memphis in 1962 in an effort to unite black and white Catholics in the city and to increase the role of the Catholic Church in the Civil Rights movement. Through the 1960s and early 1970s, the CHRC sought to increase communication and respect between people of different races and creeds. The members believed in the inherent worth of all people, and they were dedicated to brotherhood, equality and justice. They were committed to the Judeo-Christian heritage, and they worked to achieve full access and participation for all Catholics in the workings of the Church. The organization wanted the Catholic Church in Memphis to use its strength and influence to help bring about justice for all citizens of the city. -- The papers of the CHRC, which were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by a former officer of the organization, include meeting minutes, correspondence, membership rosters, newsletters, financial records, newspaper clippings and other records. This collection would be of special interest to researchers interested in the Civil Rights movement in Memphis in the 1960s and 1970s and grassroots movements committed to social justice.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Peabody-Bellevue Civic Club Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Peabody-Bellevue Club was a local civic club in Memphis, whose activities included participation in the area events that included city beautification and safety awareness during the Cold War era. The club also contributed to the area wide search for the most beautiful girls in Memphis, fire prevention and local park segregation. -- The Peabody-Bellevue collection is divided into fourteen folders, each containing correspondence and/or minutes for the civic club for the years 1956-1961. -- Minutes for the meetings are in the first seven folders that begin in December 1956 and end in September 1961. Folders eight through ten contain the civic club’s membership information along with copies of the constitution, bylaws and sample speeches. Included in folder ten is a copy of Avon Summer View Club’s constitution. -- The bulk of the Peabody-Bellevue collection contains correspondence from area businesses, the local government agencies and other organizations. Letters included are from the Memphis Chamber of Commerce, The Civil Defense Commission, the Fluoridation Committees, City Beautiful, WMC Channel 5, Les Passees Center and many others listed in the guide.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Piggly Wiggly Grocery Store Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Piggly Wiggly Grocery Store Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center by Dr. James R. Johnson in 2008. Comprising 1.25 linear feet, the Piggly Wiggly Grocery Store Collection contains business reports, correspondence, news releases, newspaper and magazine articles, and photographs related to the development of one of the most successful grocery store chains in the history of the United States. In addition to material regarding the grocery store, the collection also includes information on the merger between Malone and Hyde and Piggly Wiggly Corporation in 1982 and the Piggly Wiggly Exhibit housed in the Memphis Pink Palace Museum which opened on July 18, 1980. -- On September 11, 1916, entrepreneur Clarence Saunders opened the first Piggly Wiggly grocery store at 79 Jefferson Street in downtown Memphis. Born in Amherst, Virginia on August 9, 1881, Clarence Saunders owned a successful wholesale grocery business before founding Piggly Wiggly. Unlike the grocery stores that Saunders’ had sold goods to, the Piggly Wiggly store allowed customers to pick and choose the merchandise they wanted instead of waiting for a clerk to provide service. Saunders’ self-service concept was so popular that within a few months he opened several other stores around Memphis. He soon spread Piggly Wiggly stores to other cities and by 1922 there were 1,241 groceries in forty states which did a yearly business of nearly $100 million. -- In 1922 Saunders lost control of Piggly Wiggly and declared bankruptcy after a failed attempt to control all of the corporation’s stock. In 1928 the Kroger grocery store chain acquired Piggly Wiggly, continuing to operate many of the stores until the late 1930s when financier W. R. Lovett of Jacksonville, Florida purchased controlling stock in the company. Lovett operated the Piggly Wiggly Corporation until his death in 1978. In 1982, Memphis-based Malone and Hyde, Inc., the nation’s fourth largest grocery wholesaler purchased the Piggly Wiggly Corporation. The grocery stores founded by Clarence Saunders revolutionized the way Americans shop for food and continue to provide self-service well into the 21st Century. -- Researchers interested in the history of Memphis businesses will also want to consult the Brennan-Thomas Collection, the Business Papers of Samuel B. Williamson, Napoleon Hill and Noland Fontaine, the Goldsmith’s Department Store Collection and the South Memphis Land Company Collection also housed in the Memphis and Shelby Room.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Gideon J. Pillow Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gideon Johnson Pillow was born in 1806 near Columbia, Tennessee. He attended the University of Nashville and went on to practice law in Columbia with his good friend James K. Polk. Pillow and his wife Mary Martin Pillow had 14 children. -- Pillow was active in the Tennessee militia, and was named brigadier general by Polk at the beginning of the Mexican War. He served as second in command to General Winfield Scott and took part in the siege of Vera Cruz and battles at Cerro Gordo, Chapleted and Contreras. Pillow frequently clashed with Scott and charges of insubordination were brought against him amid the “Leonidas Letter” scandal. This mysterious letter appeared in the Delta, a New Orleans-based journal, and praised Pillow’s actions at the Battle of Contreras while trivializing General Scott’s involvement. The court failed to prove any connection between Pillow and the letter and he was acquitted by the military commission and exonerated by President Polk. Pillow returned to Columbia to resume practicing law. He later became active in national politics and was considered as a possible candidate for vice president in 1852 and 1856. -- Although originally opposed to secession at the outbreak of the Civil War, Pillow was appointed in 1861 as commander of the Provisional Army of Tennessee, which was headquartered in Memphis. He supervised the construction of fortifications on the Mississippi River bluffs and trained troops for the defense of western Tennessee. He was relieved of active command following the surrender of Fort Donelson in 1862 and spent the remainder of the war serving in the Conscript Bureau. -- Returning to Memphis after the war, Pillow again took up the practice of law and formed a partnership with former Governor Islam G. Harris. However, the war left him deeply in debt and he was forced into bankruptcy. His last years were spent running the Mound Plantation near Helena, Arkansas, where he died of yellow fever during the epidemic of 1878. -- The Pillow papers were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mary Lou Pillow on behalf of her late husband, Gideon Johnson Pillow, III, the general’s grandson. Most of the papers date from the last years of Pillow’s life – 1870 to 1878, and include legal documents, correspondence and financial records. The papers cover Pillow’s life as a landowner, an attorney and a family man. The collection also includes two of the General’s leather cases and a rare copy of the Proceedings of a Court of Inquiry in the Case of Major General Gideon J. Pillow, the record of Pillow’s trial on insubordination charges during the Mexican War. -- In 1978 Mr. and Mrs. William W. Goodman donated a manuscript collection to the Memphis and Shelby County Room containing a series of letters and dispatches written by Gideon Pillow when he was commander of the Provisional Army of Tennessee. The letters document Pillow’s efforts to raise and equip an army and his ambitious plan to invade and occupy parts of Kentucky and Missouri. The Goodman collection also includes a steel engraving of Pillow by H.S. Sudd and a book containing a biographical sketch of Pillow’s early life and his personal statement before the military court during the Mexican War. The papers donated by the Goodmans are housed in the Memphis and Shelby County Room with the other Pillow material.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Playhouse on the Square Programs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Playhouse on the Square Programs Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center by several individuals over many years. The programs were then gathered together to create this collection. -- In 1975, Circuit Playhouse, Inc. acquired a building in Overton Square in Midtown Memphis. With $30,000 provided by Overton Square Investors for renovation, and with increased funding from the Memphis Arts Council, Playhouse on the Square was born. It was an offspring of Circuit Playhouse, Inc. which continued to produce the kind of adventurous theatre its audience had come to expect. Playhouse on the Square opened on November 12, 1975 with a production of “Godspell.” -- This collection contains assorted theater programs from 1975 through 2003.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James J. Pleasants, Jr. Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The James J. Pleasants, Jr. Papers were donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center in the 1970s by the City of Memphis. Comprising 8.75 linear feet, the Pleasants Papers cover the years 1947-1948 and include correspondence, government reports, blueprints, drawings and photographs related to Pleasants’ career as mayor of the City of Memphis. Original order was maintained in the processing of the papers, with the exception of the files related to the Freedom Train controversy. Originally these documents were kept in a single file folder headed ‘Freedom Train.’ In order to assist the research process, correspondence from the American Heritage Foundation, as well as the newspaper clippings, the script from the mayor’s radio broadcast concerning the controversy and reports from other cities visited by the Freedom Train were placed in separate folders. -- The James J. Pleasants, Jr. Papers contain detailed information on the activities of municipal government in the American South in the years just after the Second World War. In addition to the Freedom Train controversy, the collection includes material on the Memphis Light, Gas and Water Division, Memphis Harbor Commission, John Gaston Hospital and the activities of the Memphis Board of Commissioners.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Susanne Conlan Scruggs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Susanne Conlan was born in Boston in 1863. She came to Memphis in 1889 following her marriage to Thomas Murphy Scruggs, a prominent Memphis attorney who later became a judge. Susanne Scruggs was active in the Progressive Movement in Memphis, and she worked tirelessly on behalf of disadvantaged people, especially children. She focused on providing safe places for children to play, access to quality education and legal representation through a juvenile court system. -- Scruggs’ work toward improving education and conditions in schools involved the founding of Memphis Woman’s Public School Association, which helped provide free school books to children who could not afford them. She also organized school lunch programs, was active in the formation of several Parent-Teacher Associations and served as president of the Central High PTA. -- Scruggs helped improve the health and welfare of children in Memphis by founding the Playground Association to provide safe places for children to play. She also worked to establish the first children’s ward in the City of Memphis Hospital and centers to care for people suffering from tuberculosis and pellagra, a condition caused by a Vitamin B deficiency which was prevalent among the poor. As the first president of the Children’s Protective Union, Scruggs found adoptive homes for many children, and through the “Friendly Visitor” program, she and other volunteers made visits to the homes of the poor to ensure that the children had proper care. Additionally, Scruggs was instrumental in the organization of the Juvenile Court system and served as an officer of the Juvenile Court. -- The Susanne Conlan Scruggs Collection contains photograph albums, newspaper clippings, correspondence, photographs and other documents that describe Scruggs’s efforts on behalf of children. The albums include a variety of photographs which show dilapidated housing and children playing in unsafe parks. The correspondence includes letters Scruggs exchanged with educators, doctors, politicians and others involved in the health and welfare of children.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Price/Davis Family Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Davis family and the Price family were joined when Carolina “Callie” Price married William G. Davis in 1879. William and Callie decided to raise their family in Gibson Station in Gibson County. The Price/Davis Family Papers date from 1841 to 1937 and primarily consist of correspondence. The bulk of the letters in the collection were exchanged between friends and family of William and Callie and their children. Members of the Hammerly family of Alabama and the Rawlins family of New Orleans, who were cousins of the Price branch of the family, frequently wrote to the Davis family and to Callie’s brother, L.D. Price of Stanton, Tennessee, and these letters are also included in the collection. -- The letters represent the type of correspondence produced by a typical West Tennessee farming family. The family members wrote to each other about farming, the weather and illness. In addition to correspondence, the papers include essays, photographs, journals, newspaper clippings, records of business transactions and copies of sermons. The collection was acquired through the generous gift of Mrs. Ann Stavley of Cordova, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Julia Raine Collection of Correspondence and Music
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Julia Woodward, an important figure in the local and national music community, was born in Memphis in 1857. She studied music at the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston and went on to become an accomplished composer. She wrote the Tennessee Centennial Hymn, In Tennessee, while she was living in Brooklyn, New York and homesick for her home state. A piece she composed for organ was played at a service in Westminster Abbey in London and her compositions were performed by well-known musicians including Victor Herbert and Sir Harry Lauder. -- Julia was living in Memphis in 1877 when she married Gilbert D. Raine, who was one of the founders of the Commercial Publishing Company and later published the News-Scimitar. The marriage was evidently not a happy one. In 1910 Julia wrote a pamphlet entitled In Nineteen-Ten: A Protest against Conditions in Tennessee, in which she laments the circumstances of married women. The Julia Raine Collection of Correspondence and Music includes a copy of the pamphlet with a copy of the license for her marriage to Gilbert attached to the inside cover. -- Gilbert and Julia seem to have parted ways, yet Julia apparently changed her mind about marriage and went on to marry Joseph Henry Hawley in 1912. Gilbert retired from publishing in 1914 and moved to Bartlett. He spent the last two years before his death in 1924 at the Wallace-Somerville Sanatorium. -- Julia and Joseph moved around a great deal. They lived together and separately in several residences in Memphis and also lived in Galveston and Houston, Texas. Julia periodically went by the name Julia Hawley, but it was as Julia Raine that she became a Memphis radio personality. At the age of 73, she began appearing on a successful weekly radio program known as “Grandmother’s Hour,” which was broadcast from the WREC studios at the Peabody Hotel. In addition to enjoying her success on the radio, Julia was active in the Beethoven Club and played the organ for a number of Memphis churches. She often played piano in her home, and people walking by enjoyed her playing so much they called her ” The Lady Who Sings with Her Fingers.” Julia died in 1937 at the age of 80 and is buried at Elmwood Cemetery. -- The Julia Raine Collection of Correspondence and Music has been held by the Memphis and Shelby County Room for a number of years, and it is no longer known who donated the material. The collection consists of sheet music, articles and letters related to Julia’s musical career.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: arts; composers; entertainment; family; marriage; music; radio; women; women's rights;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Papers of the Raleigh Community Council
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Raleigh Community Council (RCC) was formed in 1971 under the leadership of Donald “Don” R. Anderson to unite community organizations and focus their activities to better serve the Raleigh area. The Raleigh chapters of the Jaycees and the Kiwanis Club joined with Parent Teacher Associations of area schools to pool their resources and coordinate planning to improve the community. -- The importance of the RCC became apparent in 1972 when the City Council announced that Memphis would annex the Raleigh area. The RCC took an active role in protecting Raleigh’s interests during the annexation process. The RCC’s cooperation with city officials and its limited participation in City Council activities helped facilitate a smooth transition for Raleigh into the Memphis city government. -- This collection of papers, covering RCC activity from 1971 through 1976, chronicles the first few years of Raleigh’s inclusion in the Memphis municipal system. The collection is arranged according to the various projects undertaken by the RCC, including its vigorous efforts to preserve Raleigh’s historic sites, monitor zoning ordinances and provide adequate roads and traffic safety. Of particular interest are files which describe the RCC’s attempts to have a major hospital constructed for the Raleigh area, which was accomplished in the building of Methodist Hospital North. Also significant is the material relating to the implementation of busing to schools in the area beginning with the 1973 school year. In addition, the collection contains the Minute Book of the Raleigh Utility District which covers meetings from January 4, 1967 through August 16, 1973, at which time the District functions, rights, duties and assets were by resolution turned over to the City of Memphis. Many of the documents illustrate the efforts of Don Anderson, who demonstrated outstanding personal initiative and leadership skills in protecting the interests of the Raleigh community through the RCC.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Office Files of John "Jack" W. Ramsey
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jack Ramsay was born in 1901 in Vicksburg, Mississippi, but moved to the Memphis area as a small child. He attended Messick School, Memphis University School, West Tennessee State Normal School (now the University of Memphis), and the University of the South. He later earned a law degree from the University of Memphis Law School by attending school at night and working in the cotton industry during the day. -- Although he passed the bar, Ramsay never practiced law. Instead, he stayed in the cotton business and went on to found the Ramsay-Austin Cotton Company. He served as its president until 1962, when he entered politics. -- As an active member of an organization that was involved in the promotion of better government for Memphis and Shelby County, Ramsay served on a committee charged with finding suitable candidates to run for County Commissioner. Ramsay was drafted to run for Commissioner by his fellow committee members. He won the election in 1962, and was chosen to serve as Chair of the Commission. -- Ramsay planned to serve only two years, with the expectation that once a referendum could be held, consolidation of city and county governments would take place. However, Shelby County citizens voted twice against consolidation. Ramsay stayed on as Chair of the Commission until 1974. He retired from county government in 1975, after supporting the restructuring of county government and serving as Chair of the County Executive Committee during the transition period. -- As both private citizen and public official, Ramsay was involved in professional, charitable and civic organizations, often serving as director, president, or chair. He was particularly active in Junior Achievement and organizations relating to the cotton industry, agriculture and conservation. -- Jack Ramsay donated his office files to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1977. The files include newspaper clippings, correspondence, meeting agendas and reports and a transcript and taped interview with Ramsay conducted by staff from the Memphis and Shelby County Room. The papers contain numerous valuable insights into the day-to-day operation of county government and the relationship of the government with local business and civic organizations. The papers illustrate Ramsey’s transition from business executive to effective county politician and describe his duties as Commission Chairman. The papers contain material on numerous aspects of county administration including the development of Shelby Farms, industrial development, roads and traffic safety, the remodeling of the courthouse, the county budget, and tourism.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bond Family Collection: A Bartlett Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Among the most prominent citizens of early Shelby County were three brothers, Samuel, John and Washington Bond. Samuel, born in 1804, was a practicing physician. During the late 1840s or early 1850s, he and his wife, Mary Lucy, built a splendid home called “The Avenue” in what is now the Ellendale section of Shelby County. The home, now called “Cedar Hall” for the trees lining the drive, still stands, and has been restored to appear much as it did when it was the residence of Samuel Bond. Samuel’s granddaughter, Kate Bond, who died in 1974 at age 88, was a prominent member of the Bartlett community. The “Flower Lady,” as Kate was known, was an avid gardener and supplied many of the hotels in Memphis, including the Peabody, with flowers. -- John Bond, born in 1808, earned his Ph.D. and became a respected educator and farmer. Washington Bond, who was born in 1814, served a year in the state legislature, practiced medicine and was a partner in the Bond and Odell Dry Goods store. Washington was also a successful farmer, and went on to win a medal for cotton at the London Crystal Palace Exhibition in 1851. -- The Bond family helped found and donated the land for Green Bottom Church, which was later renamed Morning Sun Cumberland Presbyterian Church. They also played a large role in bringing the first railroad to Shelby County. The Memphis & Ohio Railroad stretched from Memphis to Paris and the depot was named Bond’s Station. The Louisville & Nashville, or L&N Railroad, bought the Memphis & Ohio Railroad and sponsored a contest to rename the community. The railroad chose “Ellendale” – a play-on-words of the abbreviation L&N – as the winning entry. The Bond Family Collection includes correspondence, business and legal records and photographs. The papers provide insight into the issues and the difficulties encountered by farmers, store keepers and physicians of the time. Slaves of the Bond family were freed before the Civil War, but stayed on to work the land. Names of a number of the family’s field hands appear in the collection. -- The papers cover up to the early 20th century and include the William Sidney Bond scrapbook. William Sidney was a popular Southern author of the 20th century, and his scrapbook contains reviews, biographical notes, newspaper clippings and photographs. Also included in the collection are small photographs and other information on Kate Bond, the “Flower Lady.” -- The Bond papers supplement the information found in other family collections in the Memphis and Shelby County Room such as the Connor, Gilbert and Farrow collections and particularly The Ida Cooper Collection, which contains biographical information on the Bond family. Also of interest is the daybook of Washington Bond. The daybook, which covers the years 1837 to 1847, and lists patient names and the medicines he prescribed, provides a detailed record of medical treatment in the early 19th century. The manuscript has been transcribed, abstracted and indexed by Mary Louise Nazor and cataloged separately in the Memphis and Shelby County Room.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. Jude Children's Research Hospital Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Danny Thomas was one of nine children of Lebanese immigrants. He was born Muzyad Makhoob in 1914 in Deerfield, Michigan and was raised in a loving, yet poverty-stricken home in Toledo, Ohio. His name was Americanized to Amos Jacobs, but in 1940 he created his stage name by merging the first names of two of his brothers. -- In the late 1930s, Thomas was a struggling comic who felt his career had stalled. His wife was expecting their first child and he had to decide whether to stay in show business or find another career that would support his young family. Thomas prayed to St. Jude Thaddeus, the patron saint of lost causes, and vowed to build a shrine to St. Jude if he found success in his career. A short time later he achieved his first big break as a comic at the 5100 Club in Chicago. -- Thomas went on to achieve great success in show business. He starred in the situation comedy Make Room For Daddy, which was later called The Danny Thomas Show. He also produced The Andy Griffith Show and The Dick Van Dyke Show. -- After his career developed he discussed his vow to St. Jude with his friend, Cardinal Samuel Stritch of Chicago. Thomas had heard the story of an injured black teenager who had bled to death because he was denied treatment at several southern hospitals. “I decided that day I was going to build a hospital in the South where they would treat anybody – white, black, green, or sky-blue pink.” Cardinal Stritch suggested that the hospital be built in Memphis where he had been a priest at St. Patrick’s Catholic Church. Thomas first visited Memphis in 1955. Groundbreaking took place in 1958 and St. Jude opened in 1962. -- St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital has achieved international recognition as the world’s largest center for the treatment of childhood cancer and other catastrophic diseases. St. Jude provides total medical care without cost to patients who are referred by a physician and who have a disease that is under study at the hospital. It is the first institution established for the sole purpose of conducting basic and clinical research in catastrophic childhood diseases. The research findings and accomplishments are freely shared with physicians and research scientists throughout the world. -- Although Thomas raised enough money through his own efforts to establish St. Jude, he turned to Americans who shared his heritage and founded ALSAC, the American-Lebanese Syrian Associated Charities, which became the fund-raising arm of the institution. For several years Thomas sponsored the Shower of Stars fund-raising gala for the hospital, and entertainers such as Frank Sinatra, Bob Hope and Sammy Davis, Jr. participated in the events. In 1970 he began hosting the Danny Thomas Annual Golf Tournament which later became the Federal Express St. Jude Classic. -- Throughout his career, Thomas received numerous national and local awards for his work with St. Jude. The city of Memphis showed its gratitude in 1966 by naming Danny Thomas Boulevard in his honor. He was presented an honorary doctor of humanities degree by Christian Brothers College in 1968 and received the first Marguerite Piazza Humanitarian Award in 1989. Danny Thomas died in 1991 and was entombed in a special crypt located beneath the golden dome of the hospital pavilion. -- The initial donation of material in this collection came from D.J.V. Simone, Director of St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital. Additions to the collection have come from other sources, including the Archives of the Public Library. The collection, which includes photographs, annual reports, brochures and newspaper clippings, documents the founding of the hospital and its expansion and describes the work of hospital staff in making Danny Thomas’ dream a reality.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Yellow Fever Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the 1850s, 1860s and 1870s Memphis was devastated by a series of deadly yellow fever epidemics. The disease, which was spread by mosquitoes, caused nausea, vomiting and delirium and destroyed cells in the liver, which cause the victim’s skin and eyes to yellow. At the time of the epidemics, it was not known what caused yellow fever, and cannons were set off, piles of debris were burned and the wooden streets were covered in lime in hopes of stopping the spread of the disease. Many religious groups and fraternal organizations, including the Howard Association, a group made up of young businessmen, dedicated their time and energy to providing relief to the sick and the dying. Numerous clergy members and nuns worked tirelessly to help the sick, and many died while providing aid to others. The 1878 outbreak, during which between 30,000 and 50,000 people fled the city and over 5,000 died, was the deadliest of the epidemics. The economy and population of Memphis was so devastated by the yellow fever epidemics, the city lost its charter and was declared a taxing district until 1893. -- The Yellow Fever Collection is comprised of a diary, correspondence, telegrams, newspaper clippings, death notices, a scrapbook and texts from memorials to those who died during the epidemics, particularly the medical professionals and nuns and clergy members who lost their lives while helping bring relief to others suffering from yellow fever. -- The Yellow Fever Collection also contains four additional collections or donations which have been organized and indexed in a single finding aid to assist those who are researching this catastrophic event in the history of Memphis. The Reverend Charles Carroll Parsons Collection, The Reverend Louis Sandford Schuyler Collection, The William Teasley Berlin Family Letters Collection and The Howard Association Collection each relate to the epidemics in Memphis and are referenced in one finding aid along with the material gathered in The Yellow Fever Collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Order of the Alhambra Talavera Caravan #32
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Order of the Alhambra was founded by William Harper Bennett in Brooklyn, New York in 1904 as a Catholic fraternal and social organization. The founders named the group after the Alhambra Palace in Grenada, Spain, where the Moors surrendered in 1492 to Ferdinand and Isabella after having occupied Spain for almost 800 years. In addition to its social function, the Order of the Alhambra worked to raise funds to preserve Catholic historical sites in America. Branches of the organization, called Caravans, which were each given a name of Moorish origin, were established throughout the United States and Canada. -- The Order of the Alhambra Talavera Caravan, #32 was established in Memphis in 1915, and many prominent Catholic men became members. Membership declined during World War I and the passage of prohibition meant that members could no longer enjoy alcoholic drinks during meetings. National officers encouraged Caravan members to remember that that the organization had important goals other than imbibing and interacting socially, and some local leaders attempted to rally the inactive members. Yet the effects of the war and declining interest in the elaborate, complicated and highly-structured activities of the group led to its demise. There is no evidence that Talavera Caravan, #32 existed after 1919. The papers of the Talavera Caravan, #32 include letters, receipts, and meeting notices and brochures from other Caravans. The collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by an unknown donor. -- The International Order of Alhambra remains an active fraternal organization dedicated to assisting people with mental retardation by providing education and support. Their mission also includes preserving Catholic history by identifying, conserving and commemorating Catholic landmarks, people and events.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Catholics; clubs; fraternal organizations; public service; recreation; religion; social life;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee Valley Authority Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Paul Coppock joined the Commercial Appeal as a cub reporter in 1929, and during the thirties he reported on Memphis and Shelby County government. In the early 1940s he became city night editor, and it was during this time he began to write “The Night Desk,” a question and answer column. He became an editorial writer in 1952 and served in that position until his retirement in 1972. He continued to contribute to the paper, however, until 1982, writing the Sunday column, “Mid-South Memoirs.” This column and his interest in Memphis history gave rise to three books, Memphis Sketches, Memphis Memoirs and Paul R. Coppock’s Midsouth. -- Summing up his career on his retirement from the Commercial Appeal, Coppock stated, “I think I worked hardest and got the most satisfaction in helping defeat the proposed Dixon-Yates power plant.” Coppock’s long-time interest in public utilities, particularly as they affected Memphis, led him to write about and collect material related to TVA, Memphis Light Gas & Water and related subjects. This material was compiled as The Tennessee Valley Authority Collection and was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1972 by Coppock just before his retirement from the Commercial Appeal. -- In 1954, it was proposed that the Dixon-Yates power plant be built in West Memphis, Arkansas, as an alternative to TVA to provide a power source for Memphis. The federal government, including President Eisenhower, supported the construction of the Dixon-Yates plant to guard against power shortages in Memphis. Yet the citizens of Memphis, led by Mayor Frank Tobey, opposed the abandonment of TVA as the provider of the city’s power. Tobey testified before Congress to contest the Dixon-Yates contract, and the Thomas Allen Steam Plant was built in Memphis as a TVA facility to provide expanded power resources for the city. The contract for the construction of Dixon-Yates was eventually defeated, and Memphis continued to use TVA as its power source -- The battle over the Dixon-Yates contract is well documented in The Tennessee Valley Authority Collection, which consists of news clippings and editorials from the Commercial Appeal and other newspapers, as well as a variety of related articles, reports and correspondence. Construction of the Thomas Allen Steam Plant, the evolution of the Memphis, Light Gas & Water Division, and issues such as disputes over financing and tax payments are documented in newspaper clippings and copies of financial and feasibility studies. Also included is general information on public and private utilities which was provided by the utility companies themselves or clipped from trade publications.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Theatre Memphis Programs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Theatre Memphis Programs Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center by many individual donors over several years. Consisting of programs from performances at Theatre Memphis between the years 1975 and 2007, the collection provides invaluable information on the operation of community theatre in Memphis. Each program includes the names of the director, cast and crew as well as information on the production. -- Theatre Memphis was established as the Little Theatre in 1921. For several years, plays were performed in a variety of locations in Memphis including Germania Hall and the Nineteenth Century Club. In 1929, the Little Theatre was headquartered at the Pink Palace Museum Playhouse where they would remain until the mid-1970s. When the Pink Palace closed for renovations, the theatrical company opened their own venue on Perkins Extended in East Memphis. Changing their name to Theatre Memphis, productions resumed in 1975 and have continued to the present day.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Frank Tobey Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Frank T. Tobey was born in 1890 in Memphis and attended the Memphis Military Institute, Christian Brothers College and Captain Collier’s School. He pursued studies in engineering at Queen’s University, Kingston, Ontario, South Dakota State School of Mines in Rapid City, South Dakota and then at the University of Washington at Seattle. Upon completion of his studies, Tobey formed an engineering partnership with E.H. Porter, and at his partner’s death, moved to Huntingdon, Tennessee, where he served as chief engineer for 32 drainage districts. -- Tobey began his career with the city of Memphis in 1924 as the chief of an engineering survey party. He became chief clerk in the City Engineering Department in 1928, and then became the Comptroller. In this position, Toby conducted numerous financial studies and surveys. He served as Comptroller until 1951, when he was elected to the office of Commissioner of Finances and Institutions with the support of the extremely powerful and influential political leader E.H. Crump. -- In this same election, Watkins Overton, who held a weak alliance with Crump, was elected mayor of Memphis. Overton went on to resign as mayor in 1953 in the wake of a falling out with Crump over the firing of Stanley Dillard as the City Personnel Director, who Overton had personally appointed. Tobey was chosen as Overton’s successor as mayor with Crump’s support. -- Crump had closely controlled how the mayor’s office was run, yet shortly after Tobey assumed office, Crump became ill, and was not accessible to Tobey for advice on how to serve as mayor. Tobey established an open-door policy in the mayor’s office and began to increase his number of public appearances. These practices helped increase Tobey’s popularity, yet alienated him from Crump, who felt Tobey was no longer committed to his political organization or willing to accept his advice. -- Despite being at odds with Crump, Tobey went on to enjoy great success as mayor. One of his major accomplishments was the defeat of the contract for the construction of the Dixon-Yates power plant. The plant was to be built in West Memphis, Arkansas to provide an alternative to TVA as the power source for Memphis. The construction of the Dixon-Yates plant was strongly supported by the federal government, including President Eisenhower. Mayor Tobey traveled to Washington to testify before Congress in protest of the Dixon-Yates contract, and the measure was defeated. While serving as mayor, Tobey earned a reputation for being an unusually kind, thoughtful and intelligent political leader. Sadly, Tobey died suddenly of a heart attack in 1955, just two months before he was to run for re-election for mayor against Overton. -- The Frank Tobey Papers consists of material from Tobey’s three years of service as mayor of Memphis. The collection can be divided into three basic groups: the growth of Memphis, race relations and municipal government. The office files include information on the Board of Education, the police and fire departments, MLG&W, consolidation, the Park Commission, city finances and Citizens for TVA, which opposed the Dixon-Yates contract.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Trezevant Family Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Timothy “J.T.” Trezevant was born in 1814 and came to Memphis when he was twenty one years old. J.T. became a lawyer in 1836 and served as the second mayor of South Memphis in 1847. He also achieved prominence as a railroad builder. In 1852 he oversaw the construction of the Memphis & Ohio rail line, which linked Memphis and Louisville. -- J.T. and his wife, Eleanor Louisa Beattie, had eight children. Their fourth child, Mayre Beattie Trezevant, was born in Memphis in 1846. He enlisted in the Confederate service in 1861 as a private and was quickly promoted to Lieutenant. After the war he became a leading lawyer in Memphis. He and his wife, Sue Simmons had several children: Nellie, Fannie, Roy, Hamilton, Mayre Brooks, who became a successful writer and cartoonist, Suzanne, who married E.H. Little, the president of the Palmolive Corporation and Stanley, who was a leading banker in Memphis. -- The Trezevant Family Papers provide information on several generations of Trezevants. The collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1979 by Eleanor Trezevant McKinney and contains material from the years 1862 to 1930. The papers include items such as letters, personal papers, newspaper clippings and numerous short stories by Mayre Brooks Trezevant. Most of the correspondence relates to family matters such as illnesses, marriages and deaths. The collection also includes two books of poetry and two scrapbooks which contain newspaper clippings on the Trezevant family and current events such as the Civil War, the Nat Turner insurrection, yellow fever, and the struggle to obtain voting rights for African Americans.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Civil War; family; genealogy; illness; military; railroads; schools; social life; suffrage; voting rights; yellow fever;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ernest B. "Tony" Vaccaro Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ernest B. “Tony” Vacarro Collection contains mementos reflecting a career of more than thirty years as a reporter for the Associated Press. Photographs taken from Vaccaro’s scrapbook and from an album given to him when he retired as president of the National Press Club are the highlights of the collection. Correspondence from various Washington figures, most notably President Harry S Truman, and newspaper articles by and about Vaccaro are included in the collection, as well as invitations to numerous receptions and parties hosted by major political figures of the time. Finally, there are several speeches, as well as Vaccaro’s introductions of speakers at the National Press Club luncheons during his tenure as president of this prestigious organization. -- Born in Memphis in 1905, Tony Vaccaro attended Maury Elementary School. He left Central High School, apparently without graduating, to take a job as a copy boy. The following year he became a cub reporter for The Commercial Appeal, then moved to Nashville to work as a political reporter for the Associated Press. He returned to Memphis as a correspondence in 1931, remaining here until 1938, when he was assigned to Washington. -- As a member of the Senate press corps, Vaccaro came to know Harry S Truman when he covered an investigative committee headed by the then-Senator. The association served him well. On Truman’s first trip to the White House after the death of Franklin Roosevelt in 1945, Truman offered Vaccaro a ride, which gave Vaccaro the opportunity to be the first person to interview the new president. Vaccaro recorded the activities of six presidents; it was Truman, however, whom he knew as a friend and poker companion. -- While still comparatively new to his position in the Washington press corps, Vaccaro was chosen by his fellow reporters to head the White House Correspondents’ Association in 1948. The following year he broke the “old school” tradition of the National Press Club by becoming a member of the Board of Governors, and in 1954 served as president. During his tenure, outstanding national and world figures appeared as speakers at the club luncheons. After his retirement, he was honored with election to the Hall of Fame of the professional journalism society, Sigma Delta Chi. Vacarro retired in 1969 and returned to Memphis, where he remained until his death in 1979.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Associated Press; inaugurations; journalists; newspapers; politics; reporters; sheet music;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Roane Waring Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Roane Waring was born in 1881 in Memphis. He graduated from Christian Brothers College and received a law degree from the University of Virginia in 1902. Returning to Memphis to practice law, he represented the Memphis Street Railway in several lawsuits. Through this early relationship, Waring established an association the Memphis Street Railway that resulted in him being named president of the company in 1934. -- Waring began a second career in the military with his enlistment in the Tennessee State Guard in 1903. When America entered World War I, Governor Thomas Rye appointed Waring commanding officer of the 2nd Tennessee Infantry Regiment. Waring fought in the Battle of St. Mihiel and the Muese-Argonne offensive and was promoted to Colonel and awarded the Silver Star for gallantry. Because of his knowledge of the military, he was appointed as a special consultant to the war department and advised on issues related to soldiers returning to civilian life. -- After the war, Waring was active in organizing the veterans’ group that became the American Legion. He served twice as state commander of the organization in Tennessee and during World War II was elected national commander. In addition to his nationally recognized work with the American Legion, Waring’s civic involvement included two terms as president of the Memphis Chamber of Commerce, membership in Rotary and service on the Shelby County Election Board. -- Roane Waring headed the Memphis Street Railway Company for 24 years, retiring at the end of December 1957. He died in Memphis in 1958 and was remembered as a man devoted to serving his city and country. -- The Roane Waring Collection consists of material related to his service as an attorney, American Legion member and president of the Memphis Street Railway Company. The bulk of the material relates to the American Legion. Also included are papers from his law firm, Waring, Walker, Cox & Lewis and correspondence with Memphis political leader E.H. Crump, U.S. Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson, and Tennessee governors Prentice Cooper and Frank Clement. Finally, the collection contains many photographs of Waring touring military facilities, speaking at American Legion conventions and working at his desk.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: attorneys; law; mayors; military; politics; public service; railroads; transportation; World War I; World War II;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rabbi James A. Wax Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: James Aaron Wax was born in 1912 in St. Louis. Wax entered Washington University at St. Louis in 1930 and later transferred to Southeast Missouri State College, where he received a Bachelor’s degree in 1935. Encouraged to enter the rabbinate by a Christian clergyman who recognized the young man’s gifts, Wax entered Hebrew Union college in Cincinnati, where he was awarded the Bachelor of Hebrew Letters in 1939 and the Master of Hebrew Letters in 1941. -- Following ordination, Rabbi Wax served congregations in Glencoe, Illinois and St. Louis. While serving the congregation in Glencoe, he married Helen Louise Goldstrom in 1945, and they went on to have two sons, Jonathan Ira and James Aaron, Jr. The Wax family moved to Memphis in 1946 when Rabbi Wax was called to be the Associate Rabbi of Temple Israel. He served as co-Rabbi with Dr. Harry Ettelson until 1954, when Dr. Wax was given the position of Senior Rabbi, which he held until his retirement in 1978. -- In addition to his work as a member of the clergy, Rabbi Wax took an active role in civic and community leadership and served with many organizations, including The Tennessee State Board of Mental Health, the Memphis Ministers’ Association, the National Conference of Christians and Jews, the Democratic Party and the Urban League. He also served as a teacher at the Memphis Theological Seminary and helped found the Christian Institute at Temple Israel to improve Jewish-Christian relations. Rabbi Wax’s deep dedication to justice led him to take a courageous stand on civil rights in the turbulent period following the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. -- The Rabbi James A. Wax Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Dr. Wax in 1987. The extensive collection contains a wealth of information on Rabbi Wax’s involvement in a wide variety of community organizations such as the Tennessee State Board of Mental Health and the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Also included are a large number of sermons delivered by Dr. Wax from 1939 to 1977, as well as lectures, speeches, eulogies and miscellaneous religious writings. The papers also contain correspondence from 1954 to 1984, newspaper clippings, photographs, honorary degrees and awards. Finally, the material on Dr. Wax’s career is rounded out with a ten-volume scrapbook collection, arranged chronologically, which contains newspaper clippings, programs, letters and awards.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: civil rights; clergy; government; Jews; mayors; mental health; mentally ill; public service; rabbis; race; religion;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Brennan-Thomas Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Harry W. Brennan was born in Nashville in 1869. As a young man, his interest and ability in math led him to study engineering, and his first business venture was in the field of engineering and contracting. He moved to Memphis in 1904 with his sister Anna, and they joined their brother Joseph, who was working for the Commercial Appeal. Once in Memphis, Brennan discovered promising opportunities in real estate. With financial backing from his brother and other investors, Brennan developed a number of successful residential subdivisions, including Red Acres. He dedicated 120 acres from the land for Red Acres for construction of Galloway Park and Golf Course. -- Brennan provided leadership in many civic activities. For 15 years he actively promoted the Chamber of Commerce and published and edited the organization’s weekly journal Civic Affairs. An advocate of the state highway system, Brennan was appointed by Governor Malcolm Patterson to serve on the Tennessee Highway Commission. He also recognized the city’s importance in the national cotton market and supported the establishment of textile milling in Memphis. With his brother Joseph, he built and operated the ballroom and swimming pool in East End Park, which was a leading recreational facility for many years and the site of numerous annual festivals. -- James Albert Thomas, Jr., a native Memphian, was a realtor and served as Vice President of Boyle Investment Company for most of his business career. Later, he went into business with his son, James Albert Thomas, III, who organized Newsouth Capital Management. Thomas was an early resident of the Red Acres subdivision and took a leading role in forming the Red Acres Neighborhood Association. His interest in the history of Red Acres led him to research early deeds and land records of Shelby County. He was also concerned with zoning issues, crime prevention, University of Memphis expansion and Memphis Park Commission decisions that affected Galloway Golf Course. -- The Brennan—Thomas Collection incorporates two smaller collections related to these two individuals that each focus on the Red Acres Subdivision and Galloway Park. The papers span the years 1908 to 1993 and contain significant information on Chickasaw Gardens, including a historical account of the neighborhood written by James A. Thomas, Jr. Also in the collection is a directory of householders in Chickasaw Gardens covering the years 1926 to 1981. -- The collection includes audits and official documents associated with Brennan’s many real estate developments. The material also contains information on early Memphis subdivisions including Hyde Park, Belmont Park and Richland Place, which were developed by the Brennan Real Estate Company. A scrapbook compiled by Brennan includes newspaper clippings which describe his leadership roles in business, civic and government activities. The material related to James A. Thomas includes minutes of meetings of the Red Acres Neighborhood Association, correspondence, and zoning and planning studies. The Brennan—Thomas Collection provides a unique history of Galloway Park and Red Acres from their initial development on the outskirts of the city to their present-day position as a residential oasis in the heart of a major urban area.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: architecture; Belmont Park; Boyle Investment Co.; Brennan, Harry W.; business; Chickasaw Gardens; clubs; Galloway Golf Course; homeowners; Hyde Park; neighborhoods; parks; public service; real estate; Red Acres; Richland Place; Thomas, James Albert, Jr.; traffic;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Business Papers of Samuel B. Williamson, Napolean Hill and Noland Fontaine
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The firm of S.B. Williamson and A.S. Hancock, Grocers and Commission Merchants, was established at 49 Front in Memphis around 1850. Like similar businesses of their day, they sold a variety of items including groceries and farm supplies, and also served as cotton factors – plantation owners would often pay for their purchases with cotton. -- In 1856, Hancock sold his interest in the business to his partner. By early 1862, Noland Fontaine was working for Williamson, and in 1863 the business changed its name to Williamson and Hill. Williamson, Hancock and Fontaine were each periodically involved in the business and over the years the firm had several different names reflecting the involvement of the partners. In 1875 a change in the current of the Mississippi River caused the building which housed the company’s cotton to fall into the river. However, the business continued to exist for another quarter of a century. After this time, the partners seem to have been occupied with their other pursuits, and the company went into liquidation. -- S.B. Williamson was involved in a number of business activities in addition to the business on Front. He was an investor in the Bank of West Tennessee at Memphis, the Hernando Insurance Company and the Memphis and Little Rock Railroad Co. In addition, he owned several lots on Union, Madison and Main Streets in Memphis, as well as land in several counties in Mississippi and Arkansas. Williamson married Mary E. Eanes in 1845, and served as an alderman of Memphis from 1848 to 1849. -- Noland Fontaine married Jennie W. Eanes in 1864. He served as a member of the Memphis School Board in 1873 and also served as a director of several banks and as president of the Factors Insurance Company. He is best remembered as the owner of the Woodruff-Fontaine House, which he purchased from Amos Woodruff and which is located in the Victorian Village neighborhood. -- Napoleon Hill was born in Maury County, Tennessee and grew up in Marshall County, Mississippi. As a teenager, he worked in a dry goods store, and then joined the California gold rush. He did not find success as a gold miner, but spent several years operating a trading post for other miners. Returning to Tennessee, he married his childhood sweetheart, Mary Woods, and established a grocery business in Memphis with Charles Dorian. Hill was a founder of the Union and Planters Bank and served as its president. He also served as one of the first directors of the Cossitt Library, and was instrumental in soliciting book donations for the library. An investor in railroads, coal mines and insurance companies, he also owned a major cotton warehousing business and served as president of the Memphis Cotton Exchange. -- The business papers of Williamson, Hill and Fontaine were originally donated to the Cossitt Library, but were transferred to the Memphis and Shelby County Room when its manuscript collection was established. The papers, which include promissory notes, correspondence and documents related to bankruptcies, real estate transactions and the sale of slaves, reveal important information about business practices during the period. Promissory notes were used almost as currency and were passed from business to business. Bankruptcies were frequent occurrences during the post-Civil War period and the buying and selling of real estate was a major business activity. The papers also show the rise in the price of slaves over time and the important role of the Mississippi River and cotton in the economy of the Mid South.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Marshall Wingfield Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Revered Marshall Wingfield was a distinguished minister, historian, author, poet and a passionate activist for peace and justice. He was the senior minister of the First Congregational Church in Memphis from 1937 to 1958 and served as president of the West Tennessee Historical Society from 1938 to 1961. During his long and productive career, he wrote numerous books and articles on religion and history. -- Wingfield was born in 1893 on his father’s tobacco plantation in Franklin County, Virginia. Although his father wanted him to be a doctor, Wingfield realized early that he wanted to be a preacher, and as a child would gather other children around him as he stood behind an ash-hopper to “preach.” As a young man, Wingfield sustained a serious injury that crushed bones in his neck, and he spent three years confined to his bed in a cast. During the long recovery period, he was tutored rigorously by a neighborhood physician. This superior education allowed Wingfield to enter college several years early. He received a Bachelor’s degree from Texas Christian University in Forth Worth and a Master of Divinity from Union Theological Seminary in New York. -- In 1912 Wingfield was ordained to the ministry of the Disciples of Christ Church in Virginia. As a young minister, Wingfield lectured extensively on religious and racial tolerance and many of his lectures were featured in local newspapers. After serving as a minister in Virginia, Wingfield spent several years at the First Christian Church in Amory, Mississippi. While there, his volume of sermons, Forces of Destiny, as well as a collection of poetry, Translating Christmas and Other Poems, was published. -- Shortly after arriving in Memphis in 1937, Wingfield was asked to conduct a weekly book review program on radio station WMC. In 1945 he was asked to host a weekly religious news broadcast on WMPS that continued for the next twelve years. -- In 1944 Wingfield organized the Memphis Round Table of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. His continuing commitment to justice inspired him to write a powerful sermon, “The Implications of the Atomic Bomb,” which he delivered in August 1945 at First United Methodist Church in Memphis, while his wife, Marie Gregson Wingfield, also a minister, read the same sermon to the members of First Congregational Church. The sermon, in which Wingfield stated that “man has eaten from the Tree of Knowledge before eating of the Tree of Life,” and [his] mentality has run too far ahead of his spirituality,” appeared in the Congressional Record in December 1945. Wingfield was recognized for his work on behalf of peace and justice with a testimonial dinner given in his honor by the Sertoma Club in February 1952, as well as the establishment of a human relations scholarship in his name at Memphis State University. -- The Marshall Wingfield Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Reverend Wingfield and additional material was later given by his wife, the Reverend Marie Gregson Wingfield. The collection includes photographs, articles, poetry, book reviews, letters, newspaper clippings and lectures reflecting Wingfield’s deep and varied interests in travel, history and social justice. Also included is a nineteen-page bibliography of his works, an entry on Reverend Wingfield from Who’s Who in America, and programs from the 1952 Sertoma Testimonial Service for Dr. Wingfield at the Peabody Hotel.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: authors; clergy; historians; public service; religion; travel;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: George Sparks Little Theatre Wartime Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George F. Sparks came to Memphis in 1943 to serve as director of the Memphis Little Theatre, replacing Fred Sears, who had joined the army. Sparks, a thirty-one year old from Emporia, Kansas, had experience in both acting and directing. -- Sparks received his undergraduate degree with a major in speech from Kansas State Teachers College at Emporia. He received his master’s degree in speech and theater at Northwestern in Chicago in 1941, and went on to direct productions at the high school and college levels, and acted in some productions himself. In addition, he served a year in the armed forces before receiving a medical discharge. -- During his tenure with the Memphis Little Theatre, Sparks directed and designed the sets for such plays as You Can’t Take It With You, Love From a Stranger, The Philadelphia Story, and The Torch Bearer. Even though he faced the wartime problems of lack of transportation and a shortage of staff, his productions were acclaimed for being highly entertaining. -- The George Sparks Little Theatre Wartime Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mr. Sparks in 1977. Included in the collection are photographs and stage drawings from a number of productions presented during Sparks’ tenure as director of Memphis Little Theatre, as well as programs from the plays and newspaper clippings about the theatre, its personnel and the productions.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: acting; arts; directing; entertainment; plays; theater; World War II;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Witzmann-Gamble Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Emile Frederick Augustus Witzmann was born in Germany in 1841 but lived his young adult years in Paris. He spoke seven languages and was known throughout his life as a voracious reader of books, enjoying reading them in their natural languages. After graduating from school in Paris, Emile moved to Madrid, where he taught modern languages and music. After Madrid, Witzmann moved to England where he taught students from the Mid-South. In 1866, Emile Witzmann moved to Memphis where he got a job teaching music and languages. It was in 1872 that Emile founded E. Witzmann and Company, a music store based in Memphis that sold pianos, organs, and other musical instruments as well as sheet music for various instruments. -- Following Emile Witzmann’s death in 1914, Witzmann and Co. continued to be run by his wife Suzie and his son-in-law Fred O. Gamble. Fred Gamble traveled the country selling pianos before he became vice president of Witzmann and Co. music store. It was during his time traveling that he began to court and eventually marry Mary Louis Witzmann, Emile’s daughter. While traveling the country, Fred kept in touch with Mary Louis by writing hundreds of letters to her, sometimes more than twice daily. Their courtship right up through marriage is documented in these hundreds of letters. It is this correspondence between Fred Gamble and Mary Louis that make up the bulk of this collection. Frederick Gamble, Jr. donated the collection to the library in 1983. Besides correspondence between Fred O. Gamble, Sr. and his wife Mary Louis, the collection includes the following: diaries, business cards, newspaper clippings, bills and band statements from Witzmann and Co., photographs, and telegrams.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Gamble, Frederick; music; social life; Witzmann, Emile;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: WKNO-TV Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The WKNO-TV Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center in 2006 by Teri Sullivan, WKNO Promotions Manager. Consisting of four photograph albums and one scrapbook, the WKNO-TV Collection chronicles the operation of Memphis’ public television station from 1956 to the beginning of the 21st century. The collection includes photographs of productions such as “All Aboard with Mr. B.” and “the Playground,” portraits of on-air personalities such as Jim Eikner, Rosanna Quinn and Tom Tichenor, photographs of the station’s studio facilities and a scrapbook of newspapers clippings covering the year 1957. -- The Memphis Community Television Foundation was formed in 1953 to establish an educational television station for Memphis and the Mid-South. WKNO commenced broadcasting on June 25, 1956 – the 22nd educational television station in the United States. In its 50 years of broadcasting, WKNO-TV has provided quality educational programming for children and adults alike.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: arts; children; dance; education; entertainment; television; theater; WKNO;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jerry O. Potter Sultana Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Sultana left Memphis on April 27, 1865 carrying three times the number of passengers for which it was designed. Tragedy struck later that evening when the boilers ruptured, causing the steamer to explode. Many were killed immediately from the blast, but others were crushed or died from burns, hypothermia and drowning. Sadly, most of the victims were former prisoners of war who had been interned at the notorious Andersonville and Cahaba Prisons for captured Federal soldiers during the Civil War. -- The sinking occurred just after the surrender of the Confederacy, the assassination of President Lincoln and the death of John Wilkes Booth, and was largely forgotten until the 1992 publication of Jerry O. Potter’s The Sultana Tragedy: America’s Greatest Maritime Disaster. -- Potter, a Memphis lawyer, became interested in the sinking of the Sultana after seeing a painting of the event in a local bank. Initial research into the destruction of the steamer revealed very little. Newspaper articles found from 1865 conveyed the enormity of the disaster, but the few modern books written about the event did little to detail the extensive loss of life. Potter decided to uncover the facts behind the ill-fated Sultana and her 2,300 passengers and bring their story to light. After a decade of extensive research, he published his book, which became one the most respected works on the subject. -- Potter, a native Tennessean who grew up in Milan, earned a degree in history from the University of Tennessee at Martin. While a student, he won the Tennessee Historical Commission Award for earning the highest marks in history, and was awarded an internship by the Tennessee Valley Authority to conduct historical research on the state. From this research, Potter published a study entitled “Problems relating to the Socio-Economical Development of Northwest Tennessee 1819 through 1900.” Potter went on to earn a law degree from Memphis State University in 1975 and became a partner in The Hardison Law Firm in Memphis. -- Potter donated the research materials from his book to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 2005. The collection consists of photocopied documents and correspondence used to write the manuscript, as well as numerous photographs. Included are documents pertaining to the court martial of Frederic Speed, the only person brought to trial following the Sultana disaster. In addition, the papers contain the proceedings of the Washburn and Dana Commissions’ investigations into the loss of the Sultana. Also included are various items such as unit rosters, published articles, correspondence and other pieces of information gathered by Potter over time. Some material that was not included in Potter’s book, such as genealogical information, photographs and information received through correspondence with other researchers is also contained in the collection.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: authors; boats; cemeteries; Civil War; court martials; hospitals; maritime disasters; military; prisoners of war; prisons; rivers; steamboats; trials; writers;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Paul Coppock Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Paul Coppock was born in Greenfield, Indiana, and during his youth lived in Virginia, New York, Nebraska, and Illinois. He attended Earlham College in Richmond, Indiana, and planned to follow in his father’s footsteps and become a history teacher. Instead, he became a journalist. His first full-time job was with the Indiana Post. After this newspaper folded, Coppock moved to Memphis and worked a year with the Memphis Press-Scimitar. In 1929, he became a cub reporter for The Commercial Appeal, reporting on Memphis and Shelby County government. -- In the early 1940s, Coppock was promoted to night city editor. While holding this position, Coppock originated “The Night Desk,” a question-and-answer column about the history of the Mid-South. The column, which first appeared in 1946, continued for 21 years. In 1972, Coppock retired from The Commercial Appeal, but continued to write a weekly article entitled “Mid-South Memoirs.” This human interest column, also centered on local history, ran until 1982. Coppock’s writings were compiled into a book called Memphis Sketches and a three volume set of books entitled Memphis Memoirs. Coppock was greatly admired by the people of the Mid-South, and his writings were a consistent source of insight into Memphis history, people and events. -- Paul Coppock’s papers were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1992 by his wife, Helen McPheron Coppock. The collection consists primarily of material from Coppock’s career as a journalist, including numerous notes, photos, booklets, brochures and a photocopied edition and original manuscripts for his book, Memphis Sketches. The Coppock collection also includes 21 scrapbooks which contain a complete series of “The Night Desk” columns. The extensive collection provides information on the subjects of Coppock’s numerous columns related to Memphis and the Mid-South, including annexation, Beale Street, cemeteries, the Mid-South Fair, hospitals and biographical information on many Mid-Southerners, such as E.H. Crump and the Church family. A comprehensive index to Coppock’s columns and other materials he collected can be referenced in the finding aid to the collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beale Street Development Corporation Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Beale Street Development Corporation Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 2005 by Thane Wheeler. Spanning the years 1972 to 1985, the collection contains correspondence, government reports, land records, legal documents, and newspaper articles related to the operation of the Beale Street Development Corporation during the formative years of its existence. -- In 1973, the not-for-profit Beale Street Development Corporation was formed to assist entrepreneurs wanting to open businesses on the famous thoroughfare. At that point many of the historic buildings on Beale Street had been destroyed owing to a federal urban renewal project and the City of Memphis hoped to secure additional federal funds to rebuild the street into an entertainment district. As a result, in 1978 city government awarded the Beale Street Development Corporation a $2 million restoration grant, and in 1982 the BSDC signed a 32-year lease with the city to co-develop and manage the property with Elkington & Keltner Properties, Inc. Although plagued by controversy, the Beale Street Development Corporation helped save a national historic landmark and oversaw its transformation into one of Memphis’ most popular tourist destinations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Everett R. Cook Oral History Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Oral History Program began in the early 1960s when former Tennessee Governor W. Browning agreed to be interviewed on audio tape by Memphis State University professor and archivist Joseph H. Riggs. This interview was very successful, and the program was expanded to include taped interviews with people from Memphis and Tennessee including Abe Plough, Blair Hunt and George W. Lee. The program also includes tapes of conversations with individuals associated with events such as the funerals of Martin Luther King, Jr., and William Faulkner and interviews conducted through the Neighborhood History Project about Memphis neighborhoods including Cooper-Young, Greenlaw, Buntyn-Messick and Vollentine-Evergreen. Interviews were also conducted on race relations, the Memphis mayoral campaign of 1967, the school lunch program, the Tennessee Poetry Society and the Memphis Blues Project. Also included are interviews with individuals who were instrumental in the history of music in Memphis which were conducted by Margaret McKee and Fred Chisenhall for their book, Beale Black and Blue. -- The Oral History Program tapes also include the memoirs of General Everett R. Cook, who had a successful career as a businessman and a military officer. As a businessman, Cook owned his own cotton company and formed E. R. Cook & Co., which was later known as Cook Industries, Inc. During World War I, Cook served in the 91st Aero Squadron, and was awarded the Croix de Guerre. He served as a lieutenant colonel during World War II, and served as deputy chief of staff under General Carl Spaatz in the U.S. Air Force. He achieved the rank of brigadier general in 1948. -- General Cook was also a dedicated civil servant. In 1953 he was elected to the Tennessee Constitutional Convention, and he served as chair of the Auditorium Commission and as a director of Eastern Airlines and Plough, Inc. The Everett R. Cook Convention Center was named in his honor in 1974, and he was awarded honorary degrees from Southwestern at Memphis (now Rhodes College) and Christian Brothers College. -- Cook’s memoirs were installed in the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1972. Transcripts of the tapes were adapted into a hardbound book, Everett R. Cook: A Memoir, and General Cook contributed 1,000 copies to be sold to benefit the Oral History Program.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: National Coalition of 100 Black Women Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 100 Black Women’s Club began in New York City as a grassroots effort to address social issues and affect change within the community. Over time, the club reached out to other black women in order to mobilize themselves into a visible and influential force. In 1971, this regional community officially organized as the Coalition of 100 Black Women. -- By its 10-year anniversary, the organization had amassed approximately 900 members from within the New York metropolitan area. Due to its effective role modeling structure and programs, black women outside of New York wished to duplicate the Coalition’s work throughout the country. The Coalition, under the direction of President Jewell Jackson McCabe, relaunched in October 1981 with chapters in 14 states and the word ‘National’ in its name. By 1986, the NCOBW boasted of 47 chapters in 19 states and national membership of over three thousand. -- The original spirit of the Coalition remains the same today. With more than 7,000 members in 25 states, it remains dedicated to rebuilding black communities and providing resources for at-risk black women. -- Founded on October 24, 1981, the Memphis Chapter works to empower and inform the black women of the Memphis area by holding several conventions and programs throughout the year on topics ranging from financial planning to HIV/AIDS awareness. -- The collection contains articles concerning the Memphis Chapter’s community involvement, membership lists, and information regarding the various programs and charity events.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; civic clubs; social life; women;
