oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Josephine Wainman Burson Collection: A Life in Public Service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Josephine Wainman Burson, community leader and social activist, was dedicated to significantly improving the quality of life for women, underserved individuals and minority populations. Her career focused on community service and political activism, especially by serving with women’s groups, where she utilized her organizational skills to provide employment and educational opportunities and break down barriers. She served in a variety of organizations, including local Democratic women’s clubs and Hadassah, the largest Jewish women’s organization in the United States. -- Burson was born in 1915 and attended local schools and Memphis State College. In 1937 she married Leo Burson, a young law student at St. Lawrence University in New York. Leo Burson, who went on to become a well-known Memphis attorney and businessman, received many honors and shared his wife’s passion for political activism. The Burson’s two children, Linda Burson, a physician, and Charles W. Burson, who served as Tennessee Attorney General from 1988 until 1996, were greatly influenced by their parent’s activism and commitment to social justice. -- Josephine Burson attributed much of her public success to the skills she acquired through her work with Hadassah. A highlight of Burson’s exceptional efforts to improve the quality of life for others was her serving as Commissioner of Employment Security for the state of Tennessee. Appointed to this position by Governor Buford Ellington in 1967, Burson was the first woman and the first Jewish person to be appointed to the cabinet of a Tennessee governor. She was one of only three women in the United States to hold such a position at that time. -- Following her term in state government, Burson spent 20 years with Memphis Senior Services, where she served as vice-president for communications. At the time of her retirement, Burson had spent more than 50 years helping to expand opportunities for women and improving the quality of life in the communities she served. -- The Josephine Wainman Burson Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mrs. Burson in 1999. The material in the collection dates from 1967 to 1970 when she served as Commissioner of Employment Security. The papers consist of correspondence, government documents, publications, newspaper clippings and news releases. -- Materials relating to Burson’s role in state government include documents on the education and training activities of the Department of Employment Security. Also included are Department of Employment Security papers regarding labor matters such as benefits or employment requests, as well as materials that pertain specifically to services for women, youth and individuals with special needs. -- In addition to professional documents, the collection includes correspondence relating to Burson’s wide-ranging activities in Hadassah and other local and national Jewish organizations, which took her across the United States, to Europe, and to Israel. Also included are personal letters and speeches she made to a variety of organizations. -- The collection provides information on the role of a woman involved in diverse and important fields of activity at a time when women were beginning to assume leadership and administrative roles previously available only to men.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: activism; Burson, Josephine Wainman; Democratic Party; employment; family; government; Hadassah; Jews; labor; minorities; public relations; public service; social justice; social life; state government; volunteerism; women

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Register of the Henry A. Montgomery Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henry A. Montgomery was born in Fermanagh County, Ireland in 1829. At fifteen he began an apprenticeship with Thos. Karnahan & Sons, a timber, slate and iron dealership. He immigrated to Canada in the spring of 1848 and moved later that year to Brown County, Ohio. By the time Montgomery applied for U.S. citizenship in 1851, he had married Maria Jane Dugan, a native of Ohio. The young family moved to Tennessee shortly after the birth of their daughter Julia, the first of Henry and Maria’s six children. The Montgomerys lived a short time in Somerville before settling in Memphis, where Henry became involved in the telegraph business. -- His early efforts involved direct control of all phases of the introduction of telegraphic communications into the Memphis area, but by the late 1850s, Montgomery was dealing primarily with the construction of telegraph lines. Through his efforts, Memphis became a junction for Morse communication. Unfortunately, the pressure of larger companies and the effects of the Federal occupation of Memphis during the Civil War forced Montgomery out of the telegraph business. He sold his interests to the Southwestern Telegraph Company, which later merged with other regional companies to form Western Union. -- After leaving the telegraph business, Montgomery explored other ventures, including lumber, dry goods and cotton speculation. His achievements in business brought prosperity and social recognition to Montgomery and his family. By the mid-1860s, the Montgomerys had become a part of the social elite in Memphis had and earned a reputation for being hospitable and concerned about community affairs. -- After Maria’s death in 1870, Montgomery continued to be active in the civic and business affairs of the city. He was elected Fire and Police Commissioner in 1884 and served as president of the Memphis Jockey Club. He was also the principal promoter and financial investor in the Montgomery Park race track. It was while serving in his role as business and community leader that Henry A. Montgomery died dramatically on October 20, 1887. Immediately after welcoming delegates of the Waterways Convention to Memphis and to the Montgomery Park races, he fell dead on the speakers’ platform. After his death, Montgomery’s children continued the family tradition of involvement in civic affairs and served in local organizations such as the Nineteenth Century Club, the Tennessee Club and the Memphis Jockey Club. -- The identity of the donor of the Montgomery family collection is unknown. The papers, which span the years 1853 to 1942, contain materials which reflect the social history and personal relationships of the Montgomery family. Also included are business papers relating to Henry’s experiences in the telegraph business and documents which list Memphis businesses and costs of living in the second half of the nineteenth century in this area. -- The collection includes papers about Henry’s granddaughter, Montgomery Cooper, which detail her attempts to establish herself as a rare book dealer and include her correspondence as Literary Editor of The Commercial Appeal in the 1920s. In addition, the papers include materials related to Henry’s daughter, Jennie Montgomery Jones, which were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room as a separate gift. The majority of these items are legal documents concerning property, business papers from the family’s cotton business, and bills and receipts from the 1870s and 1880s for living expenses from the family’s mansion, Montgomery Place.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Robert L. Waller Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Robert Lee Waller was born in 1924 in Memphis. After graduating from Booker T. Washington High School in 1942, he entered the United States Navy, where he served until the end of World War II. After leaving the navy, he enrolled in Howard University and graduated in 1949 with a Bachelor of Arts degree. He received Master of Arts degrees from Howard University and Memphis State University, and was awarded the degree of Doctor of Education from Western Colorado University. In addition, he was twice granted a Fulbright Fellowship to study in Brazil, Liberia and Nigeria. He was also an NDEA Fellow in American history at the University of Chicago. -- Dr. Waller spent more than twenty-five years as a teacher and administrator in the Memphis public schools. After his retirement, he accepted a position as Associate Professor of history at LeMoyne-Owen College and served in this position for eight years. He was also named Director of the Interdisciplinary Center for African and African American studies at LeMoyne-Owen. Two days before his death in 1990, Dr. Waller was appointed Professor Emeritus of African American Studies. -- During his career as a teacher in Memphis, Robert Waller was a familiar figure in the Memphis Public Library. After his death, his sister, Viola Waller Amos, donated his professional papers to the Memphis and Shelby County Room. Material found in The Robert L. Waller Collection traces the career of Dr. Waller from the time he left the navy after World War II until his death. In addition to correspondence dating from 1946 through 1981, there are academic papers submitted for classes at several institutions or published in various journals. The collection also includes diplomas, certificates and plaques recognizing Waller’s achievements and photographs of Waller. Finally, there are obituaries and tributes paid to him after his death in 1990.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; colleges; education; military; public service; teachers; universities;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A.W. Willis, Jr. Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The A.W. Willis, Jr. Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center by Willis’s widow, Dr. Miriam DeCosta Willis, on January 10, 2003. Comprised of ten boxes, this collection contains correspondence, newspaper clippings, programs, reports and other documents relating to Willis’s public and private life starting in the early 1950s and continuing after his death in 1988. The collection also contains an impressive amount of photographs. There are five boxes of photographs ranging from family snapshots and portraits to photographs done by Ernest Withers, famous for his civil rights photography. -- The collection contains information on several topics in Memphis and Tennessee, including: Memphis civil rights history; Willis’s political career; Memphis and Tennessee politics in the 1960s and 1980s (particularly Dick Hackett’s 1986 campaign for mayor and Ned McWherter’s 1986 campaign for governor); the National Democratic Convention; the operation of Willis’s various businesses; the failed merging of the Church of God in Christ and LeMoyne-Owen College; Beale Street development; Church Park; the founding of the National Civil Rights Museum; and family information including various wills and trusts.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Beale Street; civil rights; family life; government; integration; law; National Civil Rights Museum; politics; religion; Willis, A. W., Jr.;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. R.Q. and Ethyl H. Venson Cotton Makers' Jubilee Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Ransom Q. Venson was a native of Rapides Parish, Louisiana. In 1912 he graduated from Meharry Medical School in Nashville and then moved to Memphis to establish a dental practice in this city. In 1934, he married Ethyl B. Horton, a native Memphian, who was born in 1908. Ethyl grew up in the area near Collins Chapel and went on to earn a degree from LeMoyne College. Throughout their marriage, Ransom and Ethyl were committed to serving their community in a variety of ways. -- During World War I, Dr. Venson served as a commissioned officer in the Medical Corps. After returning to his dental practice in Memphis after the war, he was a leader in the founding of Autress Russell American Legion Post 27, which was for many years the largest African-American post in the world. He held every office in the local American Legion organization and was also active on the national level. Dr. Venson was also an active Mason and a member of the Elks. He was honored for his service to the community in 1972 by having a high-rise housing development for senior citizens on Beale Street named after him. -- Ethyl Venson was the first woman and the first African American to be appointed to the board of the Memphis Housing Authority in 1966, and she went on to be elected as chair of the board in 1972. Also in 1972, Governor Winfield Dunn appointed her to the Tennessee Commission on the Status of Women. Ethyl also devoted her time to serving with the American Red Cross, the Memphis Urban League, the Memphis Heart Association and the Girls Club. -- The Vensons are perhaps best-known as founders of the Cotton Makers’ Jubilee, which was established in 1935 as a parallel organization to the Memphis Cotton Carnival, which had been established in 1931 but did not provide for social participation by African American Memphians. Dr. Venson served as director of the Jubilee until his death in 1970, while Ethyl served as the organization’s first queen in 1935, and served as director from 1970 to 1985. -- Through the many activities of the Cotton Makers’ Jubilee, particularly the selection of a King and Queen and a royal Court, the organization provided an opportunity for African Americans in Memphis to enjoy their own parties, parades and celebrations. Over the years, the Jubilee continually expanded its activities, including many for school children. -- The Dr. R.Q. and Ethyl H. Venson Cotton Makers’ Jubilee Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Ethyl Horton Venson through the Shelby County Historical Commission and additional material was given directly to the Memphis and Shelby County Room. The collection includes thirty six Cotton Makers’ Jubilee programs from 1937 through 1991, which list the Jubilee royalty, the directors, financial supporters and others associated with the organization in various capacities. The collection also contains correspondence about the Jubilee which Ethyl Venson received from local and national officials, including several Tennessee governors and two U.S. presidents. In addition to material related to the Jubilee, the papers contain letters from civic and business leaders pertaining to Ethyl Venson’s many years of service to several community organizations, including the Memphis Housing Authority, the Bluff City Dental Society, the American Red Cross, the Memphis Urban League and the Memphis/Shelby County Mental Health Association.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; agriculture; clubs; cotton; dentists; entertainment; mayors; police; public service; race; recreation; social life; women;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: W.W. Busby's Letters
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: W. W. Busby was born in 1893 and spent his early years in the Memphis neighborhoods known as Meacham’s Shinertown and Pinch. His father, John Busby, owned several markets in Memphis before the family moved to Texas in 1904. W.W. Busby attended Market Street School and St. Mary’s Catholic School. He graduated from Chamberlain-Hunt Academy in 1912, and attended The University of Mississippi. His versatile career included stints as a railroad man in Chicago, a hotel man in Arkansas, a sailor, and a Mississippi cotton farmer. At the time Busby wrote the letters in this collection, he had retired except for working occasionally as an accountant in Eudora, Mississippi. -- The collection of letters written by W.W. Busby was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Paul Coppock, longtime Night City Editor of The Commercial Appeal. Busby and Coppock began corresponding after Coppock requested information about the Creeping Bear murder, which was believed to be the last killing in Memphis of a white man by a Native American. The two men developed a unique relationship in which they wrote about many different aspects of life in Memphis around the turn of the century. Coppock donated these letters so that researchers might gain insight into Memphis during this time in history.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: agriculture; Arkansas; cotton; dumps; firefighting; Meacham's Shinertown; neighborhoods; Pinch District; politics; recreation; social life;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Britton Duke Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Britton Duke Papers are a chronicle of an early Germantown, Tennessee, family. The papers were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Louise Duke Bedford, great granddaughter of Britton Duke, and her nephew, Edward C. Duke. The collection primarily consists of correspondence and business papers which belonged to Britton Duke. Duke, a prominent cotton planter and civic leader, owned property in Shelby County which was adjacent to the Nashoba Plantation, a utopian community founded by Frances Wright. The Duke property, which ran from Massey Road in East Memphis to Poplar Estates and from U.S. Highway 72 to the Wolf River, joined Nashoba on the east. -- Britton Duke immigrated from Scotland Neck, North Carolina, to Shelby County in 1830. He was accompanied by his second wife, Mary Louise Duke. On their way to Pea Ridge (sometimes called Pea Mount and now a part of Germantown) the Dukes delayed their trip at LaGrange, Tennessee, where their first daughter was born. Once he arrived in Shelby County, Duke immediately established himself as a leading citizen of the area, where he often acted as an agent or witness for his less wealthy and illiterate neighbors. -- Britton and Mary Louise Duke had seven children. Britton was very interested in the education of his own family and served as a long-time school commissioner for the 11th district of Shelby County. The papers include correspondence relating to his role as school commissioner, school schedules and receipts for the Duke children’s tuition and school supplies. -- The collection, which was previously called The Duke-Bedford Family Papers, serves as a valuable resource on the Nashoba Plantation and Frances Wright. The collection includes a receipt written to Duke for $20 for timber cut from Nashoba, an 1854 newspaper advertisement for Nashoba and correspondence regarding the Nashoba land. In addition to numerous receipts for farming equipment and household supplies, the collection provides important information on slavery, including bills of sale for slaves which list the slaves by name.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: agriculture; Bedford family; cotton; Duke family; education; family; Germantown, Tennessee; immigration; Nashoba; newspapers; public service; Shelby County; slavery; social life;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Martha Hamilton Embree Courtroom Art Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1994, Martha Hamilton “Ham” Embree, noted Memphis artist, donated a large collection of watercolor courtroom drawings she was commissioned to do by local television stations to the Memphis and Shelby County Room. A pioneer in television animation, Embree was the courtroom artist for CBS News and its Memphis affiliate, WREG-TV, Channel 3. Embree’s drawings gave visual reality to trials that could be covered by courtroom reporters but not photographers. -- The collection includes images from important trials from the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. Drawings from trials such as the James Earl Ray evidentiary hearings, the Judge David Lanier trial, the Deborah Groseclose murder trial, the Congressman Harold Ford case and the Dr. George Nichopolous trial are significant from both a legal and historical standpoint. The Ray hearings, related to the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Nichopolous case, with its sensational testimony related to Elvis Presley’s drug dependence, involved world-famous individuals. -- Embree was born in Como, Mississippi. After graduating from Mississippi State College for Women in 1943, she moved to Memphis and enrolled at the Memphis Academy of Art, where she received a certificate in commercial art in 1944. She and her husband, Edward Embree, were a part of the city’s “art group” that included well-known artists such as Dolph Smith, Nancy Bogatin, Mimi Dann, Billy Price Hosmer and Carroll Cloar. -- From 1954 to 1976, Embree managed the Studio of Advertising and Art with Nancy Bogatin. In 1977 the agency merged with Jan Gardner & Associates, a firm headed by Jan Gardner and Margaret Lowery. Embree assumed the position of senior vice-president and creative director in the new organization, which handled some 31 local, regional and national accounts. -- A large body of Embree’s watercolors depicting the rural South appeared in the Ford Times. Her work was also published in national magazines such as Psychology Today, Ebony and Mademoiselle. One of her best-known pieces of art was the Les Passes’ 1979 New Year’s Eve cabaret program cover, a montage that featured many of the area’s best known music personalities including W.C. Handy, Elvis Presley, Bessie Smith and Marguerite Piazza. -- Exhibits of Embree’s regional art were held in several Mid-South towns and included studies in oil, egg tempera, acrylic and opaque watercolor. Her childhood in the Mississippi Delta was reflected in her Southern themes, and she and her husband Ed traveled throughout the South searching for subjects to capture with their art. Embree was a talented portrait painter, and one of her most significant pieces was a study of Edwin Hubbard, the late jazz flutist. Her portrait work also included studies of Native Americans, children and ordinary people of the rural South. -- After Embree’s death in 1996, her friends organized an estate sale of art pieces in her home. A selection of this work was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room prior to the estate sale. These pieces include oils, watercolors, egg tempera, crayon, charcoal and pencil studies. Stored with the courtroom drawings, these additional pieces demonstrate Embree’s substantial talent.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: art; basketball; courts; crime; law; sports; trials; women;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis - Enschede Ties
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Prior to World War II, Enschede, the largest cotton manufacturing city in the Netherlands, and Memphis, the Mid-South’s cotton-exchange center, maintained firm business ties. Enschede, situated six miles from the German border, was completely devastated during the war. With its cotton mills destroyed and many of its citizens left destitute, it needed outside assistance to recover. -- During a transatlantic telephone call in early 1946, the mayor of Enschede, John van Hatem, suggested to Memphis Mayor Walter Chandler that Memphis adopt Enschede to help the city recover from the war. This call was followed by a visit to Enschede by Francis Hickman, editor of the Memphis Cotton Trade Journal, who was touring Germany at the end of the war at the request of General Eisenhower. -- Although Mayor Chandler doubted that Memphis had the resources to adopt another city, he assigned the relief effort to the Memphis International Center. The hard work of W.R. Herstein, Executive Director of the Memphis International Center, made the campaign a success. 3,000 friendship boxes were prepared and sent by the children of Memphis to the children of Enschede, followed by shipments of clothing and 10,000 tins of canned food. These efforts led to the creation of a strong bond between the two cities. -- Memphis and Enschede continued to maintain close ties after the war relief effort through numerous visits by citizens of each city to their sister city. The strength of this connection was clearly demonstrated in 1953, when the most devastating flood since 1421 swept over the Netherlands. Although Enschede was not directly affected, the Memphis Flood Relief Committee began collecting money for victims of the flood. By mentioning that the funds collected would be transmitted directly to the Mayor of Enschede, who would then channel them to the proper Dutch authorities, the organization collected a total of $14,526.09. A comparison of this figure with the grand total of approximately $16,000 collected in the whole state of Tennessee clearly demonstrates the strong bond of friendship that had developed between the Memphis and Enschede. -- The Memphis – Enschede Ties collection contains correspondence relating to the adoption of Enschede by the people of Memphis, including letters exchanged between the mayors of the two cities. The papers provide details about the gifts made to the people of Enschede after the war such as lists of items and amounts of monetary gifts shipped to the city. The collection also includes numerous newspaper clippings on the relationship between Memphis and Enschede and letters relating to flood relief efforts undertaken by the people of Memphis in 1953. -- In 1957, Ethel Schroeder, Vice-President of the International Advisory Council, Inc. wrote to Frank Ahlgren, editor of the Commercial Appeal, requesting information on the ties between Memphis and Enschede. Schroeder felt that the connection between the two cities was a good example of the type of relationship President Eisenhower was trying to promote through his People-to-People program. Letters exchanged between Schroeder and Ahlgren are included in the collection.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: aid; business; charity; children; clubs; cotton; floods; Holland; mayors; Netherlands; relief efforts; volunteerism;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Evergreen Historic District Association Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Evergreen Historic District Association is the current name of a civic organization started in 1969, but the first Evergreen association began in 1909 as the Woman’s Evergreen Improvement Club. The boundaries of the community have changed somewhat over the years, but basically Evergreen includes the area due west of Overton Park, the north-south dimensions corresponding to those of the park. In the early decades of the 1900s, the Evergreen neighborhood was a very fashionable suburban neighborhood, with comfortable family homes sitting next to elaborate mansions. During and after the war, many homes turned into rooming houses and there was an exodus to the newer suburbs to the east. In the 1960s and 1970s, Evergreen residents (as part of the Mid-Memphis Improvement Association, along with other interested parties) successfully fought against the intrusion of the I-40 expressway, though not before the demolition of a 56-acre swath of homes to make room for “The Corridor.” By 1985, the Mid-Memphis Neighborhood Association had succeeded in having Evergreen declared a National Register Historic District. Realizing their name should reflect that status, the group made a final change to the Evergreen Historic District Association (EHDA). The Corridor was successfully redeveloped during the 1990s, with noteworthy adherence to redevelopment guidelines which maintained the architectural and stylistic integrity of the neighborhood. The Evergreen Historic District Association Collection contains materials from the latter half of the 20th century and the first few years of the 21st.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: architecture; Evergreen Historic District Association; midtown; neighborhoods; transportation; zoning;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Farrow Family Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Kathryn Farrow was born in 1883 to Catherine Gooch and George Ferdinand Farrow. She was a schoolteacher for many years, and her father was a civic leader who helped to organize a public school system in Whitehaven. -- George Farrow’s father, Lemuel Farrow, came to the Whitehaven area around 1848 with his wife Sophia and their children. Lemuel and his sons, George and James Marion, were landowners and cotton planters. -- The Farrow Family Papers consist primarily of correspondence exchanged between members of George Farrow’s family. Most of the letters relate to routine matters of health, weather conditions and social activities. The papers include a series of letters between Catherine Gooch Farrow and her daughter, Kathryn, who lived in various places in Tennessee and Virginia while completing her education. Kathryn returned to Whitehaven, then known as White Haven, around 1914 to become a teacher of history at White Haven High School. Both Kathryn and her mother were interested in tracing the Gooch family history, and the collection contains correspondence and other papers related to their genealogy research. -- The collection also includes documents accumulated by George Farrow during the course of his service as a member of the school board and several items related to Kathryn Farrow’s career as a teacher. These papers provide detailed information about the development of the public school system in the area. Receipts and statements of accounts related to the Farrow family’s cotton business are also included in the collection. In addition, the collection contains several contracts with farm workers. These items give details on the price and weight of the Farrow’s cotton as well as identifying the workers responsible for picking and processing the cotton. Finally, the papers include more than 100 receipts for various purchases typical of a large family. Most of the receipts are for the purchases of staple goods, many of which were bought from the same companies that handled the family’s cotton.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: agriculture; business; cotton; education; family; Farrow family; landowners; neighborhoods; public schools; public service; social life; weather; women;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William Teasley Berlin Family Letters Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This small collection of letters was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1985 by Dexter Muller. The letters in the collection provide a great deal of information about the life of the Berlin family and the loss they sustained upon the death of William Teasley Berlin in the yellow fever epidemic of 1879. The letters are stored in the Memphis and Shelby County Room with A History of Yellow Fever in Memphis and several other small collections related to the yellow fever epidemics in Memphis. -- During the Civil War, William Berlin served in A Company of the 17th Cavalry in West Tennessee. Following the war, he was senior partner of W.T. Berlin and Company, a real estate and mortgage company. He lived with his wife, Clorinda, two young daughters, Lillian and Maye, and his two teenage sisters, Lucy and Mollie. -- It is an especially poignant that William Berlin, having survived the Civil War and the yellow fever epidemics of 1873 and 1878, died in the 1879 epidemic. The winter of 1878-79 was mild, and later scientific research confirmed that the aedes aegypti mosquito, which carried the disease, was able to survive the winter in barns, homes and other sheltered locations. The return of hot, humid weather in the summer of 1879 brought another outbreak of yellow fever. The reason that fewer people died in 1879 arises from the fact that a case of the viral disease confers immunity, and nearly every person in Memphis contracted yellow fever in 1878. The devastating 1878 yellow fever epidemic that raged in Memphis and throughout the Mississippi River Valley was a disaster of such magnitude that it has overshadowed the significant epidemic in the late summer of 1879. The 500 or more victims of the 1879 epidemic represented about ten percent of the death toll of 1878, which largely accounts for the fact that this outbreak of yellow fever in Memphis has received scant attention.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Berlin family; death; disease; epidemics; family; grieving; health; women; women's rights; yellow fever;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Firestone Tire and Rubber Company Memphis Plant Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Material in the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company Collection provides important information on the company that at one time was the largest manufacturer in Memphis, employing thousands of individuals working in a facility that covered several hundred acres in North Memphis. The parent company in Akron, Ohio, was founded in 1900 by Harvey S. Firestone, Sr., one of America’s great business entrepreneurs. The Memphis Firestone plant was built in 1936 and incorporated the Murray Wood Products Company plant, which was owned by Fisher Body Corporation. This facility was the initial unit for the new Firestone tire manufacturing operation. Raymond C. Firestone, one of the founder’s four sons, was transferred from California to head the operation of the Mid-South facility. The Memphis plant grew rapidly, soon out-producing its early goals, and the communities of Frayser and New Chicago were developed to provide homes near the Firestone operation for the company workforce. In 1956, the Firestone Company advertised its Memphis plant as the “largest single tire producing unit in the world on 35 acres of floor space, producing 1 out of every 17 tires manufactured in the U.S.” The ad pointed out that the Memphis plant employed some 4,000 men and women and contributed more than $25,000,000 annually to the local economy. Growth continued through the 60s and 70s, but the plant was forced to close in 1983. The collection includes one box of print materials and one large album of photographs, which depict all phases of tire manufacturing and production at the Memphis plant. In addition to the materials in this collection, the Memphis Information File contains more than one hundred newspaper clippings on the Firestone Company, and the Memphis Room Photograph Collection includes 34 photographs, many showing the initial 1936 construction. The Memphis Room also has bound copies of the company’s annual reports from 1938 through 1973. This material provides an important historical record of the company’s significant role in the economic history of Memphis. Materials in this collection were donated to the Public Library after the close-down phase of the Firestone plant had been completed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: business; economy; Firestone Tire and Rubber Company; Firestone, Raymond C.; Frayser; industry; New Chicago; rubber;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Official Papers of William B. Fowler
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The William Fowler collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Fowler’s grandson, John W. Fowler, in 1985. William Bingham Fowler, born in 1886, served the city of Memphis as an engineer over a span of 69 years. During this time, he was responsible for turning Memphis from a town of “cobblestones and wooden blocks” into a city of paved streets and interstate highways. He accomplished all of this while serving under eleven different mayors, including the illustrious E.H. Crump. -- Fowler began his career with the city as a water boy in the sewers in 1900. While attending Memphis High School, he received an appointment to the Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland. However, after a short time he returned to Memphis. Except for his brief stay at the academy, he never attended college, primarily for financial reasons. He acquired his substantial engineering skills while on the job. -- In 1907 Fowler married Sydney Shepard, who died ten years later of scarlet fever. The year of his first wife’s death, Fowler became superintendent of the Memphis park system. While serving in this position, he helped design and develop the Memphis Zoo. Fowler went on to marry Margaret Williams, a former teacher and school principal from Lucy, Tennessee in 1921. Margaret Williams Fowler became the first chair of the City Beautiful Commission and was also active in the Nineteenth Century Club, the Memphis Council of Parent-Teacher Associations, and the Tennessee Daughters of the American Revolution. -- After working for the city for several years, Fowler went into business for himself. His business, Koehler-Fowler Construction Company, failed because of the shortages caused by World War I. He then returned to work for the city, where he continued to serve until 1969. -- On September 1, 1918, Fowler was appointed Assistant City Engineer. Just nine months later, he was promoted to City Engineer, a position he held until his official retirement in 1962. In 1937 he and his staff designed a 16 million dollar system for controlling flooding from the Mississippi and Wolf Rivers and Nonconnah Creek. He was also responsible for over 400 miles of sewer systems, which alleviated sanitation problems. Under his guidance, roads throughout the city were widened and paved, and improvements such as the Avalon viaduct on Poplar were added. -- In 1955 Fowler designed the routes for the interstate highway through and around the city. His tenure with the city and his relationships with other officials were not always secure. During the flood of 1937, Mayor Watkins Overton fired him for not being at his desk in a time of emergency – he had gone with Mr. Crump to observe the levee outside the city limits on Third Street. He was quickly rehired. In the 1940s, Fowler had been responsible for the paving of Peabody Avenue, on which Crump lived. A huge crack developed into a pothole in front of Crump’s home. Crump was so upset that he would not approve Fowler’s appointments for seven years. -- Even after his retirement at age 75 in 1962, Fowler continued to work for the city as a consultant. He worked with the same secretary and used his former office, his same desk and drew the same salary of $434 a month as he had done before. -- The Official Papers of William B. Fowler include correspondence with city officials and other associates from 1927-1957, and miscellaneous items such as reports, papers and campaign brochures. The contents of this extensive collection also include materials related to the career of Margaret Fowler, such as meeting minutes from the Memphis Council of Parent-Teacher Associations, scrapbooks, photographs of Memphis City Beautiful Commission activities and yearbooks from the Commission and the Nineteenth Century Club.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: FreeWorld Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: David Skypeck and Richard Cushing were playing with The Midnight Syncopators every Wednesday night at Lafayette’s Corner in August of 1986, but by November the horn players had left the band. They played on even though members continued to leave the group. One night veteran jazz saxophonist Herman Green and trumpeter Nokie Taylor walked in off the street, pulled out their horns and started playing with the band in the middle of a set. -- This initial jam session led to a number of subsequent collaborations. In September 1987, Cushing and trumpeter Willy Waldman approached Green about forming a new band. They were joined by guitarist Clint Goodwin, Chuck Fields and sound technicians Dave Aron from Sun Studio and Vince Pratt, who occasionally played rhythm guitar. -- FreeWorld played its first gig at the South End restaurant in October 1987 and the band quickly became a local favorite. The initial set lists were made up of an eclectic mix of songs by other performers, but it was not long before the band members began writing original material. FreeWorld’s music blended jazz, soul, blues, funk and psychedelic rock, and improvisation was the key to the band’s identity, with each performance taking on a distinct personality depending on the current lineup. -- FreeWorld’s first self-titled CD, released in 1993, was a local hit and gave the band opportunities to perform frequently. Unfortunately, the group began to unravel as its frenzied touring pace wore on the members. The band had numerous personnel changes over the years but continued to gain exposure and popularity. The band embarked on two European tours in 1993 and released several successful CDs including You Are Here, Diversity and Live From Memphis. -- FreeWorld also collaborated with numerous guest artists and recording professionals including veteran sound technician Jim Gaines, who began his career at Stax, guitarist Calvin Newborn, John Fishman and Page McConnell of Phish, violinist Peter Hyrka, Bono from U2, Kenny Neil, The Radio Kings and Ivan Neville. In addition to enjoying commercial success, the members of FreeWorld were presented with numerous awards by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (NARAS). -- FreeWorld members also acted as movers and shakers behind the scenes in the music community, becoming involved in numerous side projects and promoting up-and-coming acts as well. Band members, most notably Richard Cushing, were active in local organizations such as NARAS and the Shelby County Music Commission. -- FreeWorld achieved wide-ranging commercial and critical success, but its reputation was largely built on its live shows that received a great deal of press coverage. Because of this, newspaper and journal articles reviewing works and updating fans on the group’s status provide an excellent source of material to outline the band’s history. Richard Cushing, the executive producer, lead vocalist, bassist, co-songwriter, musical director, band leader and business manager maintained a collection of items relating to the band since its founding. These materials were given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Cushing in 2005. -- The FreeWorld Collection is primarily made up of copies of press releases, sound recordings, video recordings, photographs, posters and miscellaneous documents outlining the development and history of the band. This chronologically arranged collection not only gives a history of FreeWorld, but also gives insight into the Memphis music scene from the late 1980s to the early 21st century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Future Memphis, Inc. Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Future Memphis, Inc., was founded and incorporated in February 1961, when a group of business leaders meeting over lunch decided that the city needed an organization to determine what efforts could be made in business, education, the arts, or in any other aspect of life in Memphis to move the city forward. The charter members were Walter P. Armstrong, Jr., R.H. Allen, Rose L. Bartlett, Hubert A. McBride and John J. Doggett, Jr. In June 1961, Future Memphis, Inc., announced the names of its directors and named Frederick F. Riley as the first executive director. -- At the first meeting of Future Memphis, Inc., the members adopted ten objectives for the organization. These objectives included providing a source of sound backing for worthy projects, obtaining the opinion of successful business leaders on problems of community interest, coordinating and supporting efforts of other organizations, providing a non-political avenue of approach for industrial developers, providing means for gathering data and supporting a broad economic study and long-term development plan. The group also sought to encourage the development of new industries, support the expansion of existing businesses, promote sports and cultural events, develop public relations and advertising for the city and maintain a non-partisan interest in honest and efficient government. -- Future Memphis, Inc., was instrumental in creating the proposal for the mayor-council government which began in 1968, vigorously supporting the routing of Interstate 40 through Overton Park in 1976, establishing the Airport Authority and founding the Memphis Community Foundation (now the Community Foundation of Greater Memphis). The organization also produced a comprehensive city-county consolidation study, provided partial funding for the feasibility study for the National Civil Rights Museum in 1985, developed the Memphis Crime Report in cooperation with The Commercial Appeal and Guardsmark in 1987 and established the Literacy Foundation. -- The organization “formed for the purpose of promoting the welfare and orderly future development of the city of Memphis, Tennessee, and its environs” worked quietly behind the scenes for 34 years before voting in June of 1995 to cease operation on July 31, 1995. New nonprofit groups had begun to support many of the causes that Future Memphis had contributed to over the years, and a more complex business environment in the city led to the loss of some top leaders. -- The Future Memphis, Inc., Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1995 by executive director Edward O. Williams on behalf of the members of the organization. The collection contains correspondence, contracts, memoranda, proposals and reports related to the civic activities of Future Memphis. The collection includes information on the Charter of Incorporation and City Development, crime, annexation, the consolidation of Memphis and Shelby County government, Memphis City Schools and the Center City Riverfront Plan. In addition to this collection, the Memphis and Shelby County Room also houses the papers of Frank Holloman, who served as executive director of Future Memphis from 1972-1980.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gayoso House and the Gayoso Hotel Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the mid-19th century, the Gayoso House was known up and down the Mississippi River for its elegance and hospitality. Nestled in a grove of trees above terraces and landscaped gardens, it had a view of the river for fifteen miles. From the inn’s own wharf, the rich and famous entered the hotel over a red carpet. -- Construction of Gayoso House, which was founded by Robertson Topp, Archibald Walker, and William L. Vance, began in 1842. Its chief designer, James Dakin, was one of the foremost architects of the day and the designer of the Gayoso’s greatest rival, the St. Charles Hotel in New Orleans. -- The hotel was named for Governor Manuel Luis Gayoso de Lemos, Spanish governor of the Natchez district, who was known for his hospitality and appreciation of beauty. The owners of the Gayoso attempted to carry on the traditions associated with Governor De Lemos. -- However, as years passed the famous landmark fell on hard times. By 1876, according to a quote from the June, 23, 1876, Commercial Appeal, it was “partly inhabited by a low class of people, and the stench that pervades the halls and rooms is perfectly horrible; indeed it is a pestilential breeding spot.” -- After a fire in 1879, there was apparently an effort to return the Gayoso House to its former glory. In 1885, as a part of this attempt, a grand piano was ordered for the price of $1,450. Despite these efforts, there was talk of demolishing the building before a second fire completely destroyed it in 1899. -- On the first anniversary of the fire which had destroyed its predecessor, ground was broken for the new Gayoso Hotel on the spot of the original hotel. When the hotel opened in 1904, it featured an elaborate grand piano bearing the Gayoso crest. The new Gayoso also featured a series of murals by Alonzo Wells which depicted the cross-country journey and death of Hernando de Soto. -- The Gayoso Hotel was sold to the Goldsmith family in 1948, and the building was gradually incorporated into Goldsmith’s Department Store. The Gayoso closed its doors on December 31, 1962, but the history of the Gayoso House and the Gayoso Hotel remains a part of the city’s heritage. -- The material in this collection comes from the Gayoso Hotel Scrapbook, which was compiled by Margaret Francis from memorabilia collected by hotel owners and managers. The material includes newspaper clippings, photographs, a menu, a key and hotel stationery.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: downtown; entertainment; fires; Goldsmith family; hotels; recreation; social life;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: E.W. Mason Church of God in Christ Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The E.W. Mason Church of God in Christ Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center in 2008 by Elsie Washington Mason’s niece, Mrs. Cenetta J. Lee. Consisting of church records, correspondence, photographs, a scrapbook and sermons, the collection chronicles the history of the nation’s largest African American Pentecostal denomination. In addition, the material also details the life and ministry of church founder Bishop C.H. Mason and his third wife Elsie Washington Mason. -- Born into slavery on a plantation near Memphis on September 8, 1862, Charles Harrison Mason founded Saint Paul Church in 1897 in Lexington, Mississippi. Ten years later, in 1907, Mason attended the Asuza Street Pentecostal revival in Los Angeles and was profoundly influenced by the experience. After five weeks in California, Mason relocated to Memphis where he incorporated the Church of God in Christ. Mason served as presiding bishop of the church until his death on November 17, 1961. By 1917, Mason’s denomination had spread to several cities including Chicago, Detroit and St. Louis. In the 1920s and 1930s, COGIC became one of the fastest growing churches in the world as it expanded into Africa and the Caribbean. COGIC continued to grow throughout the 20th and 21st centuries and by 2007 its worldwide membership stood at 6.5 million.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Papers of Memphis Mayor Walter Chandler
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Walter Chandler, who served as Mayor of Memphis during World War II, and then again briefly in 1955, was born in Jackson, Tennessee, in 1887. He moved to Memphis as a teenager and attended public schools. After earning a law degree from the University of Tennessee in 1909, he served as Assistant Attorney General of Shelby County and as a member of the Tennessee House of Representatives. Chandler served as a U.S. Army Captain during World War I, and participated in the Muese-Argonne Offensive and the Battle of San Mihiel. Following the war, Chandler served as a member of the Tennessee Senate and was appointed as the City Attorney for Memphis in 1928. While serving in this position, Chandler began his professional association with Edward Hull Crump, who dominated Memphis politics for decades. -- Chandler served three terms in Congress before being encouraged by Crump to run for mayor of Memphis in 1940. After serving as mayor for six years, Chandler entered private law practice. He served on the boards of the Cossitt Library and LeMoyne College, and served again briefly as Mayor from October to December of 1955 after the death of Frank Tobey. -- The Papers of Memphis Mayor Walter Chandler consist of materials from his professional life. The material is organized chronologically, and begins with newspaper clippings from the 1930s, including some articles written by Chandler. The papers include office files and photographs from his service as mayor during World War II. During the war, an army supply depot and Navy base were located in Memphis, and the city served as headquarters to the Second Army. The expanding role of the city during the war is addressed in these materials. -- Throughout his career as mayor, Chandler was associated with and influenced by E.H. Crump. Chandler’s papers include correspondence between these two leaders, which provides insight into the authority of Crump’s political machine in the city of Memphis. -- This collection does not include materials from Chandler’s brief service as Mayor of Memphis in 1955. Materials from this period of his service are included in the papers of Mayor Frank Tobey, which are also located in the Memphis and Shelby County Room.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Roberta Church Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sara Roberta Church, daughter of Sara Parody Johnson and Robert Reed Church, Jr., was born in Memphis into one of the nation’s most prominent African American families. Her grandfather, Robert Reed Church, Sr., was acknowledged as the South’s first African American millionaire and her father, Robert R. Church, Jr., had been the leading organizer of the Memphis Chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which received its charter in 1918. Roberta Church was educated at LeMoyne Normal School, an elementary and high school, which later became LeMoyne College. She continued her education at Northwestern University in Chicago, where she received Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees in social sciences. -- Proudly following in the footsteps of her distinguished family, Church was active in politics and worked for social justice. After her father’s sudden death in April 1952, she ran in his place for a position on the Republican State Executive Committee of Tennessee and was elected, making her the first African American woman to be elected to public office in Shelby County. Following the election in 1952 of Republican President Dwight D. Eisenhower, Church was appointed Minority Groups Consultant in the Department of Labor. She next served in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, overseeing various federal and state programs. -- Church served in other prominent national positions during her nearly 30 years of public service in Washington until her retirement and return to Memphis. After her retirement, Church continued her involvement in a wide range of activities and organizations including the Shelby County Historical Commission and the Phillis Wheatley Society. Church was especially interested in Elmwood Cemetery, where several Church family members are buried in the mausoleum. -- Perhaps the most significant undertaking of Church’s retirement years was her sustained effort to have Church Park restored as a memorial to her grandfather, Robert R. Church, Sr. When it was built at the turn of the 19th century, beautiful Church’s Park, was the setting of Church’s Auditorium, which was one of the largest in the South. Many prominent individuals appeared at the auditorium, including President Theodore Roosevelt and Booker T. Washington. However, the auditorium had become dilapidated and been torn down, and the park had fallen into disrepair. Roberta Church worked with other Memphians to have the park restored, and it was re-dedicated in 1987. -- Materials in the collection were given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Roberta Church over a period of several years and include personal and business correspondence, photographs, awards, newspaper clippings, greeting cards and memorabilia. Much of the collection relates to Church’s career in government service and her active role in the National Republican Party. Also included in the collection is extensive information on Roberta Church’s efforts to restore Church Park. Portions of the collection pertain to Church’s family members, including her aunt, Annette Church, sister of Robert R. Church, Jr., and Mary Church Terrell, older half-sister of Robert R. Church, Jr. -- The papers of the Church family, including those of Robert R. Church, Sr. and Jr., Annette Elaine Church and some papers belonging to Roberta Church were given by Roberta Church to the University of Memphis in 1976. Researchers may wish to visit the Mississippi Valley Collection at the University to view this extensive collection.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Beale Street; cemeteries; Church family; Church Park; civil rights; Elmwood Cemetery; government; NAACP; parks; politics; public service; Republican Party; women;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Circuit Playhouse Programs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Circuit Playhouse Programs Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center by several individuals over many years. The programs were then gathered together to create this collection. -- The Circuit Playhouse was formed in the summer of 1965 when Jackie Nichols and Walter Slaughter formed a troop of student actors to perform in churches and civic centers. The first production was A Life in New York by Anna Cora Monatt. Professor Ray Hill was the director. Various Broadway productions were presented during the next four summers. -- In 1969, the old Memphis Civic Ballet Academy closed and was available to rent. The decision was made to rent and to incorporate. The Fantasticks was the first official production on November 20, 1969. -- In 1971, the rented building was sold. A new home was found at 1947 Poplar across from Overton Park. Overton Square, Inc. invited Circuit, Inc. to move to the vacated Lafayette Music Room in 1975, but the offer was turned down. In 1981, the board of directors voted to purchase the Ritz-Guild-Evergreen movie house at 1705 Poplar as a new home for the theater. Circuit Playhouse remains at this location. -- Customers interested in the development of theater in Memphis may also wish to consult the Theatre Memphis Programs Collection, Playhouse on the Square Programs Collection, Memphis Open Air Theater Collection and the Ethel Taylor Maxwell Collection.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: arts; Circuit Playhouse; entertainment; music; theaters;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civil War Letters and Documents Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Civil War Letters and Documents Collection is a compilation of several small groups of papers acquired by the Memphis and Shelby County Room at different times and from various sources. The collection includes correspondence, business documents, government papers and other miscellaneous pieces. It also includes a personal diary, veterans’ reunion memorabilia, and an extensive collection of Harper’s Weekly prints. The varied material in the collection provides several distinct views of the Civil War period. -- The most significant group of papers is those pertaining to Dr. Robert Wood Mitchell, a prominent Memphis physician. These documents were donated by Willie Ayers, Dr. Mitchell’s great-nephew, and relate primarily to Dr. Mitchell’s military service as a surgeon during the Civil War. Included in these papers are two pre-war naval documents, a parole certificate, an amnesty oath, and a few post-war Confederate memorial postcards. A journal of surgical notes compiled by another Confederate medical officer, Dr. J.S. White, provides an additional view of a surgeon’s duties during the war. -- The collection also includes copies of four letters written by Dabney Minor Scales to his father related to his service in the Confederate Navy aboard the Flag Ship Savannah, the Steamer Arkansas, and the C.S.S. Shenandoah. The letters were donated by Scales’ daughter, Mrs. Yates Welford, and include detailed accounts of skirmishes at sea and a sketch of the Arkansas. -- A very important piece in this collection is the diary of Pickney Latham, a member of the Fourth Regiment of Tennessee Volunteers. The diary begins April 25, 1862, near Corinth, Mississippi, and ends on July 16 of the following year. There is also a hand-written letter to his sister, a photograph of Latham and a number of related newspaper articles. -- The collection also includes examples of Confederate bills used throughout the war, state and city notes dated prior-to and after the war and private issue notes from the years 1861 and 1862. Several documents in the collection seek to authenticate a battle-scarred tree trunk taken from the area of Brice’s Cross Roads, where General Nathan Bedford Forrest led his troops into battle. Pieces of the tree were to be sold in an effort to raise funds for a memorial monument to Forrest. Also included is a copy of a manuscript letter by General Forrest. A scrapbook of unknown provenance contains newspaper clippings, the majority of which date from the years 1860 to 1865. The compiler included articles that detail both pro-union and pro-secessionist arguments. Most of the articles appear to be from Memphis newspapers. Material on veterans’ reunions is comprised of pamphlets, programs, ribbons and medals. -- Finally, the collection contains an index of Harper’s Weekly Civil War prints that are included in the photograph and print collection of the Memphis and Shelby County Room. Harper’s Weekly, a leading 19th century periodical, was distributed nationwide, and its publication survived well into the 20th century. Harper’s Weekly relied heavily on images, and its weekly Civil War issues were eagerly sought around the country. Following the war, a compilation of selected issues was published as Harper’s History of the Great Rebellion, and several of the prints in the collection are from this publication. In addition, there are items from Leslie’s Illustrated Weekly and The London Illustrated News.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: boats; Civil War; Confederacy; Forrest, Nathan Bedford; Harper's Weekly; health; Latham, Pinckney; military; Mitchell, Robert Wood; navy; physicians; veterans;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Howard Association Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Roane Waring donated The Howard Association Collection to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1973. The collection consists of two important pieces relating to the history of yellow fever in Memphis. The first is the 1879 minute book of the Howard Association of which Roane Waring’s father, Thomas Roane Waring was secretary. The second piece is a large framed portrait of the members of the Howard Association in 1878. An inner circle on the portrait contains images of the ten members who gave their lives serving the sick and dying of the Memphis area. The collection is housed with A History of Yellow Fever in Memphis and several other small collections related to the devastating yellow fever epidemics in Memphis. -- The minutes, which are dated from August 10, 1879, through April 1880, address the workings of the Association, and reveal the impact that yellow fever had on the people of Memphis. The minute book covers business matters such as a change in the by-laws, investigation of various complaints, appeals for funds, instructions to Howard Association doctors and the ordering of supplies for the sick. -- The minutes include a motion that only yellow fever patients would be cared for, and in order to curtail expenses, supplies would be furnished only to yellow fever patients. The minutes from September 10 authorized $10 “for the burial expenses of Mrs. Maggie Bennett, late a nurse of this Assn.” The minutes of April 5, 1880, contain a great deal of history on the Howard Association’s work in the 1878 epidemic and the desire of the organization to publish reports on its work, “along with reports on the work of the Citizens Relief Committee and the other charitable and benevolent Assns of our City that were collaborators with us in that epidemic and such other information pertaining thereto as might be of interest to the public at large.”
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: benevolent associations; clubs; disease; epidemics; health; orphans; public service; yellow fever;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Robert Cohn Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Robert Cohn was born in Bremen, Germany, in 1874. He moved to Memphis at the age of 26 and began working in the cotton industry. He then shifted his focus to the operation of the Heart’s Delight Dairy and Poultry Farm at Forest Hill, which served as a source for practical experience for agricultural high school students in Memphis. Cohn also served briefly as business manager and treasurer of the A.B.C. Trailer Truck Company. Cohn was an impassioned patriot, frequently writing patriotic essays. He also used his talent for writing to support flood control measures and to call attention to the needs and struggles of farmers. He was instrumental in establishing a Red Cross Chapter in Memphis and is considered the father of the national “Plant-a-Garden” movement. In addition, he served as a Mason and Shriner and was a member of the City Club. -- The Robert Cohn Papers consist of essays, pamphlets, speeches, and newspaper clippings related to Cohn’s interest in farming, flood control, World War II and patriotic issues. Cohn sent the material to Toof Brown of S.C. Toof and Company so that a book could be compiled from the material after his death. The collection was found among the belongings of Mr. Brown after his death and was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mr. Lester Presson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Annie W. Conner Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Little is known about Anna (Annie) W. Conner; however, more can be ascertained about her ancestry. John O’Connor, the first of Annie’s ancestors to settle in America, migrated from Ireland in 1745 and settled in Culpeper County, Virginia, and several generations of Annie’s direct forbearers lived in northern Virginia. The O’Conners were active in land speculation and eventually owned land in several states, including property on what is now McLean Avenue in Memphis. Annie’s father, Charles Conner, married Eloise Colman of Brownsville, Tennessee, around 1853. He died near Brownsville in 1863, and Annie was his only surviving child. Eloise remarried L.C. Gillaspie (interchangeably spelled Gillespie), who became Annie’s guardian and the administrator of Charles Conner’s property in Tennessee. -- The Annie W. Conner Collection offers a glimpse into the lives of this family of land owners and speculators during the middle period of the 19th century. The collection, made up primarily of personal and business correspondence, provides insight into the economic and political concerns and problems of the South during the period. Much of the correspondence was written by Annie Conner’s uncle, William Conner, who wrote about his negative opinion of the Know-Nothing party, and his regard for the new Republican Party, the Whigs, and the Democrats – political views which were shared by many large landholders of the region. -- The Annie W. Conner Collection, which was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Jane Hosmer Teal Rogers, serves as a valuable resource for researchers of the South during the mid-1800s. The papers contain information about agriculture such as crop conditions and prices and the effects of weather on farming. The collection also includes letters in which family members discuss buying and selling slaves. The papers provide insight into the economy of the period through documents such as a will, a deed, and receipts for many items such as land, medical care, room and board, and gravestones. Charles Connor’s letter in which he writes to his mother to ask for approval to marry a young woman, and Eloise Conner’s letter in which she states her belief that a woman takes more risks than a man in marrying, give insight into social customs and beliefs of the period. The collection includes references to matters which greatly affected the lives of people in this time period, including disease (references are made to a cholera outbreak among a farmer’s group of hogs and yellow fever outbreaks in Memphis), death and religion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: agriculture; business; disease; economy; epidemics; family; home keeping; landowners; land speculation; political parties; politics; slavery; social life; weather; women; yellow fever;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Marie Connor Aviation History Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Donated to the Memphis Public Library in 1989 by Marie Connor, the collection contains a wide range of aviation news and memorabilia from the Memphis area. These include articles clipped from local newspapers about aviation events and history, flyers and advertisements put out by southern air companies, newsletters, press releases, speeches dealing with specific aviation events in the area, and index cards filled with Connor’s personal notes from research and interviews regarding local aviation history. The collection also contains a large album of pictures, ranging from close-ups of planes through the ages to the changing outerwear of stewardesses to famous local pilots such as the noted aviatrix Phoebe Omlie. The collection includes several miscellaneous items such as an early ticket clarifying one’s status as an aviation student and an invitation for an “aviation dance” from 1918 and printed on material from the wing of a plane. -- While composed mostly of secondary sources, this collection provides an abundance of information and history related to aviation in the general Memphis area. These include newspaper articles about the first flight in the city in 1910 and photos and memorabilia added from the World Runway Grand Opening at the Memphis Airport in 2000. Contemporary coverage of crucial events also provides significant historical insight into the development of aviation as a critical southern industry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ida Cooper Genealogical Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ida Cooper, daughter of Mary Magdalene Black and John Henry Pitts, was born in 1895. She married Howard Wilbur Cooper in 1920, and had two children, Virginia Joyce Cooper Appling and Howard Wilbur Cooper, Jr. -- Mrs. Cooper lived in Shelby County in the Arlington community and worked as an accountant at Ellendale Utility. Her particular interest was in the historical backgrounds and genealogies of old families – primarily in the Morning Sun, Ellendale, and Bartlett communities of Shelby County. She researched and recorded information on many family and church cemeteries, and this information has been alphabetized and listed in Gravestone Inscriptions From Shelby County Cemeteries, Volume III, which is available in the Memphis and Shelby County Room. -- The Ida Cooper Genealogical Collection, which was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by her daughter, Joyce Appling, consists of Mrs. Cooper’s correspondence and notes concerning family genealogy and community history. The extensive collection contains information about families, land, houses and burials gathered from her many visits with various families and a lifetime spent corresponding with other genealogists and saving records on family and community history. Ida Cooper died in 1982 in Heber Springs, Arkansas, and was buried at Morning Sun Presbyterian Church Cemetery. Her collection of papers, clippings and correspondence serves as an especially valuable resource for researchers interested in the history and genealogy of Shelby County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: E.H. Crump Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Edward Hull Crump was born near Holly Springs, Mississippi, in 1874. He was raised by his mother, Mollie Nelms Crump, after his father, a cotton planter and former Confederate officer, died during the yellow fever epidemic of 1878. When he was 19 years old, Crump moved to Memphis determined to succeed in business. After struggling to find work, Crump was hired as the bookkeeper for a carriage making company. He went on to found the E.H. Crump Company, a large and successful insurance firm. In 1902 he married Bessie Byrd McLean, and they had three sons: Edward, Jr., Robert and John. -- Crump first pursued his political ambitions when he sought the position of director of the Memphis Business Men’s Club in 1904. In 1905 he ran for a seat on the board of public works supervisors, the lower body of the bicameral legislative council. Voters elected Crump by an overwhelming majority, beginning one of the most celebrated and controversial political careers in 20th century America. -- In September 1907 Crump resigned his seat on the board of public works supervisors to successfully run for the board of fire and police commissioners, which was the upper body of the legislative council. Crump then went on to run a successful campaign for mayor in 1909. During his five year term as mayor, he enacted many progressive reforms, including the creation of a juvenile court, improvement of public health services and the regulation of utilities. -- Crump’s greatest political handicap was his refusal to fully enforce prohibition. Tennessee outlawed the sale of liquor in 1909 and anger over the mayor’s anti-prohibition policy contributed to his ouster from the mayor’s office in 1915. However, this did not weaken his political ambitions. Six months after his ouster Crump was elected county trustee, and from that position he continued to gain political power. -- In 1930 Crump was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives where he served through 1934. Crump was a strong supporter of President Franklin Roosevelt’s New Deal and voted for every piece of New Deal legislation during the president’s first hundred days in office. Roosevelt’s gratitude for Crump’s support benefited the citizens of Shelby County greatly. By the end of the 1930s, over $15 million was spent locally by the federal government on welfare and relief and an additional $6.4 million was spent on construction. Crump was again elected mayor of Memphis in 1939 but served only a few minutes. He resigned in favor of Congressman Walter Chandler immediately after taking the oath of office. Crump ran in Chandler’s place so the congressman could remain in Washington to vote for President Roosevelt’s neutrality legislation. -- Late in his career, Crump abandoned the Democratic Party and aligned himself with the States Rights Party, which caused him to lose political clout. Crump experienced one of his greatest defeats when voters elected anti-Crump Democrats Estes Kefauver for the U.S. Senate and Gordon Browning for governor in 1948. However, Crump remained a powerful political force in Tennessee until his death in 1954. -- The E.H. Crump Collection contains correspondence, government reports, campaign advertisements and other material from the years 1910 to 1954. The papers include information on prohibition, Crump’s ouster from the mayor’s office, and several card file indexes which list city employees by ward. The papers contain lists of people who received gifts from Crump and numerous photographs of Crump, his family and associates. Also included are magazine and newspaper articles from publications such as Colliers, The Saturday Evening Post and Time magazine which document the evolution of Crump’s national image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Captain Rees Vernon Downs Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Captain Rees Vernon Downs Papers were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Captain Downs’ sister, Bess Jenkins. The primary emphasis of the collection is river steamboats. The collection contains scrapbooks devoted to stern and side-wheeler boats which were compiled by an individual named F.L. Wooldridge. The collection also contains a manuscript list of steamboats compiled by the “River Historian” Wooldridge, which lists the name of the steamboat, the number of cylinders, boiler size, physical dimensions, line and fate. The remainder of the collection is comprised of Captain Downs’ personal mementos. -- Captain Rees Vernon Downs was a born and bred river man. He was born in 1878 in Pine Bluff, Arkansas, and spent his early years on the Arkansas River. After studying mechanical and electrical engineering at the University of Arkansas for two years, he began working on steamboats. He began as a cub on the Eugene, a Memphis and Little Rock packet, and was eventually granted his first government license to pilot the Arkansas River in 1900. He went on to hold pilot and master certification on portions of the Mississippi, Missouri, Illinois, Arkansas and Ohio Rivers. He was a master of the Wolf River from its mouth at the foot of Beale Street to the North Second Street Bridge in Memphis. He served as a pilot and captain of several river boats, including the Lucille Now land, the Georgia Lee, the Fred Harold and the Kate Adams. In 1912 he was appointed a U.S. steamboat inspector in St. Louis, and he became the first superintendent of the Federal Barge Line out of St. Louis in 1918. Captain Downs retired in the 1930s, but renewed his license in 1942 and was prepared to assist in any war efforts. -- Captain Downs lived in Memphis from 1920 until his death in 1955. He served as a charter member of the Propeller Club and was active in the Engineers Club, Pilot Club and the Memphis Area Chamber of Commerce. He was a member of the Vestry of St. James Episcopal Church in Memphis and served as Director of the church’s University of Practical Living. He is buried in Pine Bluff, Arkansas.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Art Association Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memphis Art Association was organized in 1914 by Florence McIntyre, a local artist and supporter of art education in Memphis, and members of the Nineteenth Century Club, a local women’s club dedicated to community-wide philanthropic activities. The association was established to promote the serious study of art and encourage interest in the fine arts. During its initial years of operation, the association hosted exhibitions and lectures and met at the homes of various members. -- Rosa Lee, an art patron and a good friend of Florence McIntyre’s, encouraged the Memphis Art Association to form a school to provide art education through free classes. The association opened the James Lee Memorial Academy of Arts in 1925 in Rosa Lee’s home at 690 Adams Avenue, with McIntyre serving as the director. -- The James Lee Academy offered courses for credit, teacher training and children’s classes. The school was supported by dues and donations, and the classes were free to the public. Courses offered included drawing, painting, design, theater arts, pottery, jewelry making and commercial art. -- Florence McIntyre continued to head the James Lee Academy until 1936 when a split occurred between the staff of the academy and the board of directors of the Memphis Art Association. The disagreement resulted in the formation of the Memphis Academy of Arts, which changed its name to Memphis College of Art in 1985, while the James Lee Academy continued to offer free classes. The James Lee Academy changed its name to the Free Art School of the Memphis Art Association in 1942 and ran until shortly after McIntyre’s death in 1963. -- Business and financial records, correspondence, photographs, lectures, essays and newspaper clippings make up The Memphis Art Association Collection. The bulk of the materials date from 1916 to 1962. The collection documents the activities of the Memphis Art Association, the James Lee Memorial Academy of Art and the Free Art School. The collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 2003 by Victoria Hyrka Wilson, a student at the Memphis Art Association’s Free Art School.
