oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Belle Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In September 1942 a new B-17 Flying Fortress was delivered to Bangor, Maine, to a crew of ten men led by Captain Robert Morgan. The airplane was named the Memphis Belle in honor of Margaret Polk, Captain Morgan’s fiancée in Memphis. -- The Belle and her crew were sent to England to join the 91st Bombardment Group of the United States Eighth Air Force. Their first mission was to bomb the locks at Brest, France on November 7, 1942. After completing twenty-five missions, the Belle and her crew were sent back home for a “twenty-sixth mission,” which was a bond-selling tour throughout the United States. -- The Belle was the first B-17 bomber to successfully complete twenty-five missions and also the first bomber to return all of her crewmen home. During the missions the crew dropped sixty tons of bombs in France, Germany and Belgium; shot down eight enemy fighters (and probably five others); damaged a dozen more; and flew approximately 20,000 combat miles. The crew was decorated fifty-one times, with each member receiving the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Medal and three Oak Leaf Clusters. Sergeant John Quinlan also received the Purple Heart for a minor injury he sustained in battle. -- Mayor Walter Chandler of Memphis obtained the Memphis Belle for the city on July 16, 1946 from an aircraft scrap yard in Altus, Oklahoma. The purchase price was $350. With time, interest in the plane waned; and in 1950 it was given to the American Legion. It was taken to the Legion hut on the grounds of the National Guard Armory, where it remained for several years. In 1977 it was removed to the new Air National Guard facilities at the Memphis International Airport, where it was partially refurbished by Memphis Area Vocational Technical Aviation School students. Later in 1977 it was relinquished to the Air Force, who loaned it to The Memphis Belle Memorial Association, a non-profit organization. The Belle was then housed for several years in a pavilion on Mud Island. In 2003 the Belle was relocated to the Millington Airport. A new museum to house the plane is planned for the area around Forest Hill-Irene Road and Bill Morris Parkway. -- The Memphis Belle collection was compiled from a number of sources. While some of the donors are unknown, Mr. Frank Donofrio contributed many significant items to the original contents. The collection includes maintenance records for 1942 and 1943 and correspondence which primarily addresses the city obtaining the plane or securing shelter for it. Newspaper articles included in the collection address the condition of the plane or the attempts to find a permanent facility to house the aircraft. Film reviews and post cards are also included in the collection. A large poster of the Belle is housed with other posters in the Memphians During War Collection in the Memphis and Shelby County Room.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: airplanes; B-17; military; war bonds; World War II;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Civic Clubs - Jackson Boulevard and Rozelle Clubs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: During the period between the world wars, civic or improvement clubs flourished as a way to provide service and entertainment to neighborhood residents. At one time there were twenty-five clubs in Memphis which were loosely connected through their association with the Council of Civic Clubs. These clubs were instrumental in persuading the city to improve and extend streets, provide better streetcar service, build schools and parks, and maintain healthful sanitary conditions. There were few matters of local public interest which were not affected by the efforts of civic clubs. During the depression the clubs provided neighborhood relief, and their meetings frequently included entertainment programs which served as a forum for local talent. -- This collection contains minutes, correspondence and other papers from two of these clubs – the Rozelle Civic Club and the Jackson Boulevard Improvement (later Civic) Club. The collection was compiled from two separate gifts to the library. Materials from the Rozelle Club were donated in 1980 by Stoy Bailey and the Rozelle/Annesdale Neighborhood Association. Marion T. Gatti contributed most of the materials from the Jackson Boulevard Club in 1980 and added additional papers in 1987. These materials provide insight into community relationships and the concerns of the clubs and present an important vignette of Memphis history.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Crippled Children's Hospital and School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the days before antibiotics, vaccinations, and public awareness of disease-related birth defects, many children in the Mid-South suffered from severely crippling illnesses such as poliomyelitis, tuberculosis of the spine and osteomyelitis as well as congenital defects such as clubbed feet and other deformities. -- In 1916, Dr. Willis C. Campbell, a nationally recognized orthopedic surgeon, approached the Good Deeds Circle of the Kings Daughters about undertaking the organization and management of a hospital to serve the needs of crippled children from Memphis and the Mid-South. Throughout its sixty-three year existence, the Memphis Crippled Children’s Hospital and School cared for many hundreds of children without any cost to their families. -- Contained in this collection are annual reports, correspondence, newspaper clippings, photographs and a brief history of the yearly operation of the institution. The materials provide valuable information on the most active years of the Memphis Crippled Children’s Hospital and School. These documents were a gift from Ellen D. Sugg of West Point, Mississippi.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: birth defects; children; clubs; disease; education; health; hospitals; schools;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reverend Charles Carroll Parsons Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles Carroll Parsons, Rector of St. Lazarus-Grace Episcopal Church, died September 6, 1878 while serving the people of Memphis during the terrible days of the 1878 yellow fever epidemic. Although he had served the congregation less than three years, he was respected and admired by the church members and the community at large. Parson’s popularity was especially significant because he had served as a commissioned officer in the Union Army during the Civil War, and his congregation was made up of a large number of former Confederate officers and leaders, including Jefferson Davis. -- Parsons was born in 1838 in Elyria Ohio. He was raised in a prominent Ohio family and received an appointment to the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1854. Upon graduation, Parsons and his Northern classmates were immediately assigned to various Union military units. -- Among the battles in which Parsons played an active part were the battles at Shiloh, Corinth, Stones River, Perryville and Richmond, Kentucky. He received numerous commendations and promotions on the field. While on leave of absence following a serious illness in 1862, he married Celia W.G. Lippett of Brooklyn, New York. -- Following the Civil War, Lieutenant Colonel Parsons served at several forts in Indian Territory. He then returned to the Academy at West Point, where he served as an Assistant Professor for two years. In 1868, Parsons met Charles Todd Quintard, second Episcopal Bishop of Tennessee. The two men formed a close friendship, which inspired Parsons to study faith and religion. In 1870 Parsons resigned his military commission to become a priest in the Episcopal Church. He was ordained at St. Mary’s Cathedral in Memphis by his friend and mentor, Bishop Quintard. -- Parsons served at St. Mary’s of the Highlands in Cold Springs, New York and the Church of the Holy Innocents in Hoboken, New Jersey. While in Hoboken, his young wife, Celia died. Brokenhearted, Parsons moved to Memphis, where he became Rector of St. Lazarus-Grace in 1876. In 1877, Parsons married Margaret Britton, niece of George Harris, the Dean of St. Mary’s Cathedral. At the beginning of the yellow fever epidemic, Parsons sent Margaret and two of Celia’s sons to Margaret’s family plantation, Annandale to escape the effects of the disease. After succumbing to yellow fever, Reverend Parsons was buried in Elmwood Cemetery next to Louis Sanford Schuyler, a priest who also died of yellow fever while serving the people of Memphis. -- The Reverend Charles Carroll Parsons Collection is stored in the Memphis and Shelby County Room with A History of Yellow Fever in Memphis and several other small collections related to the yellow fever epidemics in Memphis. The papers include Parson’s obituary, letters and information on Parson’s military career.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil War; clergy; health; military; public service; religion; yellow fever;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Citizens to Preserve Overton Park Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A small group of people organized as Citizens to Preserve Overton Park with the goal of preventing Interstate 40 from intersecting Overton Park. CPOP, as the organization became known, successfully stopped the construction of an east-west segment of the interstate. It was a decades-long fight involving local, state and federal governments and eventually the Supreme Court of the United States. -- CPOP’s biggest weapon in its fight to prevent I-40 from going through Overton Park was literally its smallest—Anona Stoner, Memphis newcomer and CPOP secretary. Mrs. Stoner saved most of the first collection of materials that the Board of CPOP donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center, including a complete file of CPOP’s minutes, treasurer’s reports, finances and correspondence. President Arlo I. Smith’s materials also came with the first donation, but several other people also had collections they eventually contributed to the library, including: Sara Naill Hines, Treasurer; Mary Evelyn Deupree, for herself and husband, Vice President William Deupree; Sunshine Snyder, member and plaintiff; Irma O. Sternberg, member and author; Franklin Wright, Professor of History at Rhodes College; Agnes Bowe, President of Mid-Memphis Improvement Association; and Waldo Zimmermann, author and frequent letter-to-the-editor writer. Covering the 1950s to the 1990s, the bulk of the items are from the 60s and 70s. -- CPOP spent many years trying to prevent Interstate 40 from going through Overton Park and the extensive correspondence is evidence of both their failures and final success. Often a lonely voice of opposition, the Citizens to Preserve Overton Park refused to accept the seemingly inevitable progress of the United States Interstate System or at least the 7.6 mile segment that intersected Overton Park. CPOP struggled against the combined forces of the US Department of Transportation, the Federal Highway Administration, Tennessee's United States Senators and Congressmen, several Tennessee Governors, the Tennessee Highway Department, the Memphis City Council, Memphis Chamber of Commerce, Downtown Business Association, The Memphis Commercial Appeal, The Memphis Press-Scimitar and many other opposition interests. And yet, after decades of skirmishes and battles, Overton Park is still intact.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Citizens to Preserve Overton Park; environment; government; I-40; law; Memphis Zoo; midtown; Overton Park; parks; Supreme Court; transportation;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: T.H. Hayes Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thomas Henry Hayes, Jr., was born in Covington, Tennessee in 1902. His father, Thomas H. Hayes, Sr., founded T.H. Hayes Funeral Home, which was the oldest African American-owned business in Memphis when his son joined as funeral director in 1928. In 1933, T.H. Hayes, Jr., co-founded the Union Protective Life Insurance Company where he served in various executive positions until it was acquired by Universal Life Insurance Company in 1980. -- Hayes was appointed to the Memphis Transit Authority in 1964. He served as Vice President from 1966 until his resignation in 1970, and during his tenure was instrumental in the hiring of many of the city’s first African American bus drivers. Hayes assisted in the organization of such African American-owned businesses as the Memphis Mortgage Company and the Mutual Federal Savings and Loan Association. He also served for many years as a trustee of Metropolitan Baptist Church where he was a member for more than 50 years. -- Hayes is perhaps best known for being the owner of the Birmingham Black Barons baseball team of the Negro American Baseball League from 1939 to 1951. During these years Hayes and his managers recruited and developed numerous internationally known baseball stars including Willie Mays and LeRoy “Satchel” Paige. Mays, who was recruited by Hayes as a student at Fairfield High School in a suburb of Birmingham, played for the Black Barons for a year and a half before being discovered by talent scouts. -- The popularity of Negro baseball reached its height during the years of Hayes’ involvement, and his importance in the sport cannot be overstated. An article in the collection states that Hayes’ contributions to opening baseball to African Americans are more significant than those of Jackie Robinson. -- Thomas Hayes, Jr., had an impact on the lives of many until his death in 1982. He served as an example of a man who did not let the prejudice of others keep him from being a success as a businessman or from making a positive contribution to the city. -- The T. H. Hayes Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by his wife, Helen M. Hayes. The collection consists of correspondence, magazines, photographs, contracts and other memorabilia relating to Hayes’ ownership of the Birmingham Black Barons baseball team. The papers include articles about Hayes and Negro baseball in general, and two scrapbooks of newspaper articles about the Black Barons. Photographs and information from this collection have been used extensively in the preparation of books and visual presentations about Negro League baseball.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; baseball; Birmingham Black Barons; business; death; entertainment; funeral homes; public service; recreation; sports;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hunter Lane, Jr. Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Hunter Lane, Jr. Papers were donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center in the 1970s by the City of Memphis. Comprising 1 linear foot, the Lane papers cover the years 1964-1967. The papers include correspondence and reports related to Lane’s career as Commissioner of Public Service. The original order of the files was maintained in the processing of this collection. -- The Hunter Lane, Jr. Papers contain detailed information on the activities of municipal government in the American South during the 1960s. The collection includes material on the Memphis Housing Authority, the Memphis and Shelby County Planning Commission, the Memphis and Shelby County Port Commission and the controversial decision to route Interstate 40 through Overton Park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: George W. Lee Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The George W. Lee Collection was given to the library by his daughter Gilda Lee Robinson in 1985. The large collection includes extensive and wide-ranging correspondence, copies of many of Lee’s speeches, hundreds of newspaper and magazine clippings, and many awards and certificates presented to Lee over the years. An important part of this collection is the array of more than 400 photographs and the five large scrapbooks which contain photographs, clippings and letters. In addition, there is one box of magazines and one box of personal Christmas cards. -- Lee was born near Indianola, Mississippi in 1894 to Reverend George Lee and Hattie Stringfellow Lee. He first came to Memphis in 1912 where he worked each summer as a bellhop at the Gayoso Hotel to finance his education at Alcorn A&M College. -- With the onset of World War I, Lee was accepted for admission to a segregated officer training school. Through hard work and determination to succeed, Lee received his commission as a Second Lieutenant in the United States Army. Decorated for bravery in battle, he was promoted to First Lieutenant. This was a proud achievement for Lee, and the title “Lt. Lee” remained with him for the rest of his life. -- Following the war, Lee established himself in the growing African American insurance business, first as a salesman for Mississippi Life Insurance Company, and then later with Atlanta Life Insurance Company, where he became a vice president in 1964 and later served as director of public relations. Lt. Lee went on to become one of the most successful African American business and political leaders in the South. He utilized his talents as an articulate speaker and a polished writer in his long local and national political career. -- Politically, Lee’s first important work was in the Lincoln League, an African American Republican organization set up in 1916 by Robert R. Church. By 1919, this group was chartered as the Lincoln League of American, and it was largely through political activism in the League that Lee attained national recognition. Although the Republican Party in Memphis won few elections until the Eisenhower years, Lee, as the local GOP leader, exerted considerable influence through his alignment with East Tennessee Republicans. -- The fraternal order of Elks, where Lee had achieved prominence, provided a national platform for his oratorical and organizational abilities. In later years, Lee worked through the Elks organization to call attention to civil rights struggles. As Elks Grand Commissioner of Education, he emphasized black pride through education and the expansion of African American businesses. -- Lee acquired the nickname “Boswell of Beale Street” through his gift of describing African American life and music in his books and stories. Beale Street: Where Blues Began received national acclaim and was a Book-of-the-Month Club selection. River George and Beale Street Sundown also portray African American life in the South. Lee’s admiration for W.C. Handy’s music and his recognition of its significance in American culture led him to support the creation of a park and statue in honor of the great blues writer. -- Lee was the recipient of numerous honors and awards during his lifetime. Among them was the naming of the George W. Lee postal station at 826 Mississippi, the first to be named for an African American. In 1973, his portrait was placed in the State Capitol at Nashville and that year he also received the R.Q. Venson Memorial Award presented by American Legion Post No. 27 in honor of his service to his country and community. Lee remained an active member of the Memphis community until his death on August 1, 1976.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: activism; African Americans; authors; Beale Street; business; civil rights; desegregation; education; Elks; insurance; military; politics; post office; public service; public speaking; race; Republican Party; writers;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Col. Joseph A. LePrince U. S. Public Health Officer Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Joseph A. LePrince Collection provides significant information on LePrince’s life and work in public health and includes a wide range of materials pertaining to worldwide efforts to conquer insect-vectored diseases, especially mosquito borne yellow fever, malaria and the less well-known dengue fever. -- Papers in Box 1 are biographical and describe LePrince’s career in the field of sanitary engineering, his work and research with outstanding men in public health such as Colonel William Crawford Gorgas and Dr. Walter Reed, and his continued efforts to educate the public regarding the control of insect vectored disease. Documents in Box II feature information about malaria research, while Box III includes copies of publications that present the history and study of malaria and related diseases. Box IV contains published materials on malaria control and provides wide ranging information for those researching public health and sanitation in the control and elimination of insect-borne disease. -- The total collection provides a large amount of scientific material on mosquito disease and control, as well as popular material designed for students and the general public. While yellow fever and malaria are no longer prevalent in the United States, any researcher studying the history and scientific nature of these diseases will find that the LePrince Collection provides a wealth of information.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jerry Lee Lewis Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jerry Lee Lewis was born to Elmo and Mary Ethel Lewis in Ferriday, Louisiana in 1935. Lewis sang and learned to play the piano in the local Assembly of God church, while also listening to Country music on the radio and Blues music in the African American neighborhoods of Ferriday. At the age of fifteen Lewis began to play piano professionally, beginning a career that would last well into the 21st century. -- Lewis played in small clubs around Ferriday, and in Natchez and Nashville, but musical success eluded him. In 1956, after noting the success of Elvis Presley, Lewis and his father sold thirteen dozen eggs to finance a trip to Memphis, where they hoped for him to audition for Sam Phillip’s Sun Records. Lewis began recording for Sun in November of that year and in 1957 he released Whole Lotta Shakin’ Goin On, and Great Balls of Fire. Both cuts were top five hits on both the Pop and Country charts that year, which lead to an appearance on the Steve Allen television program in July. The success of Lewis’ recordings and stage act made him one of the most popular performers during the early days of Rock and Roll. -- As musical tastes changed in the 1960s, Lewis abandoned Rock and Roll to focus on Country music. Between 1968 and 1973, Lewis recorded several hit Country songs and appeared on the Grand Ole Opry. Lewis was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1986, and in 1989, MGM released a biographical film, Great Balls of Fire!, starring Dennis Quaid. Continuing to perform through the beginning of the 21st century, Lewis is widely recognized as one of the founders of Rock and Roll. -- The Jerry Lee Lewis Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Jud and Rose McAfee Phillips in 2002. The collection consists of business records, correspondence, legal documents, magazine and newspaper clippings, photographs and recordings related to Lewis’ life and musical career. The bulk of the material relates to Lewis’ Country music career in the 1970s and his role as an elder statesman of Rock and Roll during the 1980s and 1990s. The collection contains numerous clippings on the 1985 Sun Records reunion recording session with Johnny Cash, Carl Perkins, and Roy Orbison, which produced the album Class of ’55. The collection also includes clippings related to the filming of Lewis’ movie biography Great Balls of Fire! and some information on Lewis’ family life and financial aspects of his career.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Selma S. Lewis Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Selma S. Lewis Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by her daughter, Jane Lewis Ross in April 2000. The collection, which includes a wide range of newspaper clippings, correspondence, photographs and publications, provides significant information pertaining to the history and life of the Jewish and African American communities of Memphis. The greater portion of the collection is composed of local Jewish history and biographies. Also included are manuscript copies of Lewis’ books, The Angel of Beale Street: A Biography of Julia Ann Hooks, A Biblical People in the Bible Belt: The Jewish Community of Memphis, Tennessee, 1840s-1960s and her dissertation “Social Religion and the Sanitation Strike.” Also of importance are the transcripts of oral interviews with members of the African American community, which were conducted by Selma Lewis and Marjean Kremer in 1978 as part of the research for the Pink Palace Museum exhibit “Historic Black Memphians.” These transcripts were given to the Library by Mrs. Lewis during her lifetime. -- Selma Seligman Lewis grew up in Nashville and earned a bachelor’s degree from Vanderbilt University. In 1942, Selma and her husband, civic volunteer and businessman, James Marshall Lewis, moved to Memphis, where they reared three children. Lewis went on to earn a Master’s and PhD. in American History from the University of Memphis. -- After years of working to raise public awareness of social issues, Lewis became the first female president of Jewish Family Services in 1962. She served as a Vista volunteer for the Metropolitan Inter-Faith Association (MIFA) and a coordinator of the Memphis Coalition for the Homeless in 1972. Mrs. Lewis also worked with Myra Dreifus and others in Memphis to organize the Fund for Needy School Children, which she chaired from 1972-1974. This program helped to provide free or reduced cost lunches for many area school children. -- Mrs. Lewis served on the board of numerous organizations, including the Memphis College of Art, the Memphis Literacy Council, the Mental Health Society of Memphis and Shelby County, Theatre Memphis, and Facing History and Ourselves. She was president of the Jewish Historical Society of Memphis and the Mid-South and in 1993, she received the Women of Achievement Steadfastness Award. -- Selma Lewis died in an automobile accident in March 2000. She was mourned by family and her many friends who described her as a courageous woman who made the city a better place.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Adele Litty Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Adele Litty was one of two daughters born to Harry H. Litty and his wife, Elizabeth Clarke Litty. Harry H. Litty served as the mayor of Memphis from 1917 to 1918. Adele was unmarried and rather shy, compared to her sister, Marion. Jimmy Blakely, a family friend, told The Commercial Appeal in an article after Adele’s death that Marion “was a socialite who could dance and all of that, but Adele never did as far as I know.” Adele lived in the family home on South Willett Street until her death on June 2, 1998. She bequeathed $9.5 million to the King’s Daughters and Sons Nursing Home, formerly known as the Home for Incurables, located at 1467 E. McLemore. A portion of the money Adele donated went towards the construction of a new home at 3568 Appling Road in Bartlett, TN. -- Michael Hartsfield, Adele’s attorney, donated this collection to the Memphis Public Library in 2006. The collection includes large amounts of correspondence from Adele’s male friends to her, mostly dating from the mid-1920s to the early 1930s. Besides this, it also includes documents relating to her father’s term as mayor as well as important family documents such as marriage certificates, deeds, letters, invitations, poetry likely written by her father, and even Mr. Litty’s Last Will and Testament. -- Also included in the collection is a large amount of Litty family photographs split into two albums. Many of the photographs were unable to be identified, but some of them were either already labeled or labels were added based on the envelopes they were found in or on connections made by looking at other photographs. This collection provides valuable information on a prominent Memphis family and one of its daughters, her lifestyle, and the climate of the era she lived in.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Harry H. Litty Family Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Harry H. Litty was born in 1862 in Toledo, Ohio. After attending North Kentucky College, he began his business career with the Toledo, Cincinnati, and St. Louis Railroad. His work with the railroad brought him to Memphis, where he was an engineer with the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. Litty also worked with the Rogers and Ballentine Company, a major railroad construction company, which built rail lines throughout the South. -- While Litty worked for Rogers and Ballentine, the company was awarded the contract to build the Great Bridge at Memphis (later known as the Frisco Bridge). Construction began in 1888 and the bridge opened with a great public celebration on May 12, 1892, when some 50,000 people gathered on the river bluffs to watch a string of 19 locomotives cross the bridge. As a former railroad engineer, Litty had the honor of driving the first train across the bridge. -- Litty next began to study law under Colonel G.A.C. Holt, and in 1890, he was admitted to the bar. As a result of his legal training, Litty received an appointment to serve as a collector for the Internal Revenue Service during the Cleveland administration. He also served as a member of the City Board of Public Works from 1896-1900 and was selected to head the City Club of Memphis, which was founded in 1908. From 1917 to 1918, he served a term as mayor of Memphis (mayoral terms were two years at that time). Many of Litty’s activities as mayor were directed toward supporting America’s efforts to win World War I. -- In 1922 Litty donated land for a park in the Glenview neighborhood. The neighborhood honored Litty by naming the park after him, and each August the people of Glenview celebrated “Litty Day” in his honor. One of Litty’s favorite pastimes was to walk through the park and watch children play. -- Litty pursued a wide range of interests, including fishing and big game hunting. He also had a large collection of books and especially enjoyed poetry. He combined his enthusiasm for the outdoors and his love of poetry in a humorous poem entitled “Hatchie Coon,” the name of his fishing club in Arkansas. -- The Harry H. Litty Family Collection was given to the library in 1997 by Michael Hartsfield, attorney for Harry Litty’s daughter, Adele Litty, who died in 1998. The collection includes three scrapbooks, two of which contain information about World War I. The third scrapbook has clippings which focus on Harry Litty’s activities while mayor of Memphis. Also in the collection are various newspaper articles and a large number of family photographs, as well as material on the Glenview neighborhood and the creation of Litty Park. -- Much of the material in the collection relates to World War I, and the names of Memphians who were killed in combat have been excerpted from the scrapbooks and placed in an alphabetical listing in the finding aid to the collection. The scrapbooks also include a number of newspaper photographs and biographical profiles of men in the military, and the names of those who were profiled have also been put in an alphabetical list.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Papers of Henry Loeb, III
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henry Loeb, III was born into a wealthy and prominent family in Memphis in 1920. After graduating from Brown University and serving as a Naval lieutenant World War II, he returned to civilian life in Memphis. As Secretary of Loeb’s Laundry-Cleaners, he became prominent within the business community, and in 1950 he was appointed to the prestigious Park Commission. -- Initially, Loeb had the support of E.H. Crump and his colleagues, who had dominated politics in Memphis for nearly a half century. However, he became an enemy of the Crump machine through his criticism of Park Commission expenditures and his defeat in 1952 of a Crump-backed candidate for a post in the American Legion. Crump died in 1954, leaving a political vacuum. Loeb ran successfully for a seat on the City Commission in 1955 and was on his way to becoming the most influential political figure in West Tennessee in the post-Crump era. -- When health problems forced incumbent Edmund Orgill out of the 1959 race, Loeb easily defeated the other candidates and was elected mayor. During his term, the city public facilities were desegregated peacefully, before federal legislation mandated such changes. Despite Loeb having worked with the city’s bi-racial committee to implement integration, he became increasingly viewed as a segregationist. -- In October 1963 Loeb ended his campaign for re-election and resigned as mayor. The death of the president of his family’s laundry business left the enterprise without a leader and Henry felt obliged to take over. He became president of the company in 1964, yet disagreements with family members led him to sell his interest in the company in 1967 and begin planning his re-entry into politics. Loeb defeated the incumbent Mayor Ingram in 1967 in a campaign which had strong racial overtones and established a highly-charged, racially-polarized climate in Memphis for the next four years. -- Loeb’s second term as mayor was among the most significant periods in Memphis history. Municipal employees in Memphis unionized as the nationwide struggle for African American civil rights gained momentum. Martin Luther King, Jr., came to Memphis to support sanitation workers who were on strike, and was assassinated on April 4, 1968. The sanitation workers’ strike was settled soon after Dr. King’s tragic death, however, the city remained divided, and Loeb’s effectiveness and political strength were weakened. -- Near the end of his second term, Loeb decided not to seek re-election. At the urging of his wife he left office, but he virtually named his successor and remained active in public affairs for several years. He taught briefly at Christian Brothers College and seriously considered running for Governor of Tennessee before moving to Forrest City, Arkansas to run a farm and agricultural equipment business. -- Loeb’s papers include a very large number of letters related to his political career, his personal life and the Loeb family business. The correspondence from his terms in city government shows the workings of its various divisions and departments, his influence over policy, and his fantastic attention to detail. The papers also indicate Loeb’s high level of involvement in regional, state and national affairs. The letters reflect the significant social change which took place during Loeb’s years of public service, and address numerous issues such as housing and renewal projects, school desegregation, labor relations, annexation and the city budget. The collection also includes scrapbooks maintained by Loeb which contain primarily newspaper clippings. The articles cover local, state and national issues and events which shaped the city of Memphis.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reverend Louis Sandford Schuyler Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Louis Sandford Schuyler, son of the Reverend Montgomery Schuyler and Lydia E. Schuyler, was born in Buffalo, New York in 1852. A serious, scholarly young man, he followed his father into the Episcopal priesthood. He served at a number of churches in New York before he was assigned to the Church of the Holy Innocents in Hoboken, New Jersey. The Reverend Charles Carroll Parsons, who went on to become Rector of St. Lazarus-Grace Episcopal Church in Memphis, also served at the Church of the Holy Innocents prior to Reverend Schuyler. -- Father Schuyler decided to follow Reverend Parsons to Memphis to be of assistance when the city was hit by a devastating yellow fever epidemic in 1878. He arrived the day after Father Parsons’ death from yellow fever on September 6, 1878. Louis Schuyler died of yellow fever on September 17, 1878. -- This small collection includes correspondence, a photograph of Schuyler and a book, Memorial of Louis Sandford Schuyler, Priest, which provides a detailed account of his life and work. The collection is stored in the Memphis and Shelby County Room with several small collections related to the yellow fever epidemics in Memphis, including The Reverend Charles Carroll Parsons Collection and A History of Yellow Fever in Memphis.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: clergy; health; public service; religion; yellow fever;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ruth F. Loewenberg Shelby Farms Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ruth Friedman Loewenberg grew up in Washington, D.C. and attended George Washington University. While in Memphis visiting her sister, she met William A. Loewenberg, and she described their meeting as “love at first sight.” They later married and had two daughters, Joanne Loewenberg Markell and Freddie Loewenberg Felt, and a son, William Ira Loewenberg. -- Ruth Loewenberg said, “I’m a joiner. I have learned, like my husband, not to say no.” The Loewenbergs’ joint philanthropic and humanitarian efforts were recognized through numerous awards, and Mrs. Loewenberg was honored individually by various organizations for her special contributions to social agencies such as Family Link, the Pink Ladies volunteers at St. Francis Hospital, and the Riverview-Kansas Day Care Center. Her extensive community service included taking an active role in many organizations such as the Sisterhood of Temple Israel, the National Council of Jewish Women, the Association for the Preservation of Tennessee Antiquities, the Beethoven Club, Hadassah, and the Ladies of St. Jude. Loewenberg served as president of Neighborhood House, and sat on its board for 35 years. She was also instrumental in the founding of Runaway House and contributed to the development of Dogwood Village, a residential facility for emotionally disturbed children. With her husband, William, she helped establish the Loewenberg School of Nursing at the University of Memphis. -- Ruth Loewenberg’s dedication and commitment in the fight to save the Shelby County Penal Farm from private development in the 1970s as a member of the Shelby Farms Planning Board was an outstanding achievement. The Ruth F. Loewenberg Shelby Farms Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Ruth Loewenberg in 1980. The material in the collection is primarily from the years 1973 to 1976. The earliest material relates to the Rouse-Boyle proposal which would have resulted in private development of the Shelby County Penal Farm. This proposal was soundly rejected by community leaders in 1973. Subsequently, a $50,000 grant from Abe Plough, matched by the city of Memphis and Shelby County, was used to finance a study, which resulted in the creation of the Shelby Farms Planning Board. -- While the bulk of the correspondence in the collection centers on the selection of a planner, the planning process itself, and communication between the principal participants, it also includes government documents, municipal department and committee responses, reports on public meetings and subcommittee activities, and the final comprehensive proposal. The collection provides an important source of information on the interaction of citizens and government in community planning and social change.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Robert F. Looney Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Robert Fain Looney was a descendant of a Virginia family who pioneered in Tennessee. His great grandfather distinguished himself in the Revolutionary War, and both of his grandfathers were members of the convention that drew up Tennessee’s first constitution. A native of Maury County, Tennessee, Looney was born in August 1824. After attending Jackson College in Columbia, he studied law with his brother-in-law, Judge Edmund Dillahunty, and practiced law in Maury County before moving to Memphis. -- Although Looney was a Whig and opposed secession, he formed the 38th Tennessee Regiment when the Civil War began. Under his command, the regiment won distinction at battles at Shiloh, Perryville and Murfreesboro, and served with honor in numerous other battles in Tennessee and Georgia. At Shiloh, Looney led a charge that took at least 1,000 prisoners, including General Benjamin M. Prentiss. Looney himself was later taken prisoner, but was exchanged. Returning to active duty for the duration of the war, he surrendered at Oxford, Mississippi in 1865. -- Following the war Looney returned to his law practice for five years before turning his attention to business and financial matters. He was active throughout the rest of his life on behalf of the Democratic Party, and was appointed as one of the commissioners responsible for the Shiloh battlefield being designated a national military park. -- Looney was married to Louisa Crofford of Maury County in 1847, and was the father of three sons and five daughters. His children continued in the family tradition and distinguished themselves in the political and civic life of Memphis and Tennessee. Looney died in November 1899 and is buried in Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis. -- The Robert F. Looney Collection was donated to the library by Dr. Simon R. Breusch as part of The Monte Cooper Collection. Perhaps the most interesting items in this collection are those from Looney’s military career, which detail his distinguished record in battle and his conflict with Confederate leaders as he attempted to gain permission to raise a brigade in west Tennessee. -- In addition to the extensive materials relating to Looney’s military service, the collection includes a small number of documents having to do with his life before the war and numerous letters between Looney and members of his family. The papers also include correspondence having to do with the creation of Shiloh National Military Park. -- The Looney papers, which describe the life of an active political figure of Tennessee and his role as a military leader and Southern patriot during and after the Civil War, are an extremely valuable part of the Memphis and Shelby County Room holdings. The papers provide researchers with a better understanding of life in the South during a dramatic and critical period of United States history.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: business; Civil War; economy; family; law; military; politics; prisoners of war; public service;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary Graham Love Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Graham Love was born July 27, 1884. She was the daughter of Memphis Mayor George Collins Love, who held office from November 1915 to February 1916, and Mary A. Graham Love. Mary Graham Love graduated from St. Mary’s Episcopal School for Girls and she and her family were active members of the Calvary Episcopal Church. Mary was active in various church organizations and served as president of the Women’s Auxiliary of the Diocese of Tennessee from 1937 to 1939. -- Love also served the community through her leadership in the Girl Scouts of America and the Women’s Department of the Tri-State Fair Association, where she served as chair for three years. She was active in the Nineteenth Century Club, where she served a one-year term as president, and she served a two-year term as president of the Eleventh district of the Tennessee Federation of Women’s Clubs. She further demonstrated her civic interests when she donated the Love family home, along with five other houses, to the city of Memphis to encourage the redevelopment of the Greenlaw neighborhood, one of the city’s oldest residential areas. -- The Mary Graham Love Papers were given to the library by an anonymous donor. The collection includes letters written to Mary Love and her sister Octavia, as well as correspondence written to their mother. Also included are photographs, newspaper clippings, a scrapbook on the Tri-State Fair, and other miscellaneous pieces. The collection also includes information about Mayor Love and other members of the Love family.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John William McAfee Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John William “Bill” McAfee, Sr. was born in Little Rock, Arkansas, in 1915. His family moved to Memphis when he was quite young and settled in the South Memphis area. McAfee dropped out of Southside High School and became a film projectionist, working with his father screening films at local movie houses. His early work with film would set him on a unique and lengthy career path as a newsreel cameraman and photojournalist. -- In 1944, McAfee was drafted into the U.S. Navy. His duties while he was stationed in the South Pacific included photographing Japanese military installations and the atomic bombing of Japan. After World War II, McAfee returned to Memphis, where he worked as a freelance newsreel photographer for major press and media networks, including ABC, CBS, NBC and UPI. He covered some of the most dramatic events of the post-war period, including the rise of Elvis Presley and the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. McAfee’s work during the tumultuous years of the Civil Rights Movement included covering Freedom Marches and the enrollment at Ole Miss of James Meredith, the first African American to attend the University. McAfee’s also served as chair of motion picture photography for the Memphis Cotton Carnival Association during its heyday in the 1950s and 1960s. -- McAfee’s work with the motion picture industry included screening films for the Memphis Board of Censors headed by the infamous Lloyd T. Binford. McAfee noted that a “Banned in Memphis” label ensured higher box office sales in other cities. He continued work as a film projectionist at the Main Street motion picture houses in Memphis, and he ran the projector when the last picture was screened at Lowe’s State theater in 1969. -- Toward the end of his career, McAfee worked as a cameraman on major motion pictures including The People vs. Larry Flynt and The Firm, both filmed in Memphis. After retirement, McAfee was owner-operator of Mid-Town Photo Service and Mid-South Theatrical Motion and Photo Supply Company. -- The photographs and papers in The John William McAfee Collection were given to the Library by his daughter, Rose McAfee Phillips. The material in the collection documents McAfee’s active career as a newsreel photographer, as well as his work with motion pictures and other forms of photography. -- While this collection does not include film footage, copies of detailed notes and headlines McAfee provided for each frame shot document the significant events he covered. McAfee’s work required a great deal of travel, and among the material in this collection are expense reports and weekly logs of his locations and subjects filmed. -- Some of the material reflects McAfee’s work as cameraman or projectionist on motion pictures such as Intruder in the Dust, filmed in Oxford (1949) and based on William Faulkner’s novel of the same name and A Family Thing (1995), The People vs. Larry Flint (1995) and The Firm (1992) which were filmed in Memphis.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Personal Papers of Judge Walter Malone
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Walter Malone served as Circuit Court Judge for the last twenty years of his life, but he was best known as an accomplished poet and writer. His personal papers were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by his niece, Alba R. Malone. The papers consist primarily of correspondence and handwritten and typed drafts of Judge Malone’s literary works. Much of the correspondence was exchanged with someone Malone addressed as “My Dear Friend,” who is presumed to be a fellow poet whose last name was Van Troppen. The collection also includes a few business papers and documents. -- Born in DeSoto County in 1866, Malone was the youngest of twelve children. He showed early promise as a writer and sold his first poem for publication at the age of twelve and had his first book of poetry published when he was sixteen. At the University of Mississippi he was editor-in-chief and a frequent contributor to the college magazine. -- For several years he worked in New York City as a writer for magazines and weekly newspapers. He corresponded with literary figures from New York about poetry, plays and short stories once he returned to Memphis. Before becoming a judge, Malone served as a lawyer and as city editor of the Memphis Public Ledger. -- Malone’s most famous poem, “Opportunity,” was written in 1904, the year before he was appointed judge. Although there are several stories concerning the circumstances under which it was written, there is a consensus that it was a reply to the pessimistic theme expressed in a similarly-named poem by former Senator John J. Ingalls of Kansas. Malone was paid $10 for the poem by the publishers of Munsey’s Magazine, who did not print it for several months. “Opportunity” was eventually translated into several languages and many readers stated that the poem is so uplifting and inspiring that it prevented them from committing suicide. Although “Opportunity” was Malone’s best-known poem, he considered his epic poem “DeSoto” to be his most important work. -- Walter Malone died in 1915, and was buried in Elmwood Cemetery. His epitaph was one which he wrote himself: "Stranger who passeth by my low house of clay, Pause for a moment in a tender mood: Think not your sigh of pity thrown away, Because I’d say 'God bless you' if I could."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John D. Martin Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Donelson Martin was born in Memphis in 1883, the son of John and Mary Walker Hull Martin. He attended Memphis University School, where he was a football player and editor of the school newspaper. He received a law degree from the University of Virginia in 1905 and established a law practice in Memphis, where he became active in politics as an associate of E.H. Crump. He was appointed District Judge for the Western Tennessee Federal Court in 1935 and quickly established a reputation as a “no nonsense” judge, working hard to reduce the backlog of cases in federal courts. Many of Judge Martin’s vacations were spent hearing cases for other circuits throughout the country. In 1940, Martin was selected as an appellate judge for the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals, a position he held until his death in 1962. -- The John D. Martin Collection, which includes over 26,000 items, provides valuable information on the history of Memphis, Western Tennessee, and the federal court system. The documents in the collection from the early part of Judge Martin’s career, describe his involvement in World War I, as well as his political activities on behalf of the Crump machine. Materials from the period 1935 to 1940, his early years as a federal judge, relate to the business of the Western Tennessee District Federal Court and Martin’s interaction with other judges in Tennessee, particularly Judge John Gore of Jackson. Papers from the period after 1940 have a national scope and address the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals and Martin’s work in other circuits throughout the nation. -- The collection includes case documents, court summary reports, docket calendars, newspaper articles, photographs and papers related to court business. The papers also provide a glimpse into Judge Martin’s personal life through letters and documents relating to his serving as president of the Southern Baseball Association, a position he held from 1919 to 1938. -- The provenance of the collection is unknown. There are no records showing when this collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room or naming the donor. From its appearance in the original boxes, it could be gathered that the collection is comprised of the contents of the file cabinets in Judge Martin’s chambers after his death.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thomas E. Maxson Collection: A Career in Public Engineering
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thomas E. Maxson was born in LaBette County, Kansas in 1901 and grew up in Fort Worth, Texas. He graduated from Texas A&M College in 1922 with a bachelor’s degree in civil engineering. After receiving his degree, Maxson worked for a year with the Texas Highway Department and a year with the Frisco Railway in Birmingham before moving to Memphis. -- In July 1924 Maxson began working in the city engineering department in Memphis as a draftsman. While working as a city engineer Maxson wrote the Report on Flood Control: Memphis, Tennessee, February 1937, an analysis of the devastating effects of the 1937 flood, in which he recommended measures to protect the city in the event of another flood. Maxson’s flood control plan identified three problem areas: the North Memphis Wolf River basin, the South Memphis Nonconnah Creek Basin and the Gayoso Basin. The plan was authorized as part of the Flood Control Act, which was approved by Congress in 1937. As a result of Maxson’s assessment, new levees, floodwalls, drainage structures and bank protection projects were constructed to withstand a fifty five foot flood. -- In 1962 Maxson was appointed City Engineer, and in 1973 he became Director of Public Works. In addition, he served as a consultant for the Memphis Port and Harbor Commission and as a member of the Memphis and Shelby County Planning Commission and the Riverfront Harbor Commission. Nearly 500 miles of city streets were planned and constructed under his guidance. -- The American Public Works Association’s Samuel Greeley Award was presented to Maxson in 1956 for his 30 years of continuous service to one city. At a national presentation in 1966, the American Public Works Association and Kiwanis International named Maxson one of the Top Ten Public Works Men-of-the-Year. He was also named 1966 Engineer of the Year by the Memphis Society of Professional Engineers and 1970 Engineer of the Year by the Memphis Joint Engineering Societies. Maxson received a singular honor in 1971 when the city’s multi-million dollar South Sewage Plant was named in his honor. -- Aside from his professional work in engineering, Maxson was an active member of Lindenwood Christian Church and participated in numerous civic organizations including the Civitan Club, the Gavel Club, the Masons and the Shriners. Maxson retired in 1972, some 48 years after beginning work with the city of Memphis. He died in 1984 at the age of 83, leaving his wife, Marian Maxson. -- Material in the Maxson collection provides an unusually complete account of the career of a professional engineer. The material includes letters, photographs, newspaper clippings, awards and a large quantity of slides and 8mm film detailing many public projects. In addition to the items pertaining to Maxson’s career as an engineer, the collection includes articles on his civic activities and church membership.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Florence McIntyre Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Florence Makin McIntyre is remembered as the First Lady of Memphis Art. She was born in Memphis in 1878 and grew up in her family home, the Pillow-McIntyre House, at 707 Adams Avenue in the historic Victorian Village neighborhood. As a child she attended the Clara Conway Institute, an early Memphis girls’ school, where her interest in art was encouraged. She studied at the Art Institute of Chicago under John H. Vanderpool, one of America’s most noted drawing teachers. She continued her studies in Philadelphia, where she worked under Marguerita Archambault, studying portraiture and miniature painting. McIntyre also spent several summers at the Woodstock School of Landscape Painting in Woodstock, New York, where she met many important fellow artists. -- Shortly after returning to Memphis in 1914, McIntyre and members of the Nineteenth Century Club organized the Memphis Art Association which promoted the serious study of art and brought exhibitions and lectures to Memphis. -- McIntyre became the first director of the Brooks Memorial Art Gallery when it opened in 1916 and held that position for six years. She mounted several outstanding exhibits during her tenure at Brooks, including Lithographs of the War Work of England and America in 1917 and an exhibit of war portraits which now reside at the National Portrait Gallery which was displayed in 1922. She resigned from Brooks in 1922 and returned to her work with the Memphis Art Association. -- In 1921 McIntyre was instrumental in organizing the Southern States Art League. She served as the organization’s first president, drawing up its constitution and by-laws. During her first few years with the League, she mounted two successful exhibits of work by Southern artists. -- In 1925, under the guidance of McIntyre and her friend and art patron, Rosa Lee, the Memphis Art Association founded the James Lee Memorial Academy of Arts. McIntyre served as the director of the Academy until 1936, when a split occurred between the board of the Memphis Art Association and the staff of the school. The James Lee Academy continued to offer classes, and in 1942, the school moved to the McIntyre home at 707 Adams Avenue. The school, which was then named the Free Art School of the Memphis Art Association, offered free art classes and continued to run until shortly after McIntyre’s death in 1963. The 1936 split also resulted in the formation of a new art school, the Memphis Academy of Arts, which changed its name to Memphis College of Art in 1985. -- Throughout her career, McIntyre published numerous articles and papers in local and national publications. In 1952, McIntyre published her autobiography titled Art and Life. The book covers the history of art in Memphis, McIntyre’s long career with various local and national art organizations and her philosophy on art education. -- The Florence McIntyre Collection includes material on McIntyre’s work with the Memphis Art Association, Brooks Memorial Art Gallery, the James Lee Academy and the Southern States Art League. The papers also contain McIntyre’s correspondence with American art directors and artists, particularly American lithographer Joseph Pennell, whose work she supported. Material related to the publication of McIntyre’s book Art and Life is included in the collection. In addition, there are lectures and notes by McIntyre on art education and the history of art in Memphis. Finally, the collection contains personal papers such as postcards, photographs, awards and newspaper clippings on art and other subjects of interest to McIntyre and information on the residences she owned in Victorian Village.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ethel Taylor Maxwell Collection: A Life in Music and the Arts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ethel Taylor Maxwell was born in Memphis in 1915 and enjoyed a long and prominent career as a musical singing star and later as a teacher of music. She credited her parents with encouraging her early interest in music and supporting her artistic ambition. Ethel began piano lessons at age 4 and continued the study of instrumental music through college. Later, she began studies in voice and drama. -- Ethel graduated from the Hutchison School in 1932 and went on to pursue a degree from Southwestern at Memphis (now Rhodes College). She earned a degree in piano in 1934 and received her B.A. degree in psychology and education in 1936. She then moved to New York to continue her music studies. While living there from 1936 to 1940, she attended the Alvine School of Speech and Drama and the Rossini Opera School and studied voice with Estelle Liebling and Arthur Wrege. -- Taylor’s career was officially launched in Memphis in 1937 when she starred in the Memphis Open Air Theater production of Sigmund Romberg’s operetta The Desert Song. For the next thirteen years, Taylor was the leading lady in the theater’s summer productions of such enormously popular works as Vagabond King, The Merry Widow and Student Prince. -- In 1942, Ethel Taylor and Early Hobson Maxwell were married in a much publicized ceremony at Idlewild Presbyterian Church. Early was a sports editor for the Evening Appeal in the early 1930s and was later made promotions editor of the Commercial Appeal. The couple had two daughters, Ethel Taylor Maxwell and Margaret Alice “Peggy” Maxwell. -- During World War II, Maxwell served in the U.S. Army at Fort Oglethorpe, Georgia. While Maxwell was in the military, Ethel performed with the Memphis Open Air Theater and the Chattanooga Opera Association while continuing her voice studies at the University of Chattanooga’s Czadic Conservatory. -- At the end of the war, Early returned to civilian life and formed his own public relations firm, Early Maxwell Associates. Ethel continued her singing career, and in 1952, she joined the faculty of Memphis State College as a teacher of voice. In 1956, she received a Master of Arts in speech and drama, and later that year joined the faculty of Lausanne School for Girls as a music instructor. -- In 1970 Ethel Maxwell became an assistant professor in the Department of Music at Memphis State University, receiving tenure in 1973. She continued her teaching at the university until her retirement in 1987. -- In addition to her success as a professional singer, Ethel served as a soloist for many years at Calvary Episcopal Church, and as organist-choirmaster at St. Elisabeth’s Episcopal. She was also an active participant in service organizations and served as President of the Beethoven Club for several years. -- The Ethel Taylor Maxwell Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Ethel Maxwell in 1991. The collection contains photographs and newspaper clippings, as well as scrapbooks and programs which describe Taylor’s professional career as a musical star in Memphis and Chattanooga. Also included are personal and family items such as memorabilia from her college years and an album of wedding photographs. In addition to the material which describes Maxwell’s musical career, the collection contains information on her teaching positions at the Memphis State University and Lausanne School for Girls. Finally, the collection includes clippings on Taylor’s husband, Early Maxwell and his public relations firm, Early Maxwell Associates, which brought many well-known performers to Memphis, including Bob Hope, Bing Crosby and golfing great Ben Hogan.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphians During War
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memphians During War collection consists primarily of materials relating to the involvement of Memphians in the Civil War, World War I and World War II. -- The material on the Civil War largely relates to events which took place in Memphis and nearby areas. Included are news clippings, mostly from Union papers, which cover the action near Memphis at Island No. 10 in the Mississippi River and describe the gunboat battle on the river at Memphis. The collection also includes a composite photograph of Union officers stationed in Memphis during the occupation of the city, a copy of the Union gunboat commander’s demand to the mayor for the surrender of the city and the mayor’s reply. The personal letters of Confederate soldier Robert Bond are included, as are numerous letters from William Augustus Jones to his family in Holly Springs, Mississippi, about his involvement in the war. Official documents and correspondence from L.D. McKissick, Civil Governor and Provost Marshal of Memphis are contained in the collection, as is the notebook of J.S. White, a surgeon in the Confederate Army. Among a variety of other items in the collection are an original telegram sent to Memphis with news of the First Battle of Manassas, forms used by former Confederates swearing allegiance to the Union and the request of a Union soldier for replacement of equipment lost during the Battle of Shiloh. -- The World War I collection consists of a large number of posters which were used as propaganda and as reminders to the public to support the war effort. The posters urge Americans to subscribe to the various Liberty Loan drives, plant Victory Gardens, and refrain from eating certain food items so that U.S. troops and our allies would have enough food. Various posters representing organizations such as the YMCA, YWCA, National Catholic War Council, Jewish Welfare Board, Salvation Army and Red Cross are included. The variety of posters presents fascinating examples of the subtle efforts used to encourage the public to support the war. Items related to World War I also include two volumes of the army newspaper, Stars and Stripes. -- The material related to World War II also includes numerous posters. The messages in the posters produced during World War II are more direct than those of World War I, and contain commands for Americans such as “Buy War Bonds.” Many of the World War II posters contain an historic appeal to patriotism and compare the current American efforts for freedom to those of the Revolutionary War. Photography began to be used as a medium to record images during World War II, and the collection contains many photographs of war scenes. Also included are a collection of plane identification flash cards, slides of silhouettes of planes, ration cards and V-Mail letters. Letters from both world wars are also included, such as those from World War I pilot Louis L. Carruthers of Memphis and newsy, chatty letters from two Felts brothers written during World War II.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Auditorium Programs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
The Auditorium Programs Collection was assembled from items collected by the Memphis Public Library and donated by individuals over many years. The collection consists of booklets, concert programs, pamphlets and playbills which chronicle events held at the Memphis and Shelby County Auditorium between the years of 1924 and 1975.
Built on the former site of the Shelby County Court House, the Auditorium was dedicated in October 1924 with a concert by John Phillip Sousa. On June 2, 1930, it was renamed Ellis Auditorium in honor of Robert R. Ellis who had played and instrumental role in establishing the building. In July 1958, Ellis Auditorium was renovated to include the North and South Halls which expanded the space available for performances. The North Hall was renamed Dixon-Meyers Hall in recognition of the support Hugo Dixon and I. L. “Ike” Meyers gave to Memphis musical arts. In 1981, the South Hall was named in honor of Vincent De Frank, founder and conductor emeritus of the Memphis Symphony Orchestra. Ellis Auditorium remained in operation until 1996 when it was closed to make way for the expansion of the Cook Convention Center. On November 19, 1996, Bruce Springsteen performed the final concert in Ellis Auditorium.
In addition to John Phillip Sousa and Bruce Springsteen, many other celebrated entertainers of the 20th century performed at the Auditorium. The included: Paul Whiteman, W. C. Handy, Will Rogers, Isadora Duncan, Ethel Barrymore, Rudy Vallee, Fanny Brice, Sergei Rachmaninoff, Tallulah Bankhead, Katharine Hepburn, Liberace, and Lawrence Welk. Researchers interested in the history of performance in Memphis will also want to consult the Memphis Open Air Theatre Collection and the Theatre Memphis Programs Collection, also housed in the Memphis and Shelby County Room.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Senator Kenneth Douglas McKellar: A Register of His Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Kenneth McKellar was born in 1869 near Richmond, Alabama. In 1892, after receiving a Bachelor’s, Master’s and law degree from the University of Alabama, he moved to Memphis. He began his extensive political career when he was selected as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1908. He served in the United States House of Representatives from 1911 to 1917, and on March 4, 1917, he took his seat as the first directly elected United States Senator from Tennessee. McKellar served in the Senate continuously from 1917 until he was defeated for reelection by Albert Gore, Sr. in 1953. He then returned to Memphis, where he lived until his death in October 1957. -- McKellar held various important posts during his career as a legislator. As a member of the Military Affairs Committee, he was instrumental in reorganizing the U.S. Army around the time of World War I. As a member and chair of the Post Offices and Post Roads Committee, he played a key part in early legislation which established the United States Air Mail Service. McKellar worked for many years on legislation on flood control projects on the Tennessee River, which later provided a basis for the Tennessee Valley Authority. During the first administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, McKellar served as a spokesman for the Democratic Party, and made a number of nationwide radio addresses in defense of the Roosevelt administration. -- McKellar’s authority and influence continued to increase through the 1930s. In 1937, during the prolonged illness of Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, he became acting chair of the Appropriations Committee. When President Roosevelt died in 1945, he became president de facto of the Senate and, by invitation from President Truman, occupied the Vice President’s place in Cabinet sessions. -- Throughout his years of public life McKellar gained a reputation for never having thrown away a scrap of paper. Consequently, he left a large collection of papers and mementos. Senator McKellar’s papers were given to the library in 1960 by his family. The collection, which is one of the largest in the Memphis and Shelby County Room, includes numerous letters and a large series of scrapbooks. About half the letters in the collection were exchanged between McKellar and his constituents on a variety of subjects. Special series within the collection contain materials of a more specific nature including correspondence between McKellar and E.H. Crump, and correspondence dealing with post office and rural routs, military affairs, legislation, politics, war priorities, appropriations, the Tennessee Valley Authority, and New Deal bureaus. The scrapbooks, which date from 1889 to 1951, contain clippings on McKellar’s activities in local and national politics, as well as items from his personal life. -- Although McKellar was primarily concerned with the welfare of Tennessee and Tennesseans throughout his career, the usefulness of the collection is not limited to those studying Tennessee history. Rather, McKellar’s involvement in many national issues makes this collection valuable to those researching American political history from World War I thru the Depression, New Deal and World War II. -- The collection may be used in conjunction with A McKellar Calendar of Speeches, 1928-1940, a doctoral dissertation by Joseph Riggs, which includes a thorough index and summaries of many of McKellar’s speeches.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: appropriations; Crump, E. H.; government; immigration; law; legislation; military; pardons; parole; passports; politics; post office; public service; rural routes;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rev. Frank Lewis McRae Collection: A Life in Ministry and Service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rev. Frank Lewis McRae, longtime minister of St. John's United Methodist Church, was also a civic and community leader. Active throughout the civil rights struggle, he continued his work in social justice with organizations such as MIFA, Friends for Life, the Church Health Center, and Mid-America Apartment Communities, Inc. This collection contains material from throughout his career and is especially useful for researchers interested in the civil rights movement and the United Methodist Church.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: George Mahan, Jr. Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Mahan, Jr., distinguished and revered architect, was born in Memphis and spent his entire life in the city. He began his career at the age of fifteen, when he joined the architectural firm of Shaw and Pfeil as a student draftsman. Mahan’s architectural style was greatly influenced by his experience at Shaw and Pfeil. Mr. Shaw taught Mahan that if he drew a cow, he should make it look like a cow; and if he built a church, he should make it look like a church. Mahan followed this maxim throughout his career. -- Recognized as the dean of Memphis architects, Mahan designed or assisted in designing numerous schools, banks and other public buildings, including the Memphis Cotton Exchange and the King Cotton Hotel. In 1913 he co-founded the Memphis Architects’ League, which was to become the Memphis chapter of the American Institute of Architects. -- During his long and outstanding career, Mahan held partnerships with several noted architects including J.J. Broadwell, Everett Woods and Arnold Shappley, Jr. Throughout his career, Mahan found time to train many promising students, and some of Memphis’ best-known architects began their work with Mahan as their mentor. -- The George Mahan, Jr. Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1989 by Mr. Mahan’s daughter, Elizabeth Mahan Ballenger. The collection consists of photographs, newspaper clippings and other memorabilia relating to Mr. Mahan’s career and his founding of the Memphis Architects’ League. The finding aid to the collection includes an interview with Elizabeth Ballenger completed around the time she donated her father’s papers to the library. The centerpiece of the collection is a copy of Mr. Mahan’s Commission Book, which is the only comprehensive record of his career. The Commission Book lists and dates each of the over 1,800 architectural projects Mahan completed from 1912 to 1967. Unfortunately, many of Mahan’s most important projects have been torn down in the name of progress, and the collection serves as a record of the significance of his work.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: architecture; banks; buildings; business; churches; houses; hospitals; jails; libraries; police buildings; residences; schools;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William A. Goodman Historic Documents Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1978, William A. Goodman, a Memphis attorney, historian and collector, gave the Library a unique collection of historic documents. Seven of the pieces are 18th century documents, including two signed by Manuel Gayoso de Lemos, Spanish Governor of the Natchez Territory, along with two signed by John Sevier, first elected Governor of Tennessee. The older documents of the collection feature items from or signed by General James Wilkinson, Andrew Jackson, James K. Polk, David Folsom, Matthew Fontaine Maury, and George Peabody. -- The largest group of letters is comprised of 85 pieces from the Civil War. Most of these are letters, orders, or telegrams issued by Confederate and Union commanders operating in and around Memphis or in strategic areas bordering the Mississippi River. Included are letters or orders signed by Union Generals Ulysses S. Grant, William T. Sherman, and Stephen A. Hurlbut and by Confederate Generals G.T. Beauregard, Nathan Bedford Forrest, Joseph E. Johnson, Edwin Kirby-Smith, Gideon J. Pillow, Daniel Ruggles, Alfred J. Vaughan and Joseph Wheeler. There are also documents bearing the signatures of Presidents Abraham Lincoln and Andrew Johnson. -- A number of the items dated after 1865 are connected to the war in some way, including letters or notes from Jefferson Davis, Nathan Bedford Forrest and General Marcus J. Wright.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Papers of Mrs. Anna E. Gilbert of Raleigh, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Anna Elizabeth Brooks was born around 1857 to William and Elizabeth Brooks. According to the 1860 census, Anna was the youngest of four siblings. Anna married Andrew C. Gilbert, who died in 1876 at the age of 26. Anna was quite a religious woman, especially after the death of her husband. She was involved with several church organizations, as well as Bethany School, a religious school in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, which provided physical and spiritual healing for those in need. -- Much of Mrs. Gilbert’s life was spent in Raleigh, Tennessee. While living in Raleigh, Mrs. Gilbert raised a young girl, Loueva Brown, whose parents had been killed. -- The Gilbert papers consist primarily of personal letters dating between 1880 and 1933. Almost all of the correspondence was written either by or to Anna, although a few early documents are signed by her father, William G. Brooks. -- A large portion of the materials contained in the collection are letters which have a distinct religious tone. Also included are several examples of 19th century land deeds and tax receipts. The materials provide a glimpse into the life of an involved, caring and devout woman around the turn of the century.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Raleigh; religion; social life; women;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Goldsmith Department Store Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Goldsmith Department Store Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by descendants of company founder Jacob Goldsmith. Materials in the collection include family papers, letters, photographs and legal documents, as well as business items such as journals, corporate minutes, ledgers, photographs and newspaper files. Six scrapbooks contain a wealth of information on the company, its officers and employees. Of particular interest is the large number of photographs which document the growth of the original downtown store, the building of the suburban stores and the company’s promotional and civic activities. -- The collection, which describes the founding and growth of a major Memphis-owned-and-operated department store, provides the history of a corporation that has played an important role in the city’s economic development. In addition, there is biographical information on the Goldsmith family as well as the company’s employees, many of whom spent their entire working careers with the organization. The collection also provides information on the founding of the Goldsmith Civic Garden Center, a part of the Memphis Botanic Gardens, one of the leading public gardens in the South. -- Jacob Goldsmith emigrated to the United States in 1867 at age 17 from his home in Hainstadt, Germany. He and his older brother Isaac lived with their uncle Louis Ottenheimer while establishing themselves in Memphis during the years following the Civil War. In 1875, Jacob married his cousin Dora Ottenheimer, and they had three sons and four daughters. -- The Goldsmith brothers founded a retail business on Beale Street in 1870. In 1881 they opened a new store on Main Street. When Isaac died in 1885, Jacob bought his brother’s interest in the business and moved to another location on Main. As a result of the company’s rapid growth, Jacob Goldsmith rented a new building in 1902 which was situated on the southwest corner of Main and Gayoso. This would become the well-known location of Goldsmith’s main store for the next 80 years. Eventually, the firm would own the entire block situated between Main and Front and Gayoso and McCall. -- Recognizing both the growth of the company and the contributions which his sons, who had become involved in the business, were making to its success, Jacob had the firm incorporated in 1904 as J. Goldsmith and Sons. Under the direction of his sons—and then grandsons—Goldsmith’s Department Store continued to prosper and grow in the years after World War II. Keeping pace with the city’s eastward expansion, Goldsmith’s built its first suburban store, Oak Court, at Poplar and Perkins Extended in 1961. Southland Mall, the city’s first mall, was selected as the location for the next suburban store. This was followed by the expansion of the Oak Court store in 1967, the opening of the store in Raleigh Springs Mall in 1971 and the opening of the Hickory Ridge Mall store in 1981. The first store outside Shelby County opened in Jackson, Tennessee, in 1981. -- Over the years, Goldsmith’s introduced innovative services such as the “charga-plate,” escalators, in-store dining facilities, the latest in retail merchandising and modern suburban stores, which, with progressive family management, made Goldsmith’s one of the leading department stores in the South. -- In 1959, Goldsmith’s became affiliated with the Federated Department Stores, Inc., the largest retail group in the United States. Members of the Goldsmith family remained active in management until the retirement of Robert Goldsmith, the last family member associated with the business.
