oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Colton Greene Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A leading citizen of Memphis in the decades after the Civil War, Colton Greene is best remembered as the originator of the Memphis Mardi Gras. Little is known of Greene’s early life other than that he was born in South Carolina in 1832. Greene was living in St. Louis when he enlisted in the Confederate Army in 1861 and took part in an unsuccessful effort to seize the U.S. Arsenal in that city. He served as commander of the 3rd Missouri Cavalry Brigade throughout the war, taking part in many battles in the Trans-Mississippi Military District. -- After the war Greene began a successful career in the insurance business. He was employed by the Memphis branch of the Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company of New York and established his own firm, Greene & Lucas, in 1871. He also founded and served as the first president of the State Savings Bank and helped organize the Tennessee Club. Greene provided enlightened leadership during the difficult years of growing debt and devastation which followed several yellow fever epidemics that forced the city to surrender its charter in 1879. Along with other concerned citizens including Elias Lowenstein and John Overton, Jr., he served on a Water Committee which was formed to investigate the feasibility of constructing a municipal water works. -- When the Memphis newspaper, The Appeal, called for a public discussion of ideas to attract business to the community, Greene proposed that the city celebrate Mardi Gras and established the Mystic Society of Memphi to promote the social events of the festival. The “Mystic Memphi” organized the grand parades, supervised the construction of floats and the design of costumes and sponsored an exclusive ball for its members. With the help of others, notably David P. Hadden, Greene persuaded railroad companies to lower fares during the celebrations and hired fashionable artists and costumers to decorate the city for Mardi Gras. The first festival was held in 1872, and the Memphis celebrations rivaled those of New Orleans and Mobile in magnificence throughout the 1870s. From the 1880s until the turn of the century, the tradition continued, but on a diminished scale. -- A world traveler and a highly educated man, Greene was an avid collector of books. His bequest of more than 500 titles to the Cossitt Library upon his death in 1900 included a large selection of classics as well as many of the latest works on history, science and philosophy. -- The Colton Green Collection consists primarily of correspondence related to Green’s military service during the Civil War and records of the Society of Memphi. The military correspondence includes hand-drawn maps of some of the areas in the Trans-Mississippi Military District where Greene took part in military actions and a series of letters and depositions concerning the “mule imbroglio.” In 1864, Greene was accused and later found innocent of encouraging officers under his command to disobey an order that required all soldiers to turn over their mules to the government. The portion of the collection related to Mardi Gras includes receipts, bills, correspondence, invitations, parade programs, sketches and items related to artists hired by the Memphi to decorate for the celebrations. The collection also includes Colton Greene’s passport (containing a written description of his physical features), a photograph of Greene and a deed for property on Main Street which was sold to John H. Stephenson by Frederick H. Cossitt, founder of the Cossitt Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Greer Family Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The collection begins with a set of letters sent between David Searcy Greer and Martha Jane Dunlap. The two were engaged in February 1833 and the wedding date was set for February 1835. Meanwhile, Greer was working as a surveyor in the Indian Territory in North Mississippi. Even so, the two corresponded frequently. Their letters deal with personal matters including David’s please to shorten the couple’s engagement. The letters also include accounts of family and community members and living conditions in Mississippi and Paris, Tennessee. -- The remaining documents deal with family and business matters after David and Martha Greer came to Memphis, Tennessee in 1842. The items related to Martha Greer include a letter to John Ripley Greer from 1858 and another letter from Martha’s niece Sue Dunlap. Other papers from the late nineteenth century and early twentieth century relate to John Ripley Greer, Sr. The collection also contains letters of condolence from relatives and friends following John and Martha’s deaths. These were sent to both John Ripley Greer, Jr. and his mother just before her death. There are also a small number of items relating to John Ripley Greer, Jr. -- The collection includes a number of photographs, newspaper clippings, and other documents. Most of the photographs are unfortunately unlabeled, but some have been identified using photographs appearing in newspaper articles. Many of the newspaper articles were included in the original collection. Others were copied, added from the Memphis and Shelby County Room’s vertical files. Other documents were copied and added to the collection as well. These include the probate records of David Searcy Greer and images from an 1888 property map of Shelby County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: E.W. Hale Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: E. William Hale was born in 1875 in Oxford Mississippi, and moved with his family to Whitehaven in 1894. In addition to running a farm, the Hale family owned a general store at the corner of Highway 51 and Whitehaven-Capleville Road in rural Shelby County. After graduating from Whitehaven High School in 1893, Hale joined his father in operating the J.W. Hale and Son Mercantile Store. In 1906 E.W. Hale was elected magistrate of the 12th district. As a member of the county court, Hale acted as the legislator and the presiding judge for his district. -- In 1911, Shelby County adopted the commission form of government to oversee the daily operation of county affairs. Made up of three elected officials, the commission maintained county roads, approved the founding of subdivisions and operated county facilities. With the support of Mayor E.H. Crump, Hale was elected a member of the first commission. He was elected commission chair in 1922, a position he held until his retirement in 1955. -- As chair of the commission, Hale established efficient county government which improved county schools and roads. His greatest accomplishment as commissioner was the founding of the Shelby County Penal Farm. Nationally recognized as a model prison facility, the penal farm also contributed to Shelby County’s agricultural economy. As the height of its output, the 5,017 acre farm had 1,700 head of livestock, produced 39 varieties of vegetables and produced 1,400 loaves of bread daily. -- When E.W. Hale died in 1959, he was praised as an honest public servant who contributed enormously to the development of Shelby County. Commenting on his death, Memphis Congressman Clifford Davis stated, “In his 44 years of devoted service to the city and county, Mr. Hale built a monument which will last until the very end of time… he filled a strong place in the material growth and development of this community as evidenced by the Shelby County Penal Farm, the Criminal Courts Building, roads, bridges and schools, but to me his strong and excellent character was even more impressive.” -- The E.W. Hale Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1977. The collection covers the years 1937 to 1954 and includes correspondence, government reports and photographs related to Hale’s career as chairman of the Shelby County Commission. In addition to Hale’s correspondence, the collection includes a small amount of correspondence belonging to Commissioners Francis Andrews, Rudolph Jones and Dan Mitchell. Much of the material in the collection concerns the operation of various Shelby County facilities and organizations including the Oakville Memorial Sanatorium, the Shelby County Hospital, the Shelby County Penal Farm, the Memphis/Shelby County Port and Harbor Commission, the Memphis/Shelby County Planning Commission, the Memphis/Shelby County Welfare Commission and the Works Progress Administration. The papers also contain material on the construction of the Memphis-Arkansas Bridge, the 1940 and 1944 presidential elections and the development of subdivisions in Shelby County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A. Arthur Halle Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A. Arthur Halle was born in Memphis in 1889. He attended the Linden Street School, Memphis University School, Betts Academy in Stamford, Connecticut, and Yale University, where he studied law. Halle’s time at Yale ended prematurely because of his father’s death. He returned to Memphis and became president of his family’s clothing business, Phil A. Halle Department Store, and continued in this position until his death. He married Dorothy Sternberg and the couple had two children, A. Arthur Halle, Jr. and Dorothy Sternberg Halle. The family lived for many years in the Midtown area before moving into a historic antebellum home in Cordova, which they named The Hollys. -- Halle was a principal organizer of the Memphis Cotton Carnival in 1931 and was also instrumental in reviving the Mystic Society of the Memphi, a secret social society. He served as Cotton Carnival president and General Chairman of the Parade Division and encouraged businesses and citizens to participate in the festival activities. His enthusiasm and love of the Cotton Carnival earned Halle the nickname “Mr. Cotton Carnival.” Halle also served as president of the Christmas Parade and participated in the Kiwanis Club, the Executives Club, the Community Fund and the Retail Merchants Association. He was involved in the Summit Club, the Petroleum Club and the Sesa Cesac Club and was a 32nd degree mason and an active member of Temple Israel. -- In 1942 Halle requested a civilian appointment to the United States War Department. He was made a Warehouse Specialist in the Quarter Master Corps and assigned to the depot in Ogden, Utah. He remained there from 1942 to 1945, and received a promotion to Lieutenant Colonel for his outstanding work. -- The A. Arthur Halle Collection covers the years 1917 to 1981 and contains business records, correspondence, legal documents, magazine and newspaper clippings and photographs related to all aspects of Halle’s life, including his business, civic and military work. The most valuable material in the collection relates to Halle’s involvement with the Cotton Carnival and includes more than 50 photographs from Carnival events from the years 1934 to 1959. Detailed information on The Mystic Order of the Memphi is also included, which provides a rare look into the operation and membership of a carnival society.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beale Street Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Beale Street Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby county Room in 1980 by the Beale Street Development Corporation. During the restoration of the 300 block of Beale Street, construction workers recovered many items which had probably been stored originally in the basement of the Pantaze Building at the intersection of Hernando and Beale and the projection room of the New Daisy Theatre. The collection includes material from the late 1930s to the early 1960s on musical artists and businesses on Beale Street and some information on the restoration of the area. -- Much of the collection focuses on the music industry of Beale Street. Posters, concert tickets, handbills and publicity photographs advertising performing artists from the 1950s and 1960s are included in the collection. The finding aid to the collection includes an “Index to Artists” which lists each musician, entertainer and concert venue mentioned in the collection. -- The portion of the collection related to businesses on Beale Street contains an historical sketch of the businesses and miscellaneous records including correspondence and receipts. Papers from Club Ebony, Club Handy, the Daisy, New Daisy and Palace Theatres, Pantaze Drug Store, the Mitchell Hotel and Mitchell Grill and other Beale Street businesses are included. Also included are contracts and letters, many of which relate to the business dealings of Andrew “Sunbeam” Mitchell, proprietor of Club Ebony and Club Handy. -- Information on the restoration of Beale Street includes landscape development plans. A map showing an abandoned design for construction of a pedestrian mall on Beale Street is also included in this portion of the collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hallelujah! Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hallelujah!, a film released in 1929, was the first all-black musical and was intended to be a dramatic portrayal of the lives of poor African Americans in the South. The producer and director, King Vidor, filmed on location in Memphis and Arkansas, and the interiors were shot at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios. Filming in several different locations led the director to use post-synchronized sound, another motion picture first which is sometimes credited to the film. -- Several Memphians were cast in the film, including Georgia Woodruff, who was unexpectedly asked to be the lead soprano of the Dixie Jubilee Singers in the movie. Eva Jessye, a life-long friend of Woodruff, directed the Dixie Jubilee Singers and was music supervisor for the film. Two other Memphians, Robert Couch and Milton Dickerson, also appeared in the film. These children were discovered while dancing for pennies in the lobby of the Peabody Hotel, and their dance was subsequently featured in the film. Couch was later offered a part in the “Our Gang Comedies” and went on to work with Memphis music legend Rufus Thomas. -- Vidor originally chose Paul Robeson to play the male lead, Zeke. However, because Robeson was unavailable, his understudy in the stage version of Show Boat, Daniel L. Haynes, was cast in the role. The female lead was played by Nina Mae McKinney, who was later called the “Black Garbo,” and the part of Zeke’s parson father was played by an 86-year-old ex-slave. Two of the musical numbers in the film, “Waiting at the End of the Road” and “Swanee Shuffle,” were written by Irving Berlin. -- Georgia Woodruff’s daughter, Rubye Woodruff Carter, donated The Hallelujah! Collection to the Memphis and Shelby County Room. The collection, which consists largely of photographs, includes publicity shots and scenes from the movie and photographs of the cast and crew on location in Memphis. The collection is supplemented by correspondence and newspaper clippings concerning Georgia Woodruff’s friend Eva Jessye, which illustrate Jessye’s long-standing career as a choral director. -- To emphasize the impact of Hallelujah! on film history, reviews from noted film anthologies and reference books have been added to the collection. Furthermore, since the library received special permission from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for a one-time showing of the film at the Main Library in February 1986, the local publicity materials for this presentation have been duplicated and placed in the collection.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; arts; drama; entertainment; film; motion pictures; musicals; social life;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: W.C. Handy Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Christopher Handy, the “Father of the Blues,” was born in 1873 in Florence, Alabama. His parents wanted Handy to become a minister, but he was more interested in music. Early in his career he directed the Knights of Pythias Band in Clarksdale, Mississippi, and then moved to Memphis, where he gained great popularity from his tunes The Memphis Blues (originally titled Mr. Crump) and Beale Street Blues. He co-founded the music publishing company, Pace and Handy Publishing Co., in 1918 and then moved to New York. Handy went on to earn worldwide success with his blues and spiritual compositions. By the time of his death in 1958, Handy was revered as a legend. He is honored in Memphis by a statue and a park on Beale Street. -- While planning the festivities for the 150th anniversary of Memphis, Memphis Sesquicentennial, Inc., under the direction of Brandon Davis, concluded that a stamp commemorating W.C. Handy would bring publicity to the city. A contest for a design was held, and the winning design, submitted by Bernice Kochan, was sent to the United States Post Office. The stamp was issued in Memphis on May 17, 1969. -- The W.C. Handy Collection, which relates primarily to the efforts to have a stamp created in Handy’s honor, consists of material which was gathered from individual donations and other collections. The collection includes the request for the W.C. Handy stamp, artistic designs and financial documents. These items were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Edward Williams, III, who handled the finances of the Memphis Stamp Collectors Society, which was instrumental in requesting the stamp. Also included are some of Handy’s personal letters and music, as well as information pertaining to the Handy memorial statue on Beale Street.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Beale Street; entertainment; Handy Park; music; parks; postage stamps; statues;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Papers of the Reverend George C. Harris
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Reverend George C. Harris, a native of Mississippi, served as Assistant Minister at St. Mary’s Episcopal Cathedral in Memphis from 1871 to 1872, and as Dean of the Cathedral from 1873 to 1880. The collection consists of correspondence related to Harris’ remarkable service to his parishioners and the citizens of Memphis during the yellow fever epidemics of the 1870s, business papers from the Harris family cattle and cotton farms and a scrapbook. The papers were gathered from The Yellow Fever Collection and The Montgomery Family Papers from the Memphis and Shelby County Room. -- Reverend Harris was ordained in 1860 and served as a Confederate chaplain during the Civil War. After the war, he settled in Memphis and began serving at St. Mary’s. During the yellow fever epidemics of 1873, 1878 and 1879, Reverend Harris sent his family to the Annandale Plantation in Canton, Mississippi, and the collection contains letters from his wife and children written to him during these periods. Reverend Harris remained at the Cathedral throughout the epidemics, and the collection includes correspondence related to his extraordinary efforts to recruit volunteers and raise funds from all over the United States to help the people of Memphis who were plagued by disease and death. -- In addition to his duties at St. Mary’s, Reverend Harris and his family owned agricultural properties they inherited from his family and that of his wife, Helen Johnstone Harris. The papers include correspondence, bills and receipts related to the family’s responsibilities on these farms. -- Reverend Harris kept a large scrapbook containing sermons, poems and newspaper clippings which reflect his personal interests such as providing aid to orphans, the yellow fever epidemics and his fellow clergy members at St. Mary’s Cathedral.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: agriculture; cattle; clergy; cotton; disease; epidemics; family; health; public service; religion; yellow fever;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Ashton Hayes Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: James Ashton Hayes, distinguished Memphis educator, was born in Hopkinsville, Kentucky in 1865. Hayes received his A.B. degree in 1911 from Lane College in Jackson, Tennessee, where he was an active participant in scholastic and athletic groups. -- Early in his career, Hayes taught at schools in Kentucky and Tennessee. While teaching in Kentucky, he was also an organizer of the Domestic Life Insurance Company of Louisville. His interest in athletics led him to accept a coaching position at Tennessee A&I University in Nashville. From Nashville, Hayes came to Memphis, where his first job was as football coach at Booker T. Washington High School. He served a short term as principal of Douglass High School before being named principal of Manassas High School, a position he held for twenty-three years. -- When Hayes assumed leadership of Manassas, the school was inadequate for the needs of a rapidly expanding student body. Under Hayes’ strong leadership, a new Manassas High School was built in the mid-1930s. Hayes was not only an accomplished administrator but also a humanitarian who brought his staff and students through the hard days of the Great Depression. -- Hayes was an active participant in civic, church and public service organizations. As an educator and civic leader, he provided an outstanding role model for fellow teachers as well as for students. Hayes’ interest in his students extended beyond their years at Manassas, and he encouraged them to continue their education in college or in other areas of training. -- When the accreditation of Memphis public high schools required that each principal hold a master’s degree in education, Hayes stepped down so that a qualified younger man might be named principal of Manassas. He served an additional two years as principal of Lester Elementary School before retiring from the field of education in 1955. When James Ashton Hayes died in 1961, he was mourned by thousands of Memphians who held him in great esteem. -- The James Ashton Hayes Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Hayes’ widow, Rosalind Ross Hayes. It consists of correspondence, newspaper clippings, programs and photographs. A large scrapbook contains photographs, newspaper clippings, greeting cards, letters and awards. The bulk of the printed material is from 1953 and 1955 testimonial dinners honoring Hayes for his years of service as an educator and especially for his leadership as principal of Manassas High School. Many of the photographs depict Manassas students and faculty, while others are of Hayes and his professional colleagues. Of particular interest are the earlier photographs from Hayes’ years as a student at Lane College in Jackson, Tennessee, and from summers spent as a college worker at Dawson Springs State Park in Dawson Springs, Kentucky.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; education; public service; schools; teachers;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Historical and Genealogical Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Historical and Genealogical Collection is a compilation of loose historical and genealogical papers and miscellaneous documents which have been given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by various individuals. Some of the papers are “found items” that came from attics and estate sales. The materials in the collection will assist individuals who are compiling family histories, as well as researchers seeking biographical and historical data. The finding aid to the collection has been organized by name and date. Additionally, the collection has been sorted by record type to assist researchers in finding particular types of documents. -- The collection includes the papers of Jean Robertson Anderson, which include a description of Jackson, Tennessee’s early town square written by Charles Barth in 1825 and information on more than 21 surnames. Other examples of documents in the collection are an 1865 furlough request by E.E. Elam, which describes him as “six foot high with a dark complexion,” an 1827 petition from heirs of Robert Goodloe who wanted to divide the land he left in his will and a probate document dated October 20, 1815, which explains the future ownership of Marriah, a ten-year-old slave girl. Valuable historical resources such as Bible records, letters and a Civil War journal are also included in the collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Frank Holloman Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Frank C. Holloman was born in Itta Bena, Mississippi, and grew up in nearby Ruleville. After graduating from Ruleville High School in 1932, Holloman attended the University of Mississippi, where he earned a law degree in 1937. Later that year he joined the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a Special Agent, and he served with this organization for the next twenty five years. -- During his service with the FBI, Holloman acted as Special Agent in Charge at the Atlanta, Cincinnati, Jackson, Mississippi and Memphis offices and conducted security inspections of South American war production plants. Perhaps most importantly, he was the inspector in charge of Director J. Edgar Hoover’s Washington office from 1949 to 1959. -- After retiring from the FBI in 1964, Holloman was named Director of Development for Memphis State University and then Executive Director of the Mid-South Medical Center Council. In 1968, Holloman was appointed the first Fire and Police Director of Memphis. Leaving the Memphis Police Department in October of 1970, Holloman became Coordinator of Security for the University of Missouri. He remained there in a full-time capacity until 1972 and served as part-time coordinator until 1978. Holloman returned to Memphis in 1972 to become Executive Director of Future Memphis, Inc., a position he held until his retirement in 1980. -- The Frank Holloman Collection, which was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Holloman, consists of personal letters, photographs and official documents spanning Holloman’s professional life. The collection includes material related to his service in the FBI and the Memphis Police Department, and the material gives details related to the inner workings of these law enforcement agencies. The material related to Holloman’s service as Fire and Police Director in Memphis is especially significant, because his period of service was marked by important events such as the sanitation workers’ strike and the assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr. Frank Holloman died in 1997 and is remembered as a man dedicated to law enforcement who served the citizens of Memphis during a very difficult period in its history.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: assassination; civil rights; Federal Bureau of Investigation; King, Martin Luther, Jr.; law enforcement; politics; public service; sanitation strike;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hugh Higbee Huhn Theater Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One of the most colorful chapters in the history of American journalism began in the late 19th century. In New York, fierce battles for circulation raged between newspaper publishers Joseph Pulitzer and William Randolph Hearst, who ran screaming headlines over the most sensational stories they could find. Eventually, newspapers nationwide followed suit. Although some periodicals were more respectful than others, all strove to entertain readers, not just inform them. -- This era gave birth to the career of Hugh Higbee Huhn, one of the South’s most respected drama critics. Huhn wrote for several Memphis newspapers in the early 1890s prior to working for The Commercial Appeal from 1897 to 1918. -- In those days, performers could not rely on movies or television to advance their careers, so they depended on national tours. Through his work as critic for the newspaper, Huhn was able to meet and befriend actresses Sarah Bernhardt and Ethel Barrymore, magician Harry Houdini, the minstrel Al G. Field and many other entertainers as they traveled around the country performing. The walls of Huhn’s office at The Commercial Appeal were lined with autographed photos of celebrities and his desk drawers were stuffed with letters from them. -- Huhn was born in Memphis in 1872, the son of accountant John Huhn and Mary Cowden. He worked briefly for Cole Manufacturing Co., and at Nick Williams’ bookstore. Huhn’s aunt, Jennie Higbee, got him his first newspaper job in the early 1890s at the Appeal-Avalanche. In 1894, The Commercial bought the paper, and Huhn left to work for the then-new Lyceum Theatre, where he worked in the box office, and then as press agent for the second Lyceum after the original theater burned down. Three years later he returned to journalism as a reporter for The Commercial Appeal. -- For years, Huhn filled an enormous amusements section in each Sunday paper. He is best remembered as a drama critic, but his assignments also included covering the police beat and writing editorials and political pieces. He also wrote about nature, and the annual arrival of the circus. From 1903 to1905 he served a term in the Tennessee General Assembly. He was also a nature lover, an inveterate walker in Overton Park and an owner and enthusiast of pure-bred dogs. -- In 1918, Huhn was 46 and living at 1882 Jefferson in Midtown Memphis when he was stricken with paralysis. He died four months later, and is buried in Elmwood Cemetery. Huhn was survived by his wife of two years, May Dunn Buchanan Huhn. -- After Huhn’s death, his widow became something of an institution at The Commercial Appeal. In 1918 May Huhn was hired as the newspaper’s switchboard operator. Her home became a temporary rooming house for new reporters, as well as a gathering place for morning chats over coffee. She stayed at the newspaper for 42 years, retiring in 1960. -- The Hugh Higbee Huhn Theater Collection consists primarily of articles and mementos from Huhn’s longtime career with Memphis newspapers, particularly The Commercial Appeal. Theater reviews, which comprise a major portion of the collection, are just a sampling of the enormous volume of material Huhn produced from the early 1890s until 1918. The collection also contains photographs, correspondence, scrapbooks and ticket stubs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Blair Theodore Hunt Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Blair Theodore Hunt prominent Memphis educator, clergyman and civic leader, was the son of former slaves Blair Theodore and Emma Clark Hunt. He was a graduate of LeMoyne College and also received degrees from Morehouse College, Roger Williams College and Tennessee State University. Hunt married Ernestine Jacobs in 1918, and they had two sons, Wilson and Ernest. -- Hunt began his career as an educator in the Memphis Public School System in 1925 as principal of Kortrecht School. He was the principal of La Rose School from 1926 to 1932. From 1932 to 1959 he served as principal of Booker T. Washington High School, where he influenced many of the city’s future leaders. Among his most outstanding students was Benjamin Lawson Hooks, the first black member of the Federal Communications Commission and the Executive Director of the NAACP. After his retirement Hunt became the first African American member of the Shelby County Board of Education. -- For a number of years, Hunt was pastor of Mississippi Boulevard Christian Church, where his sermons were an inspiration to many in the African American community. He began his career in the clergy as a chaplain with the rank of lieutenant in the U.S. Army during World War I. During World War II, he served as local chairman of the Office of Price Administration and the Office of Civil Defense, and he was the first African American to serve on the Tennessee Draft Board. Hunt was active in the Urban League, the Travelers Aid Society, the Y.M.C.A. and the Y.W.C.A. He was also an active supporter of the United Negro College Fund. -- The Blair T. Hunt Papers were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by his family and Hunt’s long-time colleague and close friend, Ms. Harry Mae Simons. The papers include materials related to his personal life and his work as an educator and clergy member. Because a good deal of Hunt’s work was accomplished over the telephone and in personal conferences, the papers only hint at the respect held for him by countless Memphians, and the crucial role he played as a mediator in the city. -- Mr. Hunt received numerous accolades in appreciation for his years of service in Memphis, including having Blair T. Hunt Boulevard named after him. A few of these numerous honors are documented in the collection. The papers also include copies of many of his sermons, which were regularly printed in the Memphis World, and which exemplify his gift for oratory. In addition, the collection contains Hunt’s personal records, books from his personal library, correspondence, photographs and drafts of speeches.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; churches; clergy; education; LeMoyne College; public service; religion; Y.M.C.A.;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Office Files of Robert B. James
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Robert B. James served on the Memphis City Council from 1968 to 1988. During his twenty years as councilman, he accumulated many documents related to council business, as well as material from other organizations and events with which he was associated. The James collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mr. James, his wife Patrice and his children, Stephen and Linda, shortly after his retirement from the City Council. Mr. James has served as an active member of the Friends of the Library, and assisted in preparing the collection for use by researchers. -- The collection is a valuable resource for those researching Memphis during the latter half of the 20th century. It includes materials on a wide range of issues faced by the city including annexation, the city budget, crime, law enforcement and traffic. Information on development projects such as Beale Street, the Agricenter, Church Park and the Mid-America Mall, and material on Memphis streets and neighborhoods are also included in the collection. -- James was born in Chariton, Iowa, in 1908. It was here that he received his first business experience, working in farm marketing from 1925 until 1934. During this time he also attended the University of Iowa for two years. He was later employed by Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for four years before opening his own business, Memphis Building Maintenance, in 1938. He retired from this business after thirty years, and he served on the Memphis City Council from the time of his retirement. -- During James’ years on the city council, Memphis experienced much turmoil and growth. The first year of his first term saw a divisive strike by sanitation workers which culminated in the assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr. These events made Memphians aware of the need to face a variety of economic and social issues, and these issues were often discussed and addressed by the council. -- Leaders in Memphis were also concerned with attracting tourists and conventions to the city during James’ tenure. In addition to bringing temporary exhibits and artistic presentations to Memphis, city leaders began to make more long-range plans. Mr. James was involved in council decisions which made the development of Mud Island possible, as well as the building of the Cook Convention Center and the Pyramid. -- James held an interest in a broad range of civic matters. He was chairman of the Chickasaw Basin Authority from 1972 to 1982, and is perhaps best known for his work with this organization. In addition, he served as chair of the State Parole Board and head of the Mississippi-Arkansas-Tennessee Council of Governments. James also founded and served as chair of the local Crimestoppers, Inc., and viewed this as one of his greatest successes. -- In addition to his experience in business and politics, Mr. James served the city through volunteer work. Mr. James devoted many hours to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center through his role as president of the Friends of the Library. James was also an accomplished painter, and for an extended period he paid weekly visits to the Shelby County Penal Farm, where he volunteered as an art instructor.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: annexation; arts; city council; crime; development; economics; farm marketing; government; law enforcement; municipal government; painting; politics; public service; sanitation strike; social issues; tourism;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Kennedy Book Club Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Whitehaven in the early 1900s was a small community with two churches, a school with some forty pupils, two stores and about twenty homes. Each afternoon a group of young ladies who called themselves the Whitehaven Walking Club took a walk together. In the fall of 1902 members of the walking club met to organize what was to become the Kennedy Book Club. The group was organized to fill a need which these young women felt for a social and cultural organization, and was part of a national movement of study clubs for women which came into existence at the turn of the century. Founding member Elizabeth Farrow suggested that the club be named in honor of Sara Beaumont Kennedy, a well-known author and prominent club woman. The group created through this small beginning was to play a major leadership role in Whitehaven for a century. -- Members met semi-monthly on Saturday afternoons from October to June in members’ homes. Roll call was answered with famous quotations, and members prepared and presented programs, followed by a social hour and usually a concert. The club adopted as its motto “to recognize and to enrich life” and selected red and white as the club colors. During the club’s early years, the women studied a wide variety of topics including American literature, the Wars of America, the countries of Europe and American drama. -- By 1940, the Kennedy Book Club had one hundred members, and meetings were held in the Community Room at the Whitehaven School. During the war years, the club chose the theme International News and Views for its course of study. Members took classes in first-aid and nursing, and the club promoted home garden and conservation programs and also made bandages for the Red Cross. -- In 1968 members decided to withdraw from the demanding activities of the Tennessee Federation of Women’s Clubs, which the club had joined in 1907, and instead, use their money to support community projects and scholarships. The Whitehaven Public Library, Memphis Preparatory School and the Bethany Maternity Home were among the many recipients of the club’s fund-raising efforts. In 2002 the decision was made to disband the Kennedy Book Club and make a gift of its assets to the Memphis and Shelby County Room. -- The Kennedy Book Club Collection was donated by Adrienne Davis, past president and long-time member. The collection spans the one hundred year history of the club from its founding in 1902 to the Centennial Celebration Luncheon in 2002. The collection is composed of correspondence, documents, written histories of the club, newspaper clippings used for study, book reviews, agendas and minutes, financial records and bazaar records. The collection also contains a virtually complete set of yearbooks, as well as scrapbooks, memorabilia, plaques and photographs. -- From its beginning in 1902 the Kennedy Book Club made significant cultural and educational contributions in Whitehaven. The Kennedy Book Club Collection provides information regarding the growth, development and transition in the club and in the community. The club’s records show that its history parallels the history of the national women’s study club movement, which was founded to raise the educational and cultural aspirations of women. Through a study of The Kennedy Book Club Collection, researchers can trace the change in emphasis from self-education to philanthropy and service to the community.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Judge Samuel O. Bates Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Samuel O. Bates, a major figure in the Memphis legal community in the 20th century, was born in Ogden, Arkansas, a town named for his mother’s family. In 1899, he came to Memphis to attend Christian Brothers College and graduated with honors in 1904. He received his L.L.B. from Catholic University in Washington, D.C., in 1906 and was admitted to the Bar upon returning to Memphis the same year. -- Shortly after moving back to Memphis, Bates was elected an alderman of Lenox, then an eastern suburb of Memphis. After a brief period of practicing law in a private firm, Bates was appointed Assistant District Attorney. Early in his career, Bates became aware that many poor people did not have equal access to legal representation, so he used his influence to secure the passage of a Public Defender Law for Shelby County. Only Oklahoma City and Los Angeles preceded Shelby Counn providing public defenders. Bates eventually went on to serve as Memphis City Court Judge, Shelby County Attorney General, State Representative and State Senator. -- In 1934 Bates was appointed to fill a vacant position as Probate Judge, and he was elected to the position later that year. He served in this position until 1947, when he resigned to become vice president and general counsel for the Commerce Title Guaranty Co. Bates, whose father was born in Kilkenny, Ireland, was quite proud of his Irish heritage. He was a founding member of the Irish Society of Memphis, and served as its president for the first ten years of its existence. He served as president of the Kiwanis Club and as co-chairman of the Memphis Round Table of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, and was active in various other civic and service organizations. He was a political associate of E.H. Crump, and maintained his interest in local government after retiring from public service. -- The Judge Samuel O. Bates Papers primarily consist of correspondence from 1934, the year he became a probate judge. The collection includes personal letters, correspondence concerning the Irish Society and professional correspondence. The papers also contain Judge Bates’ obituary and an article about one of his earliest statements as a judge.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bates, Samuel Ogden; courts; duck hunting; family; government; Irish Society of Memphis; law; Lenox; mayors; politics; public service; social life;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sara Beaumont Kennedy Literary Collection with Papers of Walker Kennedy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sara Beaumont Cannon, a descendant of several prominent Revolutionary War soldiers, was born in Somerville, Tennessee in 1859. She was educated at St. Mary’s Hall in Raleigh, North Carolina, and began writing poetry while still a school girl. -- After returning to Tennessee, she continued writing, and asked Walker Kennedy, the talented new editorial writer of the Commercial Appeal, to critique her work. A friendship developed, and they were married in 1888. -- Sara Beaumont Kennedy was a prolific writer and was recognized nationally as one of the outstanding literary figures of her day. She wrote a poetry book called One Wish, a children’s book, two novels and numerous short stories, many of which were published in national magazines. Her poetry was regularly featured in the Commercial Appeal, and appeared in various national publications. -- Kennedy learned about journalism and the newspaper business alongside her husband, Walker Kennedy. After his death, she joined the editorial staff of the Commercial Appeal and came to be known as “the only woman paragrapher” of a major newspaper in the South. Her pieces for the Commercial Appeal reflect Kennedy’s wide variety of interests and her vast knowledge of history, the arts and nature. -- Sara Beaumont Kennedy died in 1920 and was buried in Elmwood Cemetery. In 1925 her portrait was made a part of the Brooks Memorial Art Gallery collection. -- Walker Kennedy was born in 1857 in Louisville, Kentucky. He began his career in journalism with the Louisville Courier—Journal, under the tutelage of the illustrious Henry Watterson. He moved to Memphis and joined the staff of the Memphis Appeal for a year before going to work in Nashville as the chief editorial writer for the Nashville American. He returned to Memphis and co-founded The Sunday Times. In 1896 he was named chief editorial writer of the Commercial Appeal, a position he held until his death in 1909. -- Like his wife, Walker Kennedy enjoyed success as a fiction writer. He published three novels, Javan Ben Seir, Secret of the Wet Woods and In the Dwellings of Silence, and contributed short stories and poems to several leading magazines. Sara and Walker Kennedy also shared a gift for public speaking and made frequent presentations at literary and civic gatherings. The Kennedy Book Club, a woman’s study club, was named in Sara’s honor, and she often lectured at the club meetings. -- The Sara Beaumont Kennedy Literary Collection with Papers of Walker Kennedy was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Sara’s nephew, Robert Hobson. The papers consist primarily of poems, short stories and editorials by Sara Kennedy and also include several books of poetry dating back to her years as a school girl. The collection also contains a scrapbook which belonged to Walker Kennedy and holds published short stories, poetry, speeches and editorials, as well as stories and tributes published at the time of his death. The finding aid to the collection includes a comprehensive list of the writings written by Sara and Walker Kennedy which are included in the papers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Searcy Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Elizabeth Searcy was born in Memphis in 1877. Her father, Captain Mark W. Searcy, had served as a scout with Nathan Bedford Forrest and was the superintendent of the Memphis Board of Health. Elizabeth attended Miss Higbee’s School and studied art in Philadelphia. -- She went on to become a highly successful artist, specializing in etchings and watercolors. Elizabeth taught art at St. Mary’s Hall in Burlington, New Jersey, and established studios in New York City and Washington, D.C. Her work is included in the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Smithsonian Institution and the Library of Congress. -- Searcy also received several commissions from First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt. She painted a portrait of President Roosevelt and several different views of the White House and the president’s birthplace. The First Lady gave several of Searcy’s paintings to her husband as Christmas gifts and also praised her work in her daily newspaper column, My Day. -- In her later years Elizabeth returned to Memphis to live with her younger brother Albert and sister Marguerite. Albert Searcy was employed by Irwin-Leatherman Cotton Company and was a member of the United Sons of Confederate Veterans. Marguerite was employed by the New York Life Insurance Company for over thirty years, and as a young woman became a member of the United Daughters of Confederate Veterans and served as a sponsor of the Army of Tennessee United Confederate Veterans. -- The Searcy Collection, which was willed to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Elizabeth Searcy, contains letters exchanged between Elizabeth and Eleanor Roosevelt regarding her artwork and commissions. The papers also include mementoes such as diplomas, scrapbooks and family Bibles reflecting the life and concerns of Elizabeth, Marguerite and Albert Searcy, their parents and members of their extended family. Materials related to Searcy family member Paul Shirley include papers from his naval career during and after the Civil War, such as naval appointment documents signed by Franklin Pierce, Abraham Lincoln and Ulysses S. Grant. This extensive collection, which covers the years 1836 to 1960, also contains clippings, photographs, negatives, engravings and Confederate currency.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leo M. Seligman Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Leo M. Seligman, who committed himself to helping men and women lead responsible and productive lives after prison, grew up in Germany in the early decades of the 20th Century. He was born in 1900 in Frankfurt-am-Main, Germany and served in the German army in World War I. In 1932, he was sent to a Nazi concentration camp – his “crime” was having been born a Jew. However, Seligman was fortunate enough to escape his brutal captors and flee to the United States in 1936. He married Esther Bass of Memphis in 1939 and became a citizen of the United States on December 24, 1940. He found a job working as a butcher and he and his wife eventually opened their own business. -- While struggling to start a grocery business in Memphis, Seligman encountered a customer who would purchase a specific amount of food once a week, spending only a very small amount of money. He asked the man about his spending and discovered that he could only spend a small amount of money at a time because he was on parole from prison and was trapped in an exploitive work environment. Seligman felt that this man was being treated unfairly and should receive a living wage for his skilled labor. He agreed to supervise the man’s parole, and through this experience, his concern for the dignity and well-being of former prisoners began to grow. -- Seligman used his own money and sought out other financial assistance and community resources to help improve the lives of parolees. He became chair of the Optimist Club Rehabilitation Committee, and through this position he worked to secure positive changes in correctional procedures, provide opportunities for employment and improve parole practices. His efforts led to him becoming nationally known as a spokesperson for former prisoners and an expert on improving penal and parole practices. -- A high point in Seligman’s life was his appearance on the TV program, This Is Your Life, in recognition for his work with prisoners and parolees. He was given a new Edsel car and received a variety of accolades, including invitations to appear at national correctional and employment conferences and letters from prominent individuals. He went on to be featured in a number of publications including the magazines Reader’s Digest and Inside Detective. He also received honors from numerous organizations including the Optimist Club, the Sertoma Club and the Daughters of the American Revolution. -- Seligman helped nearly 2,000 parolees obtain a fresh start in life. He assisted the former prisoners in obtaining employment, proper clothing and a suitable place to live. He also saw that the men had enough money until they received their first paycheck. His continued advocacy for parolees reflected his statement that, “I am my brother’s keeper.” -- The Leo M. Seligman Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Ernest W. Stix, Jr. and Hattie Bass in July 1998. The collection includes newspaper clippings, photographs and awards, as well as interviews with journalists who wrote about Seligman’s early life, his struggle to build a new business and his determination to help former prisoners. Also included is correspondence with law enforcement officials and representatives from employment organizations. Significant portions of the collection relate to Seligman’s appearance on This Is Your Life.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reverend Eron M. Sharp Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eron Malcolm Sharp was born in Leake County, Mississippi in 1904. He graduated from Millsaps College in Jackson, Mississippi, and became a Methodist minister after receiving an M.A. in Religious Education from Duke University. Reverend Sharp was pastor for several churches during his career, including Hernando First United Methodist Church, Aberdeen First United Methodist Church, New Albany First United Methodist Church and Greenwood First United Methodist Church. -- Sharp was secretary of the North Mississippi Conference of the Methodist Church for seventeen years and edited the Conference Journal. He also served as Chair of the conference Historical Society for several terms and assisted in establishing the Methodist State Archives at Millsaps College. He was among the founders of Lake Stephens United Methodist Camp in Oxford, Mississippi and served on its board for several years. -- After his retirement from the clergy, Sharp worked as an Assistant Circulation Librarian at Memphis State University for ten years. He also taught Bible studies classes at Grenada College and served for seven years as the first Chaplain at Wesley Highland Towers, a Memphis retirement home. -- In addition to his work in the community and the Methodist Church, Reverend Sharp was a highly skilled and experienced genealogist. He wrote several genealogy and local history books and collected a large number of genealogical resources. The Reverend E. M. Sharp Collection, which consists of genealogical material, was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Reverend Sharp’s widow, Alma Blissit Sharp, after his death. The papers contain much information that will be useful to local historians and genealogists. The collection consists of genealogical information on families from several southeastern states and includes census records, Bible records, wills, church records, deeds, pedigree charts, photographs, marriage records, pension records, military service records, land grants and numerous other genealogical records. Data on hundreds of families can be accessed through the comprehensive finding aid to the collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thomas T. Hill Shelby Farms Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Thomas T. Hill Shelby Farms Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Christopher A. Mekow, a park ranger in Shelby Farms, who used the material to write a history of the park. Mekow received the papers from Thomas Hill, who served as an administrator of Shelby Farms for 12 years. Once he had completed his research in 2000, Mekow gave the material to the library. -- The collection includes extensive correspondence to and from Hill during his time as an administrator of Shelby Farms along with minutes from staff meetings, memos, newspaper clippings and photographs. Hill was named superintendent of the park in 1984, and during his tenure he received considerable recognition for his outstanding achievements. When he retired in 1996, the Shelby Farms Board made him Superintendent Emeritus to honor his exceptional leadership and special contributions to the park. -- Hill’s duties as superintendent of Shelby Farms included supervising some 20 employees, establishing regulations for the shooting range and recreation areas and overseeing the management of a 4,500 acre nature preserve. Additional responsibilities included directing the maintenance of the park, serving as a liaison with various community officials, including the Director of Public Works and consulting with the Shelby Farms Board. -- Hill helped develop a detailed master plan for park services, as well as proposals for its future development. He worked with public officials and private citizens to enhance and preserve Shelby Farms, which is the world’s largest urban park. Hill continually addressed the concerted efforts of real estate developers to construct a major highway through Shelby Farms to increase access to suburbs in east Shelby County. His energies were often focused on environmental challenges and complex aspects of forestry development and maintenance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maxine A. Smith NAACP Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Maxine Atkins was born in 1929, the youngest of the three children of Joseph and Georgia Rounds Atkins. Maxine graduated from Booker T. Washington High School at age 15 in 1945. She went on to earn a Bachelor’s degree in biology from Spelman College in 1949 and a Master’s degree in French from Middlebury College in Vermont. She was assistant professor of French at Prairie View A&M University in Prairie View, Texas and at Florida A&M University in Tallahassee. She also taught briefly at LeMoyne College following her marriage to Dr. Vasco A. Smith, Jr., in 1955 and before the birth of their son, Vasco A. Smith, III in 1956. -- In 1957, Maxine Smith, along with Laura Sugarmon, was denied admission to the Memphis State University graduate program. This injustice inspired Smith to begin her involvement in the work of the Memphis Branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which had been organized by Robert R. Church, Jr., and other leaders of the African American community in 1918. In 1962, Smith was named Executive Secretary of the Memphis Branch, and she served tirelessly in that position until her retirement in 1995. Throughout her involvement with the NAACP, particularly in her role as Executive Secretary, Smith was a major force in shaping and directing the work of this organization at the local and national level. -- In addition to her work with the NAACP, Smith received national recognition for her significant contributions to urban education. In 1971, Smith was the first African American to be elected to the Memphis Board of Education, and she served as Board of Education President for two terms. In 1994, Governor Ned McWherter appointed Smith to the Tennessee Board of Regents, which is the governing body for many public colleges and universities throughout the state. -- Throughout her career, Smith has received countless awards for her commitment to education, social justice and civil rights. Along with former president Bill Clinton, Smith was the recipient of the prestigious Freedom Award presented by the National Civil Rights Museum in 2003. Smith was also awarded the Doctor of Humane Letters from her alma mater, Spelman College in 2004. -- The Maxine A. Smith NAACP Collection was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mrs. Smith in 1996 following her retirement in 1995 as Executive Secretary of the Memphis Branch. The extensive collection provides highly-detailed documentation of the efforts of the NAACP to ensure equal rights for African Americans through a wide-range of actions such as meeting with elected officials, holding voter registration drives, requesting investigations of police brutality and coordinating protests, boycotts, circulating petitions, picketing and sit-ins to integrate public facilities. The material, which covers the years 1958 through 1995, includes correspondence, meeting agendas, annual reports, scrapbooks and a large collection of newspaper clippings. The collection documents the Memphis Branch’s local efforts such as investigating individual’s complaints of workplace discrimination at local businesses, and national efforts such as advocating for the conformation of Thurgood Marshall as a U.S. Supreme Court Justice. There are gaps in the material, some of which was lost in the several moves of the local office or from water damage; nevertheless, there is enough continuity in the collection to provide a clear and detailed picture of the activities of the organization and the important role of the Executive Secretary in shaping and accomplishing the goals of the Memphis Branch.

1 THE MAXINE A. SMITH NAACP COLLECTION 2004 Processed by Patricia M. LaPointe Curator MEMPHIS AND SHELBY COUNTY ROOM Memphis/Shelby County Public Library & Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue, Memphis, TN 38111 2 Maxine A. Smith - NAACP Collection MAXINE A. SMITH—BIOGRAPHY No single individual in Memphis has been more uniquely associated with an organization than has Maxine Atkins Smith with the Memphis Branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Soon after her marriage in 1955, Smith became an active member of the Memphis Branch, serving as Executive Secretary from 1962 until her retirement from that position in December 1995. Over the years, she has become the personification of the organization. Still active in civil rights and social justice, Smith was honored recipient in 2003 of the prestigious Freedom Award presented by the National Civil Rights Museum. She shared this honor with former President Bill Clinton. Most recently she was awarded the Doctor of Humane Letters from her alma mater, Spelman College in Atlanta. Countless awards, honors, and two doctoral degrees have been bestowed on the woman who has spent the greater part of her life fighting battles that few would choose or long endure. Such commitment is all the more extraordinary in the face of serious health problems that have taken their toll on the woman who has symbolized Black rights in Memphis. While Smith has had the guidance and counsel of equally dedicated Black leaders in business, law, education and ministry, her strongest support throughout the years has come from her husband, Dr. Vasco A. Smith, Jr., who has shared his wife’s dedication to the struggle for human dignity and human rights. Elected to the County Commission (then the Shelby County Court) in 1973, Dr. Smith served in this government body until his retirement from active political life in 1994. He has been a lifetime partner with his wife in every phase of their commitment to social justice, health, education, and political participation in the democratic process. Maxine Atkins was born October 31, 1929, the youngest of three children born to Joseph P. and Georgia Rounds Atkins. Maxine’s mother was a homemaker and her father an employee of the U.S. Postal Service. From him she inherited that outspoken quality which refused to accept second class citizenship and discriminatory treatment. Maxine graduated from Booker T. Washington High School in 1945 (at age 15), from Spelman College in Atlanta in 1949 with the A.B. degree in biology, and from Middlebury College in Vermont with an M.A. in French. She was assistant professor of French at Prairie View A&M University in Prairie View, Texas and at Florida A&M University in Tallahassee. Following her marriage to Dr. Vasco A. Smith, Jr., in 1955, Maxine Smith taught briefly at LeMoyne College prior to the birth of their son, Vasco A. Smith, III in 1956. 3 With two college degrees, Smith, along with Laura Sugarmon, was denied admission to the Memphis State University graduate program in 1957. This affront provided the impetus that began her involvement in the work of the Memphis Branch NAACP. She was, during her tenure as Executive Secretary, a major force in shaping and directing the work of this organization at the local, state and national levels. Smith believes her most important accomplishments have been in the field of education, and she has been recognized nationally for significant contributions to urban education. In 1971 Maxine Smith was the first Black elected to the Memphis Board of Education, later serving that body as president for two terms. In addition to her work in behalf of education, Maxine Smith has built a strong alliance with the Memphis business community. One of the most successful examples of this partnership has been the annual Freedom Fund Galas, which have drawn nationally prominent individuals as speakers and have provided the major source of the operating budget for the Memphis Branch. Active in the Democratic Party, Smith has had frequent contact with governors and members of Congress, as well as local elected officials. Her long tenure as Executive Secretary of the Memphis Branch NAACP, as well as her active role in the national organization, has brought Maxine Smith widespread recognition. For many, Maxine Smith represents the best of the Civil Rights Movement, while for others in the community her outspoken demands for justice and equality have garnered a wide range of negative feelings. Not always conciliatory, Smith has been unflinching in her dedication to achieving full participation in the American Dream for African Americans. Not content to rest on past accomplishment, Smith continues to maintain an active schedule in support of her vision of equality and justice for all. 4 Maxine A. Smith – NAACP Collection SCOPE AND PROVENANCE The collection of materials designated as the Maxine A. Smith - NAACP Collection was given to the Library by Mrs. Smith in 1996 following her retirement in 1995 as Executive Secretary of the Memphis Branch. There are gaps in the material, some of which was lost in the several moves of the local office or from water damage; nevertheless, there is enough continuity in the collection to provide a clear and cogent picture of the activities of the organization and the important role of the Executive Secretary in shaping and accomplishing the goals of the Memphis Branch. The local NAACP chapter has been recognized repeatedly on the national level for its large membership, its state and regional leadership, and its outstanding accomplishments as a force for civil rights and social justice. The Memphis Branch of the NAACP not only provided regional leadership but also the National Executive Director Benjamin Lawson Hooks. Hooks worked closely with Smith and others in the Memphis Branch who held important national appointments. Under the leadership of Robert R. Church, Jr., the Memphis Branch of the NAACP was organized in 1918 with 53 leading members of the Memphis African American community. The role of this organization as the primary force for social justice in Memphis is clearly seen in the collection, which covers the years 1958 through 1995. Soon after World War II, a small but dedicated core of Black Memphians undertook an uphill battle to achieve racial equality in the life and work of this community. In 1962 the Memphis Branch named Maxine A. Smith as Executive Secretary, little realizing at that time the wide-ranging impact of her work and dedication to social justice. The early civil rights work of this group was catapulted into the national spotlight following the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., as the Sanitation Workers’ Strike, which started as a labor protest, became the catalyst for major civil rights action. The papers also show that after Dr. King’s death, the local NAACP branch became more aggressive in demands for equality in the economic and political life of this city, including the full integration of public education, housing, employment, and the development of economic opportunity for Black-owned businesses. Because of the size of this collection guide, brief notes in the Table of Contents will assist the researcher to locate material by date or by subject. The introduction to each box provides a more extensive description of its contents, which is followed by a description of each folder. The Annual Reports made by the Executive Secretary provide the best summary of each year’s work and note the disappointments, successes, and the unwavering commitment of the NAACP, Memphis Branch to full civil rights for Black Americans. 5 Maxine A. Smith - NAACP Collection BIBLIOGRAPHY The following short list of books and manuscript collections is appended to the Smith Collection guide to assist those interested in further researching Memphis history after World War II, particularly in the Civil Rights period. BOOKS Bailey, D’Army. Mine Eyes Have Seen: Dr. Martin Luther King’s Final Journey. 1993. Beifuss, Joan Turner. At the River I Stand: Memphis, the 1968 Strike, and Martin Luther King. 1985. Bond, Beverly G. and JanAnn Sherman. Memphis in Black and White. 2003. Herenton, W. W. “A Historical Study of School Desegregation in the Memphis City Schools, 1954-1970.” 1971. Lewis, Selma S. “Social Religion and the Memphis Sanitation Strike.” 1976. ________. “Diversification and Unity: MIFA, 1968-1988.” 1988. Memphis Publishing Company. I Am a Man: Photographs of the Sanitation Strike and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., 1993. Melton, Gloria Brown. Blacks in Memphis, Tennessee, 1920-1955. 1982. Turner, Allegra W. and Jini M. Kilgore. Except by Grace: the Life of Jesse H. Turner. 2004. Wax, Jonathan I. “Program of Progress, A Step Into the Present: Change in the form of Government of Memphis, Tennessee.” 1968. Withers, Ernest C. Let us March On! :Selected Civil Rights Photographs of Ernest C. Withers 1955 – 1968. 1992. MANUSCRIPT COLLECTIONS The Roberta Church Collection Mayor Watkins Overton Papers The George W. Lee Collection Mayor Frank Tobey Papers The Rev. Frank L. McRae Papers Mayor Henry Loeb Papers The Rabbi James A. Wax Collection Mayor Wyeth Chandler Papers The A. W. Willis, Jr. Papers Frank R. Holloman Papers The Miriam DeCosta Willis Collection James W. “Jimmy” Moore Papers 6 Maxine A. Smith -NAACP Collection TABLE OF CONTENTS Box I ……………………………………………………………………………. Page 8 Executive Secretary, Monthly Agendas 1962 - 1989 Boxes I and II contain the detailed agendas from which the Executive Secretary made her report at monthly meetings of the Executive Board. These reports span 1962 through 1995; however, agendas are missing for a number of months because there was no meeting or the material was lost or damaged. There are no agendas for 1970 or 1980, and five years have only four or fewer items. Annual reports, which are included at the end of each year’s monthly agendas, provide an excellent summary of Memphis Branch activities and document the increasing scope and responsibilities of the Executive Secretary in local and national civil rights. Box II……………………………………………………………………………Page 120 Executive Secretary, Monthly Agendas 1990-1995 Box II contains material described above. Box III………………………………………………………………………… Page 140 Memphis Branch—Minutes of the Executive Board, 1958-1987 Box III contains 32 folders of Memphis Branch Executive Board Minutes, as well as Minutes of the Branch Meetings. Files do not contain a complete chronological run of these Minutes, either because some meetings were not held, or, as noted above, material was lost through water damage or in moves of the NAACP office. Box IV…………………………………………………………………………Page 153 Memphis Branch General Files—1960-1968 Box IV contains the general files of the Memphis Branch for the years 1960 through 1968 arranged in chronological order. Used with the collection as a whole, these early files do provide an overview of Memphis Branch activities during a significant decade in the Civil Rights movement. 7 Box V………………………………………………………………………… Page 159 Memphis Branch General Files—A-Z, 1969 Box V has a complete run of office files which cover an important year in Memphis Civil Rights and includes information on the Black Monday School Boycott, the Memphis and Shelby County Merger Study, and the Tribute Dinner for Jesse H. Turner, Sr., long-time NAACP, Memphis Branch President and civil rights leader. Box VI……………………………………………………………………… Page 166 Memphis Branch General Files—A-Z, 1986-1987 There is a gap from 1969 to 1986 in the General Files; however, the newspapers clippings and the Executive Secretary’s reports and correspondence enable the researcher to trace the monthly activities of the Memphis Branch. Box VI picks up in 1986 and these files show the broader scope of Memphis Branch activities such as involvement in the Culture of Poverty Think Tank, commitment to improve inner city schools, and the continuing efforts to improve the quality and accessibility of health care, especially for the poor. Box VII………………………………………………………………………Page 172 Memphis Branch General Files—A-Z, 1988 Box VII includes a great deal of material which continues to focus on public education, economic development in the Black community, Beale Street Redevelopment, the elimination of discrimination in all areas of public life and work, and the increased use of print and television by the Memphis Branch. Box VIII…………………………………………………………………….Page 180 Memphis Branch General Files—A-Z, 1989 Included in Box VIII are reports, information on legislation, especially as it pertains to Memphis City Schools, detailed information on the formation of the Lorraine Civil Rights Museum, and on going efforts directed toward full implementation of social justice and civil rights. Box IX………………………………………………………………………Page 184 Freedom Fund Dinners—1977-1996, Memphis Branch 8 The decade of the 1950s and 1960s were marked by financial struggles, and the Memphis Branch undertook a number of activities to raise money. The most successful was the establishment in 1977 of the Annual Freedom Fund Dinners, which attracted strong financial support from the community and increasingly prominent speakers and program participants. Box X…………………………………………………………………………..Page 188 Executive Secretary, Personal Correspondence—1968-1992 Box X includes the letters, invitations, and print material received by the Executive Secretary. Some of the material is of a purely personal nature, while most has a tie to Maxine Smith’s role as a civil rights activist. Box XI…………………………………………………………………………Page 198 Executive Secretary, Personal Correspondence—1993-1995 Material in Box XI includes the last three years of Smith’s personal correspondence and documents the high level of community involvement she maintained throughout her thirty-three years as Executive secretary of the Memphis Branch. Box XII……………………………………………………………………… Page 201 Executive Secretary, Correspondence Notebooks—1964-1972 Box XII contains the correspondence notebooks in which Maxine Smith wrote her letters in longhand, which were then typed by the Branch staff. They provide information on some years for which there are no other files or reports. Box XIII………………………………………………………………………Page 201 Executive Secretary, Correspondence Notebooks—1973-1988 Box XIII is a continuation of the notebooks described above. Box XIV………………………………………………………………………Page 201 Executive Secretary, Correspondence Notebooks—1988-1996 Box XIV contains the final batch of Smith’s correspondence notebooks. 9 Box XV………………………………………………………………………Page 201 Yearly Appointment Calendars—1990-1994 The annual appointment calendars in Box XV contain some appointments, as well as miscellaneous notes, phone numbers, etc. Box XVI…………………………………………………………………… Page 202 Awards and Photographs Box XVI contains some of the many awards and certificates Maxine Smith received during her long tenure as Memphis Branch Executive Secretary. There is also a group of photographs which represent only a fraction of the occasions when Smith would have been photographed; however, they do convey the variety of activities in which she was involved. Box XVII………………………………………………………………… Page 207 Tennessee Boards of Regents—1995 Box XVII includes material relating to Maxine Smith’s appointment to the Tennessee Board of Regents. The appointment, made by Governor Ned McWherter in 1994, was effective for one of the six-year rotating terms on the Board of Regents. Box XVIII…………………………………………………………………Page 211 Trial Transcript Case 87900 Box XVIII contains the above referenced transcript of a trial hearing of December 4, 1961, in which five young Black men and women were arrested and brought to trial for refusing to evacuate a downtown drugstore following a bomb threat. 10 SCRAPBOOKS AND NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS In addition to the correspondence, reports, and print material in Boxes I – XVIII, the Collection includes a large amount of newsprint. The Memphis Commercial Appeal, the Press- Scimitar, the Tri-State Defender, as well as neighborhood newspapers such as the Silver Saver, were regularly clipped by the Executive Secretary and the office staff, and on occasion Branch officers and members sent in clippings. The loose clippings have been organized chronologically and individually placed on gray mounts, the material on which Memphis Information File clippings are placed. (Because of the volume of clippings, mounting of earliest material is still in process.) The collection contains five newspaper clippings scrapbooks, which include articles from 1961-1966. There is considerable overlap in the later books. These books are important because they detail activities of the Memphis Branch in the 1960s prior to the changes that came about as a result of the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. The clippings reflect those issues and activities which were priority matters of the time. There is a heavy emphasis on all news items that pertain to the desegregation of the public schools and to the full integration of students, teachers, and auxiliary workers in the Memphis and Shelby County School System. Other topics include the elections of Blacks to public office and especially to the Memphis Board of Education, police brutality, the economic development of Black businesses and greater employment opportunities for African Americans, as well as matters of national interest such as presidential elections and of international importance such as the sanctions imposed against South Africa because of apartheid. Scrapbooks Box 1—Newspaper Clippings Scrapbook: 1961-1963 Box 2—Newspaper Clippings Scrapbook: 1965-1966 Box 3—Newspaper Clippings Scrapbook: 1964-1966 Box 4—Newspaper Clippings Scrapbook: 1965 only Box 5—Newspaper Clippings Scrapbook: 1965-1966 Newspaper Clippings Box 6 Clippings—1964, 1965, March 1976, January – March 1978, January – February, April, August – October 1980, and February 1982. 11 Box 7 Clippings—January – April 1979 Box 8 Clippings—May – June 1979 Box 9 Clippings—July – August 1979, October – December 1979 Box 10 Clippings—January – December 1981 Box 11 Clippings—October – December 1981, January – December 1982 Box 12 Clippings—January – May 1983 Box 13 Clippings—June – December 1983 Box 14 Clippings—January – December 1984 Box 15 Clippings—January – December 1985 Box 16 Clippings—January – December 1986 Box 17 Clippings—January – December 1987 12 Box 18 Clippings—January – December 1988 Box 19 Clippings—January – June 1989 Box 20 Clippings—July – December 1989 Box 21 Clippings—January – December 1990 Box 22 Clippings—January – August 1991 Box 23 Clippings—September – December 1991 Box 24 Clippings—January – December 1992 Box 25 Clippings—January – December 1993 Box 26 Clippings—January – December 1994 Box 27 Clippings—January-October 1995 Box 28 Clippings—November – December 1995, January – February 1996 13 Maxine A. Smith Collection Memphis Branch, NAACP Reports of the Executive Secretary Box I In April 1961, the Memphis Branch, NAACP hired its first Executive Secretary, whose duties officially began April 10, 1961. Maxine A. Smith filled that position until her retirement in 1995, playing a vital role in the organization. Boxes I and II contain reports of the Executive Secretary presented at the monthly meetings of the Executive Board. These reports are incomplete either because there was no meeting or the material was lost as a result of water damage from flooding or in the moves of the NAACP office. There are no reports for 1980, and six years have only four or fewer items. Annual reports, where available, are included at the end of the monthly reports for the appropriate year. Folder 1—Items 10 Agenda—April 10 - May 2, 1961 Major effort undertaken to intensify membership campaign through additional meetings and publicity. Mothers’ Day march for membership. May 21 program—music and publicity. Reports of Standing Committee meetings. Submission for Thalheimer award and for publication awards. Police brutality case re: Everett Johnson. Freedom movement publicity in black newspapers. Cotton Makers Jubilee—NAACP opposition to CMJ. Stay-away-from-downtown movement—pickets/publicity. Fund for freedom fight—need to seek donations. Recommendations for purchase of office equipment. Agenda—May 3 - June 6, 1961 Membership Campaign, including awards for various divisions with report of 4,756 members to date. May 21 program—report and publicity and attendance. Spring Extravaganza of Music. Arrest of Blacks at Fairgrounds. Letter sent to JUGS requesting not to use Goldsmith’s ticket office. Protests sent to officials regarding mistreatment of Black students by White students in Memphis State University cafeteria. 14 Resolutions adopted by NAACP re: policy brutality, pupil assignment policy, Board of Education. Letters of protest to Black businesses re: ads in Cotton Makers Jubilee programs. National NAACP Convention, July 10-16. Stay-away-from downtown movement includes school for pickets, new handbills, planned protest marches, and emphasis from Black pulpits. Reports of Standing Committees.
