Recommendations—purchase of office equipment; expense coverage for NAACP delegates to National Convention. Agenda—June 7 - July 18, 1961 School for sit-ins and pickets, June 7, 1961. Weekly freedom marches and sit-in movement; location of sit-ins given. Letter of commendation to Edmund Orgill, head of MATA, on hiring of Black bus drivers. Letters and telegrams of protest re: treatment of individuals and segregated facilities. Weekly neighborhood freedom rallies at churches. Black newspapers reporting weekly on NAACP activities. NAACP National Convention, July 10-16. Awards received by Memphis Chapter NAACP. Agenda—July 19 - August 1, 1961 Sit-in movement to emphasize this aspect of freedom work. Weekly freedom marches. Freedom Movement to include all stores on Main Street. Weekly neighborhood freedom rallies. Records of downtown store sales showing effect of boycott on sales. Letters sent requesting funds for freedom fight. NAACP office to be moved to Universal Life Insurance Company bldg. Agenda—August 2 - September 5, 1961 Sit-in demonstrations continue daily. Weekly freedom marches—plans for future marches. Fund for freedom fight; total collected to date $1,938.37. Expansion of efforts to boycott Main Street. Letters of protest to Commercial Appeal and Memphis Press-Scimitar, to Commissioner Moore and others. Complaint of alleged discrimination at International Harvester. NAACP office moved to 234 Hernando on August 20. Desegregation of public School system—emphasis on enrolling Black children in previously all-White schools. 15 Agenda—September 6 - October 3, 1961 Weekly freedom march reports—Owen College students will lead March Oct. 7. Sit-in movement—school opening has decreased participation; conflict with local navy and other military personnel. Freedom movement—efforts to intensify stay-away-from Main Street. Protests and complaints—re: discrimination in the Fire Dept., Post Office Dept. Letter of commendation to Bar Association and to a private citizen for protesting discrimination on public transportation. Reports of Standing Committees—mainly matters of legal redress. Weekly neighborhood freedom meetings. Protest re: segregated seating at Hawks-Royals basketball game. Fall membership campaign, Oct. 5-Nov.5, highlights of campaign. Public school desegregation—October 3, thirteen Black first graders went to four previously all-White schools: Bruce, Rozelle, Springdale, and Gordon. Agenda—October 3 - November 7, 1961 Fall membership campaign gained 700 adult members. Suit against the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company part of the Freedom Movement action—marches have been called off during negotiations with company. Freedom mass meeting—Nov. 5 meeting of 1,200 people to hear Percy Sutton, attorney for the New York Branch of the NAACP. Requests by individuals for employment assistance. Recommendation to purchase mimeograph machine and cabinet for supplies. Agenda—November 8 - December 5, 1961 On going efforts to increase Branch membership—emphasis on renewals. Downtown demonstrations and boycott suspended because Main Street merchants offered plan to integrate facilities and expand job opportunities for Blacks. NAACP Christmas seal and Christmas card drive. Equal employment opportunities action taken with Southern Bell T & T. Protest and Complaints filed in behalf of several individuals. Steps taken to desegregate Shelby County schools. Reports of Standing Committees—mainly relating to employment discrimination. Newspaper Publicity Release—December 17, 1961 The publicity report includes highlights of the civil rights actions taken by the Memphis Branch, NAACP for 1961. Noted was registration of Black voters, efforts to integrate public education facilities, policy brutality as a continued concern, discrimination in housing, failure to include Blacks on grand jury duty, efforts to alleviate employment discrimination, and Federal suits filed to desegregate all public facilities in Memphis. 16 Annual Report—1961 The Annual Report contains a summary of the organization’s actions as presented in the monthly reports, as well as reports on attendance at various conferences and regional meetings, political actions and related publicity, legal suits pertaining to desegregation, and protests of various discriminatory actions. Folder 2—Items 14 Agenda—December 6, 1961 - January 16, 1962 Equal employment efforts with Southern Bell T & T Company. Discriminatory practices at Tennessee Employment Security. Complaint by woman regarding beating at a service station. Protest re: seating at Oral Roberts religious crusade at City Auditorium. Complaint re: discrimination by Illinois Central Railroad. Memberships for 1961. Resignations of committee chairmen Laurie Sugarmon and Annie Crawford. Freedom Fund Committee report on raising money. Annual reports, including highlights of Branch activity/financial report. Recommendations re: intensive efforts to desegregate public schools. Agenda—January 17 - February 6, 1962 Letter to Ministers highlighting Branch activities. Selection of office secretary. Standing committee meetings—legal redress, membership, freedom fund. New filing system initiated. Letters of commendation to city commissioners on election of Dr. C. L. Dinkins. Investigation of discrimination in proposed research hospital administered by UT. Agenda—February 7 - March 6, 1962 Complaint re: Segregation at Front Street Theatre. Cotton Makers Jubilee—protest by NAACP challenged in court by CMJ officers. Non-partisan voter registration to organize 1962 voter registration. Membership campaign—extensive planning for large drive. Broadcast of NAACP Lincoln Day tape. Letter to School Superintendent E.C. Stimbert re: Miss Freedom Contest. Protest regarding police brutality sent to Claude Armour and local FBI. NAACP Regional Conference at Jackson, MS. Legal Redress Issues—Overton Park Shell, school case, Dobbs House. 17 Agenda—March 7 - April 3, 1962 Membership Campaign—all-out effort to enlist members led by ministers. Report on meeting of Tennessee State Conference of NAACP Branches-Mar. 17. Protest re: segregated Shrine Circus. Response to charges of police brutality received. Letter to E. C. Stimbert regarding Bluff City Teachers’ Assn. Legal redress—regarding desegregation of Dobbs Houses, school cases, etc Voter registration. Black Employment in Federal Agencies, including Postal Department. Black appointees to legal positions in US Attorney’s office. County School petition requesting desegregation of county schools . Agenda—April 4 - May 1, 1962 Protest regarding promotion of Judge Marion S. Boyd. Letters of commendation to Senators Gore and Kefauver for appointment of Odell Horton, Jr. to U.S. Attorneys office. Letter to Shelby County Court protesting action by Oakville Civic Club. Membership Campaign—detailed program given. Labor and Industry committee meeting to seek better job opportunities for Blacks. Meeting in Memphis with national government labor leaders/NAACP re: railroad discrimination suit. Petitions to desegregate County School System. Recommendations re: sending eight delegates to the NAACP National Convention in Atlanta. Workers’ Information and Instruction sheet for 1962 membership campaign. Agenda—May 2 - June 5, 1962 Massive NAACP action protesting promotion of Judge Marion S. Boyd. Letters urging Gore and Kefauver to hasten confirmation of Thurgood Marshall. Telegrams sent regarding debate on the literacy test bill. Protest to Commissioner Armour regarding conduct of police officers. Arrest of Mrs. Sanders of Jackson, MS at Memphis Airport Dobbs House. Merit Award to CME Bishop H. C. Bunton for work in the Freedom Movement. Federal Officials in Memphis for Civil Rights Hearing June 25-26. Conclusion of membership campaign. Voter Registration Campaign begun May 17—services and publicity scheduled. Board agrees to spend no more than $500 to send delegates to National Convention. Recommendation made to urge parents to send children to “White” schools. Agenda—June 6 - July 10, 1962 Protests filed with city officials re: Black citizens expelled from Fairgrounds. 18 Federal Commission on Civil Rights received much help from local NAACP. Memphis Branch received Thalheimer Award at Annual NAACP Convention. Voter registration efforts intensified. Recommendations: steps to increase membership and what actions to take. Resolution adopted to redouble efforts in to end discrimination in nine areas. Agenda—July 11 - August 7, 1962 Voter registration closed July 3; 75,950 Blacks registered to vote in County. NAACP memberships down nationally and locally—suggestions to increase. Question regarding Shiloh National Park—possible discrimination. Memphis Branch placed on FHA list of home foreclosures. Complaint filed with local Social Security Administration re: no Blacks hired in local agency—NAACP to assist all Blacks who have passed civil service exam. Legal Redress: Supreme Court refused to review Pupil Placement plan to desegregate schools—School Board must adopt plan in accordance with law. Complaint of police brutality in arrest of Black soldier. Complaint regarding excessively long wait in John Gaston emergency room. Meeting with head of Holidays Inns regarding desegregation of all facilities. Agenda—August 8 - September 4, 1962 Replies requesting investigation of police brutality charges. Memphis Branch opposed to consolidation of City and County governments. Plans for voter registration prior to November election. Complaint re: no Black patients accepted at Memphis Mental Health Hospital. Meeting of Freedom committee to end Main Street racial segregation. Labor & Industry Committee to bring discrimination in hiring charges against Southern Bell Tel & Tel Company. Board of Education school desegregation plan for grades 1 thru 3 to be presented to Judge Boyd for approval not acceptable to NAACP. Agenda—September 5 - October 2, 1962 Continued effort needed to get Blacks registered before October 8 cut off. Conference with head of Memphis Mental Health Hospital re: Black patients. Freedom Committee continuing to work for equal employment—meeting with Memphis Community Relations Committee to expedite—also efforts initiated to desegregate downtown movie theatres. NAACP attorneys will press to speed school desegregation at Dec. 3 hearing. Letter to Senator Kefauver commending his vote to confirm Thurgood Marshall. Books of the Memphis Branch audited, bill for services submitted. Fall membership campaign theme “James Meredith and You;” program kick-off October 8. 19 Agenda—October 3 - November 7, 1962 Petition to end discriminatory hiring policies to be presented to Southern Bell Negotiations continuing re: ending segregation in movie theaters Complaints filed with Buckeye Cotton Oil regarding employment discrimination Suit filed against St. Louis & San Francisco Railroad Company because of discrimination. Equal employment workshop conducted by Tenn. Council on Human Relations. Fall membership campaign extended until December 6. Alzada Clark, Chair, 1962 Freedom Seal (substitute for Christmas seals) project. Agenda—November 8 - December 4, 1962 Case dismissed against Mrs. Sanders, arrested at Airport Dobbs House. Meeting with group in Tipton County who want to form local NAACP chapter; voter registration drives being conducted in five West Tenn. Counties. Protest to Board of Education re: segregated school symphony concerts. Letter to President Kennedy re: banning discrimination in Federal housing. Annual meeting will be freedom mass meeting Dec. 9 Metropolitan Baptist Church. Membership campaign focus of much effort; contacts with many organizations. Agenda—December 5, 1962 - January 8, 1963 Annual Meeting held Dec. 9; Rev. C. T. Vivian of Chattanooga speaker. Membership campaign closed on Dec. 9—total membership is 6,952. Complaint filed with Civil Rights Division, Justice Dept. re: Lee C. Laney. Telegram sent to Rep. Clifford Davis re: House Rules Committee membership. Annual Report—1962 The extensive report covers areas of the Memphis Branch’s greatest activity: representation at national, regional and state meetings, protests of discriminatory practices and policies, action pertaining to legal redress, civil rights hearings, political action—especially voter registration, desegregation of downtown facilities, education—especially desegregation of public schools, labor and industry—especially action taken against SBT&T and Frisco RR, membership, youth council work, and engagements filled by the Executive Secretary and and Branch Officials. Folder 3—Items 8 Agenda—January 9 - February 5, 1963 Executive Committee meeting Tennessee State Conference—January 12, 1963. Letter from Executive Secretary to Commercial Appeal on meaning of NAACP. 20 Discrimination complaints at John Gaston presented to the Chief of Staff, CEO. Hotel Committee formed to end discrimination in Memphis hotels. Complaints re: segregation at Memphis Blood Center. Names submitted for the Youth Advisory Board. Meeting of Standing Committees—church work, legal redress. Southeast Regional Conference Mar. 14-16, Tampa, FL—one delegate to be sent. Standing Committee chairmen have been elected except for Housing. Desegregation of downtown movie theatres for four-week trial period. Agenda—February 6 - March 5, 1963 Requests for investigation of police brutality sent to national and local officials. WLOK and WDIA broadcast Lincoln Day tape as public service. Representatives from Owen College, LeMoyne College, and Memphis State University met with Executive Secretary to discuss a city-wide college chapter of NAACP. Charge of racial discrimination at Brushy Mtn Penitentiary sent to the Governor. Dr. Clark, John Gaston Chief of Staff, working to remedy hospital discrimination. Reply from Charles Newsom of Memphis Hotel Assn re: NAACP meeting. New voter registration sign-up Shelby County Court House during car tag sale. Downtown movie theatres now desegregated following “no incident” trial period. Report on Standing Committee meetings. Emancipation Proclamation program at Parkway Gardens Presbyterian Church. Equal employment opportunities seeking better job positions for Black citizens. Audit of NAACP books for year 1962 shows books in order. Agenda—March 6 - April 2, 1963 Ten Memphis movie houses now integrated—suburban locations. Better employment opportunities for Blacks being pressed with downtown merchants—also milk and beer firms. March voter registration at Court House added 1,472 new voters. Membership campaign kick-off March 28 at Mt. Olive CME Church. Agenda—April 3 - May 7, 1963 Missing Agenda—May 8 - June 4, 1963 Celebration of 1954 Supreme Court Decision at Metropolitan Baptist Church. To date 17 movie theatres desegregated, including all drive-in theatres. As of May 20, all major downtown hotels and all Holiday Inns are desegregated and negotiations are underway to desegregate all restaurants. Request sent to School Board to fill Board vacancy with a Black appointee. Russell Sugarmon and Samuel Billy Kyles met with County Board of Education re: desegregation. Supreme Court ordered immediate desegregation of all recreational facilities. 21 Judge Marion Boyd upheld Board plan for gradual school desegregation. Complaints filed re: clerical training program and new housing development. Membership campaign to close on June 5 with all-out effort to get members. Gerber’s dining facilities now desegregated—other downtown stores desegregated their eating facilities in February 1962. Agenda—June 5 - July 9, 1963 Local NAACP chartered bus to take members to June 15 funeral of Medgar Evers. Suit filed in Federal Court to force desegregation of Shelby County schools. Injunction filed by NAACP to force desegregation of Memphis City schools. Replies received to discrimination complaints previously filed. Meeting with Automobile Dealers to discuss discrimination in hiring and facilities. Southern Bell to open six clerical jobs to all applicants based on qualifications. Reply sent to newspapers re: attack on NAACP by local Unitarian minister. Some local restaurants desegregated—effort to push others to drop barriers. Memphians attend the 54th Annual NAACP Convention in Chicago July 1-6. Agendas—July 10 - December 2, 1963 Missing Agenda—December 3, 1963 - January 7, 1964 Program for sale of Christmas seals moving slowly. Freedom Fund Dinner Committee planning testimonial for Jesse H. Turner. Executive Secretary and other NAACP members toured City Hospital to talk to Black workers re: discrimination on the job. Membership report—total for 1963 6,831 (adults 6,140-youth 691). Visit by NAACP National Treasurer planned for February 7 at mass meeting. Emancipation program sponsored by Board of the National Baptist Church. Letter sent to Board of Education re: appointment of Mr. Bosworth. Complaints regarding public accommodations and employment—especially restaurants and firms having dropped racial barriers. Submission for Thalheimer Award The report is a request from the Memphis Branch to be considered for the annual Thalheimer Award and gives a concise summary of its activities in the following areas: Membership, Freedom Fund, Press and Publicity, Legal Redress, Labor and Industry, Education, Youth Work, Housing, Voter Registration, Hospitals, and Public Accommodations. Folder 4—Items 14 22 Agenda—January 8 - February 4, 1964 Shelby County Hospital Complaint re: racial discrimination in employment and patient care. Memphis Transit Authority Complaint re: carding student bus riders. Memphis State University complaint re: some classes closed to Black students. Executive Secretary spoke at the Unitarian Church. Telephone Company—SBT&T will employ Blacks as telephone operators. Women’s Auxiliary to NAACP—planned organization. Agenda—February 5 - March 3, 1964 Lincoln Day tape—WLOK and WDIA will broadcast Feb. 12. Complaints from Black employees of local bread companies Meeting with major Memphis businesses re: hiring of Black employees. Women’s Auxiliary organized reception for National Treasurer February 7. Restaurant Desegregation—30 more restaurants to begin controlled integration. Distributive Education classes added to four Black high schools. Intercollegiate NAACP chapter again active—interest groups formed. NAACP suit filed to desegregate Shelby County School System—teacher and student ratio based on population ratio. Agenda—March 4 - April 7, 1964 Protest re: no Blacks hired to work annual license tag sale. Complaint and protest re: MATA bus seating incident. Complaint filed with Alcoholic Licensing Commission; license denied Black. Complaint filed with Hull-Dobbs Ford re: insulting treatment of Black customers. Women’s Auxiliary plans for a Miss NAACP contest and talent show. Finance Committee plans to expand Sustaining Donation Program. Board of Education—efforts to end discriminatory wages paid cafeteria workers. Protest filed against WMC after slanted presentation of Civil Rights Bill. 2,000 Petitions supporting Civil Rights Bill distributed—also letter writing urged. Complaint sent to Memphis Hotel Assn—jobs not desegregated. Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee and Intercollegiate NAACP Chapter visit local churches in integrated groups; only barred from Second Presbyterian Church. Intercollegiate Chapter served notice on restaurants in Memphis State area. Membership Campaign—kickoff social for 1964 campaign with plan of action. Agenda—April 8 - May 5, 1964 Complaints filed for abusive treatment re: postal worker, Covington hospital nurse, and Tennessee Psychiatric Hospital worker. Meeting with Board of Education re: failure to end discriminatory policies. 23 Letters and petitions to U.S. Senators and Congressmen asking support for passage of Civil Rights Bill. WMCT provided NAACP time to speak on Civil Rights Bill. Civil Rights Bill Debate—Jesse Turner and others speak at Memphis State. Dr. Vasco Smith traveled to Washington to request Tennessee Congressional support for Civil Rights Bill. Sustaining Donor Program meetings held. Freedom Sunday mass meeting on May 17. Membership Campaign to climax on Freedom Sunday. Report on Intercollegiate Chapter direct action program—kneel in at Second Presbyterian Church; also sit-ins at Normal Tea Room. Agenda—May 6 - June 2, 1964 Fund raising activities—Sustaining Donations and Fighting Fund for Freedom. Memberships—continued efforts to increase 1964 memberships. Complaint to Memphis Chapter of Co-Ettes re: their publicity and fund-raising. Letters sent to City Commission re: numerous public accommodation laws and planned June 9 march on the City Commission School desegregation focused on efforts to get more Black children in White schools. Agenda—June 3 - July 7, 1964 Candlelight memorial service for Medgar Evers June 12, 1964. NAACP march on City Commission June 16. Letter of commendation to Senator Clair Engle. Protest March re: Senator Albert Gore’s negative vote on Civil Rights Bill. Telegrams sent to civic leaders requesting compliance with Civil Rights Bill. Bonanza television star to come to Mid-South Fair only if fair desegregated. Supreme Court upheld conviction of student demonstrators who disrupted a local church service in 1960. Agenda—July 8 - August 11, 1964 Continued action to implement Civil Rights Bill. Immediate goal is elimination of all hospital discrimination. NAACP files suit against Shelby County Quarterly Court to change poll hours. Branch officials working to get out a big Black vote in support of all candidates who took positive stand on Civil Rights Bill—Jesse H. Turner and A. W. Willis first Black elected since Reconstruction. Memberships—concern regarding lagging memberships, about 900 behind. State Conference to convene in Memphis Sept. 24-26—Charles Evers to speak Massive voter registration drive launched. Executive Board recommends election of officers on Dec. 12 at NAACP office. 24 Agenda—August 12 - October 6, 1964 Protest to Gov. Frank Clement re: dismissal of Fred Davis and Rufus Jones, employees in State tax office. Protest re: police officers’ racial slurs and exclusion of Blacks from Grand Jury Duty. Legal Redress action re: injustice of students sentenced to 60 days in jail. Freedom Fund Committee planning fund-raiser to pay fines for jailed students— first Miss Social Belle Contest planned for Oct. 12. Agenda—October 7 - November 4, 1964 Newsletter sent to members re: Branch meetings and election of officers. Legal Redress action in high courts re: arrest and order to jail student protestors. Complaint re: police brutality in arrest of two men charged with public drinking. Complaint filed with City Finance re: extreme discourtesy to Black customers. Miss Social Belle Contest attracts 14 young lady entrants. Membership Campaign—efforts to secure more members, meeting November 5. Intensive vote campaign resulted in 78% of Black voters going to polls—voted for President Johnson and other liberal candidates Agenda—November 5 - December 1, 1964 First Miss Social Belle contest successful—income from event $4,857.15. Membership campaign resulted in total of 5,523 adult members, 675 youth. Complaints filed with Retail Merchants Assn. expressing extreme dissatisfaction with tokenism in Black employment. Agenda—December 2, 1964 - January 5, 1965 Memberships—push to raise 1964 memberships--total adult 5,886; youth, 695. Complaints to Bd. Education re: segregated performances outside school. Telegrams to local banks urging boycott of Mississippi bond issue. NAACP asks for information on Memphis Anti-Poverty Program; request for minimum wage of $1.25 for all county employees. Complaint re: discriminatory signs on restrooms in Lowenstein’s parking garage. Complaints sent to Justice Department re: prisoner segregation in city jails. Party honors Miss Social Belle contestants. Complaint of police brutality—unprovoked beating and injuries sustained. Legal Redress: student religious disturbance case conviction upheld; appeal filed. Annual Report—1964 Executive Secretary’s Report summarizes Branch activities under the following categories: state, regional and national meetings, complaints filed re: racial 25 discrimination, efforts to open employment to Blacks, efforts to end discrimination in all public accommodations, complete school desegregation, Youth Council/NAACP College Chapter, efforts to support passage of Federal Civil Rights Bill, legal redress—cases appealed to various courts, political with regard to all phases of voting, election of Black candidates Jesse H. Turner, A.W. Willis, Charles Ware, and H. T. Lockard. Other important action includes two major fund-raising activities: Sustaining Donor Program and first Miss Social Belle Contest. Folder 5—Items 16 Agenda—January 6 - February 2, 1965 Jail Discrimination—Commissioner Armour replied that inmates not segregated. Discriminatory signs removed from Shoppers Garage (Lowenstein’s). Complaints received re: discrimination in employment, television, unions, failure to recruit Black firemen and policemen. Letter of commendation to Press-Scimitar editor. Complains filed re: discrimination in eight local hospitals. Letter to Park Commission urging re-opening of city swimming pools and elimination of segregated little league baseball teams. Minimum wage rates—additional requests for $1.25 rate for all county employees. No information from City Commission re: Memphis Anti-Poverty Program. Picketing and direct action against local banks re: discriminatory hiring practices. Meeting called for Jan. 23 with representative of small West Tennessee Branches. Meeting of standing committees. Youth Council and Intercollegiate Chapter reports. Continue planned protests against Second Presbyterian Church for segregated worship services. Legal assistance given to young man using “White only” restroom in restaurant. Agenda—February 3 - March 2, 1965 Veterans Hospital—investigation of alleged discrimination in employment and patient care by national government agent. Meeting with Commissioner Pete Sisson re: sanitation employees fired because City Government opposed efforts to organize a union. NAACP challenge to Education Board re: compliance pledge on desegregation. Protest to Memphis State and YMCA re: black students not allowed to use Y pool. School budget request for minimum wage of $1.25, non-discriminatory hiring, and teacher assignment to be made without regard to race. Anti-Poverty Program workshop had 200 participants studying Federal Anti- Poverty Act and Title VII of 1964 Civil Rights Law. Weekly demonstrations against banks continued re: discriminatory hiring. 26 Complaints filed with OEO and Labor Dept. re: hiring in Neighborhood Youth Corps Program and inability to get information on Anti-Poverty Programs. Complaint filed with WHBQ-TV- discriminatory statement made about NAACP. HEW Dept. will monitor local hospital discrimination through federal funding. Memphis Branch represented at State Ministers Conference. Request to County Clerk to hire Blacks for annual license tag sale. Agenda—March 3 - April 6, 1965 Meeting with Commissioner Sisson re: sanitation workers fired for union activity. Complaints filed against Tennessee Employment Security re: discrimination in job placement. Protest March re: discrimination at U of Alabama; memorial service for Rev. Reeb; March 20, a second protest march against U of Alabama. Bank demonstrations—weekly picketing of banks guilty of discrimination in violation of Federal law. Kennedy V. A. Hospital complaints—ongoing investigation of discrimination. Petitions to City Commission to re-open city swimming pools. Public accommodations violations—Rainbow Lake Skating Rink, Pat’s Pizza. Meeting with Pepsi Cola officials re: job changes in company reducing number of Black employees. Suits filed against YMCA re: Y facilities that remain segregated. Newsletter sent to Branch members. County school segregation protested by Memphis Branch—sent to County Court. Request for closed session conference with City School Board. Legal Redress Committee examined four cases. Membership Campaign—Spring campaign kick-off April 1. Minimum Wage request for $1.25 per hour not met by City and County. Agenda—April 8 - May 4, 1965 Demonstrations against local banks bring meetings and promises of non- discrimination in employment; demonstrations planned against Goldsmith’s. NAACP defending victim of police brutality. Reports of discrimination at auto testing station. Protest re: exclusion of Blacks from jury service. Further investigation of job discrimination at Kennedy V. A. Hospital. Telegram sent urging Rep. George Grider to support Civil Rights Voting Bill. Membership campaign workers to increase local membership. Petitions sent to City Commission to re-open city swimming pools. Hearings scheduled in Nashville re: student religious disturbance case. On-going fight to raise minimum wage has increased wages for some city employees to $1.00/hour. Federal investigators indicate Memphis hospitals guilty of job discrimination. 27 Agenda—May 5 - June 1, 1965 Spring Membership Campaign to end with social for workers on June 3; adult membership to date 4,111; youth, 474. Freedom Sunday Celebration honoring May 17, 1954 Supreme Court ruling. Direct Action—demonstrations called off at Goldsmith’s following negotiation for increased Black employment; Intercollegiate Chapter surveying restaurants. Life Membership Drive honoring subscribing and potential life members. Protest filed with beer distributors regarding discriminatory hiring practices. Letters of inquiry sent to directors of the Head Start Program. Agenda—June 2 - July 6, 1965 Response to Head Start Program Inquiry; Branch President taken on tour of facilities and given details of program. Meeting with HEW Officials relative to complaints of hospital discrimination. Meeting with Bricklayers Local #1 to discuss discrimination by union and by contractors in violation of Title VII and Civil Rights Act. Life Membership Social June 16—15 new members. Delbert Spurlock, NAACP Legal Defense Fund, met with local officials to discuss filing of Title VII complaints. Direct action-picketing of Lowenstein’s for one month resulted in arrests of protesters thereby increasing the number of those picketing Lowenstein’s; result, all charges by Lowenstein’s dropped; store to pay court costs and immediately open store to equal employment of Blacks. Complaints received from Army Depot employees re: discrimination in upgrading job positions of Black employees; complaint filed against two skating rinks. Legal Defense assistance provided victim of police brutality. Memphians (17) attended National NAACP Meeting in Denver June 28-July 13. Meetings with representative of two private hospitals re: no Black staff members and other discriminatory practices; these hospitals receive federal funding. Letter to HEW Assistant Sect. re: racial discrimination by Boards of Education. Agenda—July 6 - August 13, 1965 Hospital meeting—June 20 meeting with chiefs of staff City of Memphis Hospital, St. Joseph and Baptist; Methodist not represented; administrators state Black patients accepted and employment opportunities open; Black doctors should apply for staff privileges. Legal Redress-defense furnished for picket arrested at Lot-A-Burger; action joined by Hyde Park-Hollywood Civic Club. Complaints filed against Rainbow Lake Swimming Pool for discrimination; against Memphis State University re: rush party discrimination; by Cornelia Crenshaw against Memphis Housing Authority; against Poverty Program for excluding Blacks from top positions. 28 Discriminationcharges filed against Kroger, Ryder Truck Lines, Big Star #54, Buckeye Cellulose Co., Bricklayers Local, Mead Paper Co., Fire and Police Commissioner, Shelby County Board of Education for segregated In-Service for teachers. Direct action—Intercollegiate Chapter testing Millington public accommodations. Telegrams sent requesting Senators Gore and Bass to support one man, one vote. Sustaining Donation Program—need for regular support to raise funds. Meeting with West Tennessee Branch leaders to initiate effective NAACP work. School suits re: slow progress in City/County school desegregation. Agenda—August 13 - September 7, 1965 Intercollegiate members test public swimming at Gaisman Park. Discrimination by ambulance companies that refuse to pick up injured Blacks. Legal Redress for labor official who would not accept segregation at restaurant. Employment survey of department stores and banks re: non-discrimination. Letters to editor of Commercial Appeal protesting recent article. Telegrams sent protesting segregated in-service training for teachers. Protest continued re: Community Action Program—Federal funds withheld. Letters sent to Senators Gore and Bass commending vote against Dirksen Amendment. Agenda—September 8 - October 5, 1965 Fall Membership Campaign kick-off Oct. 7 with rally at First Baptist Lauderdale. Birmingham Convention Sept. 11-12 had good representation from Memphis. Miss Social Belle Contest—planning underway for second contest. Letter to Sargent Shriver re: Community Action Program director. Conference with Commissioner Claude Armour re: discrimination in Police and Fire Departments, meter maids, city ambulance service, and other areas. NAACP Protests re: inequalities in Memphis Anti-Poverty Program; action taken. Title VII re: employment discrimination—Mead Paper and Kroger Baking Co. Agenda—October 6 - November 2, 1965 Miss Social Belle Contest—second contest underway, coronation ball Nov. 19. Letter to S.U.N re: discriminatory policies of S.U.N. agencies. D. Canale Company targeted for not hiring Black route salesmen.. Complaints filed against Buhler Mills, local hospitals and Kroger Baking Co. Meetings held in various areas of city to stimulate membership drive. Anti-Poverty Program; aggressive action taken re: Community Action Com. City Commission passed non-discriminatory ambulance ordinance. Agenda—November 3 - December 7, 1965 Memberships—final membership effort with total to date—6,757. 29 Busch Beer Company boycott—do not buy beer from D. Canale & Company Anti-Poverty actions continue re: Memphis Community Action Program, NAACP protests and trip to Washington to meet with OEO officials. Employment complaints filed against Liberty Cash Warehouse, Kroger Baking Company, Greyhound Bus Restaurant, and Memphis Housing Authority. Police Brutality charges filed on behalf of two injured individuals. Complaint filed re: exclusion of Blacks from jury duty. Miss Social Belle Contest netted $5,700 for this effort. Annual Report—1965 The Executive Secretary’s Report covered the following categories: National, State, and Regional Meetings; Complaints of discrimination in employment, public organizations and agencies; Rebuttal to John Birch Society letter; Desegregation of city and county public schools; Protest marches; Legal Redress pertaining to individual cases; Complaints regarding places of public accommodation; Political Action; Memberships, Freedom Fund and Finances; Youth and College Units; Anti-Poverty Program; Press and Publicity; and Equal Employment and Minimum Wage. Thalheimer Award Submission The twelve activities of the Memphis Branch that were submitted for the Thalheimer Award are covered in the Annual Report of the Executive Secretary Folder 6—Items 19 Agenda—December 8, 1965 - January 4, 1966 Police Brutality—good resolution on one case; other cases sent to Police Commissioner Claude Armour. Letter of complaint re: jury discrimination sent to numerous Judges and Bar Assn. Hospital report—new minimum pay scale for non-professional workers and new fee scale required of indigent patients. Letter sent challenging eleven Black ministers who support the mayor’s stand on the anti-poverty program; City Commission and County Court adopted joint resolution Jan. 3 for the formation of a Memphis Community Action Committee. Plans initiated for the 1966 Miss Social Belle Contest. Agenda January 5-February 1, 1966 NAACP membership information provided by WDIA w/o charge--good response. Jury Discrimination—Frank Graham, Jury Commission Chairman, to retire in April--criticized for use of word “niggers” and “darkies.” NAACP has requested Bar Association to require all court officers to adopt and use courtesy titles when addressing all Blacks who appear in court. 30 Investigation of discriminatory treatment of Black military by William Len Hotel employees; complaints filed against Fisher Lime & Cement and IC Railroad. Draft Board discrimination—no Blacks on draft board service. Letter sent to newspapers re: Jack Ruby ambulance that would not pick up Black Patient, who died later that same day. Letters sent to 350 Black-owned or supported businesses to boycott D. Canale & Co. for failure to hire Black route salesman; Memphis Distributing Co., and Shelby Sales Co., are interested in hiring Black beer route salesmen. Complaint filed with Commissioner Moore re: John Gaston’s refusal to treat 13- month old baby on first attempt to secure treatment—baby sent to crowded clinic; died later in second emergency room attempt. Parents of rape case defendants contacted NAACP for legal assistance. Membership Committee held first meeting of 1966. Branch May 17 celebration speaker Mal Goode, Black ABC news correspondent. Youth Council to celebrate 57th NAACP birthday and Black History Week. NAACP to investigate RCA hiring policy for new Memphis plant. Agenda—February 2 - March 1, 1966 Protest sent to Shelby County Planning Commission re: inconsistent rezoning practices that discriminate against Black homeowners. WLOK to broadcast Lincoln Day message as public service. Complaints re: restaurants, Juvenile Court employees. Complaint re: treatment of Black employees at Shelby County Hospital. Meeting with RCA re: hiring of employees for new Memphis plant. Complaint re: Aid to Dependent Children. Title VII Complaints against Local 1441 AFL-CIO; Kroger, Bricklayers Local. Voter registration in Tipton County and revitalization of that branch. Voter Registration Committee planning for 1966 voter registration. Membership campaign—plans for spring kick-off March 22. All defendants in pending rape trial requesting NAACP legal defense aid. Continued protests re: exclusion of Blacks from the six draft boards in Shelby Co. Labor & Industry Committee working to have young Blacks admitted to apprenticeship training programs. Agenda—March 2 - April 5, 1966 NAACP Legal Defense Fund assisting six defendants in rape case. U.S. Dept. of Education representatives states Memphis Education Boards not in compliance with Federal desegregation guidelines. Discussion with manager of Montesi East re: discrimination in employment. MLG&W removing all racial designations--using courtesy titles with customers. Meeting with City Hospital administrator and board to demand that Crump Hospital be desegregated and Title VI guidelines be met. RCA Corp. still not in compliance with employment opportunities for Blacks. 31 Complaints regarding discrimination in various businesses, police brutality, and Title VI and Title II non-compliance. Membership Campaign organized for a major drive. Memphis Branch represented at Southeast Regional Conference in Mobile March 17-19. Voter Registration carried on during annual sale of automobile license tags. NAACP filed complaints re: city’s proposal to purchase Club Paradise, an integrated entertainment faciltity, and use it for a segregated community center. Complaints sent to Memphis Housing Authority re: relocation of Black apartment tenants being moved to accommodate expressway construction. NAACP requesting County Board of Education to fill vacancies with Blacks . Request that new Jury Commission Chmn. obey Federal law in appointing jurors. Complaint re: unequal bonds for Whites and Blacks charged with same offense. D. Canale has agreed to hire Blacks in various positions; boycott to be lifted. Agenda—April 6 - May 3, 1966 National President of NAACP spoke at Branch Life Membership program. H.E.W. official met with Memphis hospital representative to formulate plan for compliance with Title VI guidelines relative to desegregation of hospitals; specific violations cited. Employment complaints filed against General Electric and Memphis Publishing. Membership campaign report given. Agenda May 4-June 26, 1966 Melvin Goode spoke at May 17 Celebration of 1954 Supreme Court decision. Efforts continue to increase memberships. 1966 Voter Registration Campaign underway; support provided by WDIA. Justice Dept. intervention in NAACP suit against Shelby County School System. March led on May 21 to protest slow pace of desegregation in all areas of the Memphis educational, judicial, medical, housing, and employment systems. Numerous complaints filed under Title VII employment violations, Title II public accommodations, housing, park commission, police department, election commission, and city ambulance services. Mass meetings and marches held after shooting of James Meredith. Medgar Evers memorial service held June 12—Bishop J.O. Patterson, speaker. Agenda—June 27 - August 9, 1966 NAACP representatives met with Postmaster General’s Task Force on equal employment to discuss discrimination in the Post Office. Complaints re: police brutality, Title II, Neighborhood Youth Corps, numerous Memphis businesses, and John Gaston Hospital. Congressman George Grider urged to uphold Title IV section on housing. NAACP adopted resolution re: Police and Fire Department discrimination.. 32 Legal assistance provided teenaged boys charged with murder. NAACP supports change of city government from Commission to Council. NAACP protests voter registration identification required of Black registrants. Voter Registration drive has resulted in 4,300 new voters (see report at end). Agenda—August 10 - September 6, 1966 Title VII and Title II Complaints filed. Meeting with Commissioner Armour re: eliminating racial discrimination in Police and Fire Departments. County Attorney ruled that prospective voters do not have to prove residency. Branch protests sent to WMCTV for failure to carry national civil rights program. Complaint filed re: inequitable treatment of blind Black persons. Continued work to end discrimination in the Shelby County Hospital. Protest sent to Commissioner Lane re: segregated MLG&W work crews. Protest filed re: tokenism in Selective Service System hiring. Protest sent re: shooting of Black robbery suspect. Agenda—September 6 - October 4, 1966 Protest to Shelby United Neighbors re: funds given to agencies that practice discrimination in policy or services. Greyhound Bus Depot discrimination in Calhoun City, MS. Complaint to Sheriff Morris—White man who killed man in car fatality not charged a/c victim was Black. Complaints re: discrimination filed at meeting with Memphis Postmaster. WMC-TV letter sent to station asking them to eliminate discriminatory policies. Letters to County Board of Education asking more Black representation. Protest filed over treatment of eight Blacks at time of their arrest. Complaint sent to John Gaston Hospital re: treatment of dietary employees. Fall membership and voter registration being heavily promoted. Miss Social Bell Committee to plan for 1966 contest. Title VI complaints filed against Southern Boiler & Tank Workers, Local 2172. AFL-CIO, Butcher Mills, and S & W Construction Company. Complaint filed against U of TN downtown center for failure to register Black women in an electronic data processing course—women later admitted to class. Memphis delegates at 20th Annual Meeting of Tennessee Branches NAACP. Agenda—October 5 - November 10, 1966 At close of voter registration on Oct. 10, 1,000 additional Blacks registered, bringing total eligible Black voters in Shelby County to 87,616. Active Miss Social Belle Contest will climax with coronation Nov. 11. Increase in membership will be emphasis for next ten weeks. Complaints re: policy brutality, Title VII violations. Protest re: proposed change in voting hours from 8 – 8 to 7 – 7; change failed. 33 Neighborhood Youth Corps is threatened with discontinuance. Complaints again sent to Shelby County Commission re: Shelby County Hospital. Letters charging discrimination in American Legion Baseball—Black players not permitted to play—Squire Jesse Turner files protest. West Tennessee Branches need help to keep Branches going; Collierville Branch formed. Agenda—October 24 - November 27, 1966 (note overlap with dates above) Six Title VII complaints filed against five companies and one union, two Title II complaints, and numerous complaints filed with Postmaster General West Tennessee Branches, especially Hardeman County, receiving help. Miss social Bell Coronation Ball successful—plans underway for next year. Intense membership efforts to bring number to 7,500 by end of year. New City Charter passed; nine amendments to the State Constitution passed with NAACP support in November General Election. Agenda—December 1, 1966 - January 4, 1967 NAACP sent letter urging continuation of Neighborhood Youth Corps. Complaint filed re: rigid segregation of prisoners at Penal Farm. NAACP protested investigative report of Shelby County Hospital--no mention of discrimination in the report. Shelby United Neighbors asked to eliminate discrimination in all agencies. Letter to Liberty Bowl Festival Committee stating no team selected has Black players or appeals to Black football fans. Complaint says Harold Whalum denied admittance to Top of the 100 Club although he had joined and paid all fees. Complaint filed against Millington trailer park for refusing residency to Black service man and wife. Complaint re: failure to reappoint a Black member to County Electrical Board. NAACP Executive Secretary appeared on WDIA to report on activities and answer questions; copy of discussion points and participants attached to agenda. Meeting with Commissioner Armour re: full integration of Fire and Police Depts. Annual Report—1966 The Executive Secretary opened her report by stating discrimination had become more subtle and entrenched making it more difficult to fight. Highlights of the report pertain to assistance provided to West Tennessee NAACP Branches, efforts to open housing to all citizens and to break down discrimination in hospital services and employment, ongoing legal action to eliminate segregation in public schools for students and teachers, and continuing focus on voter registration and education. Mass protests were staged after the shooting of James Meredith. Special observances included the third anniversary memorial commemorating the death of Medgar Evers and the May 17 celebration. The Miss Social Belle 34 Contest was the major fund-raising project. Active involvement by college students also was recognized. Folder 6A—Items 6 Special Reports for 1966 Guide Lines for Citizenship Classes and Voter Education by W. C. Patton, Associate Director NAACP Voter Education Program. Organizing a Successful Registration Campaign by W. C. Patton Shelby County, TN, Analysis of Election, August 4, 1966—detailed statistical compilation of number and percentages of Black voters casting ballots in various district races; Judge Ben L. Hooks, the top vote-getter; identification of Black voting patterns and impact on election outcome. Memorandum from Margaret C. McCulloch re: Post Office Department and equal employment information with form letter attached. Date of July 11, 1966 contained in text of the letter. Voter Education Project, Southern Regional Council, Inc., Atlanta, GA: “What Happened in the South, 1966,” provides documentation on the Black vote as a major factor in the November 1966 Elections. Thalheimer Awards nomination lists outstanding achievements of the Memphis Branch, NAACP for 1966. Heavy emphasis on voter education and registration, as well as desegregation of schools, businesses, public facilities. Folder 7—Items 10 Agenda—January 5 - February 7, 1967 Letters sent to 60 individuals requesting sustaining donations; letters will be sent next to churches and organizations. Title VII complaints against seven local businesses; complaints against city divisions, police abuse, and Title II complaints. Telegrams sent to senators Gore and Baker requesting a vote for revision of Senate Rule 22; telegram of protest sent to Gore for alleged support of George Wallace. NAACP requested Superintendent E. C. Stimbert to submit list of organizations sponsored by the Memphis Board of Education receiving federal funds. Complaint to WMPS re: failure to include photos of more Black service men on bulletin board at the Metropolitan Airport. Complaint to Commercial Appeal for failure to use courtesy titles for Blacks. 35 Resolutions adopted in January: urged Shelby County Quarterly Court to vote against hiring of Dan Mitchell; requested Shelby County Quarterly Court to dismiss Superintendent and all board members. Conference with newly appointed Postmaster re: alleged harassment of employees. Press and Publicity in all areas of media discussed. Agenda—February 8 - March 7, 1967 Complaints filed re: St. Joseph Hospital, Civil Service discrimination, Title VII U.S. District Attorney’s Office charged with discrimination. Conference with S.U.N. official re: agencies that discriminate on basis of race. Lincoln Day—NAACP Birthday Celebration aired by WDIA and WLOK; other festivities planned. NAACP requested investigation of city hiring policies—Blacks not fairly treated. Organizational meetings to prepare for spring membership campaign. Southeast Regional Conference in Greenville, SC March 2-4. Agenda—March 7 - April 6, 1967 Complaints: Title VII employment, Title II public accommodations, charges of police brutality filed. Protest re: appointment to Shelby County Hospital Board. Letter to Commercial Appeal re: request to include minorities in textbooks. Housing Authority protests re: segregated housing and poor job opportunities. Standing Committee Reports: membership, education, publicity, and church work Meetings and Conferences: youth council, intercollegiate chapter, meeting with HEW officials regarding local hospitals’ failure to comply with Title VII. Shelby County Hospital complaints re: violation of Black employees’ rights. Direct Action re: continued segregation in restaurants. March to City Hall to protest police brutality and abuse of Blacks. Agenda—April 7 - June 6, 1967 Complaints filed re: discrimination at V. A. Hospital, Harlem House not paying minimum wage, poor wages at Chromium Mining, racist statements by Memphis State University Coach, no service at Firestone Lounge and Dyers Inn, lack of equal opportunity at Kroger Baking Co., against International Printing Pressmen’s Union for denial of membership, racial discrimination at Plough, discrimination at Blind Workshop, Police Department charged with brutality in beating prisoner, against Carousel Coin-Op Laundry Cleaner, segregation at Pidgeon Thomas Iron Company, firing of MLG&W employees, complaint of personal abuse by police officer, and against Izzy Rosen’s Men’s Shop for insulting treatment of customer. Formation of NAACP Youth Council Advisory Board; meeting with Memphis State University students to form NAACP Chapter on the campus. NAACP supporting enrollment of more Whites in Head Start Program. 36 Telegrams sent to Tennessee Congressmen requesting support for bill dealing with Elementary and Secondary Education Act (H.R. 7819). Miscellaneous requests for aid re: suspended Juvenile Court employee, several disabled/discharged veterans, assistance for employees with children because of employment situations, police harassment of Black businessmen, job restrictions by Baptist Hospital prevent Blacks from gaining employment. May 17 Celebration held as Mass Meeting at Metropolitan Baptist Church. Memberships total as of June 6 is 5,880 compared with 4,387 on same date in 1966. Protest filed against Memphis Housing Authority re: segregated assignment of tenants based on race. NAACP picketed Shelby County Court House during selection of Grand Jury members, as no Blacks selected. Letters sent to city and county public officials asking that 50% of summer jobs be assigned to Black youth. Protest filed re: Board of Education demand that Black and Spanish students be retested because their grades were higher than White students’ grades. Memphis Park Commission states all phases of city parks’ programs will be integrated this season to conform to Title III of 1964 Civil Rights Act. Agenda—June 7 – July 3, 1967 NAACP lawyers and Executive Secretary met with Board of Education re: Board demand that Melrose High School Spanish students be retested; letters sent to newspapers. NAACP has received only tokenism on request that Black students be hired by city and county public agencies. Intensive campaign to register Black voters—also door-to-door registration. Plans made for Annual Life Membership Drive. Spring Membership Drive ended June 28—intensive efforts as campaign climaxed; memberships reported as of July 3, 1967 total 6,861. Resolutions adopted at June 25 meeting include: all Black voters urged to register and vote their convictions on the liquor-by-the-drink referendum and not be influenced by White groups; request the Mayor to remove all members of the Memphis Park Commission for their defiance of Civil Rights law and their closing all park swimming pools. Complaints filed against Humko for dismissal of nine employees, against Memphis Housing Authority for failure to protect Black tenants at Lamar Terrace Housing Project from threats and broken windows, against YMCA for denying Black child enrollment in swimming class, against Commercial Appeal for not including wedding announcement of Black couple in the newspaper, against Kroger Baking Company for harassment and discrimination, against Diversified Plastics for discrimination, against Dixie Wax Paper for failure to promote Black employees, against Southern Bell Telephone for prejudice and discrimination, against the Police Department for abusive treatment and false arrest. 37 Legal Redress working to develop a type of formal written notice of charges rather than just word of mouth. Agenda—July 5 - September 5, 1967 Complaints filed against Southern Bell Telephone, Memphis Molding Company, Hungerford, Inc., MLG&W, Memphis Loan and Thrift Co., Farmers Market, Claybrook Restaurant, General Electric Co., Major Casket Co., GMC Truck and Coach Division for various discriminatory practices. NAACP all-night picket vigil protesting discrimination postponed; fewer than 8% of the white collar jobs in city and county government held by Blacks, protests directed to finance and loan companies. Protests filed re: de-facto segregation at public wrestling matches. Protests re: police killing a 15 year old Black suspect; NAACP members attend City Commission meeting to protest. Efforts intensified to bring adult NAACP membership to 10,000 by end of year. Shelby County Black voter registration as of July 18 totals 90,144; protest filed opposing racial identification of political candidates. Agenda—September 6 - October 10, 1967 Complaints filed re: police abuse and unjust treatment, unfair salary practices in public and private businesses, as well as discrimination in hiring and promotion. Complaint to the Board of Education re: discrimination in administering Federal programs. Complaints filed with the courts re: no Black considered for Grand Jury foreman. Protest unfair public photographic display of servicemen which includes fewer than ten percent Black soldiers. Plans are moving ahead for the fourth Miss Social Belle Contest. Dr. C. L. Dinkins planning a six-week leadership development workshop. Voter registration drive resulted in 91,574 registered Black voters in Shelby County. Planning for fall membership renewal drive. Agenda—October 11 - November 7, 1967 Employment discrimination complaint filed against Professional Specialties Company. Housing complaint re: University of Tennessee discrimination in housing. Hospital complaints: John Gaston Hospital’s careless treatment of Black emergency room patients and discriminatory treatment of employees; however hospital has made over-all improvement in employment practices. School complaints re: harassing treatment of Black students at Guthrie, attack made on Black Bellevue student. Complaint filed with office of Attorney General re: unjust treatment of Black teen. 38 Complaint filed against Del Farm Food Stores re: asst. manager knocking a woman to the ground who was suspected of shop-lifting. Complaint filed against Shelby County Hospital for employment discrimination. Complaints file against Memphis Post Office referred to Regional Director. Request for assistance from Quitman County resident for beating received from unknown assailant. Fall membership campaign underway—will terminate December 17. Analysis of Oct. 5 and Nov. 2 election results included with Secretary’s report. Agenda—November 8 - December 5, 1967 Telegrams sent to TN Congressmen urging their support for Community Action Programs operated under OEO jurisdiction. Employment discrimination complaints filed against McKesson Robbins, White Stone Co., and Schevenell Ready Mix Concrete Co. Administrator of City Hospitals reports complaints re: discrimination brought to the attention of appropriate managers. Del Farm Food Stores officials deny charge of abuse of Black customer. Commercial & Industrial Bank denied complaints of discrimination re: customers and employees. Meeting with Superintendent of Memphis City School to discuss discrimination brought no solutions. Title II complaint filed against restaurant in Cleveland, MS which refused service to Black customers. Final membership report due by Annual Meeting on Dec. 17—memberships to date total 8,106. Memphis Housing Authority charged with racial discrimination—Federal official in Memphis investigating charges. Leadership Development Workshop successfully ended with some 70 participants. Fourth Annual Miss Social Belle Coronation Ball held Dec. 1; profit, $3,500. Letters to Mayor-Elect Loeb and Councilmen-Elect emphasize need to appoint Blacks to administrative positions in all agencies of government Submission for Annual Thalheimer Awards List of outstanding achievements in the areas of membership, freedom fund, press and publicity, labor and industry, education, housing, youth work, political action, leadership development workshop, administration of justice, recreation, and city ambulance service. Folder 8—Items 7 (Note: Executive Secretary’s Reports for January-March are missing) 39 Agenda—April 3 - May 14, 1968 Membership activities are tied to issues centered on the Sanitation Workers Strike—ministers contacted to solicit church support. Southeast Regional Conference in Clearwater, FL April 18-20. Police Brutality is escalating and many injured; lengthy listing of unprovoked attacks, threats, endangerment of life—citizens from all classes threatened; NAACP appealing to City Council and Shelby County Quarterly Court for a special panel to hear complaints—charges filed with U.S. Attorney General. NAACP continued support of the Sanitation Strike through April 16 settlement; four buses from Memphis attended Dr. M. L. King’s funeral in Atlanta. Voter Registration campaign to start May 30—much planning and requests for wide support in the Black community. May 17th Celebration will be mass meeting on May 19th with testimonials, awards and presentation of NAACP life membership plaques. Board of Education working to eliminate discrimination for cafeteria workers; NAACP continues to protest omission of Blacks from school text books and wants commitment to teach Black History. Employment discrimination complaints: investigation of airlines reveals less than 4% of employees are Black—letters sent to airline presidents; Western Union has no local Black employees. Title VII complaints filed against Methodist Hospital, Wooten Transport Company, Baptist Hospital, Nu-Craft Manufacturers, A.P. Mills Industries, United Parcel Service, Mobile Chemicals, Medical Group, and Mustin Nursing Home. Title VII complaints filed against J. C. Hobbins Restaurant and Grand Café. Complaint filed against Health Department for harassment of barber shop owner. Agenda—May 15 - June 22, 1968 Title VII employment complaints filed re: American Airlines, Western Union, Methodist Hospital, International Distributors, University of Tennessee, Augusta Manufacturers, Union Planters National Bank, General Electric Lamp Factory, and International Masons Local 521. Political Action taken re: voter registration, request for additional registration sites, protest that no Blacks are on the Shelby County Election Commission. Spring membership campaign ended May 27 with meeting featuring Clarence Mitchell of NAACP Washington office; membership totals 8,496. Legal redress protest filed re: punitive bond amounts. Protest sent to Mayor and City Council re: increase in City Court costs. Letter of opposition sent to Mayor re: appointment of Judge Marion Boyd to MLG&W Commission; complaints re: MLG&W discrimination. Charges filed with U.S. Attorney General’s office re: six additional cases of police brutality. Title II complaints filed against Pat’s Pizza House. Complaint filed with Fire and Police Director re: employment discrimination. 40 Complaint filed with WMC-TV re: no Black children on “kiddie shows.” Agenda—June 22 - August 6, 1968 Letter of protest sent to Mayor and City Council re: appointment of a citizens police reserve unit. Voter registration campaign shows 6,000 Blacks registered since January 1968; total number of registered Black in Shelby County 94,640. Memberships in 1968 to date total 9,478, including youth and adult—end of year goal is 10,000 adult members. Employment discrimination complaints filed re: Pace Corp., J. B. Hunter, Double Cola Co., Kennedy Veterans Hospital, General Electric Lamp Co., American Airlines, U.S. Engineers, E.L. Bruce Co., Universal Warehouse Co., Roadway Express Co., Liberty Cash and Retail Clerks Union 1529, and Don Russ Bubble Gum Co. Police brutality complaints are increasing—U.S. Dept. of Justice investigating. Memphis League Baseball excludes Black umpires. Complaint filed against John Gaston Hospital after baby’s death. Concerted project underway to demand more Black employees in companies located in all-Black communities. Agenda—August 7 – September 3, 1968 Concerted effort to obtain additional voter registration locations in ghetto areas. Ghetto Development focusing on increased employment for Blacks in all-Black communities; surveys made to determine ratio of Black employment in targeted areas and businesses. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Coca Cola Bottling Co., Lucky Heart Cosmetics (Black products), General Electric Co., Fred Montesi Supermarket, Baptist Memorial Hospital, Gordon Truck Lines, and Jamerson-Horn Lumber. Police complaints re: unjust arrest or failure to investigate accident when Black was a party to accident. Complaints filed re: fees charged at John Gaston Hospital. Title II complaint filed against Pepi’s Lounge. Protest filed re: delays in NAACP supported Frayser Turnkey Housing Project. Agenda—September 4 – October 8, 1968 Frayser Turnkey Housing Project killed by City Council vote; NAACP protesting the alternate site at Riverside Park. Voter registration cut-off final tally—97,317 Blacks registered in Shelby County. Complaints re: police abuse filed with Justice Department; cases relating to beatings of teen-aged males. Request for grand jury investigation of death of incarcerated prisoner—police allege suicide; family believes otherwise. 41 Miss Social Belle Contest plans underway—tentative coronation Nov. 22. H.E.W. complaints filed against Methodist Hospital for dropping first Black women enrolled in School of Nursing and Memphis Area Vocational School for segregating students and not allowing Black students free choice of courses. Complaint re: Bellevue Jr. High discrimination against Black student. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Humko Products, Armour & Co., General Cable Corp., American Tel & Tel Co., General Electric Co., Dixie Mart, Nationwide Mutual Insurance Co., D.H. Overmyer, Kellogg Co., Lerner Shop in Southland Mall, American Finishing Co., Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., Riviana Foods, Inc., Avco Finance Co., Sears Roebuck Co., and Tennessee Employment Security. Ghetto Development Project proving successful in greater employment of Black workers in ghetto areas; efforts made to build better relationships between Black and White communities. Agenda—October 9 – December 3, 1968 Fifth Annual Miss Social Belle well underway, coronation ball to be Dec. 6. Protest over City Council’s delay in approving Map-South funding because of animosity toward its chairman Rev. J. M. Lawson. Complaint filed against bill collector from Greater Tennessee Finance Co. for striking pregnant Black woman. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Schneider’s Modern Bakery, Wabash, Inc., Phil’s Men’s and Boy’s Shop, Pace Corp., Humko Products, Memphis Publishing Co., Holiday Inns, J. J. Hunter, International Harvester, Memphis Furniture Factory, and Western Auto. Complaint filed against Sears in Southland Mall store for rude treatment of Black customer. Complaint filed with Holiday Inns re: exclusion of Blacks from Club Rivermont, a private facility in Memphis Holiday Inn Rivermont. Memphis Branch NAACP sent telegram of support to Roy Wilkins, NAACP National Director; local Branch pledged a membership of 10,000 in support. Letters sent to the Shelby County Election Commission setting out several grievances re: hindrances imposed on Black voters. Student complaint filed against South Side High School principal. Complaint filed with Police Department re: victim of police beating who died as a result of blood clots on the brain. Fall membership drive divided into two major phases; membership total through December 2 is 10,696. Annual Report—1968 The Executive Secretary’s Annual Report for 1968 highlights a year that brought in a new form of city government, a labor strike that turned into a national civil 42 rights action, the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., in Memphis, and stepped up activity at all organizational levels of the Memphis Branch, NAACP. Of particular significance in the report are the following areas of activity: increased contact with city and county governmental agencies; support of the sanitation workers’ strike; more direct contact with Federal justice agencies, continued pressure on Memphis businesses to eliminate discrimination in all forms of employment; complaints filed regarding rising numbers of police brutality reports; a successful voter registration campaign, great increase in memberships; dissatisfaction with the Board of Education; failure to eliminate discrimination in education and integrate the public schools; and special appreciation to Jesse R. Turner retiring president of the Memphis Branch NAACP for his outstanding leadership. Folder 9—Items 11 Agenda—January 1 – February 4, 1969 Employment discrimination complaints filed against Baptist Memorial Hospital, Levy’s-Poplar Plaza, St. Jude Hospital, Firestone Tire & Rubber Company, teamsters Local 667, Pic-Pac Food Stores, and J. B. Hunter. Title II complaint filed against Skate Haven Skating Rink, violation of public accommodation. Two complaints filed re: police brutality—unprovoked beatings alleged. Charges of election irregularities filed by NAACP; denied by Election Commission. NAACP opposes the proposed “stop and frisk” law as a threat to Black citizens. Protest filed with Shelby County Quarterly Court re: lack of any public services for Carver Heights (no water, garbage, sewers, etc.), which is located adjacent to Raleigh. Complaint filed against Hobson-Kerns for unjust eviction of East St. tenant. Agenda—February 5, 1969 – March 4, 1969 Southeast Regional Conference met in Atlanta Feb. 13-15. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Keathley’s, Inc., Memphis Defense Depot, Memphis & Shelby County Health Dept., Tennessee Employment Security, Illinois Central Railroad, Jones Janitor Services, Millington Naval Air Station, St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, and Linwood Convalescent Center. Complaints filed against the Police Department re: abuse of psychiatric patient, beatings of individuals arrested; unjust arrest; severity of problem has resulted in formation of an NAACP committee to seek solutions. NAACP’s school desegregation case in Federal District Court, complaints from parents of Black school children in the county, complaint re: fight between students at Messick High School. 43 Eviction of Black tenant in apartment called off because HUD officials in Memphis. Complaint filed against allied Collection Company. Letter sent to Mayor asking that Memphis State University not be allowed to conduct business census in Walker Homes Area because MSU does not hire Blacks. No Black workers handling registration during auto license tag sales. Legal redress cases include financing for Blacks who are in cases vs. the State of Tennessee. Complaint filed re: garnishment of salary to pay John Gaston Hospital bill. Agenda—March 5 – April 1, 1969 Walker Homes census will hire seven individuals—three are Black. Voter registration at Fairgrounds during auto tag sale recorded 1663 persons. Complaint of harassment at Longview Junior High School. Complaints registered by Black teachers in county schools that were annexed by city regarding not being rehired by the same school. Police brutality charges filed against officers, including C.D. Cothran, who has a lengthy record of abusing Black citizens. Lane College protests in Nashville have resulted in police brutality directed against students and citizens—NAACP lawyers hired to assist victims. Employment discrimination complaints filed against International Harvester Parts Dept. for harassing Black, Pulvair Chemical Co., for dismissing employee, John A. Denie’s Sons for unfair work situations, Illinois Central Railroad for hounding injured employee, Hunter Fan Co., for refusing to hire Black because of confused medical reports, Vann Baking Co., for not hiring Black women, Tennessee Employment Security for not considering Black applicant who was well-qualified, Bigelow-Liptak Corp., for firing man who participated in King Memorial March, Memphis Attendants Registry, Inc. for age and race discrimination. Legal redress seeks assistance of the NAACP legal Defense Fund for two cases tried in Tennessee courts. NAACP protested hiring of white man as athletic director who had been convicted of bank robbery. Committee formulating plans for the Testimonial Banquet honoring Jesse Turner for his years of dedicated service to the Memphis Branch NAACP--Roy Wilkins to be guest speaker. Planning underway for spring membership campaign. Agenda—April 2 – May 6, 1969 Education concerns include assistance requests for Black county teachers not rehired when their schools were taken over by the city; complaints from teachers fired for incompetence. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Fischer Steel Corp., Shelby County Hospital and the Home for Incurables, Pulvair Corp., Shelby County 44 School System, Grant & Co., Millington Naval Hospital, White Station Towers, Memphis House Cleaning Co., First National Bank, HumKo Products, U.S. Engineers, International Harvester, and Jones & Laughlin Steel Corp., Complaint filed against Signature Finance Co. for verbal abuse of customer. Shelby County Court has agreed to finance water lines to Carver Heights. WDIA will give NAACP radio time each week for timely issues. Ghetto Development Committee will launch 1969 campaign to secure jobs for Blacks in businesses located in ghetto areas. May 17 celebration to be held Sunday, ay 18 at Mississippi Blvd. Christian Church—Nat D. Williams will be featured speaker. Second Black student sit-in at Memphis State University president’s office resulted in arrest of all students who were bound over to the grand jury. Efforts increased to boost slow membership through special planned events. Complaint filed that no Black holds an administrative position at Veterans Hosp. Title II complaint filed against Somewhere Bar-B-Que restaurant. Letter of welcome sent to Schlitz Brewing Company with request that they hire Blacks without local discriminatory policies. Agenda—May 7 – June 3, 1969 Employment discrimination complaints re: discriminatory treatment filed against Methodist Hospital, Lamar Laundry, Nat Buring Packing Co., Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., RKO Bottlers, Kimberly-Clark, Sears Central Service, Corondolet, Juvenile Court, Guardsmark, Caradine’s Grocery, and ETWNC Truck Lines. Education complaints filed re: job security, classroom prejudice, and closing of some predominantly Black county schools. Title II violation charges filed against Manhattan Club and Somewhere Bar-b-Que. Complaints filed that Blacks denied apartment rentals in white locations. Police Dept. complaints re: treatment of arrested Memphis State students, abuse of young man caught with gamblers, abuse of Blacks at Cotton Carnival Midway, and unjustified detaining of man driving sick wife to hospital. May 22 Jesse Turner testimonial drew overflow crowd. Complaint filed re: unfair treatment of Black Lt. in Vietnam. Request for conference with director of Memphis-Shelby County Health Dept. Lagging membership drive extended through June 12 with Medgar Evers testimonial dinner to climax drive. Ghetto Development Committee meeting with Orange Mound residents re: action to increase Black employment in Lamar-Airways Shopping Center. Agenda—June 4 – July 8, 1969 Employment discrimination complaints filed against Pic-Pac Food Store at1242 Airways, Clayton & Brown Wholesale Co., Delight Egg Co., Dover Elevator Corp., Kellogg Co., General Electric Lamp Co., and Trojans Luggage. 45 Police Complaints re: murder of inmate at Pikeville Prison, harassment of pool room operator, beating in connection with arrest. Complaints filed against Memphis & Shelby County Health Dept. re: promotion discrimination; St. Joseph Hospital re: discriminatory firing. Spring membership campaign climaxed with Medgar Evers Memorial Service—memberships far behind goal—to date memberships total 6,195. Ghetto Development Committee reports significant gains for Black employment in the Orange Mound shopping area. Legal Redress re: Maywood Swimming Pool denying admission to Blacks. Complaint filed against Memphis Loan and Thrift Co. for verbal abuse of customer and only one Black employee. NAACP Annual Meeting held in Jackson, MS June 30-July 5; Memphis Branch won Thalheimer Award for effective Branch Programming in 1968 and Ike Smalls Award for 30% membership increase, as well as and first branch to exceed 10,000 members. Agenda—July 9 – August 5, 1969 Housing complaint filed against Savoy Apartments; workshop to inform prospective home buyers of their rights under Title VIII Fair Housing Law. Police complaints filed re: police beating, unjust arrest, shooting death of Richard Johnson, beating of two females (one Black, one White), physical and verbal abuse of female; of hundreds of complaints filed by NAACP charging abuse, none have resulted in reprimand of officers. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Horne’s Body Shop, Monroe Mfg. Co., Continental Trailways, Brodnax Jewelers, Memphis & Shelby County Health Dept., Army Corps of Engineers, Choctaw, Inc., E.I. DuPont DeNemours, Inc., and Illinois Central Railroad—all re: discriminatory/unjust treatment. Complaint filed against Mary Galloway Home for unequal pay and no documentation of pay amount--IRS and other Federal agencies notified. Letter sent commending Commercial Appeal on series dealing with poverty. NAACP has joined efforts of other groups to see that hungry school children are fed—School Board and Shelby County Quarterly Court support this effort. Appearance made before Quarterly Court on other issues including legal aid to the poor and licensing for Black plumbers. Legal Redress suits filed against Club Rivermont, Holly Hills County Club, and Maywood Recreation, Inc. Board of Education issues include White teachers refusing transfers to predominantly Black schools, violations of various Federal desegregation laws, written requests for compliance with Civil Rights laws, suits filed on behalf of jobless Black teachers and other Black school employees. Aid requested for Black applicant for Social Security who could not prove date of birth. 46 Agenda—August 6 – September 2, 1969 State Conference of NAACP Branches will focus on problems in all areas of housing. Memphis Branch will host the Tennessee State Conference of Branches September 25-27. State Conference mass meeting will kick off annual fall membership drive; life membership drive will climax with Freedom Fund Banquet. Police Issues: Director Holloman blamed Black leadership for token Black employment in the department--denied by NAACP; excessive numbers of police brutality cases not addressed by Holloman; complaints re: severe beatings by police officers with photo documentation sent to media and all justice agencies; complaint re: young children arrested for vandalism. Complaints re: discrimination at Kennedy Hospital and negligent care of infant at John Gaston resulting in child’s death. Employment complaints on various issues filed against Watkins Products, Fashion Products, Rodney Baber & Co., Ivers & Pond, Inc., TVA Steam Plant, Dobbs, House, Inc., Haverty’s Furniture Store, Day & Night Mfg., Co., and U.S. Naval Hospital Post Office. Efforts undertaken to block Judge Clement Haynesworth’s appoint to U.S. Supreme Court. Continued appearances before Board of Education requesting changes and compliance with law. Legal assistance provided to individual re: illegal police search of home. Title II complaints filed against Crown’s Lounge. Agenda—September 3 – October 7, 1969 Intensive drive for members launched September 25 with special efforts to secure payment of life member pledges. Police complaints filed re: arrest of student on unsubstantiated charges; lack of interest by police when complainant was Black, injuries from beatings and bites received from police dog, and failure of police to acknowledge assistance of Black citizen (Henry Currie) in the arrest of George H. Putt, charged with five murders. Hospital report includes efforts by Kennedy Veterans to improve conditions for Black workers; discrimination charges filed against West Tennessee Chest Hospital re: dining privileges and food served and treatment on the job. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Memphis House Cleaning Co., Sam Shainberg Co., Shelby County Court House, and Liberty Cash Warehouse. In a matter of legal redress, Club Rivermont enjoined from barring Dr. and Mrs. Vasco Smith. Housing matters include complaints filed against Olswanger & Michel, Rental Agency, and Americana Community Apartments. Complaint filed against Greyhound Bus Station for taxi policy that discriminates 47 against Black cab companies. Plans formulated for Sixth Annual Miss Social Belle Contest; Deanie Parker of Stax Recording Company Honorary Chairman of the contest. Board of Education complaints filed re: harassment of Black teacher, qualified Black teachers on waiting lists for years, plans for direct action by NAACP regarding Boards failure to comply with many violations of desegregation laws.
