Agenda—October 8 – November 4, 1969 Police complaints include arrest of youth without cause, beatings inflicted on two Black Vietnam veterans, beating of Black man in Jerry’s Villa on Summer Ave., man beaten and severely injured, murder of 18 year old Black burglary suspect, teen-ager sprayed with Mace, beating and serious injury of man who was taken directly to the police station and local news media, beating of teen-aged car theft suspect who sustained broken leg, and beating of suspect in basement of police station. NAACP states marked increase in police brutality follows demonstration by Black community. Police use this means to express resentment against direct action taken by NAACP. Hospital complaints filed against LeBonheur and Baptist for job discrimination. Complaint filed against city ambulance service which refused to take injured Black youth to hospital. Employment discrimination complaints filed against South Central Bell, Kroger Baking Co., and Richard’s Co. re: harassment and denial of employment. Title II complaint filed against Liberty Bowling Lanes for discrimination in use. Education matters include punitive action taken against students because of Black Monday events, firing of teacher for filing complaint, beating of student at Hamilton High. School Crisis includes October 9 school walkout, NAACP meeting with Board of Education cancelled, barring of citizens from Board meeting by armed police, October 13 first Black Monday with 63,000 students absent; Black teachers barred from meeting with Board of Education, Black teachers withdraw SUN pledges and promise that money to NAACP; mammoth march on Oct. 18, second Black Monday called on Oct. 20 with 67,000 students and 674 teachers absent; daily marches and picketing; third Black Monday on Oct. 27; live television debate between President of the Board of Education, Superintendent of Schools, and NAACP Executive Secretary; fourth Black Monday with 68,000 students absent, call for total Black work stoppage; 5,000 Blacks marched to City Hall for rally; law suit filed for immediate and complete desegregation of Memphis School System. November 9 Mammoth March for Memberships planned. Agenda—November 5 – December 2, 1969 Police complaints made re: beating of youths who were hospitalized, beating of adult male at same time who was severely injured, arrest of two men for allegedly cursing police, beating of student demonstrator, arrest of Black family for no stated cause, complaint re: police breaking doors and windows of homes without 48 cause, beating of man on way home from work, force used against Manassas students, member of Marine Corps stopped by police and subjected to humiliating treatment, and mass arrests of civil rights marchers. NAACP charges police with using vendetta tactics against Black citizens. Employment discrimination complaints of various discriminatory actions, especially firings because employees took part in protests and marches, filed against Nell’s Tailor Shop, Donruss Co., Brother’s Cafeteria, Fox Meadows Cleaners, Cage Nursing Home, South Central Bell, Kemco, Dollar General Store, and Freuhauf Corp. Miss Social Belle Contest lagging because of intense efforts made in behalf of the crisis in education. Education concerns re: discriminatory actions at the Adult Education Center and at Coleman Elementary School. Crisis in Education actions include school boycott through Nov. 13, daily marches with arrest of 53 leaders, various legal actions taken with some progress made in negotiations between NAACP and Board of Education. Complaint re: discrimination at Savoy Apartments. National office of NAACP will supply legal counsel for four Millington Marines charged with rioting and assault in connection with marches. Folder 10—Items 2 Note: All 1970s agendas are missing except the December agenda. No Annual Report. Agenda—December 2, 1970 – January 5, 1971 Complaints charging racial bias filed by parents of Sheffield High School students. Employment discrimination complaints filed against McLean Truck Line. Police harassment complaints filed re: home search without warrant; beatings of individuals involved in automobile accident. Clinic treating Medicaid patients hires blacks only in menial positions. Seventh annual Miss Social Belle Contest climaxed with Coronation Ball December 4; contest raised $10,706 less expenses of $2,949. Effort made in December 1970 to increase memberships—total reported-4,459. Speaking engagements of Branch officials in December 1970 listed. NAACP organized symbolic strike at Federal Reserve Bank building site to emphasize efforts to secure equal job opportunities for Blacks in construction. The folder also includes the program from the 61st NAACP Annual Convention. Folder 11—Items 14 Agenda—January 6 – February 2, 1971 Education grievances filed against Sheffield High School and Oakville School for blatant prejudice; against Memphis State Law School for bias in admitting Black 49 students; against Board of Education for unjustified suspensions of young elementary students. Employment discrimination complaints filed against El Chico, Allen & Allen Contractors, Dixiemart-Corondolet, Army Defense Depot, and Progressive Foods. Alfred Baker, NAACP National Treasurer, visits Memphis. Complaints of police brutality filed re: beating of Black fireman; police inspector’s repeated use of “nigger” during radio interview. Freedom Fund Committee planning a Las Vegas Holiday fund raiser. Speaking engagements of the Executive included six public programs during Jan. Legal redress matters include assistance for victim of police beating, help for man in Mississippi, request for help for member of Black Panther Party. NAACP and ACLU filed suit against Mayor Loeb for equal use of office space in city hall. Agenda—February 3 – March 2, 1971 Meetings with community leaders and clergy to help solve problems at Sheffield High School and Oakville School—progress reported. Memphis State University president contacted re: employment opportunities for Blacks on the campus. Meetings re: achieving more desegregation of county schools; judicial rulings on pending suits awaited; teacher at Gragg Elementary states she was reprimanded for having too many photos on display during Black History week. Employment discrimination complaints filed against McDonald Brothers, Wonder Bakeries, Shelby County Government, and Harrison’s Cash & Carry. Charges of police brutality re: prisoner sent to Arkansas penal Farm; entry of home (wrong address) without warrant and abuse of homeowner; charge of verbal abuse by police. NAACP warned owner of Phillips Food Store of legal action re: seizure of complainant’s property. Executive Secretary made two public addresses during February. WREC broadcast “The Troubled College Campus” on NAACP birthday. Title II complaints filed against Falcon Lounge, Carpenter Shell Service (Holly Springs, MS), Arcade Barber Shop, and Bates & Sons Barber Shop. Legal redress—Federal District Judge ruled City Hall space can be used only by governmental groups—not political organizations; NAACP providing legal assistance to parents of Larry Payne killed by police officer March 28, 1968. Freedom Fund Committee continuing work on Las Vegas fund-raiser; Friends of A. C. Williams dinner tribute to present funds to NAACP. NAACP Regional Conference held in Chattanooga February 25-27. Agenda—March 3 – April 6, 1971 Meeting with University of Memphis President and Department Heads does not indicate willingness on their part to increase employment of Black professionals. 50 Complaints re: failure to use courtesy titles, teacher exchange program slanted for benefit of White teachers, removal of Dr. King material at Georgia elementary, and charges of prejudice against Blacks at Gordon Elementary School. Employment discrimination complaints and actions taken: meeting with IRS officials to prevent entrenchment of discrimination in hiring; charges of discrimination filed against Coco-Cola Bottling Co., Central Batteries, U.S. Corps of Engineers, Wells Fargo, El Chico Restaurant, Sears Roebuck, Board of Education, Memphis Publishing Co., Pace Corp., Veterans Administration Hospital, Robin Department Store, Young Brothers Masonry, Herman Sowell Masonry Contractor, and Missouri-Pacific Railroad. NAACP has contacted president of Alodex Corp., General Contractor for Operation Breakthrough, to be sure employment policies meet Federal laws. Negotiations for equitable employment of Blacks in construction has broken down. Complaints of police brutality re: mistreatment of man and wife, harassment, beating of disabled vet who had been drinking, false arrest, beating of man on errand for employer, failure of police to investigate vandalism to Tri-State Defender building while providing much protection to Chickasaw Gardens. Executive Secretary filled seven speaking engagements during the month. Title II complaints filed against Village Barber and Lamar-Airways Barber Shop. NAACP represented at hearing on housing conducted by Tennessee Board of the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights; complaints by individuals re: apartment discrimination. Governor requested to take steps to retain food stamp office in neighborhood of those served. Political action included opposition to shortening polling hours, recruitment of black voter registration during automobile license tag sales, and door-to-door canvassing. Drive launched to increase life memberships. Expanded activity launched in membership drive; kick-off program March 29. Agenda April 7 – May 4, 1971 Education complaints filed re: firing in Hernando School, punishment of child in Westwood Elementary, question of child’s mental retardation, continued hearings re: problems related to school desegregation, and continued work with Black parents of Gordon Elementary. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Desoto Hardwood, Globe Department Store, Kress Department Store, Sears Roebuck, Root & Berry Pump Co., Veteran Cab Co., Everett Cook & Sons, WHBQ, Delta Container Corp., American Airlines, High’s Ice Cream Co., Ford Motor Co., Giant Foods and Fred Montesi, and B’nai B’rith Home and Hospital. Complaints filed against Police Department re: beating of youth with no arrest record, beating of man arrested required medical treatment, beating of suspect left him unable to work because of injuries, beating of man ticketed for speeding, man beaten for having white female in car, mothers of juveniles arrested in stolen car 51 state their sons were severely beaten, youth beaten for taking food stamps from another youth, arrest of man with arrest of his mother and lawyer threatened; complaints filed with all law and justice departments. Housing complaints filed in Desoto County, MS and against H & H Realty Co. Title II complaints filed against Arcade Barber Shop. NAACP Ghetto Development Committee reactivated because of failure of White-owned companies to hire Blacks. NAACP picketing construction site of the post office building. Executive Secretary filled two speaking engagements in April. Circular attributed to NAACP not the work of Memphis Branch—media carried the circular information as fact. Agenda May 5 - June 6, 1971 Education matters include firing of second Black teacher in Hernando, firing of White instructor at Northside for friendliness with Black students, hearing held regarding student problems resulting from desegregation, teacher dismissal because of personality clash, NAACP support of busing to achieve integration vs. PTA opposition to busing. Employment discrimination complaints filed against Iris Motel, Sam Belz Upholstery Co., Wells Fargo, Choctaw, Inc., foreman at post office construction site, and Marketland Foods. Police Department complaints re: police officers taking money from man who was stopped and searched, abusive treatment of minor children, harassment of residents of Foote-Claiborne Homes, man in company of white girl threatened. Ghetto Development Committee negotiating with Malone & Hyde for hiring at all levels. HUD is conducting performance review of building projects financed with Federal funds; request for help from Black masonry contractor terminated at housing project in McKenzie, TN. Political action taken re: voter registration, especially 18 year old students; NAACP opposes city-county consolidation. Legal Redress re: administration of justice in the reversal by the Tennessee Court of Criminal Appeals of the convictions of three Black youths in Sing Murder case. Increased activity in getting NAACP information and position statements before the public with WDIA and WLOK providing radio time; also, Executive Secretary appeared on Channel Five’s “Face to Face” to discuss busing. Major efforts during the month focused on membership campaign with climax in mass meeting on June 13. Special Report—May 28, 1971 Copy of speech made before the Board of Education by the Executive Secretary in support of busing to achieve school integration. 52 Agenda—June 6 – July 3, 1971 Education complaints re: dismissal of Black teacher without cause; federal suits filed on various matters relating to compliance or avoidance of school laws. Employment discrimination charges filed against Memphis Area Vocational School, Gridiron Restaurant, Memphis Transit Authority, Sears Roebuck, Don Russ Bubble Gum Factory, Shelby United Neighbors, Cleo Wrap Co., and Schlitz Brewing Company. Complaints filed against the Police Department re: beating of suspect and arrest on trumped up charges, beating of pool room manager (police charged with use of excessive force), arrest of 14 year old Vasco Smith, III for distributing NAACP literature near a polling place, discriminatory treatment of Blacks at Turney Training Center, a center for first offenders. Legal Redress re: case of Ulous Harris et al. death penalty voided by Supreme Court; a 1964 landmark Supreme Court decision. Housing complaints re: Savoy Apartments, W. H. Higgins Company Realtors, and Crosstown Storage Company. Political action successful in defeat of consolidation of city and county governments, with 90% of Black vote against. The Executive Secretary filled four speaking engagements during the month. NAACP notes the death of two long-time and faithful workers, James Lampley and Pete Higgins. Agenda—July 4 – August 9, 1971 Employment discrimination complaints filed against Memphis & Shelby County Health Dept., Commerce General, Holiday Inn Rivermont, Radio Station WLOK, Veterans Hospital, Anderson & Tully, Herman Sowell Brick Masonry Co., and Cook Industries. Complaints of police abuse filed re: mistreatment of bus rider, beating and false arrest, cursing of Black woman with White child, tape recording played to the city council in which police officer repeatedly used the word “nigra.” Legal redress—Memphis & Shelby County Bar Association indicates it will take no action in the Sing murder case. Education matters relate to legal fight to have schools comply with U.S. Supreme Court mandates on school desegregation. Las Vegas holiday a success—will repeat next year. Fifteen Memphians attended NAACP National Convention in Minneapolis, MN July 5-9; Memphis Branch won three awards. Voter registration campaign launched with support from many groups and emphasis on registering young voters. Executive Secretary filled speaking engagements and cancelled two because of hospitalization following sudden illness. 53 Agenda—August 10 – September 6, 1971 Employment discrimination complaints filed against the Home for Incurables, McDonalds, U.S. Industries, Buckeye Oil Mill, and Shelby County Government. Complaints filed against the police department for numerous beatings, arrests following alleged violations of the law, and arrest of sons of white parents, one Black (adopted) and one White, who were sent to Juvenile Court. Complaint filed against Tennessee Preparatory School for expulsion of Black student. Title II complaint filed against Moler Beauty School for discriminatory service. Complaint filed against MLG&W for failure to restore paid-for service. Complaint filed against Baptist Hospital for denying employment to trained obstetric technician; complaint filed against St. Joseph Hospital for refusing emergency treatment to child of mother who had gone on strike against St. Joseph in 1969-70. Voter registration campaign will end September 7. Complaint filed against Memphis State University by mother of son who was denied entry because of ACT score. Legal action continues on school suits filed in the various courts. Agenda—September 7 – October 8, 1971 Employment discrimination complaints filed against Holiday Woodcraft, Happy Hal Toys, Tennessee Department of Employment Security, Southern Airlines, Liberty Cash Grocery Warehouse, and Pancake House. Complaint filed against Shelby County Penal Farm for dismissal of Black math instructor; however Commissioner Lee Hyden states man was hired only for one session. Complaint filed by MLG&W employee for absentee reprimand. Complaints filed against police department re: abuse and arrest of postal employee, arrest of woman stopped for speeding in school district, arrest and beating of man charged with possession of marijuana, arrest and beating of individuals stopped while driving, abuse and harassment of White man when seen with Black friends, arrest and beating of man picked up for public drunkenness, complaint by woman arrested several times for refusing advances of police officer, threats made when man stopped for speeding, and severe beating of man when police called on domestic violence case resulting in broken bones. Board of Education matters include too many cases of racial discrimination in hiring, retention, and transfer of Black teachers with cases cited, complaint filed against Sheffield School, letter to Governor regarding his inflammatory language in discussing busing and efforts to evade. Political action taken in voter registration with a total of 105,765 registered in Shelby County, voter education program, and election of three Black members to City Council (Fred L. Davis, John Ford, and J. O. Patterson) and three Black members to Board of Education (George H. Brown Carl E. Johnson, and Maxine Smith). 54 Agenda—October 9 – October 31, 1971 Employment discrimination complaint filed against International Harvester. Education complaints filed against Adult Education Center and State Technical Institute; efforts to speed up hearing on suit filed against Board of Education thwarted, suit against County Board of Education now under appeal. Police brutality/harassment charges filed re: individuals picked up for questioning and beaten, forced confessions, beatings when individual arrested; all complaints filed with all justice agencies. On October 15, police officers beat 17 year old Elton Hayes to death and also beat two teenaged companions. Police reported this case as a traffic accident. Attorney General ruled the death a homicide. Response by NAACP includes vigorous protest before City Council and Shelby County Quarterly Court, as well as to the Sheriff’s office and Shelby County Commission, protest re: curfew called by Mayor the night after the funeral; protest filed with U.S. Dept. of Justice; resolution adopted urging hiring of Black Assistant Police Chief; letter to President of the United States asking for punishment of the perpetrators. Samuel C. Jackson, Assistant Secretary of HUD, featured at town hall meeting, spoke at breakfast sponsored by Memphis Area Chamber of Commerce, and visited federal projects built under HUD auspices. Political action at Branch meeting featured analysis of October 7 municipal elections with examination of run-off races—more Blacks than Whites voted. Plans for Miss Social Belle Contest underway—Coronation Ball December 3. Fall membership campaign kick-off October 24—detailed action plan. Agenda—November 1 – December 3, 1971 Employment discrimination complaints filed against Herman Brothers Cement, Memphis Furniture Factory, Kimco, and Globe Shopping Center. Education matters include complaint from Black teacher who failed to score 1,000 on the N.T.E.; hearings on school suit in Federal District Court and pending outcome. Complaints re: police abuse and brutality have not lessened and cases of beatings, harassment, unjust arrest, beatings of patrons in several pool rooms, threats of violence and death, and trumped up charges; progress in the Elton Hayes case drags on. NAACP has requested the courts to investigate selection of Grand Jury and its foreman, has requested the U.S. Attorney General to impanel a Federal Grand Jury to investigate the Hayes case, requested approval of a Human Relations Commission empowered to investigate charges of abuse by law enforcement officers. Great efforts made to increase 1971 membership. Miss Social Belle Contest a great success—brought in $17,000. Political action analysis of vote in mayoral run-off.; City Council has three Black Councilmen; Board of Education has three elected Blacks, including the NAACP Executive Secretary. New Standing Committee Chairmen named. 55 Agenda—December 4, 1971 – January 4, 1972 Employment discrimination complaints filed against Katz Drug Store, Delta Refining Company, Peeples Petroleum Company, W. R. Grace & Company, Cage Nursing Home, Giant Foods, Neighborhood House Day Care Center, WDIA, and suit filed against the building trades, including 17 Memphis contractors and the Bricklayers Union. Complaints re: Police Department--NAACP officials oppose recently created Community Relations Commission as having no authority to handle complaints against law enforcement officers and the growing number of police brutality cases; complaint filed by man in Mason, TN charging beating following charge of assault and battery. Executive Secretary has resumed limited speaking engagements. Memphis Branch ended year with a total of 5,504 members. Mother of five Westwood students charges her children’s lunch tickets taken away because a relative took one child to Hawaii at relative’s expense. Chairman of NAACP’s Education Com. named to Title I Advisory Com. Annual Report—1971 The 34 page Annual Report of the Executive Secretary covers an extremely busy year with wide-ranging activities undertaken by the Memphis Branch and its officers. The focus of the report has a dual emphasis on (1) efforts to eliminate school segregation and discrimination in the Memphis school system—especially busing of students as a means to accomplish that goal and (2) strong opposition to continued police brutality and harassment of Black citizens. The beating death of Elton Hayes was a clarion call in this regard. Other work detailed in the report includes meetings, speaking engagements, press and publicity, employment and business development in the ghetto, action taken regarding employment discrimination in businesses and health care facilities, housing matters, legal redress, political action such as voter registration and the election of Blacks to the City Council and the Board of Education, and the continuing efforts to expand membership. Folder 12 – Items 14 Agenda—January 5 – February 1, 1972 Employment discrimination complaints filed against Southern Warehouse, First National Bank, Memphis Defense Depot, Chrysler Parts Depot, Schlitz Brewing Co., Hogue & Knott Supermarket, Bruce Carton Co., Progressive Foods, Crown Zellerbach, and Methodist Hospital. Housing complaint filed against Hermitage Apartments. Complaints filed against the Police Department include unlawful entry and search, arrest in Arkansas and theft of complainants property and driver’s license, 56 abuse of Black students, and other abuse and harassment; NAACP has been active in trying to rid city of crime and stop police officers from shooting and killing Black youth. Executive Secretary has filled six speaking engagemen

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Katherine Hinds Smythe Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Katherine Hinds was born in Mississippi and spent her early years in Tupelo. She attended Randolph Macon Woman’s College in Virginia, but transferred to Southwestern College (now Rhodes) in Memphis and went on to graduate Phi Beta Kappa in 1953. With the goal of becoming a teacher, Katherine pursued a Master’s degree at Duke University, specializing in Southern literature. -- After graduating from Duke, Katherine returned to Memphis and married William Hamilton Smythe in 1955. Her first teaching assignment was at East High School, followed by a position at Memphis State University, where she taught literature for four years. She retired from teaching to have her first child, William Hamilton, in 1959. She had a daughter, Katie in 1962 and another son, Clay in 1967. As a young wife and mother she began working in philanthropy through membership in the Le Bonheur Club and the Junior League of Memphis. -- In addition to her public interests, Smythe dedicated much of her life to the management of Memorial Park Cemetery, which was founded by her grandfather, E. Clovis Hinds in 1924. In 1963, Smythe began working part-time at Memorial Park, under the direction of her aunt, Bess Hinds Anderson, who had become president after the death of her father, E.C. Hinds. Katherine Hinds Smythe assumed the leadership of the cemetery in 1978. -- While operating Memorial Park, Smythe continued her volunteer work by serving as president of the Junior League. She also served as president of the Rhodes College International Alumni Association and president of the board of the Memphis∙Shelby County Public Library & Information Center. In addition, she helped organize the capital campaign for the Foundation for the Library, which raised more than $20 million for the construction of the Central Library. -- The photographs and papers in The Katherine Hinds Smythe Collection were given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mrs. Smythe in 2000. The material documents the history of Memorial Park and includes advertisements, legal documents and papers pertaining to the cemetery’s advertising and public relations efforts from its founding in 1924 through the 1990s. Also included is material on the Hinds-Smythe Cosmopolitan Funeral Home, which was a Midtown Memphis expansion of Memorial Park that operated from 1984 to 1996. -- The collection contains many photographs documenting the development of Memorial Park, including photos of E.C. Hinds, Katherine Hinds Smythe, her son Hamilton Smythe and the dedication of the Memorial Park Mausoleum in 1972. A unique aspect of the collection is the material on Dionicio Rodríguez, the artist hired to create a Crystal Shrine Grotto and other sculptural works within Memorial Park. The papers include correspondence with Rodríguez, articles written about the artist and documentation of his works in Memorial Park being added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1991. The finding aid to the collection includes biographical information on other artists whose work is featured on the grounds of Memorial Park, including Marie Craig and Luther Hampton. In addition, the materials include a description of Smythe’s publication, Distinguished Citizens of Midtown, which contains profiles of prominent Memphians who lived in the Central Gardens neighborhood, as well as portraits of the individuals profiled in the book.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Morris Solomon Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Morris Solomon was born in Lomza, Poland in 1894. As a young man he moved to Memphis, where his relatives owned a small grocery store called the Sunset Market. Solomon became a police officer in 1919, starting out as a patrolman and going on to serve as a mounted officer downtown. He became the first detective of Jewish heritage in Memphis when he was promoted to detective sergeant. He retired from the police force in 1942. -- Solomon was perhaps best known for solving the “Grey Hat Mystery” in 1927. He spent months tracking down the killer of John E. Levy, the “Hot Tamale King.” The only clue was a grey felt hat belonging to the murderer which was found at the scene of the crime. Solomon took the hat door to door and had people try it on until a man named Thronbo Gunion confessed to the murder. -- Included in The Morris Solomon Papers are a number of items relating to his police work, such as a glossary of 1920s underworld terms, several of his “working notebooks” and the signed confession of a Mississippi murderer. The papers also contain letters exchanged between Solomon and his wife Adein, which include many references to his police activities. -- Solomon was a veteran of World War I and a committed patriot. He was active in the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars and frequently delivered speeches on local radio stations on topics such as national defense, communism and the rise of Nazi Germany. The texts of many of these speeches are included in the collection. -- Also contained in the collection are numerous examples of different letterhead stationery, bank statements, postcards, materials which Solomon was apparently gathering for a textbook on police methodology and even a recording of him singing My Country, ‘Tis of Thee. The collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Sears Roebuck and Co., which came into possession of the papers when the company purchased Solomon’s former home. The papers were found in the attic, where they had remained for over 40 years.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: crime; criminals; forensics; immigrants; Jews; law; law enforcement; military; murders; patriotism; police; veterans;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: South Memphis Land Company Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The South Memphis Land Company Collection was donated in 2007 by Barton Lee Mallory III, the grandson of B. Lee Mallory who served as president of the South Memphis Land Company from 1905 until his death in 1938. Comprising of 11 linear feet, the South Memphis Land Company Collection contains advertisements, correspondence, financial and legal records, newspaper clippings, maps and property records related to the operation of one of the most important real estate companies in the Mid-South. The collection also includes correspondence related to B. Lee Mallory’s involvement with several civic improvement organizations such as the Boy Scouts of America, Rotary Club, Memphis Chamber of Commerce and the Real Estate Association.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Open Air Theater Programs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Operettas and musicals provided a welcome escape from the hard realities of everyday life in the 1930s and ‘40s. They had unforgettable melodies such as Ah, Sweet Mystery of Life and Indian Love Call, as well as rousing choruses, comic relief, interesting plots, romantic relationships and happy endings. Memphians, along with people throughout the country, enjoyed operetta films with Jeannette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy, and the performances at the Memphis Open Air Theater provided people in the community with similar live entertainment. -- MOAT was founded in 1938 under the sponsorship of the Junior Chamber of Commerce. To prepare for the first season of five productions, the Memphis Park Commission budgeted $6,000 of improvements to the Shell – new spotlight towers, stage floors, lights, dressing rooms and sound equipment. Ticket prices ranged from 25 cents to one dollar. The first season ended with a deficit of $1,918. The MOAT continued to experience financial difficulty until 1940, when the company celebrated its first profitable season. -- After several successful seasons, expenses for MOAT began to increase and attendance started to decline. In August 1949 The Commercial Appeal asked its readers why fewer people were attending MOAT productions. Readers responded that they disliked the style of comedy in the productions, the performances started too late and the intermissions were too lengthy. Other factors such as hot and variable weather, a poor sound system, lack of needed improvements to the Shell stage and backstage area, inadequate parking and a desire for more contemporary musicals also led to declining attendance. The company’s deficit climbed to $38,000 after the last MOAT season of 1951. -- During the years that the Memphis Open Air Theater was active, the Library collected programs from the performances. Often, single programs, or small groups of programs, were given to the Library by individuals who attended the performances presented during the summer from 1938 through 1951. The Memphis Open Air Theater Programs represent a compilation of these programs.. The finding aid to the collection lists the title, composer, director, conductor and principals, as well as supporting singers and actors for the MOAT productions. In addition, the finding aid provides brief biographical information on some individuals associated with the MOAT. While it lasted, the MOAT produced an impressive range of productions from 19th century operettas to contemporary musicals like Hit the Deck and Brigadoon. The programs and playbills for many of the MOAT productions in this collection serve as the annals for the memorable MOAT summers. -- In addition to this collection of programs and playbills, the Memphis and Shelby County Room houses The Memphis Open Air Theater Collection which includes minutes from several MOAT committees and correspondence regarding the budget, efforts to increase attendance, scheduling of performances and selection of plays.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Ogden Carley Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Ogden Carley was born in East Ontario, Canada, in 1896. He worked for the Hearst papers as a police reporter in Los Angeles and Chicago before coming to Memphis in 1923 as a police reporter for the Commercial Appeal. He served as city editor and managing editor before becoming the editorial writer in 1939, where his editorials attracted national attention. Toward the end of World War II, he served as a correspondent in Europe covering the movement of Allied forces into German territory. -- Nicknamed “The Inspector” because of his dedication to his role as police reporter, Carley had a strong interest in law enforcement which led him to form a friendship with F.B.I. Director J. Edgar Hoover. For twenty years he regularly addressed the graduating class of the F.B.I. National Police Academy. -- Carley was perhaps best known for his efforts in flood control. He supported the activities of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and was a member of the Mississippi River Commission. His wife, Louise, was the daughter of Captain Anthony Meldahl, a famous river pilot, and Carley was instrumental, along with Kenneth McKellar and Clifford Davis, in bringing the Meldahl Dam Project to completion. -- In addition to his work in journalism and flood control, Carley was active in civic and community affairs. He served for six months as secretary for Mayor Rowlett Paine and was a charter member of the Memphis Newspaper Guild. He was also active as a Mason and acted in Memphis Little Theater productions. -- The John Ogden Carley Papers were donated to the library by his widow, Mrs. Louise Carley. The papers contain correspondence, newspaper clippings and photographs related to his interest in many varied subjects including yellow fever, the Mississippi River and the Meldahl Dam Project, E.H. Crump and the legend of George Armstrong Custer. In addition, the collection includes speeches Carley made to the graduating class of the police academy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation over a period of twenty years.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Open Air Theater Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Several attempts were made in the early thirties, most notably by the Beethoven Club, to present operas and musicals in Overton Park during the summer. These efforts were unsuccessful until 1937, when the Park Commission decided to present musicals in the Shell amphitheater which had been completed in Overton Park in 1936. The enthusiasm and support for the idea of summertime musical entertainment led the Junior Chamber of Commerce to sponsor the creation of the Memphis Open Air Theater, or MOAT, a non-profit civic corporation. MOAT began producing musicals with local and professional talent in the summer of 1938. -- The plays performed during the first season were successful and Memphis came to be seen as a cultural center of the Mid-South. The success of the MOAT productions reflected the national trend of musicals being presented in public venues during the summer. The theater company was a charter member of the National Civic Operetta Association that formed in 1946 to promote and coordinate the interests of organizations such as the MOAT, and the President of the MOAT became the first head of that association. -- In its early years, MOAT was relatively successful and extended its season from the initial five weeks to eight weeks. However, with the extension of the season and the declining popularity of musicals, it became difficult to produce a season of completely new shows every year. By the last season in 1951, five of the eight productions had been previously presented. In addition, attendance began to decline, conflict erupted among MOAT leadership, and the company faced large deficits. In January of 1952, MOAT members elected to continue the MOAT on a semi-professional basis, however, this plan was abandoned. -- The Memphis Open Air Theater Collection includes correspondence regarding scheduling of performances, selection of plays, efforts to increase attendance and the company’s budget. Also included are minutes from various MOAT committees. The Memphis Open Air Theater Programs, a collection of programs from MOAT productions, is also housed in the Memphis and Shelby County Room.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Symphony Orchestra Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Following several years of planning and preparation, the Memphis Symphony Orchestra gave its large collection of materials to the Library in 2006. Included in the collection are programs, biographical profiles and publicity photographs of artists and conductors, advertising brochures, flyers and postcards. Also included are the Board of Directors and Executive Committee minutes, as well as some fifty-three scrapbooks which contain press clippings and photographs. The major collection is contained in some 70 boxes. -- Program material for the 1940s is sparse; however, by the late 1950s there is a full run of annual programs. Alphabetical and date indexes to the performances and guest artists greatly facilitate researching this large collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mid-South Flood Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Flooding impacted the society, business environment and ecology of the Mid-South. These mostly man-made disasters interrupted and permeated all aspects of life until the mid-twentieth Century. Floods were so frequent and sometimes so devastating that they became part of what defined the South. Even areas relatively safe from high water such as Memphis suffered from the damage to the surrounding areas. Because of this, no study of the history of the region can be complete without an examination of this terrible phenomenon. -- The movement of Europeans into the Mississippi Valley led to changes in the pattern of seasonal high water that was once part of the natural cycle of life. Deforestation caused the gradual flow of rainwater from higher elevations to become a sudden torrent that caused rivers to overflow their banks. The initial response was to construct dikes to protect individual pieces of property. This idea eventually resulted in the construction of a system of levees along the Mississippi River. -- Unfortunately, the levees had the unintended effect of causing flooding to increase. The more complete the levee system became, the fewer places flood waters had to flow. The confined water continued to rise with each flood, and each time water would break through the weak places in the levees and back into unprotected tributaries. Debates raged over the proper course of action to control the rivers, while engineers made futile attempts to restrain the floods. Most clung to the old “levees only” approach until the “super floods” of 1927 and 1937. It was in those years that the United States Army Corps of Engineers adopted new methods proposed by chief of the Corps of Engineers Edwin Jadwin and the nature of flood control changed forever. -- The Mid-South Flood Collection is made up of various documents relating to the issue of flooding in the greater Memphis area in the nineteenth and first half of the twentieth Centuries. There are many differing opinions represented in these writings, making this collection ideal for anyone interested in the development of flood control methodology. These items were acquired by the library over many years, but never archived together. The collection includes pamphlets, brochures, newspaper articles, journal articles, books, maps, photographs and scrapbooks. Gathering these materials together gives researchers a better understanding of the issue of flooding, the many approaches to the problem and the controversy surrounding the development of flood control in the Mid-South region.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Official Papers of Shelby County Commissioner James W. "Jimmy" Moore
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The story of James W. “Jimmy” Moore’s life sounds like the American dream. Moore grew up in a small town and became a major league baseball player, playing in two world series. He then became a business executive before beginning a successful political career which lasted until his retirement. -- Moore was born in 1902 in Bemis, Tennessee and attended high school in nearby Jackson. He left Union University in Jackson during his third year there to begin a baseball career that lasted fourteen years. In 1930 and 1931 he played with the Philadelphia Athletics, a team which won the pennant both years and the World Series in 1930. -- Following his baseball career, Moore worked for two decades as an executive with Yellow Cab Co. and Yellow Bus Line. He also worked at Joyner Heard Realty Co. before being elected to the Memphis City Commission in 1959. As Commissioner of Finance and Institutions, he was largely responsible for the construction of the Liberty Bowl Memorial Stadium and the Mid-South Coliseum. The Memphis Metropolitan Airport was also completed during his administration. -- Moore resigned from the City Commission in 1966 to become County Commissioner of Health and Institutions. He served in this capacity and on the transitional County Executive Committee until 1975, when the Shelby County government was restructured. -- The Moore papers consist of his office files from his years as county commissioner. The material, which includes correspondence, memos, reports and other items related to the work of the Commissioner of Health and Institutions, gives researchers insight into the day-to-day operation of the Health Department. The papers also include materials on subjects of particular importance during Moore’s terms of office such as whether an employee has a right to retain her maiden name after her marriage. In addition, there is information on the restructure of the county government. In addition to Moore’s office files, there are fourteen scrapbooks containing newspaper clippings from the years of his service to the city and county.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: airports; annexation; baseball; consolidation; government; health; hospitals; politics; public health; public service; recreation; sanitation; sewers; sports; women; women's rights;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Earl Moreland Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Earl Moreland, a popular figure in Memphis radio and television, was born in Decatur County, Tennessee, and attended grammar school in Collierville, Tennessee. His family then moved to Memphis, where Moreland attended Snowden Junior High and Central High School. -- Moreland showed a talent for drama in school, winning prizes in county declamation contests and holding parts in school plays. He had the lead in his senior play, and was voted the most versatile boy in his senior class. -- In 1935 Moreland began his radio career as a rookie announcer at WHBQ in Memphis and then moved to station WMC in March of 1936. Shortly after starting at WMC, Moreland began hosting an early morning music and monologue program, “Star Time,” which stayed on the air for more than 20 years. He became chief announcer for WMC in 1939, and began serving as production manager in 1942. -- Moreland enlisted with the Army Signal Corps in World War II and was later transferred to Armed Forces Radio. At the end of the war, Moreland became program director for Radio Tokyo and the Armed Forces Japanese Network. -- In 1946 Moreland resumed work with WMC as local sales manager and became commercial manager in 1950. In 1954 he was promoted to station manager for WMCT television, and then assistant general manager of WMC Broadcasting, which included WMC, WMC-FM and WMCT. -- In addition to his work in radio and television, Moreland was active in community theater. He participated in Memphis Little Theatre productions throughout the 1930s and 40s and won the theater’s “Oswald” award for best performance of the year for his performances in Margin for Error and Kiss and Tell. -- Moreland was a strong supporter of community organizations. He served as Master of Ceremonies for the Cotton Carnival and president of the Civitan Club. He was a member of the board of directors of the Salvation Army and the Girls Club of Memphis, Inc. Moreland was also active with Boy Scouts and the Rotary Club. In addition, he served as director of the Sales Executives Club, the Memphis Advertising Club, and the Tennessee Association of Broadcasters. -- Earl Moreland died in 1963 from complications that arose during surgery for an injured vertebra. He was 49 years old. He left behind his wife, Mildred Sweetland Moreland, and a daughter, Carol. -- The Earl Moreland Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mildred Moreland. The collection is composed of letters, scripts, playbills and business materials that were saved by Moreland. These items include much inside information about Memphis Little Theatre and WMC radio station. In addition to the items donated by Mrs. Moreland, the collection includes an oral interview with Eugart Yerian, director of Memphis Little Theatre from 1933 to 1939 and 1947 to 1961.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: drama; entertainment; Memphis Little Theatre; military; public service; radio; television; theater; WMC;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Music Miscellany
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Memphis Music Miscellany is a collection of sheet music created from donations to the Memphis and Shelby County Room over the years by a number of individuals. The collection contains music published by Memphis companies such as the Bluff City Music Co., Yancy & Booker on Beale Street, O.K. Houck Piano Co., and J. Goldsmith & Sons Co. Also included is music composed by Memphians and compositions associated with the city such as "Miss Memphis: The Great booster March-Two-Step," the "Tennessee Centennial Prize March" and "Think of Me Little Daddy," which was published by W.C. Handy's music company, Pace & Handy Co., Inc., in 1919 in New York City.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Berl Olswanger Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Berl Olswanger, known as “Mr. Music,” was a highly talented and popular musician and civil leader in Memphis from the 1940s through the 1970s. During his career he worked as a performer, composer, band leader and music teacher. -- Olswanger was raised in the North Memphis Pinch neighborhood. A child prodigy, Berl began playing the piano at three years of age. By age 12, he was the staff pianist for WMC Radio, and at 18, he was made leader of the radio station’s band. He graduated from Central High School and earned a Bachelor of Arts and a Master’s Degree from Memphis State University. -- He enlisted in the United States Navy during World War II and was assigned to serve on a destroyer in the South Pacific. When Admiral William F. Halsey heard Olswanger play piano for a service event, he made the talented young man an entertainment officer. Olswanger left the navy in 1945 as a first lieutenant and briefly pursued a music career in New York City. Yet he decided to come back to Memphis “to be with the people I love.” In 1947, he married Edna Mae Long, and they had a daughter, Anna Ruth, and a son, Berl, Jr. -- After his return to Memphis, Olswanger opened a music store and formed a band. In addition to composing and arranging music for his orchestra and playing piano at numerous solo engagements, Olswanger did a great deal to bring quality music to the people of Memphis by giving free concerts at schools, churches and civic clubs. -- Olswanger was an active member of the Downtown Kiwanis Club, and was installed as president in 1961. He received the T.B. Kirkpatrick Memorial Award from the Kiwanis Club for outstanding service and leadership in the community as well as the Jewish Welfare Fund Award and the YMCA Man-for-Boy Award. -- From the late 1940s through 1965, Olswanger hosted television shows on WMC-TV, WHBQ-TV and WREC-TV. In 1970, Olswanger was named music and art consultant and public relations director for the Shelby County Board of Education. To further music education, he developed a music school associated with his stores and also organized a dance club so students and friends could enjoy his music. -- In 1980, to mark his fifty years as a musician and entertainer, he gave free programs for the many organizations which had supported him through the years. At one such program, Olswanger received the Mayor’s Award of Merit. -- The Berl Olswanger Collection was originally given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by his daughter Anna in 1985. Substantial additions to the collection were made in later years. The papers include newspaper clippings, photographs and a number of publications. A significant portion of the material relates to research conducted by Anna on her father’s extensive career in music and public service. Also included is material on Berl’s wife, Edna Long Olswanger, who was very involved in her husband’s musical career and shared his commitment to community service. Olswanger’s role as “Mr. Music” is represented in material related to his radio and television performances, while other information documents his long participation in the Downtown Kiwanis Club, the Goodfellows, the Memphis Cancer Society and other service groups. Information related to the honors and recognition Olswanger received during his fifty years as a professional musician and entertainer is also included.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edmund Orgill Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Edmund Orgill Papers were donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center in the 1970s by the City of Memphis. The Orgill Papers cover the year 1959. The papers include correspondence and government reports related to Orgill’s final year as mayor of Memphis. The original order of the files was maintained in the processing of this collection. -- The Edmund Orgill Papers contain detailed information on the activities of municipal government in the American South in the 1950s. The collection includes material on the development of an expressway system in Memphis, the relocation of Kennedy veterans’ hospital to the downtown medical center and the operation of the Memphis Police Department.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Papers of Memphis Mayor Watkins Overton
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Samuel Watkins Overton was born in Memphis in 1894 to a distinguished local family. He was the great-grandson of John Overton, a founder of Memphis, the grandson of Napoleon Hill, a wealthy businessman, and the son of S. Watkins Overton, who built the first box plant in Memphis. The family left Memphis for Waukesha, Wisconsin when Overton’s father died in 1902. -- Watkins Overton returned to Memphis after serving in France during World War I and graduating from the University of Chicago Law School. In 1922 he joined the law firm founded by U.S. Senator Kenneth McKellar. Two years later Overton was elected to the Tennessee General Assembly, serving first in the House and then the Senate. Through his service in the legislature and his association with McKellar, Overton was noticed by political leader E.H. Crump, who at that time was gaining power in Memphis. Crump endorsed Overton as a candidate for Mayor in 1927; and with Overton’s election, Crump gained complete control of Memphis. -- Overton served Crump and Memphis for the next 12 years, but policy differences with Crump led to Overton’s resignation in 1939. The two leaders reconciled, and in 1949 Overton was appointed Mayor by the City Commission with Crump’s approval. The relationship deteriorated yet again, leading Overton to resign a second time in February 1953. Overton attempted to regain his job as mayor after Crump’s death in 1954, but was unsuccessful. -- The Papers of Memphis Mayor Watkins Overton consist of his office files from his sixteen years of service as Mayor of Memphis. Overton served as Mayor during the Great Depression, and his papers reflect the impact of New Deal programs such as the Public Works Administration and the Works Progress Administration on the city. The collection also sheds light on important issues such as public ownership of utilities, race relations, education and city growth. A unique picture of municipal government can be found in these papers because of the commission form of government which was in operation at the time. The commission was made up of the mayor and four commissioners who carried out legislative responsibilities and directed city departments. -- It is important to note that many of Mayor Overton’s files are housed in the Special Collections Department at the University of Memphis Ned R. WcWherter Library. Researchers may wish to consult these files which contain information on local politics and include Overton’s correspondence with E.H. Crump.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Page/Lenox Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Warren Neville Page (1876 – 1945) was born in Calhoun County, Mississippi and moved to Memphis as a boy. He went to work for Tracy Printing Co. at age 15. After serving as an apprentice, Page became a linotype operator for the Appeal-Avalanche in 1892. Later he worked for the Commercial Appeal, the Scimitar, the News-Scimitar, and finally the Press-Scimitar. -- Page served as state senator in the fifty-seventh General Assembly in 1910 – 1912 and was the first union member to be elected to the Senate. He had been a member of the International Typographical Union for over fifty years and was elected president of the local chapter six times. He also served several terms as president of the Memphis Trades and Labor Council. Page was a charter member of the Memphis Moose Lodge and was also a member of the Masons, the Knights of Pythias, the Magnolia Camp of the Woodsmen of the World and the Maccabees. -- Page served as mayor of Lenox from 1905 to 1907. Lenox was a small area incorporated as a city on October 7, 1896, and annexed into the city of Memphis September 1, 1909. Its boundaries were Poplar Avenue on the north, Central on the south, Trezevant on the east and Cooper on the west. The town’s history dates back to 1890, when the area was created as a subdivision by the Equitable Land and Construction Co. The subdivision was a result of the building of the East End Railway Co., known as a “dummy line,” which linked eastern areas such as Lenox to Memphis. -- While Page served as mayor of Lenox, water and sewer systems were completed, fire hydrants were installed and sidewalks were constructed. In 1909, Page served as chair of the building committee of Lenox School, which operated as an elementary school until 1972. In 1973, it became a special education facility. Lenox School was officially closed in 1977 and has since been converted into condominiums. -- The Page/Lenox Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1980 by Marguerite Page Botto. Most of the material in the collection, which includes newspaper articles, photographs and correspondence, dates from 1904 to 1915.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: annexation; government; labor; mayors; neighborhoods; newspapers; politics; public service; public works; railroads; state senators; unions;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Index to The Memphis Historical Society Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memphis Historical Society had its roots in the Old Folks of Shelby County, which was founded in 1857 and published a journal called the Old Folks Record. This organization evolved into the Confederate Relief and Historical Association in 1866 and then the Confederate Historical Association in 1869. In 1884 the group came to be known as Camp 28, United Confederate Veterans, which published The Old Guard in Gray. The group reorganized in 1900 as the Memphis Historical Society under John Preston Young. In 1912, Young published the Standard History of Memphis Tennessee. Finally, in 1935, the organization grew to encompass all of West Tennessee and adopted the West Tennessee Historical Society as their name. Today, the group, which publishes The West Tennessee Historical Papers, serves to preserve the history of West Tennessee through collecting historical documents and conserving landmark structures. -- This collection includes lectures presented to the society by its members before the organization began publishing The West Tennessee Historical Papers. The lectures, which provide valuable insight into the early history of Memphis, include papers on John Overton, Marcus Winchester, Christian Brothers College, Fort Pickering, Fort Assumption, and the park system in Memphis. The finding aid to the collection contains a comprehensive index of the subjects addressed in the lectures.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: architecture; Civil War; clubs; education; entertainment; land grants; law; mayors; parks; recreation; slavery; social life; streets;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Illustrations from Harper's Weekly Newspaper and Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Over many years the Memphis and Shelby County Room has collected print and photographic materials on the history of Memphis, Shelby County and the surrounding area. This collection of Harper’s Weekly Newspaper and Frank Leslie’s Illustrated Newspaper prints, along with some photographs from 19th Century publications, provides visual documentation of the Memphis area prior to the period when photography became the common means of depicting events and places. Many of the earliest prints provide the only visual record of Memphis for the period prior to the Civil War. -- Many of the prints show Civil War battles and engagements in Tennessee and the surrounding region. Of particular interest are the images showing the naval battle at Memphis between Union and Confederate fleets. Following the defeat of the confederate gunboat flotilla by the Union naval force, Memphis surrendered to the Federal command, which prevented a land battle for possession of the city. -- Another important group of images show flooding on the Mississippi River, as well as government efforts to stabilize the river banks. Images of the devastating yellow fever epidemic of 1878 provide the only visuals for that terrible event, which had such a dramatic impact on life in Memphis. Other sketches depict important buildings and significant public events that took place in Memphis.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: buildings; Civil War; drawings; floods; military; Mississippi River; prints; sketches; steamboats; yellow fever;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Records of the Memphis Sub-District of the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Congress established the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen and Abandoned Lands, or Freedmen’s Bureau as it was commonly known, in March 1865 as the end of the Civil War drew near. An agency of the War Department, the Freedmen’s Bureau had two main responsibilities: aiding former slaves in their transition to freedom and disposing of confiscated and abandoned lands. Clinton B. Fisk served as the first Assistant commissioner for the District of Tennessee in Nashville. Under Fisk’s supervision, Davis Tillson began work as Memphis’s first Sub-Assistant Commissioner in July 1865. Over time, however, the opponents of the Bureau in Congress succeeded in diminishing its purview and authority. After 1869, the agency was primarily concerned with aiding veterans of the United States Colored Troops collect pension and bounty payments. The Freedmen’s Bureau maintained an office in Memphis through 1872, the last year of the agency’s operation. -- Reproduced on microfilm from the holdings of the National Archives, the records of the Memphis Sub-District reflect the agency’s focus on property disposition and assisting the freedmen. This collection was reproduced at the request of the History Department as part of its commitment to preserve and make available local records for historical and genealogical research. The Friends of the Library made the purchase of this collection possible through a generous donation. -- The Memphis Sub-District office was administered by the Sub-Assistant Commissioner and the Disbursing Officer of Claims. Correspondence to and from these officials constitute the single largest type of record in the collection. Also included are records of other staff officers and correspondence from Bureau officials in Washington, D.C., and Nashville, field agents from surrounding counties, former slave owners, freedmen, municipal officials, planters and farmers, property owners and representatives of benevolent societies such as the American Missionary Association. The records also include numerous letters relating to office management, personnel and costs. These documents provide much information about the operation of the Sub-District and the responsibilities and activities of its agents, and reflect the conditions under which these men worked including staffing shortages and an often volatile political climate. -- One remarkable portion of the records are the small number of letters from African Americans seeking information about missing relatives, many of whom had been dispersed by slave sales. Correspondents asked Bureau agents for their help in locating people in Memphis or a nearby area. Unfortunately, there is no record in this collection of whether reunions eventually occurred. Nevertheless, these letters document the vulnerability of African Americans under slavery and post-Emancipation efforts to reunite families. -- These documents are an exceptional resource for historians, genealogists, and students of the Civil War and Reconstruction. Researchers will find much evidence of social, economic and political conditions including race relations, labor issues, health conditions and public education. There is also much information about how the Bureau operated and its working relationships with city officials and benevolent societies. -- For researchers of African American subjects, individuals or families, the Bureau records are significant. Some genealogists, for example, may find evidence to extend their research into the pre-Civil War period. Letters, affidavits and other documents pertaining to the United States Colored Troops are especially promising in this regard. Genealogists and others searching for information about white individuals should also consult these records. Of particular interest will be such property records as applications for the restoration of property, rental receipts and a register of plantations, as well as oaths of allegiance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Civil War; economics; education; family; genealogy; government; health; race; Reconstruction; slavery;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cemetery Burial Place Record of the Congregation Beth El Emeth
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Congregation Beth El Emeth, which means House of the True God, was founded as an Orthodox house of worship in 1861 by Rabbi Jacob Peres and forty former congregants of B’nai Israel, Congregation Children of Israel. Beth El Emeth was chartered by the Tennessee legislature in 1862 and a dedication ceremony took place at a location on Jefferson near Front Street. In 1863 the Congregation elected Rabbi Joel Alexander of Brooklyn, New York as its first spiritual leader. Ferdinand Sarner was subsequently hired as the Rabbi of Beth El Emeth in 1872; he died in the 1878 Yellow Fever epidemic. -- In 1882 the Congregation consolidated with Congregation Children of Israel. However, in 1916 Congregation Beth El Emeth split a second time split from Congregation Children of Israel anrchased the Children of Israel building at 165 Poplar Avenue. The congregants of Beth El Emeth met at this building until 1957, when they constructed a new house of worship at 3771 Poplar Avenue. Beth El Emeth merged with Anshei Sphard Congregation in 1965 to form Anshei Sphard—Beth El Emeth congregation. Since 1971 the Congregation has worshiped at a synagogue they constructed at 170 East Yates Road. -- The congregation’s original funeral ledger book was loaned to the Memphis and Shelby County Room for photocopying in 2002. The ledger book dates from the 1860s to the 1880s and is an excellent resource for people conducting research in Jewish family history and local history. The records include the name of the deceased, their birthplace, their place of residence and the date of death, as well as the cemetery section number. The original ledger book is housed among the historical documents at Congregation Anshei Sphard—Beth El Emeth.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: burial records; cemeteries; Congregation Beth El Emeth; family; funerals; genealogy; Jews; Judaism; religion;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mallory-Neely House and Tennessee Homecoming Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Daughters of the American Revolution - Sons of the American Revolution - Children of the American Revolution (DAR-SAR-CAR) Chapter House of West Tennessee donated the contents of this collection to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in 1988. The collection is composed of materials collected from a 1986 scrapbook, created by the organization, whose headquarters were located at the former home of Daisy Mallory, the Mallory-Neely House. The scrapbook contained photographs, newspaper clippings, correspondence, and other documents detailing the organization’s participation in “Tennessee Homecoming ’86,” a year-long, statewide celebration of Tennessee heritage and culture. -- In Spring 1986, the organization completed a restoration of the Mallory-Neely House’s boxwood garden. The organization also planted a Tulip Poplar tree given to the community by Tennessee Governor Lamar Alexander. The Chapter House also received a Certificate of Merit from the Tennessee Historical Commission for their contributions to the study and preservation of Tennessee’s historical heritage. -- In Fall 1986, the organization focused its projects on Benjamin Babb, a previous resident of their Chapter House. The group compiled a book, “Benjamin Babb from Virginia to Tennessee,” and created an exhibit, “Benjamin Babb Years at 652 Adams: December 1864-July 1883.” In August, the group participated in the 1986 Victorian Village Festival.

Neely, and most recently the restoration of the house MNTH 2 3 The unveiling of our dedication stone, by the project chairman, Mrs. Robert Tice March 1, 1986 MNTH 6 In trying to decide what the DAR/SAR/CAR Tennessee Homecoming ’86 project would be, we, the members of the Mallory/Neely House, decided to restore the Rose Gardens at our Chapter House. After consultations with experts and visits to the site by knowledgeable rosarians, it was their decision that our “Rose Garden Restoration” project would not be feasible. Pollution and shade were our enemies. Well, as our forefathers did, we met our enemy, and although we didn’t win the war, we did win our particular battle! That is how the “Boxwood Garden Restoration” 10 came into being. We’ve worked, we’ve partied, we’ve spend our money, we’ve fought the 1986 drought, and our infamous poison ivy, we’ve fussed among ourselves, BUT, now that the restoration is completed, WE ARE PROUD! MNTH 58 “Special Tree to be Planted” The Commercial Appeal, April 12, 1986 MNTH 59 Program: Dedication Ceremony for the Official Memphis Homecoming ’86 Tennessee State Tree MNTH 60 Flyer: Dedication Ceremony for the Official Tennessee Homecoming Tulip Poplar 20 MNTH 61 Invocation By Dr. Robert D. Tice Lord, we are indeed grateful to be able to gather here this afternoon to dedicate the planting of one of your creations – a sapling of a beautiful species that was long ago chosen as one of the symbols of our state. It is fitting that this young tree – so near the beginning of it’s life – should grace the landscape of this beautiful home which reminds us all of an era past. Thus, as the young and the old come together here today we are again reminded of your infinite wisdom in establishing the ongoing cycle of life in your universe. We ask your blessing on this tree. Give it a long and beautiful life. We also ask that everyone responsible for this occasion – whether present here today or not – be blessed with these things we ask in your name. Amen! oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Metropolitan Opera in Memphis Programs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Metropolitan Opera in Memphis Programs Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by several individuals over many years. The programs were then gathered together to create this collection which consists of programs for individual performances in Memphis of New York's Metropolitan Opera Company from 1946 to 1984. In 1946, Memphis businessman Isaac L. Myers convinced his friend Edward Johnson, manager of the Metropolitan Opera, to stage productions in Memphis. On May 20, 1946, the world-renowned opera company performed "Carmen" at the Ellis Auditorium, and the following evening "Madam Butterfly" was staged. For the next 37 years, the Met performed regularly in Memphis during their annual U.S. tour. Many noted opera singers performed in his during the Metropolitan Opera's visits to Memphis, including Placido Domingo, Marilyn Horne, Luciano Pavarotti and Beverly Sills. On May 14, 1984, the Met staged its final performance in Memphis with the presentation of "Tosca".
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Metropolitan Opera; music; opera; theater;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Opera Theatre / Opera Memphis Programs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memphis Opera Theatre/Opera Memphis Programs Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by several individuals over many years. The programs were then gathered together to create this collection which consists of programs for individual performances of the Memphis Opera Theatre and Opera Memphis from 1956 to 2008. The Memphis Opera Theatre was established in 1956 by civic leaders and members of the Beethoven Club. The first event, and Introduction to Opera, was offered at the Goodwyn Institute Auditorium on October 9, 1956. "La Traviata" was the first production performed by the Memphis Opera Theatre on March 29, 1957, at Ellis Auditorium. In 1973, the organization merged with the Memphis State Opera Theater, and in 1977, it was renamed Opera Memphis. Over the years Opera Memphis performed many world-renowned operas including "Tosca," "Carmen," "Don Giovanni," and "The Marriage of Figaro". Several performers who made their debuts with Opera Memphis went on to have distinguished careers with the Metropolitan Opera, including Ruth Welting, Patricia Welting, Gail Robinson and Richard Vernon. Opera Memphis also introduced the operas "Deseret," "Riversongs," Different Fields" and Michael Chang's "Buoso's Ghost."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: music; opera; theater;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Heritage Cultural Resources Survey - Addendum 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Memphis Heritage, Inc., the city's leading historic preservation group was founded in October 1975. Some of its major accomplishments include historic building and neighborhood surveys which have helped Memphis preserve and list many structures on the National Register of Historic Places. These records, which form the Memphis Heritage Collection, were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by the organization. The collection contains field reports and photographs of historic Memphis neighborhoods examined by Memphis surveyors in 1988-1994 and 1999-2002. This section of the survey consists of five albums prepared for Memphis Heritage, Inc.'s City of Memphis Cultural Resources Survey, a joint project funded in part by the Tennessee Historical Commission and the City of Memphis's Division of Housing and Community Development. Each neighborhood survey provides information on the area's historic significance, physical description, architect, types of houses, builders, and the historical background and community information. Each neighborhood survey also includes photographs of houses and streets in the area, as well as plat maps, a history of the neighborhood, and a statement of significance. Bibliographies of sources used are also included. Researchers will find a wealth of significant information on the neighborhoods which place them in a historical context.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jacob C. H. Meanley Riverboat Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Jacob C.H. Meanley Riverboat Photography Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center by Jacob Meanley in December 1995. The collection contains 71 photographs of boats that plied the Mississippi River during the late-19th and early-20th centuries, including such famous boats as the Robert E. Lee and the Sultana. Detailed information on the history of the majority of vessels is also contained in the collection. Jacob Chandler Harper Meanley was born in Memphis to Thomas Meredith and Carol Kimball Meanley in 1949. As a young man, Meanley helped his father build excursion riverboats which began his lifelong fascination with the Mississippi River. In 1960, his father bought the Memphis Queen II riverboat where he took passengers on scenic trips down the Mississippi near Memphis. Eventually the enterprise expanded into Memphis Queen Lines which operated four passenger excursion boats. At age 18, Meanley became the youngest river pilot on the Mississippi and when his father retired in 1984, he became co-owner of the Memphis Queen Lines. According to his brother Gerald, Meanley loved the "stark beauty of the river and the fact that it was always changing. Every time he went out, there was always something new to show." Meanley died in June 2000 at the age of 51 and was mourned by many in Memphis. Commenting on Meanley's passing, longtime downtown observer Jimmy Ogle stated: "It's the passing of an era on the riverfront. He knew the river better than anybody. He could tell you anything about it, any boat going up the river."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: boats; business; Mississippi River; riverboats; rivers; transportation;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pioneers Black Firefighters of Memphis Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Twelve men in 1955 made history when they became the first African-American firefighters in Memphis, Tennessee. They endured inequitable conditions and discrimination from the very beginning. They were forced to live in segregated quarters, at Fire Station No. 8 at Mississippi and Crump, until the fire department was desegregated in 1966. For many years, they suffered through both legal and institutional racism due to their status as second-class citizens. The Pioneers Black Fire Fighters, Inc. was chartered and established in 1973. They provided a support system for African-American firefighters in Memphis. Their purpose was to deal with any problematic situations that arose in the workplace as a result of racial discrimination, such as promotions, disciplinary actions, hiring practices, and so on. Carl Stotts, one of the original twelve hired in 1955, filed a federal class-action racial discrimination lawsuit that resulted in a 1980 consent decree in which the Memphis Fire Department agreed to promote black firefighters in greater numbers. The Pioneers organization was with him throughout the process; they wanted to ensure that every African-American received the benefits and equal treatment to which he was entitled. While legally they tried to protect the rights and representation of African-Americans, unofficially they served as an arena in which the African-Americans could interact socially and bond. They organized social activities such as dances, picnics, and dinners for the members and their families. In addition, they were committed to educating and inspiring the younger generations; they led fundraisers for various youth organizations and schools. They also held educational programs and talks for the younger generations, ensuring that the legacy of those before them would not be forgotten. They believed that community involvement was just as important as commitment to their organization, and demonstrated that through their support and involvement in hospitals, churches, schools and various other institutions. The collection was a gift of Robert J. Crawford, one of the original twelve firefighters hired in 1955. He was the original president and founder of the Pioneers Black Firefighters of Memphis.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: civil rights; community groups; firefighting; labor; law;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: C. E. Dean Riverboat Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The C.E. Dean Riverboat Collection contains 117 photographs of boats such as the Kate Adams and the James Lee which carried cargo and passengers up and down the Mississippi River during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Included in the collection are detailed descriptions of each pictured riverboat which list such information as the owner of the vessel, when and where it was built, who was its master and the final disposition of the boat. The C.E. Dean Riverboat Collection also contains issues of the "S & D Reflector" magazine published by the Sons and Daughters of Pioneer Rivermen between the years 1965 and 1972. In addition to the magazine, an index for the "S & D Reflector" is also included. Articles on riverboats and river navigation from the Commercial Appeal, Memphis Press-Scimitar and Waterways Journal as well as postcards of boats and waterfronts are also included in the collection. The C.E. Dean Riverboat Collection provides a great deal of information on the history of Mississippi River transportation and complements the Captain Rees Vernon Downs Papers, which are also housed in the Memphis and Shelby County Room.
