oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Marvin and Mary Bazemore Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This inclusive collection of Memphis- and wartime-themed materials was generously donated to the Memphis Public Library by S. Carolyn Bazemore, the presumable daughter of Marvin and Mary Bazemore, in 2005, and for this reason, the collection bears the Bazemores' names. Both native Shelby County residents, Marvin Bazemore - born July 29, 1903 - a Shelby County Penal Farm worker, and Mary Rogers - born June 17, 1905 - a Cordova schoolteacher, were married on December 2, 1942. Shortly thereafter, Marvin was drafted for military service in WWII. Stationed at an army training camp off the coast of Georgia, Marvin was eventually discharged in early 1943 on account of his employment in the Roads and Bridges Department at the Shelby County Penal Farm - considered a matter of national defense. The greater part of this collection consists of correspondence between Marvin, family members and friends - including Mary - during his stay in Georgia. There are, however, additional pieces of correspondence between other WWI and WWII enlisted men - presumably friends and relatives of the Bazemores - and their respected loved ones. At once, these letters and postcards provide an invaluable document of military and civilian life as well as Shelby County society in the early-to-mid 20th century. The collection also includes: ration books from the WWII era; photographs and records from the Memphis Skeet and Trap Club; family photographs; construction photographs from Marvin's work at the Shelby County Penal Farm; vintage playbills; newspaper clippings; and miscellaneous keepsakes highlighting Memphis history, such as a Memphis Sesquicentennial Celebration pamphlet, which outlines the biographies and historical significance of such influential Memphians as E.H. Crump and John Overton, and a Shelby County Penal Farm pamphlet, which enumerates the various crops and services the Penal Farm historically provided to the Mid-South.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bazemore family; Memphis Skeet and Trap Club; Shelby County Penal Farm; war; World War II;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wolf River Conservancy Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Wolf River Conservancy was founded in 1985 as a primarily grassroots organization to "conserve and enhance the Wolf River corridor and watershed as a sustainable natural resource." Since then, the non-profit land trust has gained will-deserved prominence and admiration in the Mid-South community through its myriad of ecological, recreational, and educational accomplishments that provide widespread benefits to the community at large. This collection containing newspaper clippings, WRC newsletters, and wildlife literature, donated by Woodrow Jacobs, Kathy Steele, and other nature enthusiasts and WRC supporters from the Mid-South, chronicles the internal development and accomplishments of the conservancy and provides a comprehensive historical background of the natural habitat around Wolf River. A significant portion of the collection documents the successful campaign to save what is now known as the Ghost River, a section of the Wolf River headwaters, thanks in part to Millington businessman Babe Howard and fundraising efforts of the Wolf River Conservancy. More than anything, this collection exemplifies that the Wolf River Conservancy is an organization committed not only to the conservation of the Wolf River proper but to the sustainability and betterment of the Mid-South community at large - both people and wildlife. Through community and educational outreach programs, recreational opportunities, conservation efforts, and environmental advocacy campaigns, the Wolf River Conservancy has proved an invaluable service to the Mid-South community. In light of the recent plans to construct a 30-mile greenway along the Wolf River - a bridge between not only natural habitats, but also communities in the Mid-South, this collection proves particularly relevant to the future of the Mid-South area.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Frank M. Campbell Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1980, Frank M. Campbell donated approximately 1,100 photographs and negatives of Memphis buildings and street scenes to the Memphis and Shelby County Room. With few exceptions, the images date from the early to mid-1950s. -- Frank M. Campbell joined the Edward LeMaster Realtor firm in 1947. Soon after joining the company, he directed a detailed survey of a large area of downtown Memphis. According to an article in the September 26, 1971, edition of the Commercial Appeal, the National Real Estate Journal described the survey as "one of the most constructive that had come to the journal's attention." He later served as the company's vice president, before being elected president of the Edward LeMaster Company in 1971. -- Most images in the collection are of commercial property. Given Mr. Campbell's real estate background, researchers might assume some of these properties were of possible interest to the Edward LeMaster Company. The collection contains two albums, with the photographs and negatives listed alphabetically by street name. Any additional information included with the image at the time it was donated can be found in the finding aid. Information provided by the processor is written in italics.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: buildings; Campbell, Frank M.; commercial properties; Edward LeMaster Company; real estate; streets;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Urban Renewal Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Urban Renewal Photograph Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by the Shelby County Archives in 2002. Culled from the larger Urban Renewal Collection housed at the Shelby County Archives, the Urban Renewal Photograph Collection contains duplicate images of homes and businesses that were demolished or renovated between the years 1959 and 1961. Funded by the Housing Act of 1949 which provided federal dollars for slum clearance programs, the city's Urban Renewal projects transformed many historic neighborhoods in downtown Memphis, including Court, Railroad, and Jackson Avenues and Beale Street. Researchers interested in Urban Renewal will also want to consult the Beale Street Development Corporation, Future Memphis, Inc., Henry Loeb and Frank Tobey Collections, also housed in the Memphis and Shelby County Room.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: buildings; business; residences; urban renewal;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: E.H. Porter Railroad Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The E.H. Porter Railroad most likely come to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center through many donations as there is no record of a single individual donating the entire collection. E.H. Porter (the E. stood for Ethel) was the president of The Memphis & St. Louis Railroad Company from its founding on January 15th, 1857, when it was first chartered, up into the 1870s and 1880s. The collection has a wide and varied collection of documents. This includes personal correspondence between Mr. Porter and state auditors, along with numerous auditing documents, maps, and tax receipts from the business dealings the company had in Tennessee, Mississippi, and Arkansas. One of the biggest projects that the company performed was the construction of a levee system in Arkansas. The business dealings that the company also had with other railroads is well documented, and altogether the collection provides an important window for understanding the significance of railroads in both the ante and post-bellum South. Overall the collection of the Memphis and St. Louis Railroad Company as overseen by E.H. Porter provides an essential view in the life and times of the South during a crucial transitional period in United States History.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Arkansas; business; law; railroads; real estate; transportation;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: John Yackulics (Rhodes College)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Little Theatre Programs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In March 1929, the Memphis Little Theatre prepared to move into the east wing of the Pink Palace, which had been built for Clarence Saunders but never occupied by him as a home. This location would serve as the theater's home until 1975, when a state-of-the-art facility opened on Perkins Extended across from Audubon Park. Plays presented in the early years apparently did not have great popular appeal, and a search was made for a new director who would broaden the scope of the theater's repertoire and attract a larger audience. In September 1932, a youthful Eugart Yerian came from California to take over the helm of the Little Theatre, where he would successfully lead the organization for 21 years, except for the period from 1939 to 1947 when he was away from Memphis. In 1961, Yerian left the Little Theatre to become director of visual aids for the Holiday Inns Corporation. During Yerian's tenure, Memphis Little Theatre was recognized nationally as one of the leading amateur theaters in the United States. In 1974 the Little Theatre's directors approved a name change to Theatre Memphis for both the organization and its new facility under construction opposite Audubon Park. A small, experimental theater in the new building retained the name Little Theatre. Under the direction of Sherwood Lohrey, the new location, finished in April 1975, staged a 30-performance run of My Fair Lady as its opening production. Materials in this collection were acquired by the Library over a span of years through individual donations and accession from other sources such as the merger of the Goodwyn and Cossitt libraries. Programs have been arranged in chronological order, and each entry in the collection guide includes play title, director, cast members, and date staged. Programs range from 1925 - 1975, covering theatrical performances directed by Eugart Yerian, Talbot Pearson, Fred Sears, George Sparks and then Eugart Yerian. Long time director, Sherwood Lowrey, began his tenure with the 1962/1963. The programs also provide valuable information on stage sets, production staff, technical aspects of properties, as well as brief notes on the actors' performance history. Names of the Board of Directors and the Executive Committee reveal another significant aspect of the operation of this volunteer theatrical organization. Lastly, the program advertisements give the reader an interesting glimpse of leading businesses of the period. The collection provides the student of local theater with an incredible run of theatrical history.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: arts; entertainment; music; theater;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Patricia M. LaPointe
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Description from Finding Aid; Scanned by Jasmine Holland;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Saul Brown Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Saul Brown was born in 1910 in New York to Russian immigrants. As a young adult, Brown attended Tech High School in Memphis and graduated from the Memphis Academy of Fine Arts with a degree in Fine Art. Brown served in the Air Force during World War II. After graduation, he found work with Loew's Theaters, where he created publicity displays. Brown worked as a staff photographer for the Memphis Press-Scimitar for twenty years, retiring in April of 1980 as the newspaper's chief photographer. After retirement, Brown continued taking publicity photographs for various Memphis theaters as well as images of public figures, personal friends, and Memphis and its residents. He received the Freedom Foundation Award in 1972. In 1986, Brown donated $5,000 to Memphis State University to establish the Saul Brown/Memphis Press Scimitar Award, awarded to students in news journalism and news photography beginning in the 1987-1988 academic year. In 1987, due to his financial support of the school's academic fund, Brown was granted membership in the school's Presidents Club. Saul Brown passed away in Memphis on March 13, 1992 at the home of Myron Taylor, the brother of Mildred, his late wife. -- The Saul Brown Photograph Collection includes 33 boxes of color and black and white prints, color and black and white negative and positive film, and color slides. Dated photographs range from the 1950s to the early 1990s; the bulk of the material dates to the 1970s and 1980s. Original order has been maintained where possible and is noted in the detailed finding aid where applicable; elsewhere, the items are sorted by subject and year. -- A majority of the photographs in the collection were taken in Europe and Asia during Saul Brown's extensive travels. Researchers will also find visual documentation of local Memphis theater in the 1980s in the form of publicity photographs, Graceland at the time of Elvis Presley's death, people in the news, and many Memphis businesses, including King Cotton, Burkle's Bakery, Stroh Brewery, and others. -- Throughout the collection are images which contain insights into Brown's personal life. Friends and colleagues (including "Saul's Harem," a group of close female acquaintances) appear repeatedly throughout the years, as do locations throughout Memphis and the surrounding areas. Overton Square, Graceland, and Brown's home are some common subjects. Many photographs are dedicated to documenting Brown's many Memphis-area photography exhibits. These picture some prints not included in the donated collection. The collection also includes color film of a selection of Brown's paintings and works by other artists.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: art; Asia; Brown, Saul; Europe; photography; sports; theater; travel;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Heritage Cultural Resources Survey
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Memphis Heritage, Inc., the city's leading historic preservation group, was founded in October 1975. Some of its major accomplishments include historic building and neighborhood surveys which have helped Memphis preserve and list many structures on the National Register of Historic Places. These records, which form the Memphis Heritage Cultural Resources Collection, were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by the organization. The collection contains field reports and photographs of historic Memphis neighborhoods examined by Memphis Heritage surveyors in 1988-1994 and 1999-2002. In addition to historic homes, surveyors also compiled information and photographs of all neon signs then on display in Memphis. Field reports include the property address, owner's name, date of construction, condition of house and architectural style. -- Four neighborhood surveys were compiled and they are designated Cultural Resources Survey (CRS) 1, 2, 3 and Addendum in the index. Neon sign entries are designated Neon Sign Survey in the index. The index is organized by street address and includes historic name, common name, the survey number, the box and folder in which the reports and photographs are located, and the number of items and photographs in each folder.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: architecture; buildings; housing; neighborhoods; neon signs; preservation; residential property;

oai_dc:dc.dc:format: bibliographies; building information; field reports; histories; maps; photographs; surveys;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: German Heritage Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The German Heritage Collection is a combination of several individual collections and items that have been donated to the library over the years. Combined, the items in the collection offer a glimpse at the lives of first- and second-generation German immigrants in Memphis as well as the impact this group had upon Memphis in the 19th and 20th centuries.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Park Properties Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memphis Park Properties Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by the City of Memphis in the late 1990s. The collection contains court, land and financial records related to the development of public parks in Memphis between the years 1854 and 1931. Detailed information on the development of Astor, Beauregard, Bellevue, Charles W. Davis, De Soto, Douglass, Orange Mound, Overton, Riverside, South Side, University Circle, Washington and Williamson Parks, as well as material related to the development of the Fairgrounds, Pink Palace Museum and the Parkway system can be found in this collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Central Gardens Historic District Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Central Gardens Historic District is one of the iconic midtown neighborhoods of Memphis, Tennessee. Spanning 83 blocks, nearly 511 acres, and encompassing approximately 1,540 structures, the neighborhood has maintained its present-day appearance for nearly 100 years. The neighborhood is bounded in the north by the commercial strip facing Union Avenue, Annesdale Park Historic District in the west, the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railroad in the south, and Rembert Street in the east. -- The most characteristic trait of the neighborhood is its eclectic style. Numerous architectural styles exist including Greek Revival, Bungaloid, and the Prairie Style, but all the houses maintain certain characteristics. No doubt these similar qualities were imposed upon the builders when the structures were composed, mostly between 1905 and 1925. Some of these features include uniform setbacks from the street, cornice heights and massing, and some common details such as front porches, bay windows, and porte cocheres. The area as a whole represents the evolution of American architecture from the 1890s to the 1930s. Even the nature of the structures vary - most buildings are single-family homes, but multi-family homes, churches, stores, and schools exist within the boundaries as well. This variety of buildings creates a strong sense of community within the neighborhood. -- During the early 20th century, when the timber and cotton industries flourished, Memphis' wealthy class grew considerably. These new wealthy professionals sought new real estate, thus birthing many midtown neighborhoods, including the area now known as Central Gardens. By 1925, the area had developed to nearly its fullest extent and looks today very similar to how it looked then. Throughout the decades, the area has been home to some of Memphis' elite, including E.H. Crump, Watkins Overton, and Walter Chandler. After World War II though, the area began to decline and many of its residents abandoned the neighborhood for the east Memphis suburbs. -- Not too long passed before the neighborhood was attractive again, this time to young professionals in the 1960s who liked the spacious houses, shady trees, and low property prices. In 1967 a new neighborhood association formed and they decided to name the area "Central Gardens." New Orleans' Garden District was the inspiration for the name, as the original association found similarities between the two neighborhoods. Central Gardens quickly developed a strong presence and name in midtown, no doubt ensured by their frequent community events such as annual block parties, a 4th of July parade, and a garden club, all of which still exist today.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: architecture; Central Gardens; historic preservation; midtown; neighborhoods; social life;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Miriam DeCosta-Willis Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center by Miriam DeCosta-Willis. It chronicles a record of her achievements as a student, teacher, scholar, writer, world traveler, and community activist over a span of many decades. Also included is a very rich and detailed personal and family history, documented in letters, photographs, journals, newspaper articles, and genealogical books on the DeCosta and Hubert families. -- Miriam DeCosta Willis (MDW) has a longstanding association with Memphis as a professor at LeMoyne, Owen, and LeMoyne-Owen Colleges and at Memphis State University (now the University of Memphis), and as co-founder of the Memphis Black Writers' Workshop. She has written many columns and articles for local publications, and has authored or edited several books on Memphis history. -- The collection is divided into five groups comprising a total of thirty-four boxes and including one oversize box. Series I is composed of Boxes 1 through 3. Box 1 includes family and genealogical documents, such as books on the DeCosta and Hubert families, reunion materials, and articles related to MDW's parents, Frank Augustus DeCosta and Beautine Hubert DeCosta-Lee. Boxes 2 and 3 contain items pertaining to MDW's education, including report cards, commencement programs, and yearbooks. -- Papers from MDW's academic career are in Series II. Boxes 4 through 8 contain articles, programs, proposals, faculty reports, scholarly activities, and correspondence covering a forty-year span at four institutions of higher learning, although not included are papers from LeMoyne College, Owen Junior College, and Memphis State University. MDW's publications, including "Daughters of the Diaspora: Afra-Hispanic Writers," "The Memphis Diary of Ida B. Wells," and "Erotique Noire/Black Erotica," as well as numerous articles in scholarly journals, are included in Series III (Boxes 9-23). -- Series IV (Boxes 24-28) contains articles and programs about community activities in Memphis, including the Memphis Black Writers' Workshop and the Tennessee Humanities Council. Series V (Boxes 29-34) is an extensive collection of family, school, conference, and career-related pictures, in addition to several photographs by Ernest C. Withers. VHS and cassette tapes and a box of oversize items are also included in this series. -- Unless otherwise indicated, all articles, book reviews, lectures, manuscripts, and conference papers (published and unpublished) in this collection were authored by Miriam DeCosta-Willis.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chandler Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Chandler Collection includes information about various dwellings, lots and commercial properties in Memphis, with materials from 1968 to 2002. Some items deal with the homes and buildings demolished to pave the way for the proposed construction of Interstate I-40. Memphians fought the construction, because the interstate would have gone through the heart of the city, destroying Overton Park, the Memphis Zoo, many homes and hundreds of acres of old forest trees. -- The collection is arranged in individual folders within 9 boxes. Each box contains folders relating to different addresses, properties or areas of Memphis and Shelby County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Perre Magness Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Series I of the Perre Magness Collections contains an all-encompassing wealth of information on the city of Memphis, from its founding in 1819 to the early 21st century. Major historic events occuring in Memphis, such as the Yellow Fever Epidemic of 1878, the annual Cotton Carnival and the Earthquake of 1848 are thoroughly covered in this collection. Also including historical information about the state of Tennessee and the entire Mid-South region, this collection is by no means limited to the city of Memphis.This series includes correspondence, newspaper clippings and handwritten notes pertaining to Magness' research throughout her career as a historian, author, and writer for the Commercial Appeal. -- Series II primarily contains information on Magness' philanthropic and civic work, but also some research material. Records of volunteer ventures, organizations, and nonprofit management are plentiful throughout this series. Through this series, a researcher can gain a better understanding of Perre Magness' personal life, of which she dedicated so much of to volunteerism.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: history; Magness, Perre; nonprofit organizations; volunteerism;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Arthur Webb Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: There are nine general themes throughout this collection: personal material, photographs, churches, government, miscellaneous, history, genealogical research, African-American history, and newspapers. Within those themes are pieces of correspondence to and from Arthur L. Webb, newspaper articles, genealogical research, handwritten notes, and photographs. Though Webb's research dealt primarily with African-American historical and genealogical work, the collection includes a selection of material regarding Webb's personal life as well, thus providing a wealth of insight into his professional life at the Tri-State Defender as well.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: NOW - Memphis Chapter Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The National Organization for Women (NOW), a dedicated women's rights advocacy coalition, was founded in 1966, amid much controversy over the proposed direction of the women's rights movement. In its nascent stages, the national chapter of NOW existed under the platform of equality, adopting a bi-partisan and multi-racial stand with the goal of raising awareness, particularly among women, of the contemporary gender biases existing in both domestic and economic spheres. Still in operation today, NOW boasts over 500,000 members across 500 chapters dispersed among all fifty U.S. states. -- The Memphis Chapter of the National Organization for Women has an illustrious history characterized by, first and foremost, an intense desire to promote gender awareness, dispel existing stereotypes, and rectify the perceived vices of a very much separate and unequal society. Founded in the spring of 1970 as a result of the gathering of three women at Centenary Baptist Church, the NOW Memphis Chapter wasted no time in diving in to the major contemporary women's rights issues, with the passage of the Equal Rights Amendment being first on the agenda. -- Much like the National Chapter, Memphis NOW focused on several key topics, including child care, marriage, discrimination, economic equality, and victimization. In addressing the aforementioned issues, the NOW Memphis Chapter wasted little time, with the 1973 Employment Consultant Task Force marking the first of many efforts to further the struggle for women's rights. Designed to educate and consult with women who have been classified as victims of discrimination at the workplace, the task force aimed at educating the women of their rights, in hopes of preventing such occurrences from repeating themselves in the future by arming them with the legal framework for their defense. -- Action on behalf of the Memphis Chapter of the National Organization for Women was not limited to the designation of a discrimination-focused task force; rather, it encompassed a variety of measures including: the offering of seminars, such as 1974's "55 Things a Woman Can’t Do Under TN Law," the sponsoring of protests, such as the 1975 Overton Square march against violence toward women and the creation of support centers, exemplified by the organization of the "Battered Women's Crisis Line" in 1977. -- Piggybacking off the success of the aforementioned engagements, the Memphis Chapter of the National Organization for Women gained a notable, albeit not substantial in number, male membership. The careful nature by which former local chapter president Marion Kiesker asserted the organization's identity as the National Organization for Women, as opposed to the National Organization of Women, underscored her, and others', desire for the inclusion of all people dedicated to their cause, regardless of gender. -- Despite claims to the contrary, many asserted that the Memphis Chapter of the National Organization for Women, and the entire coalition as a whole, suffered from a failure to address the concerns of African-American women. Critics consistently pointed to the lack of membership among African-American women as an indictment of the organization's focus. -- The Memphis Chapter of the National Organization for Women is still in existence today, and remains a vibrant advocate of gender equality, women's rights, and social progress. -- The National Organization of Women – Memphis Chapter Collection consists primarily of correspondence, news clippings, and issues of the local chapter newsletter. The collection houses a wealth of information pertaining to the goals, organizational structure, and outreach plans for the Memphis Chapter of the National Organization for Women. Correspondence to and from former President Marion Keisker, in particular, plays a major role in the collection.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: discrimination; gender equality; National Organization for Women; nonprofit organizations; politics; women;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beethoven Club Programs Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Miss Martha Trudeau, a piano teacher, couldn't have dreamed of the possibilities when she invited three women to tea on October 27, 1888. They discussed the lack of classical music opportunities in Memphis and they decided to start a club, the Beethoven Club. Then "Miss Trudeau's Quartet" presented a program on December 17, 1889. The following year they presented William Sherwood, a Chicago pianist, at the Hebrew Men's Association home. This concert earned $10.00 profit. -- In 1892 the growing group was incorporated as the Beethoven Club. From the early beginnings the purpose was to encourage the musical talents of members and to stimulate musical interests in Memphis. One requirement for membership was that members had to be performers. Men could become members, but could not hold an office. -- Around 1900 the club outgrew Mrs. Napolean Hill's home and moved to the Women's Building downtown. -- In 1912, under Mrs. Hill's leadership, the club organized the Junior Beethoven Club and this group was followed by the Intermediates and Juveniles. This early commitment to the music education of children and teenagers was an important function of the club's history. -- Fro the 1920-1921 season, the New York Chamber Music Society was part of the concert series. Subscription tickets to 2 of the 4 concerts were $10.00 and single admission tickets ranged from $1.50 to $3.00. -- Great progress was made in 1924 with the purchase of the Lowenstein-Long House on Waldran, the realization of a need for a clubhouse. -- In 1925 the organization began a long partnership of 40 years with the Civic Concert Service. A galaxy of famous performing artists came to Ellis Auditorium, the Goodwyn Institute, the Music Hall and other auditoriums. It was a golden age for touring performers: Enrico Caruso, Walter Damrosch, Mischa Elman, Kirsten Flagstad, Jerome Hines, Fritz Kreisler, Yehudi Menuhin, Birgit Nilsson, Ezio Pinza, Rosa Ponselle, Isaac Stern, Joan Sutherland, the National Ballet of Washington, Marcel Marceau, the Vienna Choir Boys, the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra and the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra. -- A Student Loan Fund began in 1932. This has helped many students with their music education. Many like Mignon Dunn, who became a leading singer with the Metropolitan Opera, greatly benefited from the loans. -- The Beethoven Chorus for women gave its first concert in 1937 at the Goodwyn Institute with Burnet Tuthill directing. By this year membership had climbed to 652. -- In 1938 a library that included sheet music and music scores was expanding. -- After America entered World War II, the Student Musicians Chorus (directed by J.B. Dishongh) prepared in the summer of 1941 to sing patriotic programs. -- On August 1, 1945, the clubhouse at 217 North Waldran was sold to the Elizabeth Club, an affiliate of the Nineteenth Century Club. The membership was 3,000. In the years before the next clubhouse was purchased, meetings were held at the Parkview, the Nineteenth Century Club and Grace-St. Luke's Episcopal Church, among other places. -- A Junior Choir Festival was important in the 1950s with hundreds of children from Memphis churches participating. -- A new clubhouse at the northwest corner of McLean and Peabody was purchased in 1952. The many improved features were an auditorium with a capacity of over 175, business offices, a president's office and a director's room. The club moved to its new home in 1953. -- In 1956 the club was a key force for the birth of the Memphis Opera Theatre, and it sponsored the regional Metropolitan Opera auditions starting in the 1960s. -- Many organizations face fluctuations in their history and certainly the Beethoven Club was no exception. By 1972 the membership had fallen to around 700. -- For over 120 years, the Beethoven Club has been enriching the musical life of Memphis and is likely the oldest music club in Tennessee. Many other clubs have vanished into history, but the little endeavor of Trudeau and her friends lives on to encourage the talents of young performers and enhance the cultural life of the city.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: arts; Beethoven Club; entertainment; music; performing arts; theater;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edwin D. Thompson Trolley and Streetcar Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Edwin D. Thompson, Sr. was born in Memphis in 1918. An Eagle Scout and Silver Beaver Award recipient, Thompson served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and worked as a sales manager for an agribusiness company. But it was his passion for model railroad building that led Thompson to collect information and photographs related to streetcar and trolley operations in Memphis. A member of the Circus Model Builders Association and the Mid-South Society of Model Engineers, Thompson was an authorized Lionel Train Repair Station for over 30 years until his death in 2008. -- The Edwin D. Thompson Trolley and Streetcar Collection provides researchers with a great deal of information on the operation of the Memphis Street Railway Company and its rival Citizens Street Railway during the late-19th and 20th centuries. The collection also provides information on the re-introduction of trolley service in Memphis in the late-1980s and 1990s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Douglass Oral History Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Douglass community in North Memphis was founded 1907 by a former slave known as "Father" Plummer. Initially conceived of as an all-black community, it has remained so ever since. Community spirit, pride and dedication are the the hallmarks of this proud neighborhood. -- In 2004, the Memphis and Shelby County Division of Planning and Development set out to create a neighborhood plan for the Douglass community. As part of the planning process, planners conducted surveys and interviews with community members, with the oral history interviews being retained in this collection. Containing materials from 2004 and 2005, the collection provides a comprehensive record of an oral history project, from planning stages to the final product. -- The collection retains the original filing structure, with Box 1 comprised of planning documents, neighborhood research materials, resources from an environmental justice workshop, and interoffice correspondences about the project. Box 2 houses the transcripts and other documentation from the oral history project participants. The original cassette recordings are housed in Box 3.

Douglass Oral History Collection Processed by Sarah Frierson Memphis and Shelby County Room 2011 Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, Tennessee 38111 2 Douglass History The Douglass community is a neighborhood in north Memphis, loosely bounded by the Wolf River to the north, the Illinois Central Railroad on the west, Jackson Avenue to the south and Highland Street on the east. A combination of several subdivisions, the area is sometimes referred to as the Douglass – Bungalow – Crump neighborhood. Founded as the Douglass Park subdivision in 1907 by Reverend W.A. Plummer, a former slave known as “Father” Plummer, the neighborhood drew residents displaced by burgeoning white communities, the yellow fever epidemics which plagued the Memphis area in the late 19th century, and the disintegration of the plantation-centric agrarian system. Named for Frederick Douglass, the settlement was conceived as an all-black community and has remained so ever since. The neighborhood is renowned for its high home ownership rates and its strong sense of community spirit. The community pride Douglass is known for developed early in its history. During the devastating years of the Depression, the community learned how to serve and provide for one another. Community gardens, home improvement contests and sewing committees made sure that no resident went without necessities. In 1937, the year that Eleanor Roosevelt toured the neighborhood, the community produced 100,000 cans of food for residents and another 5,000 for the Douglass School. Schools and churches have always been the backbone of the Douglass community. The first Douglass School was a Rosenwald school, funded by Julius Rosenwald’s Fund to provide quality education for African-American children in the early 20th century. By the mid-1930s, a junior high had been added and Douglass High graduated its first class in 1946. Upon annexation to the city of Memphis in 1950, Douglass High School was incorporated into the Memphis City Schools. Closed in 1981 due to a declining student population, the school was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1998. The school building was torn down in 2006 to make way for a new Douglass High School, which opened its doors in 2008. As for churches, the community boasted at least 13 different congregations by 1940. That number has grown steadily during the years since. Douglass Park has also played a huge role in the lives of Douglass’ residents. Created in 1913, Douglass Park was the first park for Memphis’ African-Americans and served as a central gathering place for most social and recreational events. It has played host to summer camps, sports leagues, community reunions, golfers and the city’s annual Juneteenth celebration. The lasting spirit and pride of this community has been showcased over the years with reunion events (including the Douglass Expo) and publications. For more information about the history of the Douglass community, please see: Douglass, a Community Of the People, By the People, For the People: Expo ’77 History & Directory, 1977. Douglass Heritage: Historical Data Book by the Douglass Alumni Association, 1980. 3 Scope & Content The Douglass Oral History Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Nancy Jane Baker of the Memphis Landmarks Commission in March of 2011. In 2004, the Memphis and Shelby County Division of Planning and Development set out to create a neighborhood plan for the Douglass community. As part of the planning process, planners conducted surveys and interviews with community members, with the oral history interviews being retained in this collection. Containing materials from 2004 and 2005, the collection provides a comprehensive record of an oral history project, from planning stages to the final product. The collection retains its original filing structure, with Box 1 comprised of planning documents, neighborhood research materials, resources from an environmental justice workshop and interoffice correspondence about the project. Box 2 houses the transcripts and other documentation from the oral history project participants. The original cassette recordings are housed in Box 3. Researchers interested in oral histories will also want to consult the Everett R. Cook Oral History Collection and the Selma S. Lewis Collection. Those interested in neighborhoods should also consult the Central Gardens Historic District Collection, the Memphis Heritage Cultural Resources Survey, Papers of the Raleigh Community Council, Peabody-Bellevue Civic Club Collection, Evergreen Historic District Association Collection, and Memphis Civic Clubs – Jackson Boulevard and Rozelle Clubs collections, located in the Memphis and Shelby County Room of the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for the purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Peggy Jemison Neighborhood Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Peggy Jemison Neighborhood Collection contains material related to the history of the Annesdale Park, Beale Street, Bethel-LaBelle, Cherokee, Cooper-Young, Greenlaw, Smokey City, South Main, and Vollintine-Evergreen neighborhoods. -- In 1977, Dr. Peggy Jemison Bodine joined a project sponsored by the Metropolitan Inter-Faith Association (MIFA) and the Tennessee Humanities Council to research the histories of eight endangered Memphis neighborhoods. For four years she intensely researched several local neighborhoods, and that work culminated in the publication of "A History of the Cooper Young Neighborhood," "Cherokee: A History of Change," "Greenlaw Rediscovered: A History," and Vollintine/Evergreen: A Diverse Community." The research material Dr. Bodine collected for the MIFA project and included in the Peggy Jemison Neighborhood Collection is invaluable for those interested in studying the history and development of Memphis neighborhoods.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Annesdale Park; Beale Street; Bethel-LaBelle; bus barns; Cherokee; CoDe North, Inc.; community planning; Cooper-Young; Greenlaw; housing; mayors; Memphis Landmarks Commission; Metropolitan Inter-Faith Association (MIFA); neighborhoods; oral history; Smokey City; South Main district; Vollintine-Evergreen;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edward LeMaster Downtown Real Estate Survey Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Edward LeMaster Downtown Real Estate Survey Collection contains four property survey books and a card file index that gives a history of property ownership and tenant occupancy in downtown Memphis in the mid-twentieth century. Prepared by Edward LeMaster Company, each property survey book also includes a narrative which analyzes the conditions of downtown real estate. -- Edward Bennett LeMaster founded his firm, which specialized in commercial and industrial properties, in 1944. Frank M. Campbell joined the firm in 1947 and he was appointed president of the company in 1971. Both men and their company contributed greatly to the commercial development of Memphis in the second half of the 20th century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oliver - Finnie Company Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1860, J. P. Finnie arrived in Memphis on the Silver Moon steamboat and opened a small retail grocery at Main Street and South Court. In 1868, Finnie entered the wholesale business. He partnered with J. N. Oliver, forming the Oliver-Finnie Company, and moved to a new location on Front Street. In 1903, the company began its manufacturing department, naming their product line "Silver Moon," after the Steamer that brought Finnie to the city. -- The company moved to their final location at 7 Vance Avenue after a fire destroyed their plant in 1904. Oliver-Finnie manufactured 515 different varieties of candies, ranging from hand-dipped chocolates to hard candy sold in 20 quart pails for plantation commissaries. They also roasted and ground their own coffee blend, and added their label to the baking powder and flavoring extracts they packaged. The business operated continuously until 1961, at which time it was liquidated to settle the estate of Maynard Holt, the company's last president and major stockholder. -- The collection consists of one photograph album of images taken at the company's manufacturing center and colored advertisements of the company's product line. These images date to the early 1900s.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: business; candy; coffee; Finnie, J. P.; food; industry; manufacturing; Oliver, J. N.;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Parker Automobile Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When automobiles began to be produced, Jerome Pillow Parker recognized the possibilities. In 1901, the Jerome P. Parker & Company purchased six high-seated steam locomobile runabouts known as the Mobile. He sold the last of these in 1903. Parker's Company is credited with being the first automobile dealer in Memphis and he later advertised he was the first dealer south of the Ohio River. Parker was also the first Ford dealer in the city. -- The collection contains the Jerome P. Parker Company's bicycle and automobile catalogs dating from 1899 to 1907.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: automobiles; bicycles; business; carriages; Parker, Jerome P.;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Richard Halliburton Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Richard Halliburton, born on January 9, 1900, in Brownsville, Tennessee, was a well-known adventurer and travel author. The family later moved to Memphis. While attending Princeton University, Halliburton developed an interest in travel and travel writing. His first book, The Royal Road to Romance (1925), quickly became a bestseller. All of Halliburton's following books proved to be immensely popular. For over a decade, his exploits were featured on the front pages of newspapers around the world. His last adventure proved fatal. He commissioned a Chinese junk, the Sea Dragon, and attempted to sail across the Pacific Ocean from Hong Kong to San Francisco. After nearly three weeks at sea, the ship encountered a typhoon. The ship was last in contact on March 23, 1933, and Halliburton was declared legally dead by the Memphis Chancery Court the following October. -- The collection consists of one scrapbook produced by H. A. Bruno - R. R. Blythe and Associates, a Public Relations Counsel in New York City. The scrapbook is titled "The Flying Carpet, Halliburton - Stephens, 1931 - 1932." The newspaper clippings in this album date from February to July, 1932.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: adventure; aviation; Halliburton, Richard; Stephens, Moye; travel; writing;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Laura Cunningham

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1920s French Fashion Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1920s French Fashion Collection contains illustrations from Tres Parisien! Les Idees Nouvelles De La Mode Et Des Arts and Les Chapeaux du "Tres Parisien." Tres Parisien! was an art-deco French fashion journal featuring Haute Couture fashion plates and articles on fashion collections, designers, and patterns. G. P. Joumard served as the artistic director for the magazine, which ran from 1922 to 1936. Les Chapeaux du "Tres Parisien" was a quarterly supplement of Tres Parisien and focused on millinery designs. In this collection, the illustrations are hand-colored pochoir plates on thin brown paper, tipped-in on light card stock. Each plate is captioned. The magazine excerpts in this collection are from 1925 and 1926.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: clothing; fashion; France; magazines; women;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Hyter Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: James Hyter was a popular bass-baritone vocalist best known for his perfromances of "Ol' Man River" with the Memphis Symphony Orchestra at their annual Sunset Symphony concert. The collection consists of sheet music for approximately 40 songs, dating from the 1960s to the present, and spanning several genres.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Socialist Party Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memphis Socialist Pary Collection consists of materials taken from a scrapbook of the Socialist Party in Memphis. The scrapbook contained the minutes of Party meetings from May 4, 1932, to December 30, 1934. Newspaper articles about the Socialist Party are interfiled with the meeting minutes. Memphians formed the local chapter of the Socialist Party in 1903. In the early 1930s, regular meetings were held at the Arbeiter Ring Institute, located at 688 Jefferson Avenue.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tom Lee and M. E. Norman Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On May 8, 1925, members of the Memphis Engineers Club, their families and guests, took two ships, the Choctaw and the M.E. Norman on a day trip to view a levee revetment project approximately twenty miles south of Memphis. On the return trip, the M.E. Norman capsized at Cow Island Bend. As fate would have it, Memphian Tom Lee, returning home from Helena, Arkansas, passed the M.E. Norman moments before the accident. He quickly turned his 28-foot skiff, Zev, around and began rescuing the struggling passengers. Tom Lee, who could not swim, acted without regard to his personal safety, made multiple rescue trips, and even stopped to start a fire for the survivors. He continued the search for the ship's survivors and victims throughout the night. Tom Lee saved thirty-two people that day, quickly becoming the city's hero. Eight days after the disaster, Lee met President Coolidge at the White House. The Memphis Engineers' Club raised enough money to purchase him a house at 923 Mansfield Street. The City provided Lee with a job for life with the Sanitation Department, and even arranged for a generous early retirement. Tom Lee died of cancer on April 1, 1952. Two years later, the City renamed Astor Park "Tom Lee Park" in honor of one of its greatest heroes. -- The collection consists of newspaper clippings and other materials, previously compiled into an album, focusing on Tom Lee and the sinking of the M. E. Norman.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lee, Tom; M.E. Norman; maritime disasters; Memphis Engineers Club; parks;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Laura Cunningham
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: articles; maps; newspaper clippings; passenger lists;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Military Officers' Wives Club Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers officially activated the Memphis General Depot in January 1942. The mission of the Depot was to supply the U.S. Army with food, clothing, tools, and engineering equipment. The Depot provided logistical support to the U.S. military from World War II through Desert Storm before closing on September 30, 1997. -- This collection consists of a history of the first 52 years of the Military Officers' Wives Club via annual scrapbooks.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joe Bennett Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Joe Bennett Collection consists of 5 boxes donated by local businessman Roy Good in 2003. The collection is comprised of three photograph albums and one scrapbook belonging to Joe Bennett. It is possible that one of the albums belonged to his sister, Lena, whose family is the subject of several of the collection's photographs. Lena Bennett married Howard Boaz in 1912, and the couple had two children: Howard, Jr. and Thomas 'Bennett'. -- Box 1 contains the photographs from the first album, Box 2 the photographs from the second, and the third album is divided between Box 3 and Box 4. Box 5 contains the pages from Joe Bennett's scrapbook, which focuses on the Fairground Casino Ballroom from 1930 through 1950. -- With few exceptions, the photographs and scrapbook pages are maintained in the original order of the albums. Most of the photographs were taken between 1912 and 1916 and feature Mr. Bennett's friends and family, including Frank Pole and brothers John and Alonzo 'Lonnie' Bennett. The collection also includes photographs of places of interest in the Memphis area. This finding aid includes an index which focuses on these Memphis areas. Photograph captions from the original album are listed in quotation marks. Notes from the processor are in italics.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1913 flood; Bennett, Joe; Bennett family; boats; downtown; family life; parks; portraits; recreation; sports; streets; transportation; travel;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee Children's Home Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee Children’s Home Society was a Memphis orphanage known for its involvement with the kidnapping of children and their illegal adoptions. -- Georgia Tann, head of the orphanage, was well respected in the Memphis community and maintained a lavish lifestyle. She received the support of legislators, prominent families, and Judge Camille Kelley, the Juvenile Court Judge who finalized the adoptions. -- In 1941, the orphanage lost its endorsement from the Child Welfare League of America after they discovered Tann had been destroying the paperwork associated with its child placements. The Society remained unlicensed until it closed in the early 1950s.-- In 1950, a state investigation revealed Tann arranged thousands of questionable adoptions. Secret bank accounts and numerous record irregularites were revealed. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hotel Greeters of America Women’s Division Delta Chapter No. 59 Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Hotel Greeters of America, Women’s Division Delta Chapter No. 59 Collection consists of one box, spanning 1 ½ linear feet. The donor and date of donation are unknown. The collection consists of pages from a 1953 – 1954 scrapbook compiled by the Women’s Division of Delta Chapter Number 59 of the Hotel Greeters of America. The scrapbook focused on the hotel and tourism industry in Memphis. Newspaper articles about the group’s monthly meetings and events are also included. -- The last folder in the collection contains correspondence from Mrs. R. P. Irvine, the Chapter’s President at the time, to Mr. Harry Christopher at Hotel Greeter Magazine. Two of these letters were written on Hotel Chisca letterhead, one from the Hotel Gayoso.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: United Daughters of the Confederacy: Mary Latham Chapter Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This collection relates to the organization of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, specifically the Mary Latham Chapter #474 in Memphis, TN. The UDC is a women's lineage society which preserves the heritage and honors the memory of those who served and died for the Confederate States of America by monuments and cemetery donations. -- This collection is organized chronologically in each of 4 boxes with the exception of the materials concerning membership applications and dues which are arranged in folders alphabetically in the original order of their creation. -- This collection is a combination of minutes, membership lists, membership dues lists, and other correspondence and business dealings of a functioning organization. Also included are many years of the organization's magazines. In the box containing applications, also included are some reasons they were no longer affiliated, details of lineage, proof of lineage, obituaries, letters of recommendation and other correspondence concerning their membership. -- These documents provide a detailed glimpse into the past through the functioning of the organization, civil war history through various war records, and genealogy in seeing proofs of lineage included in the applications and membership dues.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Charles A. McVean U.S. Engineers Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Charles A. McVean, a native of Missouri, was a concrete engineer, notable for his work in the navigation channel on the lower Mississippi River. McVean studied engineering at the University of Colorado. In 1934, he began working with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in the Memphis Engineer District, where he served as a concrete engineer and also as assistant chief of the district’s Inspection Branch. He conducted numerous studies on the casting of concrete mattresses, which are used in revetting the banks of concave bends along the Mississippi River. In the early 1960s, the results of one study earned McVean a nomination for a Presidential citation.
In 2000, Charles D. McVean donated the Charles A. McVean U.S. Engineer’s Collection to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center. The collection consists of four boxes spanning 2.5 linear feet. Box One contains concrete laboratory reports, experiment logs, various studies, maps, and guides. Boxes Two through Four contain photographs of levee work in the Memphis Engineer District from the 1940s to the early 1970s. These photographs focus on the areas of Hickman, Kentucky; Richardson’s Landing, Tennessee; Cates Landing, Tennessee; Caruthersville, Missouri; Memphis, Tennessee; Helena, Arkansas; and Cessions, Mississippi.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: engineering; Mississippi River; river maintenance; rivers; U.S. Army Corps of Engineers;

oai_dc:dc.dc:format: articles; brochures; correspondence; maps; photographs; reports;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: J.B. Mann Suffrage Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The J.B. Mann Suffrage Collection cannot be classified as a primarily biographical collection due to its wide coverage of women’s suffrage. However, Mrs. Martha E. Allen (also referred to as Mrs. J.D. Allen) plays a large role in the collection. She was born on November 16, 1851 in Plymouth, Indiana where she later attended girls’ schools and married Jacob Davis Allen. Her dedication to women’s suffrage began during the 1870s when she saw Susan B. Anthony speak at a rally. However, she was living with her father-in-law at the time and he did not support women’s suffrage so she did not fully engage in suffrage activities until 1889, when she and her husband moved to Nashville. In 1898 they relocated to Memphis where an Equal Suffrage Association was founded in 1904, which Allen promptly joined. Unfortunately, the Association soon failed due to lack of funds. This was not the end of her involvement with women’s suffrage as proven by her role as the first president of a small group called the Equal Suffrage League, which was founded in 1906. She served as president until 1912. During this time she worked to organize the women’s suffrage movement throughout the state of Tennessee. These efforts included countless parades, rallies, pink teas, flying of flags, and rummage sales. Her efforts paid off and she earned the honor of being called the grandmother of the Memphis League of Women Voters. She was also involved in numerous other clubs including the Ladies’ Hermitage Association, Women’s Christian Temperance Union, Daughters of 1812, Daughters of the American Revolution, and the Nineteenth Century Club. She eventually retired from public life due to illness during her last years and died at the age of eighty-seven on November 12, 1936.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Allen, Martha E.; suffrage; voting; women;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Laura Fogarty

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Ford Canale Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Born in 1917, John Ford Canale was a lifelong native of Memphis, Tennessee. As a child, he attended Immaculate Conception parochial school, the Pentecost-Garrison School, and Christian Brothers High School before attending Southwestern. After graduation Canale went to work for Spencer-Sturla Funeral Home where he quickly rose to the position of President. In 1942, he engaged and married Dorothy Eugenia Stoltzenberg. The couple had six children and remained together until his death in 1982. After serving as a military intelligence officer during World War II, Canale returned to Memphis and enrolled in the old Southern Law School, which would later merge with the Memphis State Law School. -- Canale quickly became involved in politics when he campaigned for Senator Kenneth McKellar in his 1952 losing bid for the United States Senate. This campaign was only the beginning of Canale’s involvement in Tennessee and Shelby County politics. His political career began in 1956 when he was appo

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rowlett Paine Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rowlett Paine was born in Memphis on December 22, 1879. He attended local public schools and would receive his High School Diploma from the old Memphis Military Institute. -- Following his graduation he secured employment with the Singer Manufacturing Co. From there, the young Mr. Paine moved to the field of grocers first with A. B. Treadwell & Co. and then to White, Wilson, Drew Co. in 1904. It was at the latter that he rose to the position of secretary treasure. His ascension in the business world led him to be invited to join the Business Men’s Club, now the Memphis Chamber of Commerce. In 1916 Mr. Paine was elected president of the Cotton Merchants’ Association in the same year which he was also chosen as vice president of the Southern-Wholesale Grocers’ Association. The onset of American involvement in World War I would lead to yet another prestigious appointment as Mr. Paine found himself appointed as food administrator for Memphis and Shelby County. -- Mr. Paine’s involvem

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: W.C. Handy Beale Street Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On November 16, 1873, the “Father of the Blues” was born in Florence, Alabama. At an early age, William Christopher Handy showed an interest in music, and by the age of ten, he could already read sheet music. Although his parents wanted him to become a minister, Handy set out to become a professional musician, heading to Birmingham in 1892. While in Birmingham, Handy spent time teaching and working in a factory. Meanwhile in his free time, Handy worked to hone his craft playing with several small bands. -- In his youth, Handy played with a number of different bands, which travelled all across the South, but he finally landed in Memphis, Tennessee. He quickly found work and popularity in Memphis when he wrote and performed “Mr. Crump” for E. H. Crump’s mayoral election campaign in 1909. Handy would later rename and rewrite this song with the more famous title “The Memphis Blues.” -- After receiving moderate success from this composition and others, Handy began collaborating with Harry Pace. While Handy wrote the music, Pace wrote the lyrics. The two would eventually go into business together more formally when they established the Pace and Handy Music Company. Originally based out of Memphis, the two would publish a number of songs before they moved the company to New York City, including the aptly named “Beale Street Blues.” -- While in New York, Handy led the effort to popularize the blues. Based at 1650 Broadway, Handy and Pace published numerous compositions that would be featured in shows on Broadway. Even after Pace left the business, the Handy Brothers Music Company continued publishing compositions. By the time of his death on March 28, 1958, Handy was widely recognized as a music legend across the country. While he was not the first person to publish blues compositions, Handy was integral to the popularization of the blues with the publication of numerous compositions. Today he is still remembered as the “Father of the Blues” for his work. -- The material contained in the W. C. Handy Beale Street Collection was donated from a number of different sources, including items donated by Mrs. Roy Collins and Bob Crowder. Because the Collection was compiled over a period of several decades from many different sources, the collection was organized logically rather than in the order that they were received. -- The W. C. Handy Beale Street Collection contains numerous compositions by Handy, including “The Memphis Blues,” “St. Louis Blues,” and “Beale Street Blues.” In addition, the collection also holds several other compositions that were not composed or published by Handy, including Danny Thomas’ “Bring Back Beale Street.” The collection also houses letters, speeches, articles, and pamphlets that honor the life of W. C. Handy.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: blues; Handy, W. C.; music; musical composition;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mathew Jehl
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: articles; correspondence; pamphlets; sheet music; speeches;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beale Street Blue Light District
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
The “Blue Light District” of Beale Street is the name given to the section between Second and Fourth Avenues. After being recognized in The National Register of Historic Places, it became necessary to preserve the buildings in the area. However, the National Advisory Council on Historic Preservation required the Memphis Housing Authority (MHA) to suspend all redevelopment activities pertaining to the district until an architectural-historical analysis could be completed.
In November 1973, the Memphis Housing Authority partnered with the firm of Architect-Engineer Associates, Inc., from Nashville, Tennessee, for not only an analysis, but a complete photographic inventory and economic feasibility analyses in connection with individual building rehabilitations. This project was financed through a grant from the Housing and Urban Development Department.
An onsite inspection took place from December, 1973, to February, 1974. The photographs from this project, taken by Charles W. Warterfield, Jr., are available in the Beale Street Blue Light District Collection. The textual information can be found in The Blue Light District of Beale Street – Memphis, Tennessee, an Architectural and Historical Survey for Memphis Housing Authority, which can be found in the Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center, under the call number 711.409768 A673b.
The collection includes two photograph albums, spanning 2 linear feet. The photographs include captions, thought to have been written by Architect-Engineer Associates, Inc., from Nashville, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: architecture; Beale Street; buildings; urban renewal;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Laura Cunningham

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Emma K. Meacham Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
The Emma K. Meacham Collection consists of one box spanning one linear foot. The collection contains Mrs. Meacham’s “Sketches,” stories she shared with her granddaughter as she reminisced about her life. These sketches were transcribed by longtime Library volunteer, Virginia Battle.
In this collection, Emma Koen Meacham, 1869-1952, described the early history of Memphis, with notable mentions of the Lee Line of Steamers, the Kate Adams, and President Grover Cleveland’s 1887 visit to Memphis. Memphians Sara Beaumont Kennedy and Robert Looney are also mentioned. Outside of Memphis, she recalled her time as one of the first students to attend Belhaven College in Jackson, Mississippi. She also described in vivid detail the 1897 flooding and levee breech of Laconia Circle in Desha County, Arkansas.
Mrs. Meacham was the wife of William Walker Meacham, a planter in Laconia Circle, Arkansas. Together they had two children, Chlotilda Louise Meacham Rechenburg and William Earl Meacham.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: biography; Meacham, Emma K.;
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Virginia Battle
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Edited by Gina Cordell and Laura Cunningham; Description from finding aid.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary Snowden Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Mary Overton Snowden was born on October 26, 1871. She was the daughter of Annie Overton Brinkley and Colonel Robert Bogardus Snowden and raised in the Annesdale mansion in Memphis, Tennessee. Mary married Lawson Henderson Treadwell on November 21, 1894. The couple had four children. Mary passed away on March 11, 1938, at the age of 67.
The Mary Snowden Collection consists of one box spanning one linear foot. It contains the contents of an 1882 scrapbook of valentines and other ephemera collected by Mary Snowden and compiled into a ledger book from Louis B. McFarland and William W. Goodwin, attorneys-at-law, 39 Madison Avenue.
The first nine folders in the collection contain items which had separated from the book. The McFarland and Goodwin ledger book, dated 1872-1874, begins on page 219. The transcription is included in this finding aid.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: business; Goodwin, William W.; holidays; law; McFarland, Louis B.; Snowden, Mary Overton;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bryan Eagle Family Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bryan Munroe Eagle was born on July 23, 1896 to William Henry and Ada Munroe Eagle of Little Rock, Arkansas. His uncle James P. Eagle was a former governor of Arkansas. Bryan Eagle married Virginia Fleming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Hunter Fleming of Memphis, Tennessee. Virginia was an avid participant in Memphis social life. After attending The Abbey School in Washington and later the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music, she organized and attended numerous balls, luncheons, bridge games, and country club events, documenting her social life with newspaper clippings in a memory book and saving many invitations and programs. A marriage to Bryan M. Eagle followed her debut into society in 1923, and after wedding on December 21, 1924, they made their home in Little Rock. -- As a teenager, Mr. Eagle attended the Culver Naval Summer School in Culver, Indiana. He referenced this military summer camp when attempting to enlist during World War I. He graduated from Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, and a few things that were preserved from this time in his life can be viewed in this collection—an address book, a last will and testament, checks, motor vehicle registration cards, and personal correspondence. Affectionately called “Pete” by those close to him, Eagle worked for seven years at American Southern Trust Company in Little Rock as the manager of the Investment Department and later Vice President. He accepted a position at Otis and Company in New York City in 1929 and throughout his short life was a Field Finance Examiner for the Public Works Administration and the Assistant State Bank Commissioner. A member of Psi Upsilon fraternity and a “descendant of one of the oldest and most distinguished families in the south,” Eagle died in Memphis on July 4, 1938 of encephalitis. He was 41. -- Virginia remarried and became Mrs. Joseph Duncan Mallory, as can be seen on her child’s signed grade school report cards. Bryan and Virginia Eagle’s children represented in this collection are Ada Marie, Virginia, Bryan Munroe, and Mary Gayle. Ada Marie Eagle attended Ogontz Junior College and Columbia University, was a member of Phi Sigma sorority, Girls Cotillion, and Junior League of Memphis, and married George Campbell. Mary Gayle Eagle attended Hutchison School and Harvard University and married Lawrence Murray Young. Bryan Munroe was born on January 25, 1935, and attended Pentecost-Garrison School for Boys. He also attended summer camp at Round-Up Lodge in Buena Vista, Colorado. Many of his documents and personal letters were kept. He married Charlotte Fredette Smith and died on September 18, 2004 at age 69. -- From legal disputes over land and life insurance to stationary pages of love letters and debutante announcements, the Bryan Eagle Family Collection details long forgotten aspects of life in the early 20th century and is a fine representation of the struggles and triumphs of an upper class family in the south.

The majority of material in this collection dates from the early decades of the 20th century, with a few items from the 1940s and 1950s. The material includes numerous newspaper clippings, personal correspondence, photographs, postcards, report cards, official documents, invitations, telegrams, pamphlets, summer naval school catalogues, and a memory book. The original order was fully maintained in the processing of this collection. Those interested in examples of communication and matters significant to southern families should consult the Annie W. Conner Collection, the Bond Family Collection: A Bartlett Family, the Farrow Family Papers, or the Register of the Henry A. Montgomery Family. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pearl Harbor Survivors Association Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Pearl Harbor Survivors Association was founded after eleven survivors of the Pearl Harbor attack gathered in Gardena, California, on December 7, 1954 to remember their friends and fallen comrades. The reunion became an annual event, and the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association was officially founded in 1958 and recognized by the United States Congress in 1985. This organization includes members who were at or in the vicinity of Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, when the Japanese attacked on December 7, 1941. -- Today, membership is slowly decreasing as most of the members are well into their nineties. The Sons and Daughters of Pearl Harbor Survivors was founded on December 6, 1965, in response to the eventual expiry of the Association and continues to increase awareness and provide scholarship funds. -- The Tri-State Pearl Harbor Survivors Association has included veterans from Tennessee, Mississippi, and Arkansas and was chartered on December 7, 1968. Since 1996, Mr. Howard G. Lee has served as President and before that as Secretary-Treasurer. Today, there are only three members remaining of this chapter, and they celebrated their last official meeting in December 2011. During its 43 active years, the chapter hosted an annual luncheon at the Naval Support Activity Mid-South Conference Center in Millington, TN, visited local elementary schools to share their Pearl Harbor stories, and donated to various non-profits throughout the region. Throughout its community endeavors, it has actively lived the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association national motto: “Remember Pearl Harbor—Keep America Alert.”

PEARL HARBOR SURVIVORS ASSOCIATION COLLECTION Processed By: Regan Adolph 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 2 Pearl Harbor Survivors Association Collection Historical Sketch The Pearl Harbor Survivors Association was founded after eleven survivors of the Pearl Harbor attack gathered in Gardena, California, on December 7, 1954 to remember their friends and fallen comrades. The reunion became an annual event, and the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association was officially founded in 1958 and recognized by the United States Congress in 1985. This organization includes members who were at or in the vicinity of Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, when the Japanese attacked on December 7, 1941. Today, membership is slowly decreasing as most of the members are well into their nineties. The Sons and Daughters of Pearl Harbor Survivors was founded on December 6, 1965, in response to the eventual expiry of the Association and continues to increase awareness and provide scholarship funds. The Tri-State Pearl Harbor Survivors Association has included veterans from Tennessee, Mississippi, and Arkansas and was chartered on December 7, 1968. Since 1996, Mr. Howard G. Lee has served as President and before that as Secretary-Treasurer. Today, there are only three members remaining of this chapter, and they celebrated their last official meeting in December 2011. During its 43 active years, the chapter hosted an annual luncheon at the Naval Support Activity Mid-South Conference Center in Millington, TN, visited local elementary schools to share their Pearl Harbor stories, and donated to various non-profits throughout the region. Throughout its community endeavors, it has actively lived the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association national motto: “Remember Pearl Harbor—Keep America Alert.” 3 Pearl Harbor Survivors Association Collection Scope and Content Comprised of 0.3 linear feet, the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center in May of 2013 by Mr. Howard G. Lee. The majority of this material in this collection is from the 1990s and 2000s and includes personal correspondence, images and newspaper clippings of reunions, reports of member deaths, various programs and luncheon details, and miscellaneous Pearl Harbor memorabilia. The collection was split into folders by subject, but most of the original order was maintained. There is a corresponding collection on this chapter of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association donated by Howard Lee housed at the University of Memphis Special Collections. Those interested in military history should also consult the Memphians During War Collection, the Marvin and Mary Bazemore Collection, the Memphis Belle Collection, and the Military Officers’ Wives Club Collection. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research.
