oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gwen R. Awsumb Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gwen R. Awsumb braved uncharted waters in Memphis municipal politics. She emerged during a crucial time in both national and local history, serving as the only female member of Memphis’ first mayor-city council during the Civil Rights Movement. She witnessed the tension of the Sanitation Workers Strike, grieved the loss of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., rallied for the fluoridation of public water, and fought incessantly for her constituents. Gwen was among the first generation of moderate Republicans to gain political clout in Memphis. She fought political, social, and racial obstacles with her status as a white, female Republican. Her determined spirit inspired a new attitude of cooperation between municipal leaders and the citizens of Memphis. She valued the progress and urban development of the city. She respected her fellow council members and believed that improved relations between white and black communities were crucial to the betterment of Memphis. -- The material is comprised of two personal scrapbooks containing newspaper clippings that cover 1951-2000, congratulatory correspondence, personal speeches, a memoir, a summary of reports, and two government booklets. The original order was fully maintained in the processing of this collection.

GWEN R. AWSUMB COLLECTION Processed By: Regan Adolph & Lanier Flanders 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 2 Gwen R. Awsumb Collection Biographical Note Gwen R. Awsumb braved uncharted waters in Memphis municipal politics. She emerged during a crucial time in both national and local history, serving as the only female member of Memphis’ first mayor-city council during the Civil Rights Movement. She witnessed the tension of the Sanitation Workers Strike, grieved the loss of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., rallied for the fluoridation of public water, and fought incessantly for her constituents. Gwen was among the first generation of moderate Republicans to gain political clout in Memphis. She fought political, social, and racial obstacles with her status as a white, female Republican. Her determined spirit inspired a new attitude of cooperation between municipal leaders and the citizens of Memphis. She valued the progress and urban development of the city. She respected her fellow council members and believed that improved relations between white and black communities were crucial to the betterment of Memphis. Gwendolyn Van Court Robinson was born on September 25, 1915 in Marshall, Michigan. Her father was a native of LaGrange, Illinois, while her mother was born in Natchez, Mississippi. In 1930 at the age of fifteen, her family moved to Memphis as a result of personal financial hardship. Supported by family and friends, Gwen was able to graduate from St. Mary’s Episcopal School in 1932. She then attended Southwestern (now called Rhodes College) where she majored in Chemistry, pledged Kappa Delta, and graduated in 1937. Although pursued by two men, Gwen was ultimately charmed by Wells Awsumb, a future member of George Awsumb & Sons and the architect of Clough Hall at Rhodes College. The young couple married in December 1937. Wells completed his graduate degree in architecture at the University of Illinois in 1940 and was the only person in his senior class to pass the Architectural State Board exam. Together they had three children: George (1939), Carl David (1942), and Helen Catherine “Cathy” (1947). After a short stint in New Orleans from July to November 1941, Wells and Gwen relocated to Athens, Alabama. Wells served in World War II for eighteen months, and Gwen returned to Memphis to live near relatives. The family was finally reunited and moved to Forest Avenue in 1950. Gwen began working for the Episcopal Diocese of Tennessee in 1956 at the request of Bishop Barth. She devotedly attended Calvary Episcopal Church and became active in the YWCA. Gwen’s interest in politics started with her involvement in the voters’ registration effort through the YWCA. This innocent endeavor led to political fervor, action, and passion. She campaigned for General Eisenhower during the 1952 presidential election. She co-chaired the Orgill Campaign for the Memphis school board and served on the City Beautiful Commission. The Republican party convinced her to run for a seat in the Tennessee House of Representatives 3 in 1956 as a “guinea pig”. Yet Gwen’s campaign surpassed expectations. Eight candidates out of a large field were elected and she finished ninth. For Gwen, the legislative campaign was merely a stepping stone for future political ambitions. After a large town hall gathering at Ellis Auditorium, she was one of twenty five persons selected for a charter committee. This committee lobbied for a mayor-council form of government. Their proposal was passed in 1966 by the City Commission with a narrow 3-2 vote. In the spring of 1967, Gwen represented the District Two seat of the newly-created Memphis City Council. She was the only woman of the 13-member body. Her success as a council member continued; she served as Chair of the City Council in 1970. In 1971, her election to an at-large seat on the council attested to her growing popularity across the city. Although considered a viable candidate for mayor, Gwen opted for a new avenue and accepted Mayor Wyeth Chandler’s appointment as the city’s director of the Department of Housing and Community Development in 1975. She performed this role until her retirement in 1981. Gwen’s commendable political career serves as a testimony to her devotion, integrity, and fortitude. In addition to politics, Gwen also served numerous organizations with distinction. Some of her roles included Chair of the Memphis and Shelby County Bi-Centennial Commission, Secretary of the Program of Progress Committee (POP), and board member of the YWCA, the Episcopal Church Home, Theatre Memphis, and Les Passees. She was also a member of the Tennessee Board of Regents and the Memphis Book Club. Her interests were as diverse as her contributions were unique. She supported arts, education, and church outreach. In her memoir, Gwen recorded her honorary doctorate from Rhodes College in 1976 as her finest hour. This doctorate recognized Gwen’s inspirational contributions as both a civil servant and city leader. In 1996, St. Mary’s Episcopal School named Gwen the recipient of the Distinguished Alumnae Award. Gwen R. Awsumb died in 2003 leaving a legacy of awsumbness. 4 Gwen R. Awsumb Collection Scope and Content Comprised of 0.3 linear feet, the Gwen R. Awsumb Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center in 2001 by Gwen R. Awsumb. The material is comprised of two personal scrapbooks containing newspaper clippings that cover 1951-2000, congratulatory correspondence, personal speeches, a memoir, a summary of reports, and two government booklets. The original order was fully maintained in the processing of this collection. Those interested in examples of Memphis women in politics should consult the NOW - Memphis Chapter Collection and the Roberta Church Collection. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. Awsumb Collection Container List Box Number Folder Number Folder Name 1 n/a Scrapbooks 2 1 Government Booklets and Reports 2 2 Correspondence 2 3 Speeches 2 4 Memoir 6 Gwen R. Awsumb Collection Box 1 – Scrapbooks Box 1 contains two personal scrapbooks of newspaper clippings compiled by Gwen R. Awsumb of her political achievements in Memphis, Tennessee. The first chronicles 1951-1968, and the second records 1969-2000. These scrapbooks document her career highlights including managing finances for the Episcopal Diocese of Tennessee, being elected the first woman to serve on the City Council, directing Memphis Community Development, and serving on the Republican State Executive Committee. Box 2 – Documents Folder Number Folder Name Number of Items Description of Contents 1 Government Booklets and Reports 3 Contains two booklets entitled “Your City Government” (1969) and “Welcome to Your City Government” (1972). The latter was edited by Gwen Awsumb. Contains one packet of summary reports of the Midtown Demonstration Project. 2 Correspondence 40 Contains mostly congratulatory correspondence between Gwen and personal friends including senators, government officials, and church leaders. 3 Speeches 10 Contains typescript copies of speeches given by Gwen R. Awsumb on various occasions. 4 Memoir 1 Contains one bound memoir written by Gwen R. Awsumb entitled “Gwen Remembers When: A Personal Memoir”. This follows her childhood through her retirement, her family and work life, and special anecdotes throughout her life.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ronco Spaghetti Company Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ronco Spaghetti Company originally began in 1926 as the business endeavor of Italian immigrant John S. Robilio. Several years later, Ronco became a local partnership between Robilio and Thomas Cuneo. The name Ronco cleverly combines the “RO” of Robilio and the “CO” of Cuneo to form a fitting title. Mr. Robilio imported the finest durham and semolina wheat for his pasta products which included elbow, spaghetti, and macaroni noodles. The company also served as a local importing and distribution center for the Memphis region until 1961. Although Mr. Robilio died in 1929 before the height of Ronco’s success, the operations were continued with the oversight of his son Albert Robilio and family. -- The company thrived after World War II as it expanded its consumer base across the Southeast. Soon, Ronco pasta and noodles were featured on the display aisles at many of the main grocery stores including Kroger, A & P, Winn Dixie, Piggly Wiggly, and Super Stores. The insightful sales managers sought to develop a strong brand identity via advertisement. Utilizing many nuanced marketing and advertising strategies of the twentieth century, the Ronco Pasta label appeared daily on city buses and decorated the highway with colorful billboards. In 1938, the first large transit ad of the area featured the company. Ronco was proud to call itself a local, independent enterprise. It relocated from its original address on 124 N. Front Street (now the current site of City Hall) to a larger, more comprehensive site on 800 S. Barksdale Avenue in 1972. This location enabled the company to expand its manufacturing site and increase production quality. The process for producing pasta requires efficient machinery and expert skill. First, the grains must be stored in large barrels. Next, the product is pressed into its desired shape and lastly dried to achieve the best results. -- The Ronco Company worked extensively with advertising agencies and promotional companies, distributing coupons in the newspapers and offering weekly specials on select products. These strategies were evidently successful; in 1978, the Memphis Press-Scimitar reported that 13,000 tons of pasta were produced, generating sales of approximately $10 million. In 1981, Ronco was managed by an outside party for the first time. L.M. Anderson served as the general manager and L.P.A. Giannini (Tony) worked as the assistant manager. These managers remained loyal to the founding families’ vision, vowing to maintain independence despite pressure from greedy conglomerates in the food industry. Despite this vision, the Ronco Company was sold to food giant Borden Inc. who proceeded to close the pasta plant in the late 1980s. Although the Ronco Pasta brand is now externally owned and sold nation-wide, its economic contribution to the Memphis community cannot be denied.

Ronco Spaghetti Company Collection Processed by Lanier Flanders Rhodes College 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Popular Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 2 Ronco Spaghetti Company Collection Historical Sketch The Ronco Spaghetti Company originally began in 1926 as the business endeavor of Italian immigrant John S. Robilio. Several years later, Ronco became a local partnership between Robilio and Thomas Cuneo. The name Ronco cleverly combines the “RO” of Robilio and the “CO” of Cuneo to form a fitting title. Mr. Robilio imported the finest durham and semolina wheat for his pasta products which included elbow, spaghetti, and macaroni noodles. The company also served as a local importing and distribution center for the Memphis region until 1961. Although Mr. Robilio died in 1929 before the height of Ronco’s success, the operations were continued with the oversight of his son Albert Robilio and family. The company thrived after World War II as it expanded its consumer base across the Southeast. Soon, Ronco pasta and noodles were featured on the display aisles at many of the main grocery stores including Kroger, A & P, Winn Dixie, Piggly Wiggly, and Super Stores. The insightful sales managers sought to develop a strong brand identity via advertisement. Utilizing many nuanced marketing and advertising strategies of the twentieth century, the Ronco Pasta label appeared daily on city buses and decorated the highway with colorful billboards. In 1938, the first large transit ad of the area featured the company. Ronco was proud to call itself a local, independent enterprise. It relocated from its original address on 124 N. Front Street (now the current site of City Hall) to a larger, more comprehensive site on 800 S. Barksdale Avenue in 1972. This location enabled the company to expand its manufacturing site and increase production quality. The process for producing pasta requires efficient machinery and expert skill. First, the grains must be stored in large barrels. Next, the product is pressed into its desired shape and lastly dried to achieve the best results. The Ronco Company worked extensively with advertising agencies and promotional companies, distributing coupons in the newspapers and offering weekly specials on select products. These strategies were evidently successful; in 1978, the Memphis Press-Scimitar reported that 13,000 tons of pasta were produced, generating sales of approximately $10 million. In 1981, Ronco was managed by an outside party for the first time. L.M. Anderson served as the general manager and L.P.A. Giannini (Tony) worked as the assistant manager. These managers remained loyal to the founding families’ vision, vowing to maintain independence despite pressure from greedy conglomerates in the food industry. Despite this vision, the Ronco Company was sold to food giant Borden Inc. who proceeded to close the pasta plant in the late 1980s. Although the Ronco Pasta brand is now externally owned and sold nation-wide, its economic contribution to the Memphis community cannot be denied. 3 Scope and Content The Ronco Spagehetti Company Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library and Information Center by J. S. ‘Jay’ Robilio Jr. in 1993. His donation contained five boxes of photographs and promotional material pertaining to Ronco. This collection comprises one half of a linear foot in addition to four complete photo albums equivalent to one foot. The Ronco Spaghetti Company Collection is primarily a visual, photographic collection of Ronco’s business endeavors. These photos catalog over forty years of Ronco success ranging from the late 1930s to the early 1980s. Some photographs are in black and white while others are in color. Most photographs contain a detailed description indicating the date, location, and content of the photo, but several photos are obscure and unidentifiable. The photos carefully document Ronco inventory displays in grocery stores, as well as machinery and equipment used in the factory. Several photos capture the employees, managers, and bosses conducting daily business. This collection mainly features promotional strategies relating to Ronco. There are several examples of business correspondence with advertising agencies and newspapers, as well as a business contract with Hunt’s Tomato Paste. Promotion pamphlets, brochures, certificates, and newspaper clippings all attest to the company’s profitability and prestige. As a member of the Greater Memphis State, Ronco Company was nominated by the Memphis mayor and Shelby County commissioner to submit an excerpt to a historical book called A Metropolis on the Nile: An Illustrated History of Memphis and Shelby Co. published in 1982. Included in this collection is correspondence between the Ronco managers and the editor, in addition to various drafts of Ronco’s biographical insert. Researchers interested in the history of privately owned Memphis businesses should also consult the Firestone Collection, the Goldsmith Collection, and the Piggly Wiggly Collection. Researchers should also consider the papers of the Oliver-Finnie Company and the South Memphis Land Company. For a recent report on affiliated Robilio businesses, read this article from the Commercial Appeal: http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2011/nov/04/memphis-based-victor-l-robillio-acquired-glazers-i/?print=1 Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Awsumb Architectural Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
This collection spans the years 1921 to 1986, three generations (George Awsumb, Wells Awsumb, Richard Awsumb, and Carl Awsumb), and five firms (Pfeil & Awsumb “PA”, George Awsumb “GA”, George Awsumb & Sons “GAS”, Awsumb/Associates/Architects “AAA”, and Awsumb, Wage, & Watson “AWW”). There are 80 total boxes in the collection; 79 contain architectural drawings, blueprints, brownprints (reproductions), structural and mechanical sketches, topographic surveys, and floor plans. These documents include ink on linen and paper, pencil on tissue paper and tracing paper, brownprints on plastic, and blueprints; project types range from new structures to additions and renovations. The last box in the collection contains 51 oversized drawings of the Auditorium Market House building. -- The Awsumb Collection is divided into four series by date of project: Series I from 1921-1950, Series II from 1951-1970, Series III from 1971-1990, and Series IV Oversized.
The drawings are organized chronologically by building; all related buildings and structures, even those with different project numbers, are stored in the same or sequential box. For example, all projects concerning LeMoyne College are grouped together as well as South Side High School, Idlewild Presbyterian Church, and First Methodist Church.

AWSUMB ARCHITECTURAL COLLECTION Processed By: Jill Davis, Regan Adolph, & Lanier Flanders 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 2 Awsumb Architectural Collection Biographical Note George Awsumb George Awsumb became a nationally-recognized architect for his prize winning designs of the Market House Auditorium (Ellis Auditorium) and Idlewild Presbyterian Church, both located in Memphis. His contributions were in the traditional Classic design with regal ornamentation, making George a noted architect of the Gothic church construction in the South. George defined architecture as “frozen music” made for the “man on the street” (The Egyptians, 1941 April 17). Indeed, his designs created a visual symphony and continues to mesmerize viewers. George was born in Skein, Norway in 1880. At the age of four, his family moved to America and settled in Whitewater, Wisconsin. He attended the University of Wisconsin and studied engineering for one year. His family then relocated to Eau Claire, Wisconsin, and George entered the building trade and began constructing massive barns. Later in life, George reflected that his experience building barns led to his successful career in church and public building design. There was a great similarity between the basic principles of the two structures (Commercial Appeal, 1959 November 25). He studied for three years at the University of Illinois and worked for two years in Chicago at various architectural firms. While in Chicago, he won the Chicago Architecture Club’s traveling scholarship. Once George complete school, the scholarship transported him to Europe. Touring England and France on a bicycle, George was first exposed to the Gothic European cathedrals. He returned to Chicago and taught for one more year at the Art Institute. Again, he went abroad to examine more thoroughly the great cathedrals. On this second trip, George decided to specialize in the design of public buildings. In 1915, he married Ella Wells, a native of Beatrice, Nebraska and daughter of D.O.O. and Marie McConnell Wells. Together the couple had three children: Wells (1915), Georgiana (1918), and Richard (1919). In 1919, George came to Memphis at the request of Charles O. Pfeil, a prominent Memphis architect. Pfeil invited him to co-enter a competition for the design of the Market House Auditorium. They won the competition and created a partnership called Pfeil & Awsumb that lasted until 1929. George continued to design buildings for another forty years. After Ellis Auditorium, Pfeil & Awsumb designed the Dermon Building (listed on the National Register of Historic Places) and Ildewild Presbyterian Church (second place at the Christian Herald National Competition). 3 After parting with Pfeil in 1929, George opened his own firm called George Awsumb. He later renamed the firm to George Awsumb & Sons in 1946. After a long, distinguished career, George died on November 24, 1959. Wells Awsumb Wells Awsumb was born on October 28, 1915, the eldest son of George and Ella. He was an architect in Memphis for thirty-five years. He attended Southwestern (now Rhodes College) where he met his future wife, Gwendolyn Van Court Robinson. Gwen and Wells married in 1938 and had three children: George (1939), Carl David (1942) and Cathy (1947). Wells graduated from the University of Illinois in 1940 with a degree in architecture. He was the only person in his senior class to pass the Architectural State Board exam (Gwen R. Awsumb Collection).Upon graduation, he served eighteen months in World War II. Shortly after the war, he returned to Memphis to become partners with his father and brother in the firm George Awsumb & Sons. In 1963, he was president of the Memphis chapter of American Institute of Architects. He also served as chairman of the C.M. Gooch Foundation Board and was a member of the Kiwanis Club. Some of Wells’ signature designs include Theatre Memphis, Clough Hall at Rhodes College, and Lindenwood Christian Church. Despite these achievements, Wells preferred painting in watercolor. Once retired, Wells became an active watercolorist. Richard Awsumb Richard was born on August 4, 1919. He was George and Ella’s second son and youngest child. Like his brother, Richard also graduated from University of Illinois with a degree in architecture. He served four years in World War II and returned to Memphis to join the family firm. He married Kathryn Gibson and had three children: Richard Jr., John Kenneth, and Rebecca. Carl David The youngest son of Wells and Gwen Awsumb, Carl continued the Awsumb name in Memphis architecture. He attended Auburn University and married Priscilla Ann “Pan”. Together the couple had two children, Sarah and Matthew. In 1975, he joined the family firm renamed to Awsumb/Associates/Architects. After Richard and Wells retired in 1981, Carl changed the firm’s name to Awsumb, Wage, & Watson. This firm existed until 1989, when Carl established his own private practice. 4 Awsumb Architectural Collection Family Tree m. Gwen Robinson George Awsumb 1880-1959 Wells 1915-1995 George b. 1939 Carl David b. 1942 Catherine b. 1947 Georgiana 1918-2011 William Lockwood Jr. Alan George Richard Norman 1919-1997 Richard Jr. John Kenneth Rebecca m. Kathryn Gibson m. W. L. Ensminger m. Ella Wells 5 Awsumb Architectural Collection Historical Sketch The Awsumb Architectural Collection contains sixty years of architectural projects and designs from the 20th century that characterize the city of Memphis today. This multi-generational collection captures the artistic vision of the Awsumb architects and verifies their valuable contributions to the city’s progress and development. George Awsumb, the first Awsumb architect, defined architecture as “frozen music” designed for the “man on the street” (The Egyptians, 1941 April 17). Indeed, this Memphis architect, his two sons Wells and Richard, and grandson Carl re-shaped the traditional Classic design for Memphians, providing residences, churches, schools, theaters, and an auditorium for the public to enjoy. By examining the many original drawings, such as Ellis Auditorium, Idlewild Presbyterian Church, and Clough Hall on the Rhodes College Campus, scholars can now seek to understand the relationship between the architectural style of the Awsumbs and the “man on the street.” George Awsumb arrived in Memphis in 1919 at the request of Mr. Charles O. Pfeil, a prominent Memphis architect interested in entering a design competition for the Market House Auditorium. After winning the competition, George stayed in Memphis and continued to design buildings for forty more years. He parted ways with Pfeil in 1929 and began to design public buildings, specifically church buildings. Some of his exemplary designs include the Dermon Building, several campus buildings for LeMoyne Owen College, First Presbyterian Church in Osceola, Arkansas, local Young Women’s Christian Association buildings, and the Baron Hirsch Synagogue Worship Center. In 1946, after completing their respective service in World War II, Wells and Richard Awsumb joined their father in forming the George Awsumb & Sons firm, making an impressive team. Notary designs completed by this firm include the Bruce Hall for LeMoyne Owens College, First Methodist Church, the Idlewild Presbyterian Church Youth Center, and South Side High School. George Awsumb died in 1959. He was nationally recognized for his prize-winning designs of Ellis Auditorium and Idlewild Presbyterian Church and acclaimed in the South for his Gothic church designs. Wells and Richard continued the firm and designed the Episcopal Church Home for Girls, Otey Memorial Chapel, First Church of Christ Scientist, Clough Hall at Rhodes College, and Lindenwood Christian Church. In 1975, Well’s son, Carl David Awsumb, joined the firm and the name changed to Awsumb/Associates/Architects. Significant designs during this period were the Memphis Police Station renovations, Babcock Gallery, St. Philip Episcopal Church, and noted residences. Upon the retirement of Wells and Richard in 1981, the name changed once again to Awsumb, Wage & Watson. Carl continued the Awsumb name in Memphis architecture, designing celebrated buildings such as the Children’s Theatre, the Church of Jesus Christ of 6 Latter-day Saints on Walnut Grove Road, and several office buildings and residences. Awsumb, Wage & Watson continued to exist until 1989, when Carl Awsumb established an independent practice. 7 Awsumb Architectural Collection Scope and Content Comprised of approximately 8 linear feet, the Awsumb Architectural Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center in 1997 by Carl Awsumb. This collection spans the years 1921 to 1986, three generations (George Awsumb, Wells Awsumb, Richard Awsumb, and Carl Awsumb), and five firms (Pfeil & Awsumb “PA”, George Awsumb “GA”, George Awsumb & Sons “GAS”, Awsumb/Associates/Architects “AAA”, and Awsumb, Wage, & Watson “AWW”). There are 80 total boxes in the collection; 79 contain architectural drawings, blueprints, brownprints (reproductions), structural and mechanical sketches, topographic surveys, and floor plans. These documents include ink on linen and paper, pencil on tissue paper and tracing paper, brownprints on plastic, and blueprints; project types range from new structures to additions and renovations. The last box in the collection contains 51 oversized drawings of the Auditorium Market House building. The Awsumb Collection is divided into four series by date of project: Series I from 1921-1950, Series II from 1951-1970, Series III from 1971-1990, and Series IV Oversized. The drawings are organized chronologically by building; all related buildings and structures, even those with different project numbers, are stored in the same or sequential box. For example, all projects concerning LeMoyne College are grouped together as well as South Side High School, Idlewild Presbyterian Church, and First Methodist Church. Those interested in examples of Memphis architectural firms should consult the George Mahan, Jr. Collection. Those interested in more information about the Awsumb family should consult the Gwen R. Awsumb Collection. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reverend Eron M. Sharp Collection Addendum
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Reverend Sharp was born in Leake County, Mississippi in 1904. He graduated from Millsaps College in Jackson, Mississippi and received an M.A. from Duke University. He served as pastor for several Mid-South churches during his career including Hernando First United Methodist Church, Aberdeen First United Methodist Church, New Albany First United Methodist Church, and Greenwood First United Methodist Church. In addition to his pastoral services, Reverend Sharp also devoted his time to genealogical research. He wrote several genealogical and local history books, and collected a large number of genealogical records. -- This collection contains one box of information useful to local historians and genealogists. It includes various documents such as census records, family histories, Bible records, wills, correspondence, church records, deeds, pedigree charts, newspaper articles, maps, marriage records, pension records, and land grants to name a few. The data primarily concentrates on the Pickens-Henry family history.

REVEREND ERON M. SHARP COLLECTION ADDENDUM PROCESSED BY BEVERLY SULLIVAN AND JOAN CANNON HISTORY DEPARTMENT MEMPHIS PUBLIC LIBRARY & INFORMATION CENTER 3030 POPLAR MEMPHIS, TENNESSEE 38111 2013 Scope and Content The Reverend E.M. Sharp Collection Addendum was given to the Memphis and Shelby County Room by Mrs. E.M. Sharp on March 10, 1998, after the death of her husband. Reverend Sharp was born in Leake County, Mississippi in 1904. He graduated from Millsaps College in Jackson, Mississippi and received an M.A. from Duke University. He served as pastor for several Mid-South churches during his career including Hernando First United Methodist Church, Aberdeen First United Methodist Church, New Albany First United Methodist Church, and Greenwood First United Methodist Church. In addition to his pastoral services, Reverend Sharp also devoted his time to genealogical research. He wrote several genealogical and local history books, and collected a large number of genealogical records. This collection contains one box of information useful to local historians and genealogists. It includes various documents such as census records, family histories, Bible records, wills, correspondence, church records, deeds, pedigree charts, newspaper articles, maps, marriage records, pension records, and land grants to name a few. The data primarily concentrates on the Pickens-Henry family history. For those interested in genealogical data, please consult the original Reverend E.M. Sharp Collection and the Ida Cooper Genealogical Collection. For those interested in the careers of Mid-South pastors, please consult the Papers of the Reverend George C. Harris and the Reverend Charles Carroll Parsons Collection. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Architectural Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Comprised of approximately 7 linear feet, the Memphis Architectural Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center over a number of years by numerous architectural firms and members of the community. There are 62 boxes total; the first 61 boxes contain architectural designs by approximately 30 Memphis architects ranging from 1906 to 1998, and the last box contains various documents and publications about Memphis architecture. The designs include drawings, blueprints, structural and mechanical sketches, topographic surveys, and floor plans. They were created using ink and pencil on linen and paper, and projects range from new structures to additions and renovations. Those interested in examples of Memphis architecture should consult the Awsumb Architectural Collection and the George Mahan, Jr. Collection. -- The order of this collection is first by type of structure, then by architect, and finally by date if it is known, and the building types are divided into series. Series I is Business, Series II is Hotel, Series III is Hospital, Series IV is Residence, Series V is Public Use, Series VI is Social Club, Series VII is Theater, Series VIII is Miscellaneous, and Series IX is Publications. Publications found in the last box include brochures of the Memphis Housing Authority and the Architect League of Memphis, a 1968 economic profile of Memphis issued by the Chamber of Commerce, periodicals detailing the Whitehaven Utility District, Quantum House, and Architecture + Memphis, a 1943 record of street numbering, the completed works of Jones & Furbringer, and a 1913 portfolio of small home designs.

MEMPHIS ARCHITECTURAL COLLECTION Processed By: Regan Adolph & Lanier Flanders 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 2 Memphis Architectural Collection Historical Sketch The Memphis Architectural Collection is a diverse compilation of architectural designs that were constructed in Memphis and Shelby County throughout the 20th century. Various classifications of buildings including businesses, residences, hospitals, hotels, theaters, social clubs, and buildings that provide public services are featured. This collection represents the rich heritage of Memphis as it evolves from a trading port on a bluff of the Mississippi into a vibrant metropolitan city of the 21st century. Starting in 1900, Memphis began to flourish as a city. Attractions such as Overton Park and the Memphis Zoo emerged. In 1904, the Parkways were constructed in a quad-like pattern to surround Overton Park. Talented designers and architects found themselves working in Memphis; some of the earliest firms featured in this collection include Hanker & Cairns, Walter W. Ahlscharlger, Jones & Furbringer, and James B. Cook. Ornate, luxurious hotels such as the Peabody Hotel, the Gayoso Hotel, the Chisca Hotel, and the Chickasaw Hotel are all results of this grandiose era. Various businesses, such as Memphis Steam Laundry, Lowenstein’s Department Store, the E.H. Crump building, the Memphis Royal Crown Bottling Co., and the Pantaze Drugstore all reflect the industry, investment, and enterprise of downtown Memphis. This collection contains nearly 60 designs from the Hanker & Cairns architectural firm. After studying in Paris, Bayard Snowden Cairns arrived in Memphis in 1904 at the request of his cousin R. Brinkley Snowden to be the superintendent of the Memphis Trust Company (later known as the Bank of Commerce and Trust Company). He established the firm Hanker & Cairns in 1907. He and his associate William Julius Hanker are credited with the classical designs of the Chisca Hotel, the Nineteenth Century Club, the Chickasaw Hotel, the Marx and Bensdorf building, and various renowned residences. They were also the associate architects for the Peabody Hotel. Their firm continued until 1934. Arguably the most famous Memphis attraction, the Peabody Hotel was reconstructed in 1925. Walter W. Ahlschlarger is praised for its notable designs. The hotel resembles an oversized Spanish hunting lodge, complete with a Travertine fountain and a grand mezzanine. Born in Chicago in 1887, he studied at The Lewis Institute of Technology, in addition to attending The Armour Institute and The Art Institute. Today, the celebrated Peabody Hotel stands regally on Union Avenue, still luring guests with its traditional duck march, Art Deco Skyway, and rooftop pavilion. Another key firm featured in the collection is Jones & Furbringer. Max H. Furbringer served on the City Planning Commission, the City Board of Adjustment, and the Memphis Housing Authority. He was also a highly active member of the American Institute of Architects. 3 His associate Walk C. Jones, Sr. was born in Memphis in 1874. His tour of Europe and the Middle East influenced his architectural preference for the Moorish, classic style. Some of their notable works include the Jewish Hospital and the Oakville Sanatorium Children’s Building. Walk C. Jones, Jr. later joined the firm in 1930. A photographic compilation of their residential designs can be found in Box 62. Overall, this collection strongly reflects the diverse interests of Memphis. The city values artistic expression as is evident with the blueprints of the Majestic Theatres, the Memphis Theater, Crump Stadium, and the Levitt Shell. This white concrete orchestra shell was first constructed in 1936 as a product of the Works Progress Administration. Beginning in 2008, it now offers free outdoor concerts for the general public to enjoy. The collection even includes blueprints from the Historic American Buildings Survey, a New Deal program designed to preserve historically significant buildings and provide employment to architects. The Tennessee State Capital Building, the Hermitage Home, and the Goyer-Lee Home are all documents from this endeavor. In addition to cultural attractions, public service has also been a consistent priority for Memphis. The drawings of the Shelby County Court House, Linden Station, Memphis River Terminal, the Shelby County Insane Asylum, and the Shelby County Penal Farm all attest to the city’s growth and development. The construction of hospitals, such as B’nai B’rith Home and Hospital for the Aged, Methodist Hospital, and Oakville Sanatorium affirm Memphis’ dedication to medical services. Although this collection contains many blueprints, it is important to note not all of these structures remain in physical form. These structural designs, along with plans for prominent Memphis residences and notable publications about architecture, complete the Memphis Architectural Collection. 4 Memphis Architectural Collection Scope and Content Comprised of approximately 7 linear feet, the Memphis Architectural Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center over a number of years by numerous architectural firms and members of the community. There are 62 boxes total; the first 61 boxes contain architectural designs by approximately 30 Memphis architects ranging from 1906 to 1998, and the last box contains various documents and publications about Memphis architecture. The designs include drawings, blueprints, structural and mechanical sketches, topographic surveys, and floor plans. They were created using ink and pencil on linen and paper, and projects range from new structures to additions and renovations. Those interested in examples of Memphis architecture should consult the Awsumb Architectural Collection and the George Mahan, Jr. Collection. The order of this collection is first by type of structure, then by architect, and finally by date if it is known, and the building types are divided into series. Series I is Business, Series II is Hotel, Series III is Hospital, Series IV is Residence, Series V is Public Use, Series VI is Social Club, Series VII is Theater, Series VIII is Miscellaneous, and Series IX is Publications. Publications found in the last box include brochures of the Memphis Housing Authority and the Architect League of Memphis, a 1968 economic profile of Memphis issued by the Chamber of Commerce, periodicals detailing the Whitehaven Utility District, Quantum House, and Architecture + Memphis, a 1943 record of street numbering, the completed works of Jones & Furbringer, and a 1913 portfolio of small home designs. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gerald and Barbara Dowdy Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Gerald and Barbara Dowdy Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in January, 2013 by G. Wayne Dowdy. Comprising one 2 ½ inch box, the collection contains letters written by Gerald McLain Dowdy to his wife, Barbara Ann Nance Dowdy, and his parents John and Lucile Dowdy while he was on active duty with the Tennessee Army National Guard from October 1960 to July 1963. Also included in the collection are a letter and postcard to Barbara Ann Nance Dowdy from Myra Gale Brown Lewis, wife of rock ‘n’ roll performer Jerry Lee Lewis, as well as photographs and other miscellaneous items. The Gerald and Barbara Dowdy Collection provide a fascinating glimpse into the life of a soldier during the Cold War years of the early 1960s. The letters chronicle many of Dowdy’s day-to-day activities during Basic Training at Fort Jackson, South Carolina, Artillery School at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and while he was on active duty at Fort Campbell, Kentucky and Fort Stewart, Georgia.

The Gerald and Barbara Dowdy Collection Processed by Joan Cannon 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 SCOPE AND CONTENT NOTES GERALD AND BARBARA DOWDY COLLECTION The Gerald and Barbara Dowdy Collection was donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room in January, 2013 by G. Wayne Dowdy. Comprising one 2 ½ inch box, the collection contains letters written by Gerald McLain Dowdy to his wife, Barbara Ann Nance Dowdy, and his parents John and Lucile Dowdy while he was on active duty with the Tennessee Army National Guard from October 1960 to July 1963. Also included in the collection are a letter and postcard to Barbara Ann Nance Dowdy from Myra Gale Brown Lewis, wife of rock ‘n’ roll performer Jerry Lee Lewis, as well as photographs and other miscellaneous items. The Gerald and Barbara Dowdy Collection provide a fascinating glimpse into the life of a soldier during the Cold War years of the early 1960s. The letters chronicle many of Dowdy’s day-to-day activities during Basic Training at Fort Jackson, South Carolina, Artillery School at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and while he was on active duty at Fort Campbell, Kentucky and Fort Stewart, Georgia. Gerald M. Dowdy was born on October 17, 1942 in Orangeburg, South Carolina. Moving to Memphis with his parents during World War II, Dowdy joined the Tennessee Army National Guard’s 3rd Battalion, 115th Field Artillery Regiment, 30th Armored Division in July 1960 after graduating from Whitehaven High School. Achieving the rank of first sergeant, he served on active duty at several posts including Camp Shelby in Mississippi and Fort Campbell, Kentucky. Later he served in the Army Reserve where he was awarded the Army Achievement Medal. In a letter to his wife written in July, 1963 he described a typical day in an artillery regiment: “I fired 61 rounds at the forward position, the others fired 88 rounds. We went tactical at 1700 (5:00 PM) today and will be tactical until tomorrow at 1700. Tactical means no lights (I’m using a flashlight to write by)...no noise, wearing helmet, gas mask, rifle, canteen, first aid pouch and raincoat. Well, the capt. just came in and said to turn out my light.” Barbara Ann Nance Dowdy was born in Ripley, Mississippi on July 3, 1943 to William Herbert and Lurline Griffin Nance. As a young girl Barbara Nance Dowdy relocated to Memphis where she graduated from South Side High School in 1962. In addition to raising her sons Gerald Wayne and William Johnathan, Barbara Dowdy worked as a legal secretary for 24 years before her death on November 8, 2010. Researchers interested in the Cold War and Memphis during the 1960s will also want to consult the Jerry Lee Lewis, Everett R. Cook Oral History, John William McAfee, Hunter Lane, Jr., Marvin and Mary Bazemore and Memphians during War collections which are also housed in the Memphis and Shelby County Room. While the Memphis Public Library & Information Center may house an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. CONTAINER LIST Box One Folder 1 Items 10 Correspondence October – December 1960 Folder 2 Items 14 Correspondence January – February 1961 Folder 3 Items 4 Correspondence May 20, 1961 Folder 4 Items 7 Correspondence July 15 – 18, 1962 Folder 5 Items 9 Correspondence July 20 – 25, 1962 Folder 6 Items 3 Correspondence July 1963 Folder 7 Items 8 Miscellaneous Items Folder 8 Items 12 Photographs GERALD AND BARBARA DOWDY COLLECTION BOX 1 Folder 1 Items 10 Correspondence October – December 1960 October 26, 1960 To: Miss Barbara Nance, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Columbia, South Carolina Received your letter today. Surprised to hear from you. Won’t get to come home until Christmas. I get a pass every weekend and go to my Grandmama’s. Heard about Westside High School goofing up and glad to hear South Side is winning, but not really. Begin our work after exercising and eating. Went through the infiltration course and have been in two parades. My rank is corporal and I am a squad leader in charge of eleven other goof-offs. Don’t forget to write and tell everybody hello. With envelope cover stamped October 27, 1960, Columbia, South Carolina. (2 items) November 13, 1960 To: Miss Barbara Nance, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma Did not answer sooner because I was in the field. I will have two weeks off at Christmas and will be out of the army March 10, 1961. Would like to WHS and South Side play. Hope you’ll win the championship. Have to be ready for inspection any time of the day or night. Have a nice day room with pool tables, shuffleboard, ping pong tables, television, etc. Will go to school for six to eight weeks and then assigned to a battle group. Tell everybody hello, especially the girls. With envelope cover stamped November 14, 1960, Fort Sill, Oklahoma. (2 items) November 26, 1960 To: Miss Barbara Nance, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill,, Oklahoma Glad to receive your letter yesterday. Presently I am at the guard house (where the guys on guard stay). Walk two hours and then off for four hours. Goes on for twenty-four hours. Had a nice Thanksgiving dinner including the trimmings. Hope to be in Memphis the twenty-second or twenty-third and will ride the train. Tell Donald , Charlie and Tommy to write. Close by saying, “I’m thinking of you. With envelope cover stamped November 28, 1960, Fort Sill, Oklahoma. (2 items) Barbara Ann Nance, 1962 December 10, 1960 To: Miss Barbara Nance, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma Glad to hear from you. Got through our weekly inspection by four lieutenants and passed. It is now snowing. Also been raining and sleeting for the last four days. Were out in the field yesterday and almost froze. Snow is falling harder now and is beginning to stick. The temperature is thirty-four degrees. Had a test yesterday morning and made ninety-six. Will get home on the twenty-second. Tell everybody hello. With envelope cover stamped December 18, 1960, Fort Sill, Oklahoma. December 11, 1960 To: Miss Barbara Nance, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma Glad to hear from you. Hope it doesn’t snow until January 5, because if conditions are bad out here they won’t let us take our leave. Snowed Tuesday night and covered the ground completely. Rough week for classes. Had three exams this week. Were in the field all day yesterday. In less than five days I’ll be home. Will give you a picture of me in uniform when I get home. Be good and I’ll see you in five days. With envelope cover stamped December 12, 1960, Fort Sill, Oklahoma. Private Gerald M. Dowdy Folder 2 Items 14 Correspondence January – February 1961 January 4, 1961 To: Miss Barbara Nance, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma (Artillery & Guided Missile Center) Arrived this afternoon. Bus was late. Went into town with friends and saw the movie, “Where The Boys Are”, starring Connie Francis. Came straight back to the barracks. Did you miss me not calling and arguing with you? I was kinda mean to you, but I was just aggravating you. I like you a lot and hope you feel the same. Hated to tell you good bye. Thinking of you always and waiting on your letter. With envelope cover stamped January 5, 1961, Fort Sill, Oklahoma. January 12, 1961 To: Miss Barbara Nance, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma (Artillery & Guided Missile Center) Received your letter today. Before I left Memphis I thought you did care a little bit, but it seems you don’t. Sorry to hear Larry and Sandra had picked up our habit of arguing. Have just five more days in this Battery. Shipping the 20th to the Sixth Battallion. Grade dropped to eighty-eight today. Did you pass your exams? Saw the picture, “Mr. Roberts”, last night and “Where The Boys Are” last week. Some friends and I plan to go to Oklahoma City for the weekend if we get our Class A pass, if not we’ll go to Lawton. We were put on red alert about 4:30 this afternoon and stay ready until taken off or shipped out. I’m sorry if I have written anything to make you mad. If you do not plan to write me anymore, drop me line and let me know. With envelope cover stamped January 13, 1961, Fort Sill, Oklahoma. January 22, 1961 To: Miss Barbara Nance, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma (Battery “A”, 6th TNG. BN., USATG-FA) Received your letter today. I’ve been shipped to a new outfit and in the last phase of training. I have just six more weeks of training. Our equipment is packed and ready in case of an emergency. We get passes when we’re not on alert or in the field. Told yesterday we would leave on March 3rd and go to the transfer point and be on our way home the next morning. With envelope cover stamped January 25, 1961, Fort Sill, Oklahoma. January 24, 1961 To: Mr. & Mrs. John M. Dowdy, 2711 Merle, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma (Battery “A”, 6th TNG. BN., USATG-FA) Received Mama’s letter with my income tax return and money. Signed and mailed it tonight. Will send money home when I get paid. Hope Daddy finds a job and gets to make some good time. Hope you get to work more. It was warm yesterday, but this morning it turned cold and the wind was blowing. Started first class in communications this afternoon. Friends and I went to the gym Sunday afternoon and played basketball. Tell everybody hello and to write. With envelope cover stamped January 25, 1961, Fort Sill, Oklahoma. February 11, 1961 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma (Battery “A”, 6th TNG. BN., USATG-FA) Received your letter a few days ago. Also received a letter from Tommy on Thursday. Friends are staying at the Hotel Lawtonian this weekend. Got off yesterday afternoon because our Captain thought we looked sharp in a parade. Weather is warm. Last Sunday it snowed. Glad that you decided to write me. Going to go see “Flaming Star”, starring Elvis. With envelope stamped February 11, 1961. February 11, 1961 To: Mr. & Mrs. John M. Dowdy, 2711 Merle, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma (Battery “A”, 6th TNG. BN., USATG-FA) Received a letter from Mama yesterday and Thursday. Hope both of you are getting to work. Marched in a parade honoring the commanding general of the fourth army. Did real well, so our Captain let us have today off. Picked up passes after five. Eight of us came into town and rented a room in the nicest hotel. It cost $4.59 a night for a nice single room with bath and a free radio. Didn’t go to the field yesterday because of snow and iced over roads. Going to rent a car with five more boys in which to come home. It’ll be faster and more comfortable than a bus. Or you could come out here and pick me up and we could look around. I’ll pay the expenses. Talk it over and tell me what you think. February 16, 1961 To: Mr. & Mrs. John M. Dowdy, 2711 Merle, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma Thanks a lot for the card. First chance I had to write. I got to drive the other commo truck yesterday afternoon. I am at the laundry. Washed my field jacket, because we’ve have guard duty tomorrow and tomorrow night. I’ll be released in the afternoon of March 3rd. Have you’ll decided if you are coming or not. Hope Daddy got that job. Sorry to hear about Mr. Ellen. Tell him I said I hope he gets along fine if you see him again. If you can afford it, send me about ten stamps. February 17, 1961 To: Mr. & Mrs. John M. Dowdy, 2711 Merle, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma (Battery “A”, 6th TNG. BN. USATG-FA) Received Mama’s letter with the money in it today. Thanks a lot. I sure did need it. I’m on guard duty at the airport. Will check further about renting a car. Glad to hear that Daddy and you were working and make some good time. Glad to here that you’re having nice weather. Tornado warnings are out for us. With envelope stamped February 17, 1961. February 18, 1961 To: Mr. & Mrs. John M. Dowdy, 2711 Merle, Memphis, Tennessee From: Private Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Sill, Oklahoma (Battery “A”, 6th TNG. BN. USATG-FA) Received Mama’s letter today. Glad you decided to come out. I’ll get out of the Army on March 4. Ask for the transfer point. There is a parking lot directly across from it. Real glad to hear that you’ll were working. Turned real cold while we were working guard last night. Hope it warms up before we go to the field Monday. Going to Wichita Falls, Texas with friends in a minute. See you’ll in about thirteen days. With envelope stamped February 20, 1961. Folder 3 Items 4 Correspondence May 20, 1961 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Myra Gale Brown Lewis, 50th on the Lake Motel, Chicago, Illinois Didn’t get to call you before we left but we had planned to leave Friday. Tuesday night Jerry called and we left Wednesday morning. Chicago is some BIG! Everyone is still in their winter clothes. Almost everything I bought is white. I stick out like a sore thumb. Jerry has gone to play his last show at the Ritz Theatre. Planning on leaving Monday. Call me on Tuesday afternoon and I’ll tell you all about Chicago. With envelope stamped May 20, 1961, Chicago, Illinois. Postcard – 50th on the Lake Motel, from Myra. Folder 4 Items 7 Correspondence July 15 – 18, 1962 July 15, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Can’t get back to civilization until Saturday. Will try and sneak out and call you one night. It’s hot and dusty here. Forgive my sloppy writing because I’m writing by moonlight. Our tents are already set up and have not eaten as yet. Don’t forget me since I didn’t call. Miss you. Don’t forget that I love you. With envelope stamped July 17, 1962. July 16, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Had a rough day. I was on KP duty. Took trash to the dump and went to the nearest service station and called you. I felt better after I walked to you. Got to take a shower tonight. The water comes from a creek. I got to hit the sack, since I’m teaching a class tomorrow. Don’t forget me and write me everyday. With envelope (stamped date is not legible). July 17, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Can’t use any light tonight. Have been firing since 7:00 this morning. I’ve got to get my gas mask and start wearing it. It is warm in the daytime and cool at night. Hope to get a letter from you at mail call. Have to go back to work. I’ll write longer tomorrow. With envelope stamped July 19, 1962. Gerald Dowdy and Barbara Nance July 18, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Have to fire again tonight. Didn’t start firing until about 10:00 and stopped about 11:45. Tonight we fire 2 missions. Just finished cleaning my weapon and watched paratroopers jump. Should have brought a pair of long johns to sleep in. Disappointed I did not receive a letter from you. Please write me, it means a lot. Please write me everyday. (No envelope.) Gerald Dowdy and Barbara Nance, South Side High School Prom, 1962 Folder 5 Items 9 Correspondence July 20 – 25, 1962 July 17, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Sorry I haven’t written, but I’ve been busy. Received three letters yesterday and one today. Glad to get your letters and enjoyed talking to you Saturday night. A buddy and I agreed to stay out here, so we would not have to take down the big tent. Tomorrow is our last day in the field. Have 101 rounds to fire. It’s been raining two hours, not hard but steady. Still haven’t found my money. It seems like I just can’t get ahead, but as long as I have you, I’m satisfied. It won’t be too long before I’ll be home. One of the officers got struck on the boot by a snake, but it didn’t hurt him. Some of the mosquitoes out here are big as half-dollars. I’ll close and go to bed to try and get some sleep. Please don’t forget me. (No envelope.) July 19, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) When you receive this letter, I’ll be on my way home if you receive this letter on Saturday. Be home Saturday about 5:00 and have to leave about 6:00 on Sunday afternoon. I was on guard duty after I mailed your letter. When I wasn’t on guard duty, I was catching up on my sleep. Got out of firing, because I was on duty. Hope to find a good job, so that we can get married as soon as possible. I’ll close by saying, “I love you.” With envelope stamped July 20, 1962. July 23, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Received your letter. I’m in Dover, Tennessee. Phillip, a Sergeant, and I came to town for ice and stopped to eat and write at a café. People are staring because we are in our fatigues. Worked my rear end off. I dug two holes and the ground was like concrete. Storm warnings are out for this afternoon. Tell your step-grandmother and the rest of our family “Hello.” Call Mama and Daddy and let them know I’m alright. Don’t worry about me, I’ll be alright. I’ll call you one night this week. With envelope stamped July 24, 1964. July 24, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Just came back from the mail clerk with your letter. Had to stand guard over a road, we’re firing over and stop all vehicles. Stopped a jeep and saw a boy I hadn’t seen since basic training. Some crazy nut in a tank almost ran over me. Got KP tomorrow, but don’t mind. The time will pass quicker. Just started raining. Can usually sleep if it’s raining. Will get married as soon as I can find a good job. We’re having some entertainment tonight. The movie, Rebel Without A Cause, is being shown tonight. See you on Sunday. With envelope stamped July 25, 1962. July 25, 1962 To: Miss Barbara Nance, 609 E. Dempster, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Campbell, Kentucky (30th Armd. Div. TNG) I’m on KP. Got everything ready for supper. I got your letter from the mail clerk. Don’t ever say that you’re afraid that I don’t love you, because I do. Love you more than anybody. Don’t believe that Sandra and Harold will ever get married. Believe that Sandra is using him. Didn’t have our movie last night, because it rained. Convoy is leaving at eight o’clock on Sunday morning. Be home on Sunday morning. I’ll come straight to your house and get you. Have to go back to the Army at 3:30 and help unload trucks when the convoy arrives. Call Mama and Daddy tell them news, so they won’t worry. Don’t forget to dream about me. I’ll see you Sunday. With envelope stamped July 26, 1962. Folder 6 Items 3 Correspondence July 1963 No letter, only envelope stamped July 8, 1963? July 9, 1963 To: Mrs. Gerald M. Dowdy, 2161 Monroe, Apt. #4, Memphis, Tennesssee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Stewart, Georgia (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Received your letter today. I went out again early this morning and came back in this afternoon late. Rained three different times on the way back. Fired 61 rounds at the forward position. Went tactical at 5:00 pm today and will be tactical until tomorrow at 5:00 am. I writing to you by flashlight. Please try not to worry and be careful. I’ll write tomorrow night. With envelope stamped July 10, 1963. July 10, 1963 To: Mrs. Gerald M. Dowdy, 2161 Monroe, Apt. #4, Memphis, Tennessee From: Spec. 4 Gerald M. Dowdy, Fort Stewart, Georgia (30th Armd. Div. TNG) Didn’t get a letter from you today. I miss you more than ever. Wish you were here. I love you so much. Not much news. Had a short round fall in close to us today, but it was further away than it sounded. Not anything to write. I’ll write Friday night, because we have a night move lasting until midnight tomorrow. May call Sunday afternoon. With envelope stamped July 11, 1963. Folder 7 Items 8 Miscellaneous Items Whitehaven High School. Baccalaureate Service. May 29, 1960. Program. Whitehaven High School, 67th Commencement, May 30, 1960. Program. (Gerald McLain Dowdy) n. s., n. d. “Barbara Ann Nance To Be Wed May 10.” Wedding announcement. (2 copies) Short description about a childhood memory when living on James Street in the summer of 1952. (Barbara Nance) Obituary for Mrs. Barabara Ann Nance Dowdy. Commercial Appeal, November 10, 2010. Newsbank. Obituary for Mrs. Barbara Ann Nance Dowdy. (website) Commercial Appeal, April 10, 2011. “Nothing Left Unsaid During Mother’s Brave Struggle.” (By G. Wayne Dowdy) Newsbank. Commercial Appeal, April 10, 2011. “Nothing Left Unsaid During Mother’s Brave Struggle.” (By G. Wayne Dowdy) (website) Private Gerald M. Dowdy Folder 8 Items 12 Photographs 1 photograph – Gerald M. Dowdy in graduation gown, May 1960. 1 photograph – Gerald M. Dowdy, basic training, South Carolina, August 1960. 1 photograph – Gerald M. Dowdy, basic training photo, 1960 1 photograph – Gerald M. Dowdy, 115th Field Artillery Regiment 1 photograph – Barbara Ann Nance, Senior Portrait, 1962 1 photograph – Gerald Dowdy and Barbara Nance, South Side High School Prom, 1962 1 photograph – Barbara Nance wedding shower, 1963 1 photograph – Gerald and Barbara Dowdy, Oakville Memorial Baptist Church, May 1963 1 photograph – Gerald and Barbara Dowdy, Oakville Memorial Baptist Church, May 1963 2 photographs – Gerald and Barbara Dowdy, Oakville Memorial Baptist Church, May 1963 1 photograph – Gerald and Barbara Dowdy, Oakville Memorial Baptist Church, May 1963 1 photograph – Gerald Dowdy and Barbara Nance, March 1963 Gerald M. and Barbara N. Dowdy

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beebe Woodside Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Beebe Woodside, a retired employee of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center, was a member of the Royal Court during the 1963 Memphis Cotton Carnival. The Cotton Carnival, which had been held annually since 1931, was “The Nation’s Party in the Land of Cotton” and strove to promote and further the use of cotton, demonstrate its value and worth, encourage citizens to use more cotton products, and advertise and publicize Memphis, Shelby County, the surrounding areas, and Tennessee. It hosted parades, balls, concerts, home and garden tours, and pageants. Among the Royal Court were a King and Queen, special princesses (Cotton, Carnival, Court, and Royal Club) and escorts, club princesses and escorts, Ladies in Waiting, and Ladies of the Realm. In 1963, Beebe Woodside was crowned the Cotton Princess. -- Ms. Woodside graduated from Miss Hutchison’s School in 1960. She was a member of Tau Delta Sigma Sorority where she served as Vice President her senior year. Her yearbooks and Cotton Carnival memorabilia give an inside look into the life of Ms. Woodside during the late 1950s and early 1960s as she completed her high school education and actively participated in the famous Memphis Cotton Carnival.

BEEBE WOODSIDE COLLECTION Processed By: Regan Adolph 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 Beebe Woodside Collection Biographical Note Mary Beebe Woodside, a retired employee of the Memphis Public Library & Information Center, was a member of the Royal Court during the 1963 Memphis Cotton Carnival. The Cotton Carnival, which had been held annually since 1931, was “The Nation’s Party in the Land of Cotton” and strove to promote and further the use of cotton, demonstrate its value and worth, encourage citizens to use more cotton products, and advertise and publicize Memphis, Shelby County, the surrounding areas, and Tennessee. It hosted parades, balls, concerts, home and garden tours, and pageants. Among the Royal Court were a King and Queen, special princesses (Cotton, Carnival, Court, and Royal Club) and escorts, club princesses and escorts, Ladies in Waiting, and Ladies of the Realm. In 1963, Beebe Woodside was crowned the Cotton Princess. Ms. Woodside graduated from Miss Hutchison’s School in 1960. She was a member of Tau Delta Sigma Sorority where she served as Vice President her senior year. Her yearbooks and Cotton Carnival memorabilia give an inside look into the life of Ms. Woodside during the late 1950s and early 1960s as she completed her high school education and actively participated in the famous Memphis Cotton Carnival. Beebe Woodside Collection Scope and Content Comprised of 0.3 linear feet, the Beebe Woodside Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center in February of 2012 by Beebe Woodside. The majority of the material in this collection is from the late 1950s and early 1960s. The original order of the collection has been maintained. Those interested in mid-twentieth century girls’ schools in Memphis and the Memphis Cotton Carnival should consult the A. Arthur Halle Collection and the Perre Magness Collection. This collection consists of one box which contains the following 19 items:  4 yearbooks (“The Lantern”) of Miss Hutchison’s School, dated 1953, 1955, 1956, and 1957  3 Tau Delta Sigma Sorority Composite Photographs, dated 1957-58, 1958-59, 1959-60  2 copies of the 1963 Cotton Carnival Magazine and Official Program  2 copies of the 1963 Cotton Carnival Brochure  2 copies of the 1963 Cotton Carnival Royal Barge Ceremony Itinerary  2 copies of the 1963 Cotton Carnival Crown and Sceptre Coronation Program  1963 Cotton Carnival Royal Court List  Cotton Carnival Informational Brochure, not dated  1963 Royal Order of the Last Nighters Proclamation  1963 Sphinx Secret Society Invitation Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee Department of Transportation Interstate Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee Department of Transportation transferred five boxes of material containing information about property acquired for the building of Interstates I-40, I-240 and I-255 in Shelby County to the Memphis and Shelby County Room on May 1, 2001. The processed collection consists of thirty-two boxes divided into two series which contain the property addresses, owners, property descriptions, photos, plat maps, and comparable sales information on parcels and tracts of land to be purchased by the government. -- The twenty-three boxes in Series I contain folders on each property being acquired. They are divided by Federal Project Number (indicating which interstate), and there is a folder for each number parcel or tract of land. Each folder contains the address, the parcel number, the owner of the property, a description of the house, and photographs of the property. Sketches and floor plans, plat maps and comparable sales are often included, as well as descriptions of the neighborhood. The assessed property valuation is also recorded. -- Folders in the nine boxes in Series II contain market data and comparable sales information used to determine the value of properties to be taken by the Department of Highways, Divisions of Rights-of-Way. Plat maps indicating location of properties and photographs are included in the appraiser’s folders. -- The TDOT Interstate Collection will be used by researchers seeking information on the neighborhoods and homes affected by the routes of the interstates of Shelby County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Authors Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memphis Authors Collection is a compilation of writings and other documents written by, written about, or donated to the Memphis Public Library by Memphians. The writings range in date from the 1860s to the 1990s. The collection has a variety of materials including typescripts, xeroxed copies of books and articles, and handwritten letters. These items were donated to the Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center; however the dates of donations are unknown. In some instances, a brief biography of the author or notes about the subject matter or donor are included in italics. The Memphis Authors Collection also contains a portion of the Cossitt Writers Project. This was an attempt made by the Cossitt Library to correspond with and document published writers from Memphis.
