Merrill, Dr. Ayers Phillips Green, Gretchen Meriwether, Lee Guyton, Joseph Warren Millen, James Knox Gwynn, Bonnie Zae Hargett Millwood, Jesse Edward Hall, Marjorie Mitchell, Dodson Hardeman, Nicholas Brodie Molloy, Paul Hay, George D. Moriarty, Edward Joyce Howell, Leslie Moriarty, Marie Hughes, John Gilliam Murdock, Clyde Howry Hughes, Jr., Nathaniel Cheairs Murphy, Florence L. Hutchins, Fred L. Murphy, Frances R. Ijams, Elvin H. Murphy, Reverend S. A. Irvin, Thomas D. Murrah, Bishop William Belton Jameson, Virginia Farrar Myers, Minnie Walter Jennings, Rienzi Wilson Myrick, Reverend Charles E. Johnson, Burt Newcomer, Lee Nathaniel Johnson, Leslie Leroy Newman, Bill N. Johnston, Avin Harry Newman, Corinne R. Greenley Joslyn, Mattie Wood Nichols Newman, John Wesley Krickel, Dr. Edward l Niven, Lola Alexander Lear, General Ben Noland, Julia Tigner Le Coq, Jean Pierre Noll, Arthur Howard Likes, David Henry Norfleet, Marvin Brooks Long, Beatrice Powell O’Donnell, George Marion Loskove, Morris David Okey, Charles William Luce, Clare Boothe Oliver, Virginia Tucker Luerhrmann, Adele via Nash Buckingham Omberg, James Adolphus Lynk, Dr. Miles V. Osborne, Juanita Tyree Marshall, Zona Bays O’Sullivan, Patrick Martineau, Pierre D. Otey, James Hervey Maum, Emmett Hunter Overall, George Whitfield Maury, William Poston Overholser, James Arthur BOX ONE 5 Folder 1 – Anderson, Elizabeth Willis Anderson, Elizabeth Willis – Memoir (1822 – 1862) Elizabeth Willis Gloster Anderson, daughter of Dr. Thomas B. Gloster, was an Episcopalian of Warrenton, NC; LaGrange, TN; and Texas. She often wrote religious advice for her children and memoranda concerning family births, deaths, moves, etc. Folder 2 – Berry, Louis Perkins Berry, Louis Perkins –“The Revolution of 1888” Submitted by Earl P. Davis Louis Perkins Berry, born in 1879 in Crittenden County, Arkansas, wrote “The Revolution of 1888,” which dealt with the removal of the “final shackles of Carpet Bag Rule in Crittenden County.” Folder 3 – Bridges, Elinor B. Part 1 of 3 Bridges, Elinor B. – Stories and Articles Memphian Elinor B. Bridges was a longtime supporter of women’s rights. She was a member of the American Pen Women and Business & Professional Women. She was also the founder, treasurer and newsletter editor of the Women’s Resource Center. She died in 2002 at the age of 93. Folder 4 – Bridges, Elinor B. Part 2 of 3 Bridges, Elinor B. – Stories and Articles Folder 5 – Bridges, Elinor B. Part 3 of 3 Bridges, Elinor B. – Stories and Articles Folder 6 – Carman, James Carman, James – Memphis in May – Aus Feind Ein Freund 6 James R. Carman, 1925-2007, was a Memphian who served in the Marine Corps, Army, and Air Force. He went on to retire as a Master Sergeant in the Air Force. In addition to writing about his military experience, he often wrote poetry and short stories. Folder 7 – Conaway, James Conaway, James – Memphis Afternoons – Typescript 1993 James Conaway wrote Memphis Afternoons, a memoir about growing up in Memphis during the 1950s, after realizing his father was suffering from Alzheimer’s disease. In it, he incorporated portraits of family members, including his grandfather J. P. Alley, a Pulitzer winning cartoonist. Folder 8 – Conway, Clara - Silver Lined Days Conway, Clara – Silver Lined Days: A Travel Memoir Clara Conway was an early Memphis educator. She began her career as a public-school teacher with a desire to establish an education system for girls. She later founded the Clara Conway Institute in Memphis. Folder 9 – Conway, Ruby Conway, Ruby – Tales of Tennessee – Humberstone Club at Port Clyde, Canada Postcard – Humberstone Club, Port Clyde, Canada Miscellaneous Documents Relating to the Humberstone Club Ruby Conway, 1920 – 2005, wrote a series of columns for the Port Colborne News (Port Colborne, Ontario, Canada.) One of her chosen topics was the Humberstone Club, a summer resort in Ontario, Canada, visited by wealthy Southerners, including many Memphians, in the late 19th, early 20th centuries. Folder 10 – Cupp Family Letters Cupp Family Letters, 1921 This folder contains letters from the Cupp family; Father - Henry Clay Cupp (1871-1967,) Mother - Frances Owen Hogg Cupp (1876-1966,) and Children – Annabell (1903-Unknown) and Harvey Allen (1905-1966.) Annabell married Earl Leonard Keister and had two children. Harvey Allen married Katherine Fransioli and had two children. 7 Folder 11 – Ellis, Barbara G. Ellis, Barbara – Setting the Record Straight on the Civil War Run of the Memphis Daily Appeal Barbara G. Ellis is a long-time journalist and former technical-journalism professor. Her book, The Moving Appeal, was nominated for the 2004 Pulitzer Prize in History. Folder 12 – Evans, G. G. Evans, G. G. – Literature of Shelby County Pt. II Notes on Memphis Authors Folder 13 – Fort, De Witt Clinton – Memoirs Fort, De Witt Clinton – Memoirs De Witt Clinton Fort, 1830 – 1868, was a member of the Texas House of Representatives and a soldier in the Confederate Army during the Civil War. Despite a birth defect making him unsuitable for military service, he was an able horseman and became one of the most effective Confederate spies. Folder 14 – Gaines, Edmund Pendleton Gaines, Edmund Pendleton – Letters General Edmund Pendleton Gaines, 1777 – 1849, was an officer in the U.S. Army who worked to preserve peace among the competing factions in the American Southeast during the early 1800s. Folder 15 – Gilbert, Amos – Francis Wright Memoir Gilbert, Amos – Memoir of Fanny Wright, the Pioneer Woman in the Cause of Women's Rights Amos Gilbert, a friend of social reformer Francis Wright, wrote the first biography of Wright in 1855. Folder 16 – Hall, Jane (Jannie) Elizabeth Hall, Jane (Jannie) Elizabeth – Diary (1863 – 1864) 8 Jane (Jannie) Elizabeth Hall, born in 1846, was the daughter of Hinton Hall and Richard Jane Snead. 9 BOX TWO Folder 1 – Freeman, Mike Part 1 of 5 Freeman, Mike – Clarence Saunders’ The Piggly Wiggly Man, 1988 Memphian Mike Freeman has co-written two books about Elvis Presley, a book based upon Patsy Cline’s letters, and numerous articles about Memphis’s history. His biography of Clarence Saunders was his first project and his MA Thesis. Folder 2 – Freeman, Mike Part 2 of 5 Freeman, Mike – Clarence Saunders’ The Piggly Wiggly Man, 1988 Folder 3 – Freeman, Mike Part 3 of 5 Freeman, Mike – Clarence Saunders’ The Piggly Wiggly Man, 1988 Folder 4 – Freeman, Mike Part 4 of 5 Freeman, Mike – Clarence Saunders’ The Piggly Wiggly Man, 1988 Folder 5 – Freeman, Mike Part 5 of 5 Freeman, Mike – Clarence Saunders’ The Piggly Wiggly Man, 1988 Folder 6 – Harvey, Evangeline Harvey, Evangeline – End Well Stories from the Ozarks Evangeline Harvey is also the author of A Sampler Flower Garden of the Ozark Hills: And Cocoons for Two or More; End Well Stories. Folder 7 – Hettinger, Christian Hettinger, Christian – Family Deeds (1861 – 1862) 10 Folder 8 – Kennedy, Walker – Manuscript Kennedy, Walker – The Conquest of the United States in 1900 Walker Kennedy was the author of three books; In the Dwellings of Silence, a Romance of Russia, The Passion Flower of Magdala, and Javan Ben Seir, a Story of Olden Israel. The Conquest of the United States in 1900 is his unpublished manuscript. Folder 9 – Kennedy, Walker – Typescript Kennedy, Walker – The Conquest of the United States in 1900 – Typescript Folder 10 – Knowlton, P. Clarke Knowlton, Clarke – Stories Published in Scribner’s Magazine, 1925, 1926 Memphis Short Story Writer, Philetus C. Knowlton Jr. (1892-1930,) died in Singapore while on a world cruise. This folder contains a collection of his stories published in Scribner’s Magazine. Folder 11 – Lee, George W. - Beale Street Sundown Lee, George W. – Beale Street Sundown (Xeroxed Copy of Book) George W. Lee, 1894 – 1976, known locally as "Lieutenant Lee," was a leading Republican and African American businessman in Memphis during the 1920s and 1930s. He served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Army in France during World War I, and received his bachelor's degree from Alcorn Agricultural and Mechanical College, now Alcorn State University. He was one of the authorities on Memphis’s African American culture. He was the author of Beale Street: Where the Blues Began, River George, and Beale Street Sundown. Folder 12 – Lee, George W. - Beale Street Romance Part 1 of 4 Lee, George W. – Beale Street Romance Folder 13 – Lee, George W. - Beale Street Romance Part 2 of 4 Lee, George W. – Beale Street Romance Folder 14 – Lee, George W. - Beale Street Romance Part 3 of 4 11 Lee, George W. – Beale Street Romance Folder 15 – Lee, George W. - Beale Street Romance Part 4 of 4 Lee, George W. – Beale Street Romance Folder 16 – Martin, Anna Nye – Family Letters Martin, Anna Nye (1881-1958) – Family Letters Folder 17 – Matlock, William H. Matlock, Dr. John W. L. – The Matlock Side of the Story by William H. Matlock: An Account of the Matlock and Forrest Incident at Hernando, Mississippi, March 10, 1845 Donated September 4, 2000 via Walter Phillips and Perre Magness Folder 18 – Meriwether, Elizabeth A. Meriwether, Elizabeth A. – Recollections of Ninety – Two Years (1824 – 1916) –Typescript Includes the Note “Meriwether manuscript received with the Roane Waring Collection.” BOX THREE Folder 1 – Lewis, Selma Part 1 of 6 Lewis, Selma – A Biblical People in the Bible Belt – Typescript Memphian Selma Lewis was known not only for her years of social work, but also for her preservation of Memphis’s history. She was the author of The Angel of Beale Street: A Biography of Julia Ann Hooks, A Biblical People in the Bible Belt: The Jewish Community of Memphis, Tennessee, 1840s-1960s and a dissertation Social Religion and the Sanitation Strike. 12 She became the first female president of Jewish Family Services in 1962 and served on the board of numerous organizations. Folder 2 – Lewis, Selma Part 2 of 6 Lewis, Selma – A Biblical People in the Bible Belt – Typescript Folder 3 – Lewis, Selma Part 3 of 6 Lewis, Selma – A Biblical People in the Bible Belt – Typescript Folder 4 – Lewis, Selma Part 4 of 6 Lewis, Selma – A Biblical People in the Bible Belt – Typescript Folder 5 – Lewis, Selma Part 5 of 6 Lewis, Selma – A Biblical People in the Bible Belt – Typescript Folder 6 – Lewis, Selma Part 6 of 6 Lewis, Selma – A Biblical People in the Bible Belt – Typescript Folder 7 – Miller, James A. Miller, James A. – West Tennessee Militia – 1814 (Genealogy) Folder contains information about the men in the West Tennessee Militia who pled guilty to the charge of mutiny and desertion in 1814. Folder 8 – Naill, Millard – Biography / Genealogy Naill, Millard – Biography / Genealogy Folder 9 – O’Conner, Rebecca 13 O’ Conner, Rebecca – Right in the Middle of the Side Walk Received in 1994. Rebecca O’Conner, 1910 – 2006, was the author of three books: May the Sod Rest Lightly; Jenny Mitchel: Young Irelander; and Right in the Middle of the Sidewalk, a memoir about her struggles during the Depression and her desegregation activities in Tennessee during the Civil Rights Movement. Folder 10 – Pope, Col. John Pope, Col. John – Personal Writings “Colonel John Pope, of Shelby County, won first prize, at World’s Fair in London, for finest staple cotton exhibited. As will be noted, these old magazines once belonged to Colonel Pope. – RHW” Colonel John Pope, 1794-1865, studied law at Yale University and served in the Alabama legislature. By the 1850s, he owned over 900 acres in farmland in the Memphis area. He worked at the ‘science of farming,’ using innovative and practical methods to increase the quality and quantity of his crops. Folder 11 – Rayner, Juan Rayner, Juan - Account of Forrest’s Raid Submitted by Earl P. Davis, copied from a copy of Juan Rayner’s letter, given to Earl P. Davis by Judge W. W. Hughes in the late 1940s. Folder 12 – Richmond, Eleanor Richmond, Eleanor – “Eleanor Wilson Visits Memphis” (President Wilson’s Daughter) Folder 13 – Rust, John D. Rust, John D. – “The Origin and Development of the Cotton Picker” 14 John Daniel Rust, 1892 – 1954, invented the first practical spindle cotton picker in the late 1920s. With his brother Mack, Rust founded the Rust Cotton Picker Company in Memphis, the successor to the Southern Harvester Company. Folder 14 – Smith, D. Beecher II Smith, D. Beecher II – Short Stories Memphian D. Beecher Smith II was a lawyer with an interest in writing. He is known for having been Elvis Presley’s attorney for the last year of Presley’s life. Folder 15 – Sowell, A. J. Part 1 of 3 Sowell, A. J. A Short History of Texas Prior to 1836 Andrew Jackson Sowell, 1848-1921, was a native Texan who joined the Texas Rangers, scouting and fighting in the campaign against the Wichita Indians in 1870 and 1871. After his service, Sowell became an author, writing books about Texas history and the Rangers, including Rangers and Pioneers of Texas (1884), Early Settlers and Indian Fighters of Southwest Texas (1890), The Life of Big Foot Wallace (1899), and History of Fort Bend County (1904). Folder 16 – Sowell, A. J. Part 2 of 3 Sowell, A. J. A Short History of Texas Prior to 1836 Folder 17 – Sowell, A. J. Part 3 of 3 Sowell, A. J. A Short History of Texas Prior to 1836 Folder 18 – Steele, A. B. Steele, A. B. - “1930s: Gone But Not Forgotten” Folder 19 – Wallace, Fanny Woolfolk Wallace, Fanny Woolfolk – Trip to Dixie – Diary, 1864 Gift of Diana Wallace Crump, July, 1995. 15 Fanny Woolfolk Wallace, born in 1835, kept a diary from March – August 1864 during her round-trip journey from her home in Kentucky to Tuskegee, Alabama to visit her husband, a Confederate officer. Her diary describes the destruction observed in the South during the war. Folder 20 – Watson, Annah Robinson Watson, Annah Robinson – Plays and Poems Memphian Annah Robinson Watson was the founding member of the Nineteenth Century Club, a writer, and a collector of folklore. Folder 21 – Wuthrich, Ulrich Wuthrich, Ulrich – 2 Letters Written to Family in Switzerland from Austin, Texas 1841, 1844 Ulrich Wuthrich was a Swiss immigrant who arrived in New York in 1833. He traveled to Texas and after six months, journeyed to Mexico. Folder 22 – Browning, Gordon Part 1 of 2 Browning, Gordon – Early Years Gordon Browning was a former Governor of Tennessee who also served six terms in the U. S. House of Representatives. Folder 23 – Browning, Gordon Part 2 of 2 Browning, Gordon – Early Years 16 BOX FOUR Folder 1 – Cossitt Writers Project – G Documents – David D. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: American Snuff Company Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Documents and correspondence from the American Snuff Company, 1907 to 1911. The company was formally founded in 1900 and moved its headquarters to Memphis in 1912.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John J. Shea, Jr., MD Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. John J. Shea, born September 4, 1924, is a nationally and internationally known doctor, professor, and surgeon practicing in Memphis, Tennessee. A native Memphian, Dr. Shea attended Saint Mary’s School, Immaculate Conception, and Christian Brothers High School before going on to the Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, New Hampshire. He received a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Notre Dame, followed by a Medical degree from Harvard Medical School. At school, he enlisted in the United States Naval Reserve, achieving the rank of Lieutenant Commander, Medical Corp, in 1962. -- Throughout his career, Dr. Shea became a pioneer in the treatment of hearing loss, dizziness, and balance. In May 1956, Dr. Shea performed the first successful reconstructive stapedectomy operation, essentially solving the problem of otosclerosis, which is the most common cause of conductive hearing loss. This surgery is now commonly performed all over the world. -- In addition to developing numerous procedures, surgical instruments, and prosthesis, Dr. Shea has conducted extensive research furthering the knowledge and treatment of ear disease. He has also served as a Clinical Professor in the Ear, Nose and Throat Departments of the University of Tennessee, the University of Mississippi, the University of North Carolina, and Tulane University. -- Dr. Shea now continues his work at the Shea Ear Clinic and its charitable arm, The Shea Clinic Foundation.

John J. Shea, Jr., MD Collection Processed by Laura Cunningham 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Ave Memphis, TN 38111 1 Table of Contents Biographical Sketch ……………………..……………...……………………………………3 Scope and Content ……………………………………………………………………………4 Container List Box 1 (64 Folders)……………………………………………………………………………..5 Box 2 (48 Folders)…………………………………………………………………………....14 Box 3 (83 Folders)………………………………………..…………………………………..20 Box 4 (64 Folders)…………………………………………..………………………………..34 2 John J. Shea, Jr., MD Collection Dr. John J. Shea, born September 4, 1924, is a nationally and internationally known doctor, professor, and surgeon practicing in Memphis, Tennessee. A native Memphian, Dr. Shea attended Saint Mary’s School, Immaculate Conception, and Christian Brothers High School before going on to the Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter New Hampshire. He received a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Notre Dame, followed by a Medical degree from Harvard Medical School. At school, he enlisted in the United States Naval Reserve, achieving the rank of Lieutenant Commander, Medical Corp, in 1962. Throughout his career, Dr. Shea became a pioneer in the treatment of hearing loss, dizziness, and balance. In May 1956, Dr. Shea performed the first successful reconstructive stapedectomy operation, essentially solving the problem of otosclerosis, which is the most common cause of conductive hearing loss. This surgery is now commonly performed all over the world. In addition to developing numerous procedures, surgical instruments, and prosthesis, Dr. Shea has conducted extensive research furthering the knowledge and treatment of ear disease. He has also served as a Clinical Professor in the Ear, Nose and Throat Departments of the University of Tennessee, the University of Mississippi, the University of North Carolina, and Tulane University. Dr. Shea now continues his work at the Shea Ear Clinic and its charitable arm, The Shea Clinic Foundation. 3 4 Scope and Content The John J. Shea, Jr., MD Collection consists of four boxes spanning two linear feet. Dr. John J. Shea, Jr. donated the items in the collection to the Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library and Information Center in 2012. The collection contains scholarly journal articles written by Dr. John J. Shea, Jr. dating from the 1940s to the present. The collection also includes copies of Curriculum Vitae for both Dr. John J. Shea, Jr. and his son, Dr. Paul Flanagan Shea. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. While the Memphis Public Library & Information Center may house an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use. Any image from the library’s collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Park Commission Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1900, the City of Memphis established the Memphis Park Commission in an effort to oversee the City’s parks and to expand its parkland and resources. The Park Commission felt a large, successful park system would promote Memphis’s health and appearance. Over the next century, the Memphis Park Commission grew to include 166 parks, Golf courses, Museums, Fairgrounds, a Zoo, and Community Centers, in addition to providing indoor and outdoor recreation to the public. -- The Memphis Park Commission Collection consists of 15 boxes spanning 13 linear feet. The Collection contains correspondence, brochures, and other materials from the turn of the century to the 1990s. However, most materials date from the early-1970s into the mid-1980s. -- Highlights from the collection include information regarding the Orpheum renovation; the Pink Palace Museum renovation, the development of Mud Island River Park, Cotton Carnival Children’s Parades, and Memphis Park Commission Scrapbooks.

Memphis Park Commission Collection Processed by Laura Cunningham 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Ave 1 Memphis, TN 38111 Table of Contents Scope and Content ……………………………………………………..…………3 Container List Box 1 (31 Folders) ………………………………………………………………...4 Box 2 (14 Folders)…………………………………………………..……………12 Box 3 (13 Folders) ………………………………………………….……………23 Box 4 (17 Folders) …………………………….…………………………………29 Box 5 (21 Folders) ……………………………….………………………………41 Box 6 (21 Folders)……………………………………………………..…………58 Box 7 (5 Folders)…………………………………………………………………67 Box 8 (1 Album)………………………….………………………………………69 Box 9 (1 Album)………………….………………………………………………69 Box 10 (1 2 Album)…………………………………………………...……………69 Box 11 (1 Album)…………………………………………...……………………70 Box 12 (1 Album)……………………………………………………...…………70 Box 13 (1 Album)…………………………………………………...……………70 Box 14 (2 Albums)……………………………………………………..…………70 Box 15 (1 Album, 7 Folders)………………………………………..……...……71 3 Memphis Park Commission Scope and Content In 1900, the City of Memphis established the Memphis Park Commission in an effort to oversee the City’s parks and to expand its parkland and resources. The Park Commission felt a large, successful park system would promote Memphis’s health and appearance. Over the next century, the Memphis Park Commission grew to include 166 parks, Golf courses, Museums, Fairgrounds, a Zoo, and Community Centers, in addition to providing indoor and outdoor recreation to the public. The Memphis Park Commission Collection consists of 15 boxes spanning 13 linear feet. The Collection contains correspondence, brochures, and other materials from the turn of the century to the 1990s. However, most materials date from the early­1970s into the mid­1980s. Highlights from the collection include information regarding the Orpheum renovation; the Pink Palace Museum renovation, the development of Mud Island River Park, Cotton Carnival Children’s Parades, and Memphis Park Commission Scrapbooks. The Collection also contains extensive photographs of the Park Commission’s recreational facilities and activities during the 1970s. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. While the Memphis Public Library & Information Center may house an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use. Any image from the library’s collection published in any form must cite as the source: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Sesquicentennial Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1969, Memphians proudly hosted a year-long celebration in honor of the 150th anniversary of the 1819 founding of Memphis. The Sesquicentennial theme carried over into dozens of events and activities, generating national attention to the city. -- The Memphis Sesquicentennial Collection consists of two boxes: Box One is a 50 item photograph album showcasing many of the City's sesquicentennial events. Original captions or notes from the photographs are italicized in this finding aid. Box Two contains items collected by the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Highlights from the collection include Birthday Candles sent from cities throughout the United States; a Memphis Heritage Rose plant, created specifically for the Sesquicentennial; Commemorative coins, clocks, and decanters; a Log Cabin in Court Square; the Memphis Sesquicentennial Hiking Trail; and the Presentation of the W. C. Handy Stamp.

Memphis Sesquicentennial Collection Processed by Laura Cunningham 2013 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Ave Memphis, TN 38111 1 Table of Contents Historical Sketch / Scope and Content …………………………………………………….....……3 Container List Box 1 (Photo Album)………………….………………………………………………………… …………..4 Box 2……………………………………………………………………………………. ………………………..10 2 Memphis Sesquicentennial Collection Scope and Content In 1969, Memphians proudly hosted a year-long celebration in honor of the 150th anniversary of the 1819 founding of Memphis. The Sesquicentennial theme carried over into dozens of events and activities, generating national attention to the city. The Memphis Sesquicentennial Collection consists of two boxes (including one photo album) spanning .5 linear feet. Box One is a 50 item photograph album showcasing many of the City’s sesquicentennial events. Original captions or notes from the photographs are italicized in this finding aid. Box Two contains items collected by the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Highlights from the collection include Birthday Candles sent from cities throughout the United States; a Memphis Heritage Rose plant, created specifically for the Sesquicentennial; Commemorative coins, clocks, and decanters; a Log Cabin in Court Square; the Memphis Sesquicentennial Hiking Trail; and the Presentation of the W. C. Handy Stamp. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. While the Memphis Public Library & Information Center may house an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Orpheum Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1890, the Grand Opera House opened at the corner of Main and Beale Streets in Memphis, Tennessee. In 1907, the theater became part of the Orpheum Vaudeville circuit and was renamed the Orpheum Theatre. In 1923, a fired destroyed the building, which was rebuilt. A new, larger theater opened in 1928. The Malco theater chain purchased the building in 1940, running first run movies until 1976. The following year, the Memphis Development Foundation purchased the Orpheum and began bringing Broadway productions and concerts back to the theater. The theater underwent another renovation in the early 1980s, restoring it to its 1928 grandeur. At present, the Orpheum continues to bring in performances and averages ten to twelve Broadway shows a year. -- The Orpheum Collection consists of two boxes spanning 1 linear foot. The collection contains materials from the Memphis and Shelby County Room pertaining to the Orpheum Theatre. Items in the collection include the souvenir opening programs from 1928 and 1984; Orpheum publications: Backstage, After Five, Broadway at the Orpheum, Marquee, and the Orpheum Circuit News; and miscellaneous memorabilia.

A new, larger theater opened in 1928. The Malco theater chain purchased the building in 1940, running first run movies until 1976. The following year, the Memphis Development Foundation purchased the Orpheum and began bringing Broadway productions and concerts back to the theater. The theater underwent another renovation in the early 1980s, restoring it to its 1928 grandeur. At present, the Orpheum continues to bring in performances and averages ten to twelve Broadway shows a year. The Orpheum Collection consists of two boxes spanning 1 linear foot. The collection contains materials from the Memphis and Shelby County Room pertaining to the Orpheum Theatre. Items in the collection include the souvenir opening programs from 1928 and 1984; Orpheum publications: Backstage, After Five, Broadway at the Orpheum, Marquee, and the Orpheum Circuit News; and miscellaneous memorabilia. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Park Commission Minute Books
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Memphis Park Commission met for the first time in September 1900. Its final meeting took place nearly a century later in March 2000, and in April it was abolished by the Memphis City Council. The Commission customarily met once a month, although at times meetings could be held on two or more successive days. At the other extreme, several months might pass (especially in late summer) without a quorum being present. The frequency with which meetings took place over the years was, in a word, irregular.-- During its tenure the Commission was made up of at least 47 Commissioners (one serving twice), of whom at least 16 served as Chairmen. Some Chairmen may be perceived as being more forceful or involved than others. It seems likely that successive Park Commission Secretaries (also numbering at least sixteen) smoothed over the occasional behavioral quirk or contentious issue as they compiled the minutes. This is to say that, as reflected by the minutes, the Secretaries seem to have striven to be informative and impartial. -- In addition to the actual accounts of meetings, during certain periods the Secretary or staff or Chairman inserted material that was bound into, or pasted or glued to, or simply inserted between pages of, the minutes. Such material is sometimes not where it belongs chronologically; nevertheless for the most part this paperwork will be found as the Park Commission Secretary left it. Indeed, some of this material may be considered more significant than the minutes themselves, although always being related to the Commission’s concerns. It should also be observed that, especially in the 1970s and ‘80s, there are occasional errors in page numberings, as well as other problems affecting the continuity of the minutes.

204 Box 25 Book 26 1 to 7 Jan. 17, 1990 – Nov. 20, 1991 Page 212 “ Book 27 1 to 6 Jan. 22, 1992 – Dec. 17, 1993 (Total of 13 folders in Box 25 from Books 26 and 27) Page 221 Box 26 Book 28 1 to 8 Jan. 26, 1994 – Nov. 20, 1996 Page 231 “ Book 29 1 to 6 Jan. 29, 1997 – Mar. 23, 2000 (Total of 14 folders in Box 26 from Books 28 and 29) Page 240 Box 27 Cassettes Recording Various Meetings, 1988-1994, 1997 Page 242 Box 28 Photocopies of Indexes to Minute Books Page 244 Figure 1. Watermark on Memphis Park Commission Stationery, ca. 1983 Page 245 Appendix 1. Park Commissioners, Superintendents, Secretaries, Attorneys, and Other Personnel Page 245 Members of the Park Commission for the Period Covered by Each Minute Book Page 251 Names and Terms of Park Commissioners in Order of Appointment Page 252 Names and Terms of General Superintendents, Executive Directors, or Directors Page 252 Names and Terms of Park Commission Secretaries Page 253 Names and Terms of Park Commission Attorneys Page 254 Lists of Park Commission Personnel Found in the Minutes, 1919-1959 Page 256 Appendix 2. Some Primary and Secondary Sources in the Memphis and Shelby County Room for the History of the Memphis Park Commission Page 256 Some Relevant Publications by the Memphis Park Commission or City of Memphis Page 258 Early Park Maps Page 258 Contributions to the History of the Memphis Park Commission, Park System, or Individual Parks Page 260 Relevant Bartholomew Reports Page 260 Other Archive Collections of Significance 5 Notes on the Scope and Contents of the Memphis Park Commission Minute Books, and on Using This Collection The Memphis Park Commission met for the first time in September 1900. Its final meeting took place nearly a century later in March 2000, and in April it was abolished by the Memphis City Council. The Commission customarily met once a month, although at times meetings could be held on two or more successive days. At the other extreme, several months might pass (especially in late summer) without a quorum being present. The frequency with which meetings took place over the years was, in a word, irregular. During its tenure the Commission was made up of at least 47 Commissioners (one serving twice), of whom at least 16 served as Chairmen. Some Chairmen may be perceived as being more forceful or involved than others. It seems likely that successive Park Commission Secretaries (also numbering at least sixteen) smoothed over the occasional behavioral quirk or contentious issue as they compiled the minutes. This is to say that, as reflected by the minutes, the Secretaries seem to have striven to be informative and impartial. In addition to the actual accounts of meetings, during certain periods the Secretary or staff or Chairman inserted material that was bound into, or pasted or glued to, or simply inserted between pages of, the minutes. Such material is sometimes not where it belongs chronologically; nevertheless for the most part this paperwork will be found as the Park Commission Secretary left it. Indeed, some of this material may be considered more significant than the minutes themselves, although always being related to the Commission’s concerns. It should also be observed that, especially in the 1970s and ‘80s, there are occasional errors in page numberings, as well as other problems affecting the continuity of the minutes. Before they were disbound, all minute books except Book 1 consisted of heavy-duty archive-type covers with three lockable binding posts containing up to 500 of 8 ½- by 14-inch pages (that is, 250 sheets of paper) punched with three holes. In Book 1, on the other hand, the sheets of paper were folded and sewn together in true book form, yielding 400 pages (of which only 357 have been used). The book has not been taken apart, but it has been photographed. Because it is still intact, the various portions of Book 1 are described here in its Inventory as “Sections” (each spanning a decade), rather than as “Folders” containing disbound pages. A review of the various parts of this finding aid may be helpful. Table I summarizes the features of the Minute Books and lists the period of years each book covers, book sizes, the extent to which the minutes are enhanced (or burdened) by additional matter, and whether or not they are indexed. Table II is a list of photocopied indexes that are provided in Box 28 for the convenience of the researcher, making it largely unnecessary to consult the originals in their nearly two dozen separate archive boxes. Tables IIIa and IIIb summarize and date the appearances of the names of some of the Park Commission’s acknowledged facilities over the period 1906-1941, as they are listed in budgets, audits, reports, and the like. 6 The Container List of Minutes of the Memphis Park Commission is probably self-explanatory. Each of the Minute Books (including the still-fully-bound Minute Book 1, as described above) is found in its own archive box, from Minute Book 1 (Box 1) through Minute Book 22 (Box 22). However, the later minute books are of irregular length and their contents have been distributed into boxes for which the book numbers and archive box numbers no longer coincide. An Inventory as well as an Introduction and Excerpts have been prepared for each of the 29 books, as well as Inventories for a set of cassette tape recordings (see below) and for the set of photocopied indexes listed in Table II. The paragraph introducing each of the 29 Inventories includes a short note about the various types of minute-related material present in each book, material that is almost always adjunct to the minutes and included because the Secretary or others felt it should be bound in or pasted in or simply inserted between two pages. The Inventories are intended to assist in locating information about audits, budgets, lists of employees, and the like (dealing with finances or fiscal matters in general, including fees, rentals, and other uses of Park properties), as well as references in later years to Capital Improvement Projects (CIPs). There may well be overlap between items mentioned in both a book’s Inventory and its counterpart Introduction and Excerpts. Any organization is likely to evolve greatly over the course of a century. Some of the more obvious or significant changes noted during the processing of the minute books have been tracked, and are summarized in the Introductions to the 29 successive books. Among these are changes in the Commission’s membership and senior staff and the attendees at its meetings, its bidding and billing practices, references to its audits, budgets and financial situations, its accounting practices, its establishment or adoption of new parks or other venues, significant issues that it dealt with or were forced upon it, and the relations between the Commission and the City of Memphis. Note that the Commissioners comprise what is sometimes referred to in the minutes as “the Board.” The accompanying Excerpts are intended to showcase both the large concerns as well as the ephemera that the Park Commission attended to, and to provide some continuity in the stories of its more significant enterprises – the development of the Zoo or the Fairgrounds, for example, or the Clarence Saunders or Lichterman properties, or Mud Island. A number of cassette Tape Recordings were made of Park Commission meetings during the period 1988 through 1994; there are also a few such recordings from 1997 as well as eight others whose recording date has not been identified. The recordings that have been auditioned are not of very good quality, and only a few have been authenticated as having been made during the meetings they claim to record, i.e. the date written on the cassette. It remains to be seen whether future research may prove any of these attributions false. As mentioned above, Photocopies of Indexes to the minute books (those that have been indexed, or for which indexes have been preserved) have been provided for the greater convenience of researchers. The size of the Park Commission increased many-fold during its hundred-year existence. The minutes show that in Feb. 4, 1919, 13 named staff members were paid monthly salaries. No laborers are mentioned, although laborers there certainly were; one of the accounting categories in a Dec. 7, 1904 audit was “Statement of Cash belonging to laborers 7 not called for up to date,” naming 25 men to whom small sums of money were owed. By Jan. 1, 1931 park employees numbered 199, and the list now includes named laborers and truck drivers, as well as “watchmen, maids, grass mowers, & keepers . . . of Small Parks.” By Nov. 1, 1951 the number had risen to 245 names; and by Feb. 17, 1992 the Park Commission was informed that there were 426 full-time employees and 44 vacancies. In addition to names, many of these lists fortunately include duties, and salaries or wages. References to such lists, as well as lists of Commissioners and Commission officials and their terms of office, are collected into Appendix 1, providing glimpses of the men and women who led and staffed the Park Commission during its historic hundred-year run. Appendix 2 is a compilation of sources for the history of the Commission that will be found close to hand in the Memphis and Shelby County Room, including the Commission’s own publications from its first decade. A final special note is required to define the number of “Items” enumerated for each folder in this collection, although this may only be of peripheral or bookkeeping interest to users. Most such “Items” are defined as the dated Minutes of a Park Commission meeting, or indeed even a dated notice that e.g., for lack of a quorum no meeting was held, or that it was postponed or canceled. Minutes themselves, or such a “lack of quorum” notice, will almost always be signed by both Chairman and Secretary. These “Items” will usually include supporting documents such as audits, budgets, bids, blueprints, letters, internal reports and memos, as well as City Commission or City Council approval of Park Commission proceedings, acquisitions or appropriation requests, etc., even though such material may not always bear the same date as the minutes they support. Other “[Items.]”, preceded by this underlined and bracketed label in the Inventories, are notable documents or ancillary material relating to the Park Commission, its staff or its activities; they may be more or less independent of the specific minutes where they are found. The total number of “Items” in each folder is thus the sum of the number of meetings held during a calendar interval (along with their supporting documents), plus the other “[Items.]” as labeled separately. It should be noted that occasionally late in Book 6, in Book 7 throughout, and in the earliest part of Book 8, “bids received” for work or products often appear on their own individual pages and usually were entered into the minute book, dated and signed in, as it were, by both Chairman and Secretary. However, these are not considered to be individual “Items” as defined above, unless it is clear that a quorum of Park Commissioners was also present when these bids were received and considered. If extensive sets of bids appear, sometimes amounting to 20 pages or more as occurs in Books 15 and 16, some of them may have been labeled as “[Items.]”. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. Here and in the minute books to follow, and as more fully described earlier in the Scope and Content Notes, bracketed material indicated thus, [Item.], may be of more than passing interest. These [Items.] are often separately paginated or dated from the minutes. No extra pay to be allowed him for travelling expenses, draughtsman or anything else."
