oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Marilyn J. Califf Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After attending the University of Miami, the University of Memphis in the early 1950s, and a brief sojourn in 1968 at the Internacional Universidad of Saltillo, in Mexico, Marilyn Califf enrolled at the Memphis College of Art, where she studied painting. This was the beginning of a string of artistic achievements ranging over fifty years. She achieved her Bachelor of Fine Arts in 1970, but had been exhibiting in and around Memphis since the early 1960s, with a showing in the 6th and 7th Annual Mid-South Exhibitions at the Memphis Brooks Museum in 1961 and 1962. She also exhibited in the Atlanta Drawing Society Exhibition in Atlanta, Georgia in 1965 and was commissioned to complete several public art installations and murals from 1962-67. These were at Margolin Hebrew Academy Day School, the Baron Hirsch Synagogue in Memphis and the Memphis Jewish Community Center. She would later return to the University of Memphis to receive her Master of Fine Arts in 1988. -- A long-time Memphian, Marilyn J. Califf has contributed substantial amounts of time and energy to the city’s art community, as well as enjoying success in many different creative mediums. Califf has established herself firmly within the Mid-South environment, with Memphis as a strong base. She has an impressive exhibition record in photography, drawing, painting, murals and quilting. She has garnered many honors throughout her career, and standouts include First Prize in Oils at the 13th Annual Mid-South exhibition at the Memphis Brooks Museum in 1968, First Prize in Photography at the 1982, 1995 and 1997 National League of American Penwomen, Tennessee State competition, and has permanent gallery representation in Memphis and Jackson, Tennessee, Atlanta, Georgia and Florida. She has also participated in a number of international and American invitational exhibitions, juried competitions and art biennales. -- As relevant to this library’s collection, Califf spent a significant decade of her artistic career interested in quilting. She began by developing a mail-order quilt catalog business in 1972, and continued by teaching quilting and patchwork at the University of Memphis and Southwest Tennessee Community College in 1973. Califf explained her interest as beginning when her mother-in-law passed down a family quilt to her, and that she became intrigued with traditional quilts and how to make contemporary patterns or variations. With that impetus, in 1976 she established a small business, with the title ‘Contemporary Quilts, Home of the Quilt Lady’, which had its office near the corner of Summer Avenue and Highland Street. Califf was instrumental in the design of the quilts, and made the venture a cottage industry of sorts, with a small number of staff who made the quilts to sell. As well as this, Califf collected and curated almost 100 antique quilts herself, which were on display in the store. They helped to contribute to the profile of the medium and helped further a perhaps renewed interest in quilting as an art form. The business closed in 1986 for Califf to pursue further academic achievements. -- It is clear that Califf was passionate about reviving quilting to the mainstream artistic community and maintained a commitment to teaching quilting in an accessible way, with an emphasis on contemporary designs. -- The Marilyn J. Califf Collection is a representation of Califf’s quilting years. It consists of one 5-inch box with thirteen folders. Included in the collection are copies of the artist’s curriculum vitae as well as short artistic statements, with Califf’s ‘Quilt Story’ describing her foray into the medium and business. There are also photographs, contained on a CD, of both traditional quilts and those of Califf’s own patterns; the negatives to this are also included. Larger copies of these photographs will be available in the library’s digital archive. There are painting and collage inventories included, with small-scale photographs of each. As well as this, there are four self-published books, three of them pertaining to quilting and pillow making, written by Califf, as well as a book about gardening, written by Aileene Chasteene. The rest (and the bulk) of the collection consists of original quilt patterns designed by Califf for her business, and which range from 1976 to 1981. These patterns are organized chronologically, and then alphabetically within respective year groups. An effort was made to keep duplicate copies of patterns together, with no more than two of each pattern displayed. All undated patterns are contained at the end of the last folder.

Marilyn J. Califf Collection Victoria Grey 2014 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 1 Biographical Note: After attending the University of Miami, the University of Memphis in the early 1950s, and a brief sojourn in 1968 at the Internacional Universidad of Saltillo, in Mexico, Marilyn Califf enrolled at the Memphis College of Art, where she studied painting. This was the beginning of a string of artistic achievements ranging over fifty years. She achieved her Bachelor of Fine Arts in 1970, but had been exhibiting in and around Memphis since the early 1960s, with a showing in the 6th and 7th Annual Mid-South Exhibitions at the Memphis Brooks Museum in 1961 and 1962. She also exhibited in the Atlanta Drawing Society Exhibition in Atlanta, Georgia in 1965 and was commissioned to complete several public art installations and murals from 1962-67. These were at Margolin Hebrew Academy Day School, the Baron Hirsch Synagogue in Memphis and the Memphis Jewish Community Center. She would later return to the University of Memphis to receive her Master of Fine Arts in 1988. A long-time Memphian, Marilyn J. Califf has contributed substantial amounts of time and energy to the city’s art community, as well as enjoying success in many different creative mediums. Califf has established herself firmly within the Mid-South environment, with Memphis as a strong base. She has an impressive exhibition record in photography, drawing, painting, murals and quilting. She has garnered many honors throughout her career, and standouts include First Prize in Oils at the 13th Annual Mid-South exhibition at the Memphis Brooks Museum in 1968, First Prize in Photography at the 1982, 1995 and 1997 National League of American Penwomen, Tennessee State competition, and has permanent gallery representation in Memphis and Jackson, Tennessee, Atlanta, Georgia and Florida. She has also participated in a number of international and American invitational exhibitions, juried competitions and art biennales. As relevant to this library’s collection, Califf spent a significant decade of her artistic career interested in quilting. She began by developing a mail-order quilt catalog business in 1972, and continued by teaching quilting and patchwork at the University of Memphis and Southwest Tennessee Community College in 1973. Califf explained her interest as beginning when her mother-in-law passed down a family quilt to her, and that she became intrigued with traditional quilts and how to make contemporary patterns or variations. With that impetus, in 1976 she established a small business, with the title ‘Contemporary Quilts, Home of the Quilt Lady’, which had its office near the corner of Summer Avenue and Highland Street. Califf was instrumental in the design of the quilts, and made the venture a cottage industry of sorts, with a small number of staff who made the quilts to sell. As well as this, Califf collected and curated almost 100 antique quilts herself, which were on display in the store. They helped to contribute to the profile of the medium and helped further a perhaps renewed interest in quilting as an art form. The business closed in 1986 for Califf to pursue further academic achievements. It is clear that Califf was passionate about reviving quilting to the mainstream artistic community and maintained a commitment to teaching quilting in an accessible way, with an emphasis on contemporary designs. 2 Scope and Content: The Marilyn J. Califf Collection is a representation of Califf’s quilting years. It consists of one 5-inch box with thirteen folders. Included in the collection are copies of the artist’s curriculum vitae as well as short artistic statements, with Califf’s ‘Quilt Story’ describing her foray into the medium and business. There are also photographs, contained on a CD, of both traditional quilts and those of Califf’s own patterns; the negatives to this are also included. Larger copies of these photographs will be available in the library’s digital archive. There are painting and collage inventories included, with small-scale photographs of each. As well as this, there are four self-published books, three of them pertaining to quilting and pillow making, written by Califf, as well as a book about gardening, written by Aileene Chasteene. The rest (and the bulk) of the collection consists of original quilt patterns designed by Califf for her business, and which range from 1976 to 1981. These patterns are organized chronologically, and then alphabetically within respective year groups. An effort was made to keep duplicate copies of patterns together, with no more than two of each pattern displayed. All undated patterns are contained at the end of the last folder. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: During the late 19th and early 20th century, Memphis was a hot spot in the area for music publishers and producers. Publishers such as Frayser Hinton and Memphis Music Publishers set up shop to produce and publish sheet music in Memphis, while other publishers such as A. E. Blackmar and Blelock & Co put offices in the city. These publishers produced what was popular at the time, ranging from marches and fox-trots to two-steps and schottisches, all for the piano. -- The average music consumer in Memphis also had a variety of music to choose from. All types of sheet music from New York to Chicago were available to Memphians, though the music represented in this collection consists mainly of piano scores. The culture of buying dance music for the piano suggests a great love of music and an interest in musicianship. Perhaps a family member would play the piano while others would dance or sing to the music. -- While purchases of sheet music would dwindle during the Great Depression, new sheet music would still be produced and published; however, most of the publishing houses in Memphis shut down. There would be a rise of production in the 1970s, but Memphis had already hit its heyday in the 19th century. -- The Memphis Sheet Music Collection mainly consists of piano sheet music from the late 19th century and the 1920s. There are also copies of sheet music from the 1970s and the 2000s. The collection consists of about one and a half linear feet and was donated to the Friends of the Library by Rita Satterfield. -- Due to being partially processed by a former Memphis Room employee, the original order has not been kept. Instead, it is organized by publisher and place of origin. Some folders have been organized where the sheet music has been linked to a common publisher. When this was not applicable, the sheet music has been organized in a miscellaneous manner.

Memphis Sheet Music Collection Processed by Anthony Perez Rhodes College 2014 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 1 Memphis Sheet Music Collection Historical Sketch During the late 19th and early 20th century, Memphis was a hot spot in the area for music publishers and producers. Publishers such as Frayser Hinton and Memphis Music Publishers set up shop to produce and publish sheet music in Memphis, while other publishers such as A. E. Blackmar and Blelock & Co put offices in the city. These publishers produced what was popular at the time, ranging from marches and fox-trots to two-steps and schottisches, all for the piano. The average music consumer in Memphis also had a variety of music to choose from. All types of sheet music from New York to Chicago were available to Memphians, though the music represented in this collection consists mainly of piano scores. The culture of buying dance music for the piano suggests a great love of music and an interest in musicianship. Perhaps a family member would play the piano while others would dance or sing to the music. While purchases of sheet music would dwindle during the Great Depression, new sheet music would still be produced and published; however, most of the publishing houses in Memphis shut down. There would be a rise of production in the 1970s, but Memphis had already hit its heyday in the 19th century. 2 Memphis Sheet Music Collection Scope and Content The Memphis Sheet Music Collection mainly consists of piano sheet music from the late 19th century and the 1920s. There are also copies of sheet music from the 1970s and the 2000s. The collection consists of about one and a half linear feet and was donated to the Friends of the Library by Rita Satterfield. Due to being partially processed by a former Memphis Room employee, the original order has not been kept. Instead, it is organized by publisher and place of origin. Some folders have been organized where the sheet music has been linked to a common publisher. When this was not applicable, the sheet music has been organized in a miscellaneous manner. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dilettante Club Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: “All you girls ever talk about are the three C’s—cooks, cotton, and children!” This remark, made by Merle “Mink” Lawrence’s aunt, Mrs. M. M. Ruffin, as she listened to five friends chatting one afternoon, started the Dilettante Club in Memphis, Tennessee. Founded in 1919 by Mrs. Giles Bond (Bertha), Mrs. Willis Campbell (Bessie), Mrs. Lewis Haskell (Robin), Mrs. W. S. Lawrence (Merle), and Mrs. Simpson Tate (Adele), this group of society matrons, organized for the enjoyment of fine arts, still meet monthly to present and discuss their papers. -- Literally meaning “admirer or lover of the arts”, a Dilettante must write an original research paper focusing on the yearly topic once every two years. She may be asked to host a meeting on “off” years, held on the first Thursday of the month, October through May, but she is only allowed to serve water—for the speakers. The final May meeting usually concludes with a luncheon. Sometimes called “Dils” for short, these ladies collect annual dues that help support donations to local area food banks and educational institutions like Rhodes College. Since 2007, the Dils have donated to Shelby County Books from Birth, the local affiliate of Dolly Parton’s Imagination Library which promotes kindergarten readiness and strengthens family bonds by providing age-appropriate books for all children from birth to age five. -- There are thirty-five active members, annually elected officers, and sustaining members. Their collection at the Memphis Public Library & Information Center contains numerous photographs from past meetings, minutes and yearbooks dating back to the 1920s, and a score of miscellaneous documents chronicling their almost one hundred year history, including a few papers. -- The material in this collection dates from the 1920s through the 2000s and includes meeting minutes, yearbooks, by-laws, correspondence, history of offices, newspaper clippings, original research papers, photographs, and treasury files. -- The collection was organized into folders while maintaining most of the original order. Along with numerous copies of yearbooks, the first box houses the paper history of the Dilettante Club including correspondence between club and community members, recently presented papers, copies of revised by-laws, and financial history from 1981-2004. Boxes 2 and 3 contain minutes of the monthly meetings documented by secretaries since the first records were kept in 1920.

DILETTANTE CLUB COLLECTION Processed By: Regan Adolph 2014 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 1 Dilettante Club Collection Historical Sketch “All you girls ever talk about are the three C’s—cooks, cotton, and children!” This remark, made by Merle “Mink” Lawrence’s aunt, Mrs. M. M. Ruffin, as she listened to five friends chatting one afternoon, started the Dilettante Club in Memphis, Tennessee. Founded in 1919 by Mrs. Giles Bond (Bertha), Mrs. Willis Campbell (Bessie), Mrs. Lewis Haskell (Robin), Mrs. W. S. Lawrence (Merle), and Mrs. Simpson Tate (Adele), this group of society matrons, organized for the enjoyment of fine arts, still meet monthly to present and discuss their papers. Literally meaning “admirer or lover of the arts”, a Dilettante must write an original research paper focusing on the yearly topic once every two years. She may be asked to host a meeting on “off” years, held on the first Thursday of the month, October through May, but she is only allowed to serve water—for the speakers. The final May meeting usually concludes with a luncheon. Sometimes called “Dils” for short, these ladies collect annual dues that help support donations to local area food banks and educational institutions like Rhodes College. Since 2007, the Dils have donated to Shelby County Books from Birth, the local affiliate of Dolly Parton’s Imagination Library which promotes kindergarten readiness and strengthens family bonds by providing age­appropriate books for all children from birth to age five. There are thirty­five active members, annually elected officers, and sustaining members. Their collection at the Memphis Public Library & Information Center contains numerous photographs from past meetings, minutes and yearbooks dating back to the 1920s, and a score of miscellaneous documents chronicling their almost one hundred year history, including a few papers. 2 Dilettante Club Collection Scope and Content Comprised of 1.5 linear feet, the Dilettante Club Collection was donated to the Memphis Public Library & Information Center in 2010 by Sallie Johnson. The material in this collection dates from the 1920s through the 2000s and includes meeting minutes, yearbooks, by­laws, correspondence, history of offices, newspaper clippings, original research papers, photographs, and treasury files. The collection was organized into folders while maintaining most of the original order. Along with numerous copies of yearbooks, the first box houses the paper history of the Dilettante Club including correspondence between club and community members, recently presented papers, copies of revised by­laws, and financial history from 1981­2004. Boxes 2 and 3 contain minutes of the monthly meetings documented by secretaries since the first records were kept in 1920. Those interested in Memphis clubs and organizations should also consult the Kennedy Book Club Collection, the Beethoven Club Programs Collection, the Peabody­Bellevue Civic Club Collection, the Memphis Civic Clubs­Jackson Boulevard and Rozelle Clubs, and the Military Officers’ Wives Club Collection. The Index to the Memphis Historical Society Papers and the Index to ‘The Egyptian’ also feature civilian research essays similar to the Dilettante Club’s. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Henry Kahn Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henry Kahn was a businessman who lived in Hardeman County, Tennessee. He and his wife Louise, originally from Germany, immigrated to the United States, and set up a dry goods store in Bolivar, Tennessee in 1844. Located on the Hatchie River, Bolivar established itself as a trading hub and Kahn’s store prospered accordingly. By all accounts he was a successful businessman, and in 1853 relocated to Louisville, Kentucky. Kahn established a similar business in that city, leaving his wife and five children in Bolivar. He retired in 1868, and died in 1880, and left a business legacy for his sons, notably Isaac and Samuel, who continued in the same line of work until the late 1890s.

Henry Kahn Collection Processed by Victoria Grey 2014 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center Benjamin L. Hooks Central Library 3030 Poplar Avenue 1 Memphis, TN Biographical Note: Henry Kahn was a businessman who lived in Hardeman County, Tennessee. He and his wife Louise, originally from Germany, immigrated to the United States, and set up a dry goods store in Bolivar, Tennessee in 1844. Located on the Hatchie River, Bolivar established itself as a trading hub and Kahn’s store prospered accordingly. By all accounts he was a successful businessman, and in 1853 relocated to Louisville, Kentucky. Kahn established a similar business in that city, leaving his wife and five children in Bolivar. He retired in 1868, and died in 1880, and left a business legacy for his sons, notably Isaac and Samuel, who continued in the same line of work until the late 1890s. 2 Scope and Content: The Henry Kahn Collection consists of one box, with three folders, and is almost wholly made up of personal and business correspondence and receipts of arrears and transactions. It initially appeared to have been organized as loosely chronological, but eventually deviated from that format. Aside from that, the collection remains in its original order. The bulk of the collection ranges in date from the 1820s up until the 1850s, with several items dating from the latter nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Interestingly, the collection contains little of Henry Kahn’s own personal effects. Instead, with the exception of a short, personal letter to his family, the collection holds items authored by many other prominent Bolivar residents. Although many of the residents feature more than once, much of it exists in isolation: there appears to be no overarching relationship between different pieces in the collection, aside from geographical location. The value of the collection in fact lies within its fragmented nature. It allows for a unique look at many different facets of nineteenth­century Bolivar life, and a window to several of its most prominent founding citizens and their business, family and social interactions and activities. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. For all requests, please contact the History Department at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphishistn.gov. As previously mentioned, the collection is housed in one box, and measures .21 linear feet. The contents of each folder shall be described below, with descriptions of author (generally by surname), locations and content when applicable. Container List: Folder One: (12 items) 1. Correspondence: Ashurst, of Philadelphia, to Rhea and McCrabb of Bolivar, TN, 1828. 2. IOU agreement: between McCrabb, Smith and Pearsall, 1827. 3. Correspondence: Con to Rhea and McCrabb, concerning the purchase of a boat, 1827. 4. Correspondence: Burke of Philadelphia to Rhea McCrabb & Merchants, 1828. 5. Correspondence: Rhea to Con, concerning the boat purchase mentioned above, 1828. 6. Correspondence: Boon of Washington to Judah of Vincennes, Indiana, discussion of the Supreme Court, and District Attorney fees, 1830. 7. Correspondence: Eveline McNeal of Bolivar to brother Albert McNeal, Coffeeville, Mississippi, concerning family matters, 1837. 8. Correspondence: E to A. McNeal, admonishment at dearth of letters, 1837. 9. Correspondence: Schaffer of Philadelphia, to Bills of Bolivar, concerning payment of debts, 1848. 10. Correspondence: Mansfield and McIntosh, to McHardy of Bolivar, bill of sale, 1848. 11. Correspondence: Ashurst to Rhea, McCrabb and Merchants, receipt and log of money owed, 1828. 12. Correspondence: Bills of Bolivar, to a John of Ripley, Mississippi, 1838. 4 Folder Two (12 items): 1. Correspondence: E.P. McNeal of Bolivar to brother Sam McNeal of Ripley, Mississippi, concerning family matters, 1838. 2. Correspondence: A.E. Laird of Louisville, Kentucky to Sam McNeal of Ripley, Mississippi, concerning local gossip, a letter between friends, 1839. 3. Correspondence: E.P. McNeal of Bolivar to brother Albert McNeal of Coffinsville, Indiana, concerning family matters and local business, 1841. 4. Correspondence: J.J. Neely of Louisville, Kentucky too Sam McNeal of Ripley Mississippi, local gossip, reminiscences of Bolivar, a letter between friends, 1842. 5. Correspondence: To Bills of Bolivar from Nashville, discussion of business, wills and estate holdings, 1842. 6. Correspondence: Graham of Washington City, to Bills of Bolivar, concerning federal Whig politics and Tennessee’s representation in Congress, 1847. 7. Land title deed: A.T. Browne to Jarrett, seventy five acres of land annexation and sale, 1849. 8. Correspondence: Goodich & Co. to Bills of Bolivar, discussion of market conditions and sales, 1850. 9. Land title deed: Minder and Hardy of Hardeman County, land annexation, 1861. 10. IOU: Originating from Philadelphia, to the value of five hundred and eighty dollars – signature no longer intact, but amount payable to Armstrong of Bolivar, 1827. 11. Land title deed: T.C. Price and E.H. Morgan of Hardeman County, land annexation and sale, 1881. 12. Correspondence: Henry Kahn of Louisville, Kentucky, to wife and family in Bolivar, concerning local business and family matters, 1875. 5 Folder Three (7 items): 1. Land title deed: Miller of Hardeman County, 1874 2. Correspondence: Schaffer of Philadelphia, to Bills of Bolivar, business receipt of payment, 1857. 3. Correspondence: Protection Insurance Company of Cincinnati, Ohio, to Bills of Bolivar, concerning insurance business and payments, 1852. 4. Haskins from The Nashville Tennessean Information Bureau, to a Mr. Kahn, reply to a request for information, 1940. 6. Certificate: State of Mississippi Office of Adjutant General, acknowledgement of election of Sam McNeil to office of Judge Advocate of 49th Regiment, Mississippi Militia, 1839. 7. Pamphlet: War Department Pension Office informational pamphlet, rules and regulations of applications for war pensions, 1827. 6

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rabbi Max Samfield Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Max Samfield was born in Marksteft, Bavaria on January 23, 1844. His father Samuel was an ordained rabbi under whom Max studied in pursuit of the rabbinate. At the age of twelve, his studies were so advanced that he attended post-Talmudical school. Around 1859, he enrolled in a Talmudic school. While studying at Julius University in Duerzburg, Samfield became interested in Reformed Judaism. He graduated with a doctorate in philosophy and, after an advanced course in linguistic studies, ventured to the United States in 1867. He was installed as the rabbi of Congregation B’nai Zion in Shreveport, Louisiana. Rabbi Samfield advocated for constructive programs in his Shreveport congregation and the larger community. -- In July of 1872, Samfield was elected as rabbi of Congregation Children of Israel in Memphis, Tennessee. He married Pauline Frank in January 26, 1873. Later that year he helped the sick and needy of Memphis when the yellow fever epidemic struck. Five years later, when the epidemic reappeared, the rabbi remained in Memphis and continued to care for the sick. Samfield’s humanitarian efforts during these crises are matched by his continued advocacy for sanitation reform, better public education, organized charities, and prison reform. Samfield was a founder of the Tennessee Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and Children, the United Charities of Memphis, and the Young Men’s Hebrew Association. He served as president of the Hebrew Relief Association and first vice-president of the Federation of Jewish Charities of Memphis. He acted as one of the governors of Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati and he was a trustee of the New Orleans Orphan Asylum Home. He was a respected member of the Freemasons and the Elks. -- Samfield’s accomplishments within the field of Judaic studies are also notable. He served as President of the Second Annual Conference of the Southern Rabbinical Association, and he founded The Jewish Spectator in 1885, editing it for nearly thirty years. He remained rabbi for the Congregation Children of Israel for over forty years. Samfield was lauded as a man who could be “identified with every Jewish charitable movement in the South and with every non-sectarian benevolent institution in Memphis and Tennessee.” -- On September 28, 1915, the first day of his retirement as Rabbi Emeritus of Congregation Children of Israel, Max Samfield died. On the day of the funeral, streetcars and vehicles planned a coordinated pause in a moment of remembrance. No flowers were requested at the funeral, as the rabbi and his family saw them as a waste of resources better spent on charity. Samfield was memorialized in several newspapers and journals throughout the region. -- The collection is largely comprised of newspaper clippings and journal publications. Some personal correspondences with members of the Samfield family, speeches, and sermons add another dimension to the collection. A large portion of the collection is made up of memorials and obituaries of the late rabbi which discuss the impact Samfield had on his community. -- The collection is organized into five folders. The first folder contains sermons, lectures, and secondhand accounts of the work of Rabbi Max Samfield. The second folder contains documents pertaining to the death and funeral of Samfield, including pictures from funerary service and numerous newspaper articles. The third folder contains documents published or pertaining to the Memphis Elk lodge, including the Elkdom publication, with references to Rabbi Max Samfield. The fourth folder is comprised of documents that relate to Samfield’s family and legacy. The fifth folder is solely comprised of the Jewish Spectator, Thirtieth Anniversary Number, dedicated in memoriam to Rabbi Max Samfield.

Rabbi Max Samfield Collection Processed by: Matthew Hicks 2014 Memphis and Shelby County Room Memphis Public Library and Information Center 3030 Poplar Avenue Memphis, TN 38111 1 2 Rabbi Max Samfield Collection Biographical Note Max Samfield was born in Marksteft, Bavaria on January 23, 1844. His father Samuel was an ordained rabbi under whom Max studied in pursuit of the rabbinate. At the age of twelve, his studies were so advanced that he attended post­Talmudical school. Around 1859, he enrolled in a Talmudic school. While studying at Julius University in Duerzburg, Samfield became interested in Reformed Judaism. He graduated with a doctorate in philosophy and, after an advanced course in linguistic studies, ventured to the United States in 1867. He was installed as the rabbi of Congregation B’nai Zion in Shreveport, Louisiana. Rabbi Samfield advocated for constructive programs in his Shreveport congregation and the larger community. In July of 1872, Samfield was elected as rabbi of Congregation Children of Israel in Memphis, Tennessee. He married Pauline Frank in January 26, 1873. Later that year he helped the sick and needy of Memphis when the yellow fever epidemic struck. Five years later, when the epidemic reappeared, the rabbi remained in Memphis and continued to care for the sick. Samfield’s humanitarian efforts during these crises are matched by his continued advocacy for sanitation reform, better public education, organized charities, and prison reform. Samfield was a founder of the Tennessee Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and Children, the United Charities of Memphis, and the Young Men’s Hebrew Association. He served as president of the Hebrew Relief Association and first vice­president of the Federation of Jewish Charities of Memphis. He acted as one of the governors of Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati and he was a trustee of the New Orleans Orphan Asylum Home. He was a respected member of the Freemasons and the Elks. Samfield’s accomplishments within the field of Judaic studies are also notable. He served as President of the Second Annual Conference of the Southern Rabbinical Association, and he founded The Jewish Spectator in 1885, editing it for nearly thirty years. He remained rabbi for the Congregation Children of Israel for over forty years. Samfield was lauded as a man who could be “identified with every Jewish charitable movement in the South and with every non­sectarian benevolent institution in Memphis and Tennessee.” On September 28, 1915, the first day of his retirement as Rabbi Emeritus of Congregation Children of Israel, Max Samfield died. On the day of the funeral, streetcars and vehicles planned a coordinated pause in a moment of remembrance. No flowers were requested at the funeral, as the rabbi and his family saw them as a waste of resources better spent on charity. Samfield was memorialized in several newspapers and journals throughout the region. 3 Rabbi Max Samfield Collection Scope and Content The Rabbi Max Samfield Collection consists of a total .92 linear feet. The donor of this collection is unknown. The collection is largely comprised of newspaper clippings and journal publications. Some personal correspondences with members of the Samfield family, speeches, and sermons add another dimension to the collection. A large portion of the collection is made up of memorials and obituaries of the late rabbi which discuss the impact Samfield had on his community. The collection is organized into five folders. The first folder contains sermons, lectures, and secondhand accounts of the work of Rabbi Max Samfield. The second folder contains documents pertaining to the death and funeral of Samfield, including pictures from funerary service and numerous newspaper articles. The third folder contains documents published or pertaining to the Memphis Elk lodge, including the Elkdom publication, with references to Rabbi Max Samfield. The fourth folder is comprised of documents that relate to Samfield’s family and legacy. The fifth folder is solely comprised of the Jewish Spectator, Thirtieth Anniversary Number, dedicated in memoriam to Rabbi Max Samfield. Researchers interested in Jewish history in the South should examine the Rabbi James A. Wax Collection and the Selma S. Lewis Collection. Single photocopies or scans of unpublished writings in these papers may be made for purposes of scholarly research. For all requests, please contact the History Department at 901.415.2742 or hisref@memphistn.gov. 4 Rabbi Max Samfield Collection Container List Bo x # Folde r # Folder Name # of Item s Description of Contents 1 1 Sermons, Lectures, and Works 10 Contains newspaper articles recounting the accomplishments of Max Samfield, an address given by him as president of the Second Annual Conference of the Southern Rabbinical Association, an obituary written by the rabbi for Mrs. Euphrasie Marx, and a transcription of the final sermon delivered by Samfield to the Congregation Children of Israel 1 2 Obituaries and Remembranc e 18 Contains a translation of the epitaph on Max Samfield’s grave, notes of gratitude from the Samfield family, pictures taken of the funeral procession and funeral, various newspaper articles and journal publications commemorating the life and mourning the loss of Rabbi Samfield from The News Scimitar, the Commercial Appeal, The Memphis Public, and other regional sources 1 3 Elkdom Publications 6 Contains newspaper articles from the Commercial Appeal dealing with the Memphis Elk chapter and Rabbi Samfield; the November 1915 publication of Elkdom, which contains articles in memorial to Rabbi Samfield from pages 16­21; a pamphlet from the Memorial Services of the Memphis Elk Lodge of December 5, 1915; and a scan of the April 1905 issue of Elkdom, page 17 1 4 Family and Legacy 10 Contains an article on the 25th wedding anniversary of Rabbi Samfield and his wife Pauline; correspondences between Mrs. Pauline Samfield and the Congregation Children of Israel and between Mrs. Samfield, her daughter Helene, and Milton S. Binswanger; a dedication to Rabbi Samfield from the Thirtieth Anniversary Edition of The Jewish Spectator; an article from the Commercial Appeal about Pauline Samfield; an article on Max Samfield from Southern Jewish Heritage, Volume 5, no. 1, April 1992; a pamphlet for the B’nai B’rith Home for Aged; newspaper clippings about the donation of a portrait of Rabbi Samfield; and a copy of the book 5 Favorite Quotations and Original Mottoes from Memphis People 1 5 The Jewish Spectator, Thirtieth Anniversary Number 1 Contains a copy of The Jewish Spectator, Thirtieth Anniversary Number Edition, with several pages of memorial to Rabbi Max Samfield 6 Rabbi Max Samfield Collection Box #1 Folder One Item 1 Newspaper clipping from the Daily Appeal, August 5, 1871, about Rabbi Samfield, and a clipping from another unnamed newspaper about the dedication of the first Jewish Temple in East Arkansas by Rabbi Samfield Folder One Item 2 Presidential Address of Rabbi Samfield delivered at the Second Annual Conference of the Southern Rabbinical Association, Wednesday, March 9, 1904 Folder One Item 3 Obituary of Mrs. Euphrasie Marx, written by Dr. Samfield, September 10, 1904 Folder One Item 4 A fragment of page four of the January 15, 1915 edition of The Jewish Spectator, edited by Samfield; the completed article discusses the reading of the Bible in public schools. The original has been photocopied Folder One Item 5 Article from The Jewish Spectator, Thirtieth Anniversary Number, titled “Memorial Sermon: Last Sermon Delivered Before Congregation ‘Children of Israel,’ Memphis, Yom Kippur, Saturday Afternoon, September 18, 1915” Folder One Item 6 Newspaper clipping of an article titled “Rabbi Samfield’s Eloquent Lecture: ‘Poetic Genius of Emma Lazarus.’” Original has been photocopied Folder One Item 7 Newspaper clippings with articles titled “Dr. Samfield Opposes Death Penalty” and “A Cleaner Memphis: Reducing the Number of Homicides” Folder One Item 8 Newspaper clippings with articles titled “The Bible in Public Schools,” “Fit for Sanctuary of Any Religion,” “Doesn’t Believe In Hell: Dr. Samfield Says What He Thinks about It Is Immaterial,” and “In Memoriam: Resolutions of Respect on the Death of Brother Max Samfield of Memphis Lodge No. 35, I.O.B.B.” Folder One Item 9 Newspaper clippings with articles titled “Rabbi Samfield Elected for Life,” “Rabbi Samfield Retired,” and “Jewish Role In Louisiana History Told” Folder One Item 10 Newspaper clipping with article titled “The Jewish Sabbath: Rabbi Samfield’s Views on Proposed Change” Folder Two Item 1 The epitaph inscribed on Rabbi Samfield’s grave, translated from Hebrew Folder Two Item 2 Notes of gratitude from the Samfield family in response to “sincere expressions of condolence and sympathy” at Rabbi Samfield’s death Folder Two Item 3 Two pages of photographs of the Samfield funeral and procession 7 8 Folder Two Item 4 Newspaper clipping from the News Scimitar, September 29, 1915, of the article titled “Dr. Samfield to Be Buried on Day Set for His Retirement.” Scans of the two separate complementary original fragments are included Folder Two Item 5 Newspaper clipping from the Commercial Appeal, September 29, 1915, titled “Rabbi Samfield Dies After Short Illness”; original copy has been photocopied Folder Two Item 6 Newspaper clipping from the News Scimitar, September 30, 1915, with articles “Street Car Wheels to Stop 10 Minutes As Honor to Rabbi” and “Street Cars Will Stop 10 Minutes During Funeral” Folder Two Item 7 Copy of The Memphis Public, October 2, 1915, including article titled “Memphis Bows in Sorrow at Dr. Samfield’s Death—Was One of Country’s Most Brilliant Men—Famous as Student, Educator, Religionist and Man” Folder Two Item 8 Service pamphlet from The Temple, dated Sunday, October 31, 1915, Vol. II, no. 6. Memorial donation on behalf of Dr. Max Samfield is mentioned in section “The Commemoration Fund” Folder Two Item 9 Club Affairs: October 1915 of the Nineteenth Century Club; Rabbi Max Samfield is commemorated Folder Two Item 10 The B’nai B’rith Reporter Volume 1, no. 3, March 1916, which includes a tribute to Rabbi Max Samfield. The documents relevant to Samfield are photocopied and included with the original Folder Two Item 11 Newspaper clippings; article titles include “La Hache Fulfills Promise He Gave Rabbi Years Ago” and “Pays Tribute to Memory of Late Rabbi Samfield” Folder Two Item 12 Newspaper clippings; article titles include “Eulogizes Dr. Samfield: Baptist Minister Says Rabbi Will Long Be Remembered” and “Jewish Charities Will Raise Fund as a Memorial.” Some article titles are missing Folder Two Item 13 Newspaper clippings; one article is titled “Eloquent Tributes Are Paid to Late Rabbi M. Samfield.” Some article titles are missing Folder Two Item 14 Newspaper clipping from the News Scimitar of an article about Rabbi Max Samfield Folder Two Item 15 Newspaper clippings; article titles include “Rabbi Max Samfield Will Be Buried on Day Set to Retire,” “Memphians Pay Last Respects to Samfield,” and “Announce Program for Samfield Funeral.” Some article titles are missing. Includes an obituary entry for Rabbi Samfield Folder Two Item 16 Newspaper clippings; article titles include “Rabbi Samfield Dies After Short Illness” and “Masonic Services at Samfield Funeral” 9 Folder Two Item 17 Newspaper clippings; article titles include “Hundreds Attend Funeral of Late Rabbi M. Samfield,” “High Tribute Paid to Rabbi Samfield,” and “Men of Many Faiths Honor Deceased Rabbi” Folder Two Item 18 Newspaper clippings with articles titled “Rabbi Samfield Dies at His Home,” “Dr. Bogen’s Heartfelt Tribute,” and an untitled article Folder Three Item 1 Newspaper clippings; one article is titled “Elks Pay Tribute to Honored Dead.” One article title is missing. Possibly from the News Scimitar Folder Three Item 2 Newspaper clipping with an article titled “Oration Delivered By Rev. Dr. M. Samfield Upon Laying of Corner Stone of New Elk’s Home” Folder Three Item 3 Photocopy of Commercial Appeal article titled “Tribute to Dead Elks.” Two complementary photocopies Folder Three Item 4 Elkdom Volume 12, no. 11, November 1915, with a commemoration of Rabbi Samfield on page 19. Two copies included. Folder Three Item 5 Pamphlet for Memorial Services of the Memphis Elk Lodge, December 5, 1915 Folder Three Item 6 Photocopy of Elkdom magazine issue, April 1905, page 17; includes an image of “Rev. Dr. M. Samfield” Folder Four Item 1 Article clipping titled “Silver Wedding,” about the 25th wedding anniversary of Rabbi Max Samfield and Pauline Frank Samfield Folder Four Item 2 Correspondence between Pauline Samfield and Secretary of Congregation Children of Israel, I. Dinkelspiel, dated December 19, 1918 Folder Four Item 3 Correspondence between Helene Samfield – Rabbi Samfield’s daughter – and Milton S.
